The Daughters of the King are stiled Princesses. And the title of Royal Highness is attributed to all the Kings Children, both Sons and Daughters; they are likewise reverenced and honoured. The Kings Court and its Government.

The Court of the King is freed from the Jurisdiction of any Court, whether Ecclesiastical or Civil, except that of the Lord Steward; and in his absence to the Treasurer and Comptroller of the Kings houshold, with the Steward of the Marshalsey; who by vertue of their offices may hear and determine Treason, Felony, and all misdemeanours committed within the Court.The Kings Palace is a place esteemed so high and sacred, that no insolencies are, or (at least should be) suffered therein, insomuch that not only striking is forbidden, but also all occasions of the same, and that with strict punishments
ments both corporal and pecuniary, according to the heinousness of the offence: as for striking (if blood be drawn) the right hand is to be cut off; to be committed to Prison during life, and fined besides. The Kings Court may not unproperly be tearmed a Monarchy within its self, by reason the Persons, or Officers and Government in which it consisteth, are both Ecclesiastick, Civil, and Military. Degrees of Honour.

The Degrees of Honour which are here in England observed, and according to which they have precedency, may be comprehended under these two heads, viz. Nobiles Majores, and Nobiles Minores. Those included under the first rank, are Dukes, Arch-Bishops, Marquesses, Earls, Viscounts, Bishops and Barons. And those of the last are Baronets, K nights, Esquires, and Gentlemen: But there are some that will have Baronets to be the last under the first rank; and their reason is, as having their honour Hereditary and by Patent, as the Nobility have. And all these said Degrees of Honour are speculatively distinguished the one from the other, and that in their Ensigns, or Shields of Honour, which shall be taken notice of in place convenient.

As concerning Precedency, all the Nobles of each degree take place according to their seniority of creation, and not of years; unless they are descended of the Blood Royal, and then they take place of all others of the same degree. Yet there are some, that by their Offices, or Places at Court, or fetting at the Helm of State, have precedency; as the Lord K eeper, Lord President of his Majesties Councel, Lord Privy Seal, Lord High Chamberlain, the Earl Marshall, the Lord Chamberlain, the Master of the Horse, &c. Precedency and degrees of Honour.

Precedency may also be thus observed; The K ing, who is the Fountain of Honour. The Prince of England, who is eldest son to the King, and is born Duke of Cornwall, and about the age of 17 years, is usually created Prince of Wales. Princes of the blood Royal, who are the Sons, Brothers, Uncles, and Nephews of the King. The ArchBishop of Canter bury. The Lord Chancellor, or Lord K eeper of the Great Seal of England. Arch-Bishop of York. Lord Treasurer of England. Lord President of the Privy Councel. Lord K eeper of the Privy Seal. Dukes. Marquesses. Duke's eldest sons. Earls. Marquesses eldest sons. Duke's younger sons. Viscounts, Earls eldest sons. Marquesses younger sons. Bishops. Barons. Viscounts eldest sons. Earls younger sons. Barons eldest sons. Privy Councellors. Judges. Viscounts younger sons. Barons younger sons. K nights of the Garter (if not dignified with any other Title) as it is seldom found but that they are, it being so noble an Order. K nights Banerets, Baronets, K nights of the Bath, and K nights Bachelors. Colonels, Sergeants at Law. Masters of Chancery and Doctors. Esquires, and those may be comprehended under five several heads 1. Esquires unto the K ings body. 2. The Descendants by the Maleline from a Peer of the Realm. 3. The eldest sons of K nights of the Garter, Baronets, K nights of the Bath, and K nights Bachelors. 4. The two Esquires attending upon K nights of the Bath at their K nighting; every K night at his making having two Esquires. And 5. officiary Esquires, as Justices of the Peace, Baresters at Law. Lieutenant Colonels, Majors and Captains: and lastly Gentlemen. Priviledges enjoyed by the Nobility.

The priviledges which the Nobility do, or may enjoy, are very great, and too tedious to repeat: I shall only take notice of some few. For instance, their persons are freed from all Arrests, Utlawries, or Attachments, by reason of being free to serve the K ing and Nation. So that Debts, &c. may be satisfied out of their Estates, which is judged sufficient.

They may in their Journeys to Court, being summoned thither, or to Parliament by the K ings Writ, Letter, or Messenger, kill one or two Deer out of the K ings Forests, or Parks; and the like may be done at their return.
They are freed from attendance at Sheriffs Tourns, or Leets.

In Criminal causes they are to be tryed by a Jury of Peers, and none other. They are not to be bound to their good behaviours, nor required totake an oath, but only to promise upon their honour so and so.

They are not required as at the beginning of a Parliament, or at other times, to take the Oath of Supremacy. And when they give evidence for the deciding of a controversie, or otherwise, they are not sworn, but deliver the truth upon their honours.
In places of Trust committed unto them, they have power to constitute Deputics.

If a Peer doth commit any heinous fact, not only the priviledge of the Clergy allowed to common persons, shall be granted him, although he cannot read; but also he shall be discharged without burning in the hand, loss of estate or otherwise.
And lastly, they have the priviledge of qualifying a certain number of Chaplains. The Priviledges of the Bishops.

The Priviledges which the Bishops and Clergy enjoy, are very many; as power of keeping of Courts of Judicature, concerning Ecclesiastical asfairs. They have power to depute their Authority to their Chancellors, Commissaries, or other Officers.

They are not to be tryed upon any criminal offence by any but by their Peers; They are freed from Arrests or Utlawries; Their office is to look after the Ministers in their respective Diocesses, and to see that they be godly, righteous and sober men. No Clergy-man in general is constrained to follow any personal function, or service of the Kingdom; neither to serve in the War. Likewise they are freed from all temporal offices; neither are they compelled to appear at Sheriffs Tourns. And to conclude, their Goods are freed from payment of Toles and Customs of Avirage, Pontage, Muriage and Paviage. The Priviledges of the Gentrey.

The Priviledges which the Commonalty, or those under the Degree of Nobiles minores, enjoy, are also many. They are not to be fined for misdemeanours, but according to the quality of the offence. They are not to be forced to march out of the County where they dwell, to serve as a Souldier, except it be upon a Rebellion at home, or the invasion of an enemy. Neither are they constrained to go out of the Kingdom to serve aforeign Prince. They are not to be Imprisoned, without cause shewed, and that according to the Laws of the Land: And if imprisoned, they are not denied a Writ of Habeas Corpus. They have the priviledge of Hawking, Hunting, Fowling, and Fishing, with divers other immunities too tedious to name. But a word or two of each particular degree, and first of a Duke. Dukes.

A Duke, next to the King, is the highest of all others; by Patent be is created by a cincture of a Sword, imposition of a Cap, and Coronet of Gold on his head, and a verge of Gold put in his hand. This Dignity was at first conferred upon the most deserving persons in martial affairs, and then was not Hereditary as now it is. The Titles attributed unto a Duke, are, the Illustrions, the most high, and noble Prince, like wise the Title of Grace. The Armorial Ensigns, by which they are distinguished from other Nobles, is the Coronet on which the Helmet standeth, viz. a Ducat Crown flowre. Arch-bishops

Arch-Bishops (especially of Canterbury, which is the chief) for dignity, claim the next place. His Title is Primate, and Metropolitan over all England, is called his Grace; likewise the most Reverend Father in God; he hath great Priviledges and Authority;
he doth appoint the Lent Preachers, hath power of keeping ofCourts of Judicature concerning Ecclesiastick affairs; as the Court of Arches, the Court of Audience, the court of Faculties, the Prerogative Court, and the Court of Peculiars: he hath the power of all probate of Wills, and granting of Letters of Administration, where the party which dyeth hath 5 l. or upwards out of the Diocess where he dyed. Likewise he hath the making the Wills of all such as dye intestate within his Province, and to administer their goods to the Relations, or to pious uses, according to his discretion; he hath power to grant publick Notaries, to appoint Guardians; he may grant to sick, or ancient people, dispensations to eat flesh in the time of prohibition: And further, his care is to see that good pious Bishops be put into the Bishopricks under his Jurisdiction.Marquesses.

A Marquess, is created by a cincture of a Sword, Imposition of a Cap of Honour, with a Coronet, and delivering of a Patent into his hand. The Title belonging unto him, is, The most noble and potent Prince, The Right Honourable, &c. The distinction by which he is known in their Atchievement, is the Coronet, which is Meslee, that is, part flowred, and part pyramidal pearled, the flowers and pearls being of equal height.Earls.

An Earl, is also a dignity very ancient and honourable; he is created by a cincture of a Sword, a Mantle of State put upon him by the King, with a Cap and Coronet upon his head, and a Patent given into his hand. The Coronet, which serveth for the distinction, is pyramidal, poynted and pearled, having flowers intermixed, but much shorter then the pearled points. The Title of Prince, also the most potent and noble Lord is attributed unto him. Viscounts.
A Viscount, is also created with the like Ceremony as an Earl; his Title is The Right Honourable and Truly Noble; his Coronet or Chaplet, is only pearled, with a close row of pearls. Bishops.

Bishops, are also Peers of the Realm, by reason ofthe Baronies annexed to their Bishopriks, to which they are created by Patent at their consecration, and are so called by Writ to Parliament. Their Title is, The Reverend Fathers in God. Barons.

A Baron, is also created by Patent, and is esteemed very honourable;his Title is the Right Honourable and truly Noble; and for distinction, the coronet hath but six large pearls about it, whereas the Viscounts is thick beset.Baronets.

Baronets, were first created by King James in Anno 1611. By their institution, they were to keep, for three years in the Province of Ulster, in the Kingdom of Ireland, at their own proper cost and charge, for the defense thereof, thirty foot Souldiers, at 8 d. per diem, which amounteth unto 1095 l. but in liew thereof, they now answer to the King at their first creation 1000 l. They are to be persons of good quality and reputation; and Gentlemen at the least of three discents; and for estate, to have not under 1000 l. per annum. The Augmentation of honour given to this Order, is the Arms of Ulster, viz. on a Canton or Escocheon Argent, a sinister hand couped gules; which said augmentation they bear in the most convenient place of their Escocheon. Knights.

A Knight, is an Order of very great antiquity and honour, not only in this Kingdom, but also throughout Europe: It being an honour not bestowed on any, but those that for their personal worth and desert do merit the same, and is not hereditary, but dyeth with the person; yet the Heirs enjoy some priviledges, and honour thereby, being Esquires: and although they are not worth 200 l. or 10 l. per ann. yet may they keep for their recreation, Grey-hounds, Setting-doggs, and Nets, for the taking of Pheasants or Partredges; may keep hawks, hounds, and have the use of a birding or fowlingpiece:
likewise if they are of the Ecclesiastical Function, they have the priviledge of holding more then one benefice.

Of Knights, there are several sorts or degrees; viz. Knights of the Garter, (which, as I said before, is an Order of such great dignity, that it is not conferred on any under the degree of a Baron; nay, scarce under an Earl, so that it is too high to be ranged with Knights, though of the first degree, yet it will not be unfit to give some account thereof.) Then Knights Banerets, Knights of the Bath, and lastly, Knights Bachelors. Knights of the Garter.

Knights of the Garter, or of St. George, is an Order of all others by far the most honourable; making them Companions to Kings and Emperors. It is a fellowship of all the Orders in Christendom the most ancient and famous; encircling all Titles and Degrees of Nobility from the Throne downwards. This Order was first instituted by that victorious Prince, King Edward the third, in the 23 th year of his reign, and by him called Knights of the Blew Garter; but commonly of the Garter. He likewise appointed his Successors, the Kings of England, as chief; and the number of this Honourable Fellowship to be twenty and five other Knights, so that with the King there are twenty six, which said number are never to be encreased: and these twenty five were, and are called the Fellows, or Companions of the Order of the Garter, or St. George. See Elias Ashmole Esq; his Book of the Order of the Knights of the Garter: a worthy, and a laborious piece The solemnity in the celebration of these Knights, is performed at Windsor, the birth-place of that puissant Prince, with much grandure and magnificence; there being diversrites and ceremonies performed, too tedious to name. There are belonging to this noble Order, besides those aforesaid, and as subservient fourteen secular Canons that are Priests, thirteen Vicars which are also Priests, and twenty six poor Knights, who receive their maintenance from the Colledge. Also the Prelate of the Garter, the Chancellour of the Garter, the Register, the principal King at Arms, called Garter King at Arms, whose office is to marshal and order their solemnities at their Instalments and Feasts, and then the Usher of the Garter. The said solemnity is, or ought to be performed every 23 th day of April at Windsor, as aforesaid. The habit or badge by which this Honourable Order is distinguished on ordinary dayes, is; about their body they wear a blew Ribbon or Garter, whereto is affixed the Figure of St. George and the Dragon, all imbellished with Diamonds; and about their left Legg they wear also a blew Garter, or Band with studs, buckles, &c. and with these words in Gold, HONI SOIT QUI MAL Y PENSE, Shame be to him that evil thinks; and on their Garments they wear a silver Star. But on Festival dayes, they also wear rich Robes, with a Collar of Garters cast over their Shoulders, &c. This noble Order hath been, and yet is, of such great esteem in foreign parts, that Emperors, Kings, and several soveraign Princes, have thought themselves honoured, to be admitted into this Fellowship. Kt. Baneret.

A Knight Baneret, is a degree of great honour, and is to be ranked above all other Knights, except those of the Garter. It is an honour alwayes conferred in the field by the King, under the Kings Standard or Banner displayed in open war, for some signal piece of service there performed. Knights of the Bath.

A Knight of the Bath, is a degree of honour of good antiquity; and so tearmed from the custom of bathing, before the said honour is conferred on them; who is alwayes made at the Coronation of a King, and upon the installment of a Prince of Wales. The Ceremonies in the making these Knights are very many; and the common ornament or badge of the said honour, is a scarlet Ribbon, which they wear cross their Shoulder, with an Escocheon hanging at the end thereof.
Knights Bachelors.

A Knight Bachelor, is a degree of honour, which in ancient time was conferred on Military men, as a reward for their valour and noble exploits. They are made Knights by the ceremony of kneeling down, and the King laying a drawn Sword on their shoulders, bids them to arise Sir John, Sir Thomas, or the like, as their names are. In their Helmets they are distinguished from all Esquires and Gentlemen, (whose Helmets is one and the same) by an open Helmet, whereas those under the degree of a Knight have it close. Esquires.

An Esquire is a degree of honour, either made so by the King, or else by birth, or office. Those made so by the King, are such, as for their noble parts, or publick undertakings, have merited the same. Those by birth,are the sons of Viscounts, Barons, the younger sons of Dukes, Marquesses, and Earls, the eldest sons of Baronets and Knights. And those by office are such as are chief Officers at Court, (if persons no otherwise dignified;) also those that are imployed in publick offices of State, as Sheriffs, Justices of Peace, Majors, &c. Gentlemen.

Lastly Gentlemen, and such are those that are either descended of ancient Families, and bear Coats of Arms; or such as have arived to fair Estates by their virtuous endeavours, and qualified with those natural endowments befitting the mind of man, and are made so by the Kings at Arms, by giving them a Coat of Arms. And although they have no other Title then a Gentleman, yet if well qualified, they are received as fellow Companions with those of the highest degree of the Nobility.

But before we pass further, let us take a Survey of the several Counties of England, which for method sake shall be placed Alphabetically; and then the first that offereth it self to view will be Barkshire.

div1.n: BARKSHIRE: Being the ATTREBATII, and part of the ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: BARKSHIRE: Being the ATTREBATII, and part of the ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.
div1.p: BARKSHIRE, or BERKSHIRE, a County of a pleasant, temperate, and whol some air; of a soil fit for corn and pasturage, yielding good encrease (especially in the vale of White-horse;) and generally the whole County, both for prosit and pleasure, producing corn and cattle in great plenty; being well cloathed with wood, and watered with fresh streams, (which afford excellent fish and fowl) is inferiour (for its extent) to few Shires in England. Dignified with the Title of an Earldom.
It is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which at present, is in the person of the Right Honourable Charles Howard, Earl of Barkshire, Viscount Andover, &c. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds Surrey, which of all other parts is less fertile, as being full of Woods and Forests; For its Southern, Hantshire; for its Western (which taketh up the greatest breadth) Wiltshire; and for its Northern, the Isis, which afterwards taketh the name of Tamisis, or the Thames, and in a winding channel, full of reaches, severeth it from the Counties of Oxford and Buckingham. Its extent.

Its extent in length, from old Windsor in the East, to Inglesham in the West, is about 40 miles; and from Inkpen in the South, to Weightham in the North, about 24; and makes in circumference about 120 miles. Its Rivers.

Amongst the Rivers that water this Shire, the Isis,the Oke, and the Kenet (which afford excellent Trouts, especially about Hungersord) are of the chiefest note: over which, for the conveniency of passage, are several Bridges. Much cloth here made.
The principal comodity that this Shire affordeth is cloth, which in several Towns is made in great quantities; especially at Reading and Newbury. Ancient Inhabitants.

Its ancient Inhabitants known to Casar were the Attrebatii, and them of those that descended from Gallia; amongst whom Comius (conquered by the Dictator) was had in good esteem amongst the Britains. And after the downfall of the Roman power, it became part of the Kingdom of the West-Saxons. Its Hundreds and Towns.

This County is severed into 20 Hundreds, (the names of which are set down in the Mapp) in which are numbred 140 Parish Churches; and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, there are dispersed in it twelveMarket Towns, which are as followeth.
Reading.

Reading, the largest Town in the County, conteining three Parish Churches, graced with fair and large Streets, and beautified with good built Houses. It is a place well Inhabited, of a great resort and trade, especially for its Cloth and Mault here made; and its Market which is on Saturdays is very considerable, and plentifully provided with all sorts of Grain, Flesh, and other necessaries. It is a Town pleasantly seated near the banks of the Thames, and well watered with several rivulets which run through its streets, besides the river Kennet (large and navigable for Barges) which falleth into the Thames, and affordeth great conveniency to its Inhabitants in the conveyance of their goods by water; over which said Rivers are about fourteen or fifteen Bridges, amongst which that over the Kennet is the fairest. It was once beautified with a fair and rich Monastery; and a strong Castle built by King Henry the First, wherein the Collegiate Church of the Abbey, himself and Queen (who was a professed Nun) together with Maud their daughter (stiled the Lady of England) were interred; which said Castle was rased to the ground by Henry the Second, for that it should not be a refuge for the followers of K. Stephen; nor hath the Monastery ought to boast of save its ruines. And here the Danes setled and fortified themselves, after their great overthrow at Inglefield, a small Village, by the hands of King Ethelwolf. It is a Town Corporate, enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is governed by a Major, twelve Aldermen, and as many Burgesses or Assistants, besides a Steward and other sub-Officers. New Windsor.

New Windsor, pleasantly scituate near the banks of the Thames, and in a healthful air; a fair, large, well frequented, and inhabited Town, of great note for its famous and stately Castle, and Royal Palace of his Majesty, which sometimes did belong to the Abbot of Westminster, till William the Conquerour (who so much thirsted after it) by composition obteined his desires, and made it his Palace. Windsor Castle. It hath in it a Chappel for devotion, a Colledge for learning, and an Almes-house for decayed Gentlemen, who are called the poor Knights of Windsor. It is a place of great strength, and the rather by its scituation, being seated on a great eminence, which affords so delectable a prospect round about, that our Kings do oft make it their retiring place; and to make its delight more perfect, it hath a Park and Forest near adjoyning, well stored with Game both for the Hawk and Houna. The present Governour of this Castle is the illustrious Prince Rupert, &c. This Castle gave birth to several Kings, Queens, and Princes; amongst which to King Edward the Third, who much added to its beauty, and where he held as his Prisoners, John King of France, and David King of Scots: and here lyeth inter'd (in its Chappel) the bodies of several Kings and persons of honour. Knights of the noble Order of the Garter here enstall'd. And yet more famous is this Castle for being the place where the Ceremony of the Knights of the Garter is solemnized on St. George's day, in great pomp and grandure, fit for so noblean Order, said first to be instituted by King Richard the First, at his going to Wars against the Turks, Saracens, and Eastern people, begirting the Leggs of certain worthy Knights with a tache of Leather, which promised a future glory to the wearer: Although others will have it, that the institution was first from a Garter that fell from the legg of the beautiful Lady Joan Countess of Salisbury, as the danced before him; and thereupon that French Posie was set in a Garter, HONI SOIT QUI MAL Y PENSE: which in English is, Shame to him that evil thinks. This Town of Windsor, is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major, and other sub-Officers; sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is considerable for Provisions.
Old Windsor.

Nigh unto New Windsor is Old Windsor, a Town of greater antiquity, though not of so much splendor. Likewise adjoyning to it, but on the other side of the Thames, in the County of Buckingham, where there is a fair Bridge that leadeth to Windsor, is Eaton Colledge, a fine Structure, and famous School of Literature. Eaton. Maidenhead.

Maidenhead, seated on the Banks of the Thames, over which it hath a Bridge; a small thorow-fair Town, full of Inns and Places of entertainment, considering its largeness. Its Market, which is kept every Wednesday, is well frequented, and the more for the conveniency of its Barges, in conveying of Goods to and from London, and other parts. Ockingham.

Ockingham, a large and well frequented Market- Town, conteining several Streets, and graced with a fair Market-house, seated in the midst thereof. A place of note for its Silk-stockings here made. Its Market is on Tuesdays, which is well provided of Corn and other Provisions. Finchamstead.
Nigh unto Ockingham is Finchamstead, where, in Anno 1100 (as 'tis reported) for the space of 15 dayes, there was a wonderful Spring which streamed forth blood. Newbury.

Newbury, seated very commodiously on the River Kennet, and in a Champain Plain; a large, well frequented, and inhabited Market and Town Corporate, governed by a Major, Aldermen, and Burgesses: Beautified with a spacious Market-place, and with a well built Market-house. This Town had its rise from the ruins of that ancient Town Spinæ, which now is but a small Village adjoyning to it, and called Speenhamland. Its Market is on Thursdays, which is very considerable for Corn, and well served with Flesh, Fish, and Fowl. This Town is of note for its Jack of Newbury; a man of great repute in the time of Henry the Eighth, as well for his jolly and hospitable humour, as for the great Estate he got by the Trade of Clothing, (which this Town to this day is very considerable for.) But of more note for the first bloody Battle here fought in the late distracted times, where his Majesty, King Charles the First of blessed memory, was perfectly victorious, as having the plunder of the Field, the burials of the Dead, dispersing of the Enemies, and where he stayed to establish a Garison in the Castle of Donnington near adjacent. Which said Castle was famous for having been the House Jeoffrey Chawcer, where under an Oak, called Chawcers Oak, (which was in being within this 25 years past) he penned many of his famous Poems. But this place is of greatest remark, for that signal relief it had by his said Majesty, who, with about 10000 men relieved the same, in the view of above 20000 of the Enemy, which were drawn up in Batalia; who observing his Majesties incomparable conduct, and personal valour in the whole design, stood as men astonished, and durst not attack him, and without one stroke struck, were enforced to their shame, to see his Majesty withdraw his Cariages and Cannon from under the Works of the said Castle, which some few dayes before he had there lodged, for the more commodious march of his small Army, not exceeding 1/3 of the Enemies; and under the conduct of that noble Col. Sir George Lisle, the Enemies whole Army received a notable check a Shaw within half a mile of Donnington Castle, a house belonging to Sir Thomas Dollman Kt. a place noted for the commodious reception of the Kings and Queens in their Western Progress, in times of Peace. And in the War it had the honour and good fortune to receive his late Majesty, and his Majesty now reigning; at which time it was at tacked by the greatest part of the Enemies Army, who lost near 1000 of their men upon the place, with a
great number wounded; and in the defence thereof, the men killed and wounded did not exceed 80, which was occasioned by reason of the commodiousness of the place, in sheltring them from the Enemy. Hungerford.

Hungerford, seated on the Banks of the River Kenet, very low and waterish; of chief note for having the best Trouts and Craw-fish in all England. It is a small Town, and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is but indifferent. Langborne.
Langhorne, pleasantly seated near the Confines of Wiltshire, in an open Countrey, sit for hawking and hunting. A small Market Town. East Ilsly.

East Ilsly, scituate betwixt two Hills, amongst fertile Corn- fields, and excellent Downs for the feeding of Sheep; and very commodious for all sorts of Field sports. The Town is indifferent good, and hath a Market kept every Wednesday during the Summer season, chiesly for the sale of Sheep, for which it is very considerable. Wallingford.

Wallingford, commodiously seated on the Banks of the Thames, over which it hath a fair Stone Bridge: A Town of great antiquity, and in times past very strong and large, being begirt with a Wall and Fortifications, which took up a mile in circuit; and had once a strong Castle, now demolished. And contained four Parish Churches, two of which in the late troubles were demolished. It was the chief City of the Attribatians, and in Edward the Confessors time was accounted a Burgh, and contained 266 Houses or Stages. It was formerly a Barony; then in the reign of Henry the Third, it belonged to the Earls of Chester; then to Richard King of the Romans, and Earl of Cornwall, who repaired it; and in the end it became annexed to the Duke of Cornwall; since which time, it hath by little and little fell to decay. Which was principally occasioned through the destruction of its Inhabitants in the great Sickness in Anno 1348 and the turning of London rode through Abington and Dorchester; nevertheless, by reason of its great Trade of Maulting, and the commodiousness in transporting Corn and other Commodities to London, its Buildings and Inhabitants are of late much increased; and its Markets, which are on Tuesdays and Fridays, which is the chief, is very considerable for all sorts of Grain and Provisions. It is at present a Town Corporate, enjoyeth large immunities; sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is governed by a Major, six Aldermen, who are Justices of the Peace within the said Borough, with other sub-Officers. Here is lately erected a fair Market-house or Guild-hall, with a Free School; in which Market-house the Major and Justices keep their Quarter Sessions, and Courts for the affairs of the said Burrough. Abington.

Abington, the Shire-Town, seated on the plain of a Hill, and also on the Banks of the River of Thames, over which it hath a Bridge; It is a Town of good antiquity, and florished in times past, by reason of its rich and magnificent Abby, beautified by King Edgar after its destruction by the Danes; and is at present a Major, and Market-Town, enjoying several priviledges, and sendeth one Burgess to Parliament. It is a place well frequented, inhabited, and traded unto, especially for its Mault. And its Markets on Mondays and Fridays, are well provided with Corn, Malt, and Provisions. Sunningwell of old Sheovesham.

Nigh unto this Town, where now standeth Sunningwell, was Sheovel- sham, once a famous City, very delectably seated, where was the Regal seat of their Kings; but so soon as Cissa, King of the West-Saxons had
built the Abbey, it began by little and little to lose its name, and was called Abington, as raised out of its ruins. Wantage.

Wantage, seated on a branch of the River Ock, of chief note for giving birth to the famous and renowned Prince King ælfred, who was a scourge to the Danes. It hath a Market on Saturdays, which affordeth the best Flesh, and at the easiest price of any Town in the County. Faringdon,

Faringdon, highly seated, and not far from the Thames; a well frequented Market-Town on Tuesdays. In former time here was a Fort raised by Robert Earl of Glocester against King Stephen, who won it, and afterwards laid it level to the ground. The Ornament of the County.

This County is adorned with many fair and stately Buildings; hath been strengthened with six Castles, and graced with three of his Majesties Houses: and in times past had divers Religious Houses and Monasteries; as at Abington, Reading, Bysham, Bronhall, Henley, Hamm, and Wallingford.

div1.n: BEDFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the CATEJULANI and ancient
div1.head: BEDFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the CATEJULANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.
div1.p: BEDFORD, a County of a temperate air, bringing forth delight and health to its Inhabitants; by reason thereof, and its vicinity to the Counties of Lincoln and Huntington, which are troubled in some parts with unhealthful Foggs; it is very populous, and crowded with Gentry. Its fertility.

It is generally of a fertile soil, producing all sorts of Grain in great plenty, especially Wheat and Barly, which is bettered by no one County in England. And their Pastures feed very good Cattle, and have great Daries: but their Sheep deserve no great commendations. The North, and North East sides of the Shire, are a deep Clay; the South a Chiltern; and in the midst, from Potton to Dunstable, runs a sandy ridge of Hills, which are well clothed with Wood both for Timber and Fuel, from whence the Inhabitants are supplyed. Its Rivers.
It is watered with two Rivers, the Owse, a fair large River, and the Iwell; And before the Draining of the Fenns, had great plenty of Fowl and Fish, but now scare any. Its ancient Inhabitants.
The ancient Inhabitants known to Cæsar, were the Catejulani, a stout and warlike people, who being afterwards subdued by the English Saxons, became part of the Kingdom of the Mercians.
In the Barons wars this County suffered great spoyls, especially the Shire- town, Bedford, with the Castle, which was almost laid level to the ground. Its Extent.

This County is but of a small extent, being in length from Tilbrook in the North, to Studham in the South, about 24 miles; and in breadth from Turvey in the West, to Coking Hatley in the East, scarce 12; which makes its circumference to be about 73 miles. Its Bounds.

This Shire is severed into Nine Hundreds, the names of which are set down in the Mapp; in which are numbred 116 Towns, besides 59 Engships, or Constablaries: And hath intercourse for the Traffick of Commodities with ten Market-Towns, one of which is now dis-used, or so inconsiderable, that it deserves not the name. Bedford.

Bedford, the chief Shire-town, pleasantly seated in a most fertile soil, and on the Banks of the River Owse, which divideth it in the midst (so
that it may seem to be two Towns) but joyned together by a fair and strong Stone-bridge, which for the prevention of passage (as occasion requireth) hath two Gate-houses. Not far from the Bridge, and on the Banks of the Owse, sometime stood a little Chappel, wherein (as ancient Writers record) Offa the Mercian King was interred, whose Monument remained a long time, until the overflowing River washed it quite away. This Town hath sufficiently withstood the shocks of ill fortune, having felt the sore hand of the Danes; also in the civil Wars; and when the Barons waged war against King Jobn it suffered much: and lastly by King Henry the Third. Its Castle (a place of an exceeding strength) was laid level, with its foundation; and in the place thereof is now a Bowling-Green, esteemed (by the Gentrey, which do much resort unto it for their recreation) as good, if not the best of any in England. It is a place well inhabited, and frequented, of a good largeness, numbring five Parish Churches, three seated on the North side of the River, and two on the South. It is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which said Dignity is now in the Person of the Right Honourable William Earl of Bedford, Knight of the noble Order of the Garter, &c. For its civil Magistrates, it is governed by a Major, two Bailiffs, two Chamberlains, a Recorder, Town-Clark, and other sub-Officers, who takes the Toll of the Town, which is very considerable; and gives its voice in Parliament by two Burgesses. Here are weekly two Markets, on Tuesdays and Saturdays. That on Tuesdays being kept on the South side, and is considerable for all living Cattle; and that on Saturdays, which is on the North side, is very great for Corn, there being generally vended, one day with another, about 300 Quarters.
And the Market of this Town, with those of Potton, Bigleswade, and Shefford, are of late years grown much quicker, and greater for Corn, then formerly. Dunstable.

Dunstable, seated on a Hill, in a chalky dry ground, where no Springs are found, without digging about 20, or 24 Cubits; yet by reason of a large pond of standing water, (which scarce is ever dry) in every one of the four Streets of the Town (which answereth to the four Quarters) the Inhabitants find no want. This Town was the Station which the Emperour Antonine in his Itinerary, calleth Magioninium, Magiovinium, and Magintum; for besides that it is seated on the Romans high-way, there are oft- times found in the fields here adjacent pieces of the Roman Emperours Coyns, which the Inhabitants call Madning money: and within a small descent of the Chiltern-hills, there is raised up round with a Rampier and Ditch, a Military modell, conteining about nine Acres of ground. This Town is said to be built by Henry the First, out of the ruines of the aforesaid Town, and called Dunstable, for the better suppressing the Robberies of one Dun a notorious Robber, that used to pester these parts. It is at present a fair and well frequented Market-Town, full of Inns for the accommodation of Passengers, as seated in the high Road from London to Westchester, which formerly bore the name of Watling-street. In this Town, by order of King Edward the First, was erected a Cross or Column adorned with Statues, the Arms of England, &c. in memorial of Eleonor his Queen, as being a place where her Corps rested in her journey from Lincolnshire, where she dyed, to Westminster-Abbey where she was interred. Its Market is kept on Wednesdays, which is large, affording Corn, Cattle, and Provisions in great plenty. Great store of Larks here taken.
About this Town are caught abundance of Larks, which are esteemed the best in England, and where they are likewise the best drest. Leighton.

Leighton, or Leighton-Buzard, on a branch of the Owse, over which
it hath a Brridge, which leadeth to Buckinghamshire: a very large Town, whose Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very considerable for all sorts of fat Cattle. Luton.
Luton, a pretty good Town, with a large Market- house; pleasantly seated between Hills, near the confines of Hartfordshire, and hath a very good Market On Mondays for Corn and Poultry. Tuddington.

Tuddington, scituate under the Hills, or Downs, and in a good soyl. It had formerly an indifferent good Market on Saturdays, but at present is very inconsiderable, being hardly frequented, or rather disused. Woburne.

Woburne, on a rising ground, of late much frequented by Passengers, in their journeys from London to Northampton: It was formerly of some account for its goodly Monastery, as it is at present for its Free School, founded by Francis Earl of Bedford. The Market is here kept on Fridays, which is of good account for Butter, Cheese, and such like commodities. Aspley. Excellent Fullers earth

Near this Town is Aspley, where the nature of the soil is such, that it petrifieth Wood. And about this Town is digged up excellent Fullers earth in great plenty, which, if not transported, would be very advantagious to the Clothiers of this Kingdom, it being not to be had in most parts beyond Seas, and without which they cannot make cloth. Ampthill.
Ampthill, or the honour of Amphthill, a pretty Town, seated very pleasantly between two Hills, but in a barren soil, and hath an indifferent Market on Thursdays. Shefford.

Shefford, commodiously seated between two Rivulets, which below the Town joyn, and loose themselves in the Owse; over each of which is a Bridge. It hath a good Market for Corn and Poultrey on Fridays. Bigleswade.

Bigleswade, pleasantly scituated on the Ivel, which falleth into the Owse at Temesford, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge. The Town was formerly very inconsiderable; but of late years grown into request, by reason of the commodious Inns for Passengers, in their journeys from London to York; and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is at present very considerable for all sorts of Grain, store of Cattle, milch Kine, and Provisions. Potten.

Potton, a small Town, of a pleasant scituation, and watered with a small Brook, but on a sandy, gravelly, and barren soil. It hath a very good Market on Saturdays, for Corn, Cattle, and Poultrey. Temesford.
Not far from Potton at Tamesford, the Danes kept their standing Camp, and had their Castle. Sande, Chesterfield.

Also at Sande and Chesterfield near adjoyning, which is now nothing but a Warren, stood the famous City of Salena of the Romans, which by the ruins of the Walls (in many places yet to be seen) doth declare it to have been a place of a large extent.

At a place near Harwood in Anno 1399. the River Owse stood suddenly still, and severed it self, in so much, that men went about three miles in the bottom of its channel on foot, without danger. Its Castles and Religious Houses.

This Shire hath been beautified with divers fair Castles, as at Ampthill, Eaton, Temesford, Woodhill, and Bedford; as also with several famous Religious Houses, which are now utterly abolished, and laid level with their Foundations; as at Bedford, Dunstable, Harwood, Woburne, Warden, Helen- slow, Chicksand, Newenham, Bushmead, and elsewhere.

div1.n: BUCKINGHAMSHIRE: BEING Part of the CATEJVLANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: BUCKINGHAMSHIRE: BEING Part of the CATEJVLANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.
div1.p: BUCKINGHAM, a County, for the generality, of a rich and fertile soil, yielding Corn, Grass, and Marle in great abundance; and blest with a temperate and healthful air. It is divided into two parts: That towards the South and East (which riseth into Hills, which are sufficiently clothed with Wood) is called the Chiltern; The other lying Northwards (being plain) is called the Vale; and this part is the most fruitful for Tillage and Pasturage, feeding infinite numbers of fleecy Sheep, and other Cattle, which the Inhabitants are considerable gainers by. Its name, Why? The Chilternhills formerly very dangerous.

This County is supposed to take its name from the Saxon word Bucken, which signifieth Beech-trees, wherewith this Shire was, and yet is, so plentifully stored, especially on and about the Chiltern-hills, which formerly were unpassable, and became a receptacle for Robbers, which then so pestered these parts, that Travellers could hardly escape them: For the remedy of which, and the good of the Wayfaring-man, Leostan, Abbot of St. Albons, caused them to be cut down, and made more passable, which did occasion those ravenous Woolves soon to quit their Sanctuary. Its Bounds.
This Shire hath for its Eastern bounds the Counties of Bedford, Hartford and Middlesex; for its Southern, Barkshire; for its Western, Oxfordshire; and for its Northern, Northamptonshire. Its Extent.

Its Extent from Ash-ridge in the East, to Bostall in the West, is about 18 miles; and from Wrasbury in the South, to Lavenden in the North, about 39; whereby the whole Circuit is about 138 miles. The ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants were the Catejulani, who yielded themselves to Cæsar, and upon the Saxons subduing the Romans, it became part of the Kingdom of the Mercians: then fell it (with the rest of the Kingdom) under the Danish Scepter, who sorely harassed it, and destroyed divers of its Towns; amongst the rest, the City Bury-hill, now a small Village, and called Brill, which by the pieces of Coyn there found, doth declare it to be an ancient City of the Romans. Bury-hill, now Brill, an ancient City of the Romans. And lastly, it became subject to William the Conquerour, as did the whole Kingdom. The Castles and Religious Houses.

This Shire hath been strengthened with four Castles; viz. at Buckingham, Newport, Lavenden, and Hanslop; and had in it many Religious Houses, which time hath now ruinated, and converted to other uses; and such were those at Luffeld, Launden, Bidlesden, Bradwell, Astwoodbery, Olney, Tilford, Missenden, Notley Asbridge, Chitwood, Ascot, Whaddon, Weston-
Underwood, and Alisbury, which above all others was had in great esteem, for St. Edith, who abandoning all worldly pleasures, betook her self to a holy life, and was grealy renowned, even as far as the working of Miracles. Its division.
It is severed into eight Hundreds, (whose names appear in the Mapp) in which are numbred 185 Parishes, and is traded unto by thirteen or fourteen Market Towns. Its Rivers and Bridges.
It is watered with two Rivers, the Owse and the Tame, or Thames, which are passed over by no less then fourteen Bridges.
Amongst the Towns in this Shire, these following are of most note. Buckingham.

Buckingham, the Shire Town, fruitfully seated in a low ground, and on the Banks of the Owse, which almost encompasseth it, save on the North part; over which it hath three fair Stone Bridges, one leading Eastwards, another Southwards, and the third Westwards. In times palt it was fortified by King Edward the Elder, with a Rampier and Sconces on both sides of the River; and upon a high Hill in the midst of the Town, was sometime raised a strong Castle, formerly in the possession of Humphrey Duke of Buckingham, which long since was reduced to ruins. The Town is fair, well frequented and inhabited; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with all manner of Flesh, Corn, Fruit, and some Fish. It is dignified with the Title of a Dukedom, which at present is invested in the persorn of the Right Noble George Duke of Buckingham, &c. and for civil Magistrates, is governed by a Bailiss, twelve principal Burgesses, a Steward, and other sub-Officers. And as a Town Corporate hath several immunities, and electeth Parliament men. In the North part of the Town is seated the Town-Hall; and in the South the Church, which is of chief note for having in it formerly the shrine of St. Rumald a child, who through the zeal of our Fore-fathers, was canonized a Saint. Night to this Church was a once stately Prebend-house belonging to the Church of Lincoln, which was endowed with Lands of 1000 l. per annum. And here was also a Chappel. called St. John Baptist, founded by Tho. Becket, now converted into a Free School. Stoney-Stretford.

Stoney-Stretford, scituate on the Banks of the Owse, a Town of great antiquity, being the Romans Lactoradum, and built upon that ancient Causway, called Watling-street, which was a Military high-way of the Romans, and passed through England. At this place Edward the Elder obstructed the passage of the Danes, whilst he fortified Towcester against them; and here King Edward the First, for a memorial of Eleanor his Queen (whose Corps here rested in her journey from Lincolnshire,where she dyed, to Westminster the place of her interment) erected a beautiful Cross, inmemorial of her. It is at present a good large Town, conteining two Parish Churches; is well accommodated with Inns, and hath a very great Market for Corn, Flesh, and some Fish on Fridays. Newport.

Newport, or Newport Pagnell, seated on the Owse, and a branch thereof, over which it hath two Bridges: It is a good Market-Town on Saturdays, affording Corn, Cattle, and Provisions; and is of chief note for the Bone-lace here made. Oulney.

Oulney, seated also on the Owse, in the Northern part of the County; a pretty good Town, whose Inhabitants drive a great Trade for the Bonelace here, and in parts adjacent, made; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is well served with Corn and Provisions. Winslow.
Winslow, seated in a good soil, where there is plenty of Wood, hath a Market on Thursdays, which is well furnished with Corn and Provisions. Ivingo.

Ivingo, seated amongst Woods, but in a barren soil, hath a small Market on Fridays.
Ashridge.

Not far from this Town, in a corner of the Shire, and on a pleasant ascent, is seated Ashridge, where there was formerly a retiring House of the Kings. And here Edmond Earl of Cornwall, son to Richard King of the Romans, founded a Religious House, for a new order of Religious men, called Bon hommes; now the seat of the Right Honourable the Earl of Bridgwater. Alisbury.

Alisbury, scituate on a small Hill, on branch of the River Tame, and in a fertile Vale so called, being encompssed with rich Meadows and Pastures, which feed store of Sheep. This Town was formerly famous for its St. Edith, who having obteined it of her Father Frewald for her Dowry, bid her Husband and the World farewell, here betaking her self to a Religious Life, and became very renowned. And it is at present of note for giving title, the Right Honourable Robert Earl of Alisbury and Elgin, &c. It is a fair and well inhabited Borough Town, electing Parliamentmen; and hath a well frequented Market for Cattle, Corn, and all Provisions on Saturdays. In the midst of the Town is seated a fair Shire-Hall, where the Assises are usually kept, as being the most commodious place in the County. Wendover.
Wendover, a Borough Town, which electeth Parliament men, hath a small Market on Thursdays. Amersham.

Agmundeham, or Amersham, scituate on the River Coln, and in the Chiltern, a good Borough Town, which hath the election of Parliament men; but its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is but small. Prince Risborough.
Risborough, or Prince Risborough, which took its name from the Black Prince; an indifferent Town, seated on the Hills, and hath a small Market on Saturdays. High Wickham

High Wickham, seated on a small River which falleth into the Thames, and in a low and fertile Vale. It is a Major Town, which for largeness and fair Buildings, is not inferiour to any in the County; and its Market, which is on Fridays, is very considerable for Corn, and is well served with Flesh, Fish, and all Provisions. Beaconfield.

Beaconfield, scituate on a dry Hill, and on the high road from London to Oxford; by reason thereof it is a fair Town, and well accommodated with Inns; yet its Market, which is on Thursdays, is but indifferent. Marlow.

Marlow, an indifferent good Town, seated on or near the River Thames, over which there is a Bridge which leadeth to Barkshire: It is a Borough Town, and hath the election of Parliament men; as Chipping Norton hath, not far distant. Chipping Norton. This Town is said to take its name from the great store of Marl, or Chaulk, which the Husbandmen here dig up, which addeth no small advantage to them, by the enriching their grounds. Eaton.

Eaton, scituate on the Banks of the Thames, over which there is a fair Bridge which leadeth to Windsor. It is a place of particular fame for its stately Colledge and School of Literature, founded by that pious Prince, King Henry the Sixth. Colebrook.

Colebrook, seated on the River Coln, which severeth this County from Middlesex, and divideth it self into four streams or Cateracts, which after no long course, joyn themselves in one, but soon part in twain; and the said River thus forming several Isles, made the Danes (when they were put to flight by ælfred) to take sanctuary here, where they defended themselves, until such time that the English, for want of Provisions, were forced to raise the Siege, and leave them. This Town is but small, nor its Market, which is on Wednesdays, of any account, yet as seated in the Western road from London to Reading, and elsewhere, is of some account; and hath several good Inns.

div1.n: CAMBRIDGSHIRE: BEING Part of the ICENI and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Angles
div1.head: CAMBRIDGSHIRE: BEING Part of the ICENI, and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Angles.
div1.p: The County of Cambridge, by the English-Saxons called Grenthrig-Scyre, is of a different soil, and not over-fertile; occasioned by its Fenns on the Northern part so over-charged with water. The lower or Souther part being Champain, indifferent fertile, well manured, garnished with fair Meadows and Pastures, and beareth excellent Corn and Barley, of which is made great store of Malt, which the Inhabitants vend to London and other parts to their great profit: and here is gathered good store of Saffron, which is the dearest Commodity that England produceth. Commodities And the upper or Northern part is Fennish, occasioned through the over-flowings of the several Rivers, (and principally the Owse) which as it were formes so many Isles, and called the Isle of Ely; which said part is not so pleasant nor whol some to live in as the Southern; but is recompenced by its rich Pastures (since the draining of the Fens) for the grazing of fat Cattle; and 'tis observed, that when the grounds are not over-flown in the Winter-season, the Summer Crops are not so good; for the waters not only fatten the Earth, but kill the weeds, which these grounds are much subject to produce. And in these Fenny grounds grow great store of Willows, of which the Inhabitants reap good profit by making of Baskets, &c. Its bounds.

This County is bordered upon the East with Suffolk and Norfolk; on the South with Essex and Hartfordshire; on the West with the Shires of Bedford and Huntington; and on the North with those of Lincoln and Huntington. Its extent.

It extendeth it self in length from St. Giles-tyde in the furthest part of the Fens, to Royston in the South, about 35 miles; and from East to West, where broadest about 20, making in circumference (tracing its many indents) about 130 miles. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers (especially its Northern parts) the chief of which are the Owse, and the Cam or Grant, which traverseth the County, and sendeth forth several Rivulets. Religious Houses.

This County hath had many fair foundations of Religious Houses, as at Barnwel, Charteres, Denny, Eltisley, Shingay, Swavesey, and Thorney, but these, as well as the rest in other Counties of England, were supprest by K. Hen. 8 th. Its division.

It is divided into two parts, the upper and the lower, which again are subdivided into 17 Hundreds, in which are numbred 163 Parishes, and for the conveniency of its Inhabitants, hath 8 Market Towns; and was formerly strengthened with 7 Castles. And of these 17 Hundreds, 14 are in the lower part, and but 3 in the upper, which are large, and contein almost the moiety of the County.
Cambridge.

Cambridge, seated in an Air somewhat unhealthful, by reason of the Fenny grounds near adjoyning, and on the river Cam, or Grant, which separateth it into two (but unequal) parts, which are joyned together by a Bridge. And from this River, as some hold, she received her name, although ancient Histories derive it from Cantabar a Spaniard, who about 375 years before the Incarnation of Christ, had there setled the Muses seat. It is a place of great antiquity; for in the year of Grace 141. several Scholars were baptized, and began to preach the Gospel amongst the Britains, in the reign of Hadrian the Emperour. But when the Picts, Scots, Hunns, and Saxons, had laid all things wast, and destroyed all Learning, this with the rest (having lost her Athenian Students) lay like a desolate Widow deploring her sad condition, till at length the Saxons became civil themselves; and Sigilbert the first Christian King of the East-Saxons, established here several Schools, as also at other places in the Kingdom, and cherished Learning, calling hither the Professors of Arts and Sciences, which soon florished; but the merciless Danes in their destructions, sparing neither root nor branch, this felt their heavy hand, and was again laid wast: But when the Normans became Masters of the Kingdom, these Danish storms were soon blown over, and Professors of Arts and Scientes resorted hither, and where they could get convenient places, read Lectures of Grammer, Logick, Rhetorick, and Divinity upon the Sabbath, and Festival dayes. And from this little Fountain grew this now famous University or Seminary of true Learning, which is now the chiefest ornament of Cambridge, being beautified and fairly adorned with sixteen magnificent Colledges and Halls, all which are well furnished with painful Students, and Professors of the several Arts and Sciences, which (with her Sister Oxford, the other University of this Kingdom) doth sufficiently enrich this Land with the knowledge of true Literature. And by reason of these Seminaries, it is a place of a large extent, numbring fourteen Parish Churches, is adorned with well built Houses, and its Streets are paved and well ordered. It is a Town-Corporate, endowed with ample immunities, and sendeth four Burgesses to Parliament; that is to say, two for the University, and two for the Town. Here was formerly a large Castle, which time hath now reduced to ruin. According to the observation of Dr. Fuller in his Worthies of England, it is a Town within a University, where the Colledges are not surrounded with Streets, but for the generality seated on the out-side of the Town, affording the better and more delightful Walks and Gardens about them, which is not so generally at Oxford, which he tearmeth a University within a Town. This place is very well inhabited, and frequented, enjoyeth a good Trade; & its Market which is on Saturdays, is sufficiently furnished with Provisions, which are here had at easie rates. Gogmagog-hills

Nigh unto Cambridge Southwards, are Gogmagog-hills, which are of a great eminency, and retain yet the remembrance of the Danish station (where, on the top thereof is to be seen a Rampier, strengthened with a threefold Trench, and was held to be a place in a manner impregnable: and of these Hills the Country people will tell fine fabulous stories. Ely.

Ely, seated in the Isle so called, in a Fenny and waterish place, and on the Banks of the Owse, which rendreth it unhealthful. It is a City of great antiquity, being said to be first built by Audrey, wife to one Tombret, a Prince of this Province, who had this place assigned her for part of her Dowry, who having departed from her second Husband, Egbert K. of the Northumbers, devoted her self to the service of God, and built here a Nunnery, and was the first Abbess thereof, which brought no small fame to the place, at which time the City was reckoned to contein about 600 hides or
Families.

This place felt the sore hand of the Danes, but was soon after re-edified by Ethelwold Bishop of Winchester, who planted here a Monastery of Monks, which grew exceeding wealthy, and so continued till the Reign of Henry the Eighth. It enjoyeth ample priviledges; for in the Iste of Ely, the Bishop hath all the rights of a County Palatine, and beareth chief sway therein; for by his own power he appointeth a Judge, to hear and determine all causes arising within the said Isle; he holdeth Assises, Goal delivery, and Quarter Sessions of the Peace for the said Liberty, and hath his chief Bailiff, and under Bailiffs of the Hundreds, for the execution of Process. It is at present a City of no great splendor or grandure, neither is it over-much frequented or inhabited, and would be far less, were it not for being the See of a Bishop, whose Palace is now so ruinous, that it is unhabitable. Its Cathedral or Minster (dedicated to St. Ethelred, and was the work of several Bishops) is a lofty Structure, proudly sheweth it self to all the adjacent parts, and is beautified with a stately Lanthorn, being a curious piece of Architecture. This Diocess conteineth within it 141 Parishes, of which 75 are Impropriations, and hath but one Arch-Deacon, which is of Ely. And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with Provisions. Wisbich.

wisbich, scituate in a Fenny part, between two Rivers, a Town of some account, where the Bishops of Ely had their Castle; and hath a Market on Saturdays, which affordeth great plenty of Provisions. Merche.
Merche, seated moist, a new made Market-Town, which for the present is not very considerable. Littleport.
Littleport, scituate in the Fenny part, formerly a Market- Town, but at present disused. Reche.
Reche, also formerly a Market-Town, but now discontinued. New-market.

New-market, seated part in this County, and part in Suffolk, and in a large and pleasant Heath so called; and although a Town of no long continuance, yet is a place well known and frequented by the Gentry, as being a usual place for Horse-rases and Hunting, by reason of the commodiousness of its scituation. And in this Heath is a Ditch, called by the Inhabitants the Devils Dike, which is vulgarly said to be cast up by the Devil in one night; whereas in truth it was made for a defence of the East-Angles against the Mercians, and as a division of their Kingdoms. This Town is not very large, yet conteineth 2 Parish Churches, one of which is in this County, and the other in Suffolk; and is replenished with well built Houses, where his Majesty hath his Palace, and doth often honour this Town with his royal Presence for his divertisement, which adds no small advantage unto it. The Market is here kept on Tuesdays, which is not very considerable, by reason of its vicinity to Cambridge, Bury, and other considerable places. Linton.
Linton, on the confines of this Shire towards Essex, hath a small Market on Thursdays. Caxton.
Caxton, seated in the Clay, and on the North road, a small Town, which of late hath a Market on Tuesdays, not very considerable. Royston.

Royston, scituate low, amongst Hills, partly in this County, and partly in Hartfordshire, through which Town ran Ermingstreet-way to Huntington, which was one of the ancient High-ways of the Romans. The Town is large, well inhabited, and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is very considerable, especially for Mault, here and elsewhere made in great quantities, and from hence conveyed to London and other parts.

div1.n: CHESHIRE: BEING Part of the CORNAVII and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: CHESHIRE: BEING Part of the , and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: The County Palatine of Chester with its hundreds

div1.p: CHESHIRE, or the County Palatine of Chester, for that the Earls thereof had Royalties, and Princely priviledges apperteining unto them: and to whom the Inhabitants paid their allegiance, as to the King. Its fertility.

It is a County of a fat, fruitful, and rich soil, both for Tillage and Pasturage; is plentifully provided with Fowl, both tame and wild; Corn, and other Grain; as also with aboundance of Cattle, from which the Inhabitants reap good profit by the sale of their Butter and Cheese to most parts of England; and the rather by reason of the goodness thereof. And their Oxen are very large, which they plentifully supply London with. Its Commodities.

The Commodities that this County affordeth, are chiefly Corn, Cattle, Sheep, Fish, (especially Salmon) Fowl, Butter, Cheese, and Salt in great plenty, which is their staple Comodity: also in the bowels of the Earth are Mines of Metalls; and out of the Rocks and Quarries, very fair Stones for Buildings, as also broad Slates are dug up, as are excellent Mill-stones out of Moucop-hill. Its Air. Scituation.

It is blest with a sweet and heal thful air, yet is the Summer and Winter cooler then in the Eastern parts of this Kingdom, and more subject to storms of Wind. It hath a pleasant scituation, is every where sufficiently replenished with the habitations of Gentry; and in a word, it aboundeth with all Provisions necessary for the use of man, as well those for pleasure as profit, insomuch that it merited the name of the Vale Royal of England; which name King Edward the First gave unto the Abbey of Vale Royal, which he founded upon the River Weever, in the midst of this Shire. Bounds. Helbree Isle.

It hath for its Eastern bounds the Counties of Darby and Stafford; for its Southern, those of Salop and Denbigh, with part of Flint; for its Northern, Lancashire; and for its Western, the other part of Flint, and the Irish Sea, where it formeth a Promontory, made so by the Rivers Dee, and Mersey, called Wirall, once all a Forest; whereas the further point thereof Westward, night unto the Shore, lyeth a small, sandy, and barren Isle, called Helbree, which at low water may be passed over on the Sand; and here in former times was a little cell of Monks.
Extent.

Its extent from Woodhead in the East, where the River Mersey springeth, to the furthest part of the Werall in the West, near Helbree Isle, is about 44 miles; and from Titley-hall in the South, to Crossford-bridge in the North, about 25; which makes its circumference to be about 112 miles. Its chief hills

And although (in most places) it is flat and even, yet is it not without several noted Hills (besides the Mountains which divide it from the Shires of Darby and Stafford) as Mowcop-hill, which is a mile from the bottom to its summet; Congleton-hedge or edge, Peuket-cloud, Helsby-tor; then the Hills of Shutbingslow, Winecader, Buckley, Peckfarton, Frodsham, and Burwardsley. Its Woods Forests.

It is well clothed with Wood, having several Woods, and two Forests; to wit, that of Delamer near Chester, from whence the Right Honourable Sir George Booth, Baron of Delamer, takes his Title; and that of Maxfield adjoyning to the Town of Maxfield. And it is so well stored with Parks, that almost every Gentleman hath one peculiar to himself. Its Rivers,

It is plentifully watered with Rivers, the chief of which are the Dee, and the Mersey, which may rather be tearmed arms of the Sea, then Rivers; and these kindly send forth their several branches into the Countrey; amongst which are these following, the Weever, Dane, Bollin, Pever, Taume, Wheelock, Goit, Ashbrook, Mar, Gowy, Betley, Hurston, Biddel, Croco, &c.Meres and Pools. And besides these Rivers, there are great store of Meres, or Lakes, as Bag-mere, Pick-mere, Comber-mere, Raustorn-mere, Comberback, and Oakhanger-mere: Also several Pools, as those of New-pool, Ridley-pool, Pitty- pool, and Darnal-pool, with several others, in all which are abundance of excellent Fish. Heaths and Mosses.

Here are several Heaths, and Mosses; the Heaths serving for the feeding their Sheep and Horses; and out of the Mosses, in the summer season, they digg up Turves for their fuel: and in these Mosses (especially in the black) are oft-times dug up Fir-trees of a great bigness, which lye hid six or seven foot deep in the Earth, supposed by the Inhabitants to have lyen here since the Deluge. Its Inhabitants.

The ancient People of this County were the Cornavii of Ptolomy, and after the departure of the Romans, this with other Counties made the Kingdom of the Mercians. And according to Lucian the Monk, they are said to differ from the rest of the English. Its ancient Castles and Religious, Houses.

This Shire hath been strengthened with eight Castles; viz. Old-castle, Stourton, Dunham, Frodesham, Chester, Beeston, Haulton, and Shotwick. And where were also the like number of Religious Houses, as at Maxfield, Stanlwo, Chorton, Gebree, Bunbery, Rudheath, Vale-Royal, and Combermere, besides the White and the Black Fryers, and the Nunnery at Chester, all which were suppressed, and converted to other uses by King Henry the Eighth.

It is severed into seven Hundreds (whose names are set down in the Mapp) in which are numbred 86 Parish Churches, besides 38 Chappels of Ease, and hath entercourse of Traffick with 13 Market Towns; whose names are as followeth. Chester.

Chester, or West-chester, by reason of its Western scituation; a City that hath been known by divers names; Ptolomy called it Deunana; Antonine the Emperour, Deva, of the River Dee on which it is seated; and the Britains, Caer-Legion, Caer-Leonvaux, Caer-Leon ar Dufyr Duy. And besides these names, its Vaults, Pavements, and pieces of Roman Coyns here oft-times dug up, do sufficiently declare its antiquity: And if Henry Bradshaw is to be believed, it was built before Brute, by the Gyant Lcon Gauer, a man (as Speed noteth) beyond the Moon; and called (by Marius)
the Subduer of the Picts. This City is pleasantly seated on the River Dee, or Deva, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, susteined by seven Arches; and at each end of the said Bridge is a Gate, the chief of which is Water-gate (now beautifully repaired, and stronger then formerly) where great Ships in times past at full Sea did come; but the Channel is now so choaked up with Sand, that it will scarce give passage to small Boats, insomuch that all Ships now come to a place called the New-key, about 6 miles distance. Its form is Quadrangular, and taketh up about two miles in circuit, which is enclosed with a Wall of good strength; to which, according to the four cardinal winds, it hath four Gates for entrance; to wit, East- gate, Bridge-gate, Water-gate, and North-gate, which now is made use of by the Citizens, as a Prison for Debt. And besides these four principal Gates, there are three others of less note, called Posterns; and on the Wall are several Watch-towers, and broad Battlements for the placing of pieces of Ordnance. Its Castle. And of these Gates the East-gate is esteemed one of the stateliest Gates in England. Its Castle. It hath also for its further defence a strong Castle, seated on the Southern part near the Bridge, and on a Rocky-hill, an ancient and large structure, where they have their Shire-hall, a goodly large place, somewhat resembling that of Westminster, where all matters of Law concerning the County Palatine are heard, and determined, having their particular Officers, viz. a Chamberlain, a Justice for the Common-Pleas of the Crown, two Barons of the Exchequer, a Sherifs, an Escheator, and other Officers; and at the end of the said Hall is the new Exchequer for the County. Customhouse. And formerly in this Castle they had their Customhouse, which in Anno 1633. for their more conveniency they quitted, as having built a stately one of Brick and Stone, near the middle of the Water-gate-street, which beareth the name of the Kings Store-house, as well as his Customhouse; Being past the Bridge, and entred the inner Ward, there are goodly Appartments for the Justices when they come to the Assises, and other Meetings, as also others made use of by the Governour. Cathedral Church. This City is large, numbring ten Parish Churches, besides its Abbey, Minster, or Cathedral, a large Structure, having a Dean and Prebends thereto belonging, adjoyning to which is the Bishops Palace. This Cathedral was formerly a Monastery founded by Leofricus, once an officiary Count in these parts, who dedicated it to St. Wereberg; but it was repaired, beautified, endowed, and replenished with Monks, by Hugh Lupus the first Earl of Chester, which said Earldom is invested in his Majesty, for want of a Prince of Wales, this Earldom being annexed thereunto; and the Freemen of Chester swear to be true to the King and Earl of Chester. This Diocess conteineth the Counties of Cheshire and Lancashire in whole, and in part those of Flint, Cumberland, and that part of Yorkshire called Richmondshire; in which said Diocess are numbred 256 Parishes, amongst which are 101 Impropriations. It is a City beautified with divers fair Buildings, both publick and private, and graced with large, and well ordered Streets; where are Conduit-pipes which are supplyed with fresh water from a Tower at the Bridge, called the Water-Tower, 35 yards high, and 8 broad; and along the chief Streets are Galleries (or rows as they call them) having on both sides Shops, through which a man may walk free from wet, though in the greatest shower. It is a place well frequented, and inhabited by Gentry and Tradesmen, and the more as being the place where the Courts Palatine, and the Assises are kept twice every year; as also for its being the usual place of taking shipping for Ireland, with which it hath a great intercourse, and is a place of a very considerable Trade. How governed.

It was made a County Corporate by King Henry the Seventh, and the Government
committed to a Major, two Sheriffs, 24 Aldermen, a Recorder, Town-Clark, Sergeant of Peace, four Sergeants, and six Yeomen; and once a year, at an appointed day, the Major (who lives in some Grandure) with the Aldermen, and several of the Companies, go about the City in manner of a Processioning, and make a fine show. As to its immunities, they are large, and is the only place in the County that sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. This City, in the dayes of King Edgar, was in good esteem, where seven Kings of the Scots and Britains (in paying him homage) rowed his Barge from St. Johns to his Palace, himself as supream Lord holding the Helm. Besides what the Shambles afford (being seated in the midst of plenty) here are weekly two Markets, on Wednesdays, and Saturdays, which are in great plenty provided with all necessaries.

About the 24 th of June, there is yearly a Ceremony observed amongst the Musicioners of this county, worth the taking notice of, which was grounded upon this occasion, as followeth. The Ceremony of the Musicioners.

Ranulph the third of that name, and sixth Earl of Chester, after the Conquest, atchieved many enter prises against Lewellen Prince of Wales; but being once forced to take the Castle of Ruthen for his refuge, he sent to Roger Hell (alias Lacy) Constable of Chester to come to his aid: And Lacy calling his Friends together, desired them to make as many men as they could, and to go with him; at whose request, Ralph Dutton his Son in Law (being a lusty youth) assembled all the Players and Musicioners in the City, with what others he could get, and went forth with the said Constable against the Welth-men, who fled upon the sight of such a great body of people; and the Earl being delivered out of danger, granted unto his said Constable divers Freedoms and Priviledges within the said City, and in other places; and withal granted to the said Ralph Dutton and his Heirs, the Rule and Ordering of all Musicioners within the said County, which by his Heirs is to this day observed and enjoyed: And in memorial of that signal Exploit, that famous meeting of Minstrils hath been duly observed at every Midsomer-fair, at which time the Lord, or Heir of Dutton, or his Steward causeth a Banner, or Pennon of his Arms to be hung out where he keepeth his Feast, and then a Drummer goeth about the Streets, to give notice to all that are, or will be concerned, to appear betwixt the hours of ten and eleven in the Forenoon. Then most of the Gentlemen of the County being mounted, all the Musicioners here, and in adjacent Counties, that will have liberty to play in this City or County, go playing before them with Trumpetters also sounding, and the Steward with a Staff in his hand, (like unto a Sheriff before the Judge) with the aforesaid Banner borne before him by one of the principal Musicioners; and after him goeth a man with the like Coat, in imitation of a Heralds Coat. Some distance backwards cometh the Lord, or Heir of Dutton, with most of the Gentry of the City, and in the midst of Eastgate-street maketh Proclamation; after which they go to St. Johns Church (the Musicioners still playing before them) which when they have entred, the Steward calls for all the loud Musick, who kneel down, and play several solemn Lessons, which done Divine Service is read; after which the Steward nobly entertaineth them, and in the Afternoon impannelleth a Jury amongst them, giveth them their charge to enquire of any Treason against the King, Prince, or Earl of Chester; likewise whether any man of that Profession hath exercised his Instrument without Licence from the Lord of that Court; also what misdemeanours
he is guilty of, or whether they have heard any Language amongst their Fellows, tending to the dishonour of their Lord and Patron, the Heir of Dutton. And after the Jury hath given up their Verdict, Licences are granted unto every one of them that are throught worthy, authorizing them to use their Musical Instruments within the said City and County Palatine, for one whole year: For without such a Licence, none are permitted to play within the limits aforesaid. The right of all which is now fallen to the Right Honourable Digby Gerrard, Baron of Gerrards-Bromley in Staffordshire, great Grandson to Eleanor, Daughter and sole Heir to Thomas Dutton of Dutton Esquire, Viscountess of Kilmurrey, who dyed the 12 th of March 1665. aged 80 years; a Lady of great worth and honour. Forest of Delamer.

Not far from this City of Chester is the famous Forest of Delamer, in which, as Camden noteth, ædelsted the renowned Mercian Lady, built a small City, which time hath long since reduced to ruin; and the place is now called by the Inhabitants, The Chamber in the Forest. Ouver.
Nigh unto this place is Ouver, which though a small place, yet hath it a Major, and enjoyeth several immunities. Nantwich.

Nantwich, scituate on the Banks of the River Wever, the greatest, and fairest built Town (next to Chester) in the Shire, having a large and good Church. It is a place well inhabited and frequented, and the rather by reason of its Salt-pits, or Salt-wich, in the making of White Salt, which is esteemed excellent, and here had in great plenty. The making of Salt. For the making the said Salt, they carry the Brine which is taken out of the Brine-pit, or Salt-spring, to the Wich-houses, within which are placed deep in the earth great Barrels, which are filled with the Salt-water, and at the ringing of the Bell, they begin to make fire under the Leads, in which they seith the said Salt-water (every house having six of the said Leads;) and as it seiths, the Wallers (which generally are women) with a wooden Rake, gather the Salt from the bottom, which they call a Salt-barrow, from which the water droppeth away, and the Salt remaineth. This Salt-spring is very remarkable for having within a few feet distance a fresh River, which affordeth excellent sweet water. The Market for this Town is kept on Saturdays, which is sufficiently provided with all provisions, and necessaries, especially Corn and Cattle. Malpas.

Malpas, seated on a great eminencie, not far from the River Dee, and on the edge of the Shire, where it bordereth on the Counties of Salop, Flint, and Denbigh. The Town is fair, conteining three Streets, which are paved and well ordered; hath an Hospital and a Grammar School, was once strengthened with a Castle; and its Market, which is kept on Mondays, is of good account. Comber-mere-Abbey.
About six miles from Malpas formerly stood Comber-mere Abbey by a Lake so called. Beeston-Castle.
About five miles Northwards from this Town, was the famous Castle of Beeston, strongly seated on a great Hill, with a turretted Wall of a large circuit. Tarvin.
Tarvin, scituate near the River Gowy, beautified with a fair Church, and hath an inconsiderable Market. Budworthmere.
Nigh unto Tarvin Northwards is Budworth, not far from the great Lake called Budworth-mere. Frodsham.

Frodsham, or Frodesham, not far from the great River of Mersey, and near unto Frodsham-hills, which for height are said to exceed all others in the County, and hath thereon a Beacon. It is a Town composed but of one long Street, at the west end thereof is seated a Castle; and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is but small.
Haulton. Haulton Court.

Not far from Frodsham is Haulton, a pretty Town with a Castle so called, on and round about a Hill; in which said Castle there is a Court kept every Monday forthight, for all matters done within its limits, between party and party; where there is a Prison for Malefactors taken in the said Jurisdiction, but are presented to Chester Assises for their Tryals. Northwich.
