Northwich, seated near the River Dane falling into the Wever, a proper good Town, of chief note for its Salt-wich, or Brine-pit; and hath a good Market for Corn and Provisions on Fridays. Middlewich.

Middlewich, so called, as standing between Nantwich and Northwich, and seated on the River Croke, near its influx into the Dane; of chief note also for its Salt-pits, and making of Salt. It is a large Town, governed by Burgesses, and conteineth several Streets and Lanes; its chief place being called the Kings Mexon, which is in the midst of the Town, where its Market is kept every Saturday, which is well served with Flesh, and other Provisions. Sandbach.

Sandbach, or Sandbich, on the Banks of the Welock, a Town of no large extent; nor its Market, which is on Thursdays, very considerable; but graced with a fair Church of Stone. And in the Market-place doth stand near together two square Crosses of Stone mounted on steps, with certain Images and Writings thereon. This Town at present may be taken notice of for its strong Ale, sold at London for 12 d. the Bottle, which for strength and clearness doth equalize Canary. Congleton.

Congleton, seated on the Dane, and not above two miles from the edge of Staffordshire; a large and noted Town, governed (as Cambden noteth) by a Major, and six Aldermen, yet hath it but a small Chappel of Ease, its Mother Church being Asturby, about two miles distant, which is a fair building. Actbury. Its Inhabitants make great store of Leather Gloves, Purses, and Points; and the Market, which is on Saturdays, is well provided with Corn, Provisions, &c. Maxfield.

Maxfield, or Macclesfield, scituate on the edge of the Forest so called, upon a high Bank, and at the foot of the River Bollin in the Parish of Prestbury. It is a very large and fair Town, graced with a goodly Church, which hath a very high spire Steeple; adjoyning to which on the South side is a Colledge built by Tho. Savage Bishop of London: The Inhabitants of this Town drive a great Trade in making of Buttons; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is well served with Corn, Provisions, &c. Knutsford.

Knutsford, of which there are two, and not far distant from each other; viz. the higher and the lower; The higher hath the Parish Church; and the lower a Parochial Chappel of Ease, with an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Altrincham.

Altrincham, in the North part of the County, governed by a Major, hath two Courts Leets yearly kept at Easter and Michaelmass, with Court Barons every moneth for the Manour of Dunham Massey; and hath a good Market on Tuesdays. Thelwall.

Not far from this Town, on the confines of this County reguarding Lancashire, is seated Thelwall, which though at present a small and obscure Village, in the dayes of King Edward the elder, was a large Town, and of good repute. Stopford.
Stopford, scituate on the River Mersey, over which it hath a Bridge, which leadeth into Lancashire; hath a very considerable Market for Corn and Provisions on Fridays.

div1.n: CORNWALL: BEING Part of the DANMONII and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: CORNWALL: BEING Part of the DANMONII, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of the county of Cornwal

div1.p: CORNWALL, of old CORNUBIA; so called from its waxing smaller and smaller, in manner of a horn, and thrusting it self forth into the Sea, with little Promontories. Its Scituation.

This Shire is seated the most Western of any County of England, and bordereth on the East with Devonshire, from which in most places it is severed by the River Tamer, which looseth it self in Plimouth Haven; Its other parts are washed by the Sea, so that it may not improperly be esteemed a Peninsula. Its Extent.

It was formerly of a far larger extent then now it is; for according to ancient Chronicles, 'tis said that Brute landed at Totnes in Cornwall, a Town now seated in the heart of Devonshire. And until the time of Athelstanes (who hemmed them within their present limits) the Cornish-men bare equal sway in Exeter with the English; like wise the encroaching Sea hath taken from it the whole Country of Lionness, with several other parcells of ground of no small extent. The Country of Lionness.

And that there was such a Country of Lionness, these proofs are yet remaining: The space between the Lands end and the Isles of Stilly, being about 30 miles, to this day reteineth that name, which in Cornish is called Lethowsow, and carrieth a continual equal depth of about 40 or 60 Fathom, except that about the midst there lyeth a Rock, which at a low water sheweth its head. That Fishermen casting in their Hooks there abouts, have drawen up pieces of Windows and Doors; like wise the ancient name of St. Michaels Mount, Cara Clowse in Cowse, that is, in English, The hoar Rock in the Wood; and at some low Ebbs, great roots of Trees are discovered in the Sands. Its present extent. The present extent of this County is, in length from Launceston in the East, to the Lands-end in the West, is about 70 miles; and its breadth, where broadest, is not above 35; and at the narrowest, and most Westwards, not above 3; but by reason of its several Promontories which it thrusteth forth into the Sea, its circum ference maketh about 150 miles.

This County and Devonshire, as lying the farthest into the Sea Westwards, makes their Ports to be very well frequented by Sea-men, as well
in their Royages out ward bound, to take their farewels of England; as at their returns home, in desiring to set footing on English ground; which doth occasion a good trade in these parts. The Air.

The Air is subtile and pure, and more apt to preserve then to recover health, especially to Strangers. The Spring is not so forward as in the more Eastern parts of this Kingdom, which doth occasion a later Harvest; they seldome housing all their Corn till Michaelmass; and although their Spring and Harvest are found thus late, their Winter is milder then in those Ealtern parts; but subject to storms, which off-times doth much anoy the Inhabitants. The soil.

It is generally very hilly, consisting ordinarily of Rocks and Shelfs, but crusted over with a shallow earth, and more inclined to sterility then fertility: but the parts towards the Sea, by reason of the industrious Husbandman in manuring the ground with sand and orewood taken from the sea shore, beareth good corn, and feedeth store of sheep and other Cattle. And the middle part (except the inclosures about some Towns and Villages) lyeth waste and open, bearing Heath and spiry Grass, and serveth chiefly to sommer Cattle. It is generally very bare of Wood and Timber Trees. The chief Hills.
The chief Hills in this County are those of Godolphin, rowtor, Hinxson, St. Agnes, Brownwelly, the four Boroughs, Haynborough, Carnbray, Roche, the two Castellan, Dennis, &c, The chief Rivers.

The several sresh streams that spring from the Hills, well water the ground; on the South part are the Foy, Newton, Dranes, Lo, Fala, Seaton, Loo, Liner, Tavy and the Tamer; and on the North the Camell, and the Halæ; and most of these Rivers have their influx into the Sea, where they afford good Creeks and Bays. Excellent Game for the Hawk and Hound.

This County hath great store of Game both for the Hawk and Hound; and its Seas and Rivers plenty of several sorts of excellent Fish and Fowl, as well those common to other Counties as appropriate to themselves.
It graizeth good store of Cattle, and their Horses, though of a low stature, are very serviceable and hardy. The Inhabitants.

The Inhabitants, or Cornish People, as to their names and language, do hold great affinity with the Welch, but more easie to be pronounced, and not so unpleasant to the ear. They are esteemed excellent Wrestlers; the Gentry are well accomplished, and the people generally are inclined to hospitality, and making merry meetings; which said Feastings are not without several Pastimes and Recreations for the exercise of the body, as wrestling, hurling, and the like. They were known to the Romans under the name of the Danmonii's, who according to Diodorus Seculus, were acourteous, yet valiant people; and after wards became part of the ancient Kingdom of the West-Saxons. Its Stones and Metalls.

In the bowels of the earth lye hid Quarries of sundry sorts of useful stones and sllates for buildings; also copper, precious stones, called Cornish Diamonds, and some silver; but chiefly Tynn, which carrieth the Bell from all others, which is here found in great plenty, to the much enrichment of the Inhabitants by the sale there of to most places of Christendom, or rather to the known traded World. See Carew his Description of Cornwall. fol. 10.

As concerning the working and coynage of the Tynn, as also of the laws & customs observed by the Tynners, I shall borrow from Mr. Carew his Survey of Cornwall, where he treateth there of at large; a brief Accompt whereof here followeth. The finding of the Tynnworks.

These Mines or Tynn-works are found out by certain Tynn-stones, lying on the surface of the earth, or but shallowly covered, which they call shoad, as fallen from the main Load. The colour both of the shoad
and Load resembleth his Bed, as the Sea sand doth the Cliffs, and is so diversified to blackish, duskie, reddish, and such other earthy colours.

If the Load where the Tynn lyeth, carrieth a foot and a half in breadth, and be not over-barren, it is accounted a very rich work; but except many Loads run together, it seldom exceedeth a foot. The Overseers office.

If the work is large, and there fore requireth many hands, they have an Overseer, which they call their Captain, whose office is to alot each Workman his Task, and to see them perform the same: Also to look after the preservation of the said Work, placing Pumps for the drawing out of the water, and the like.
The labour being so hard, the Workmen seldom work above four or five hours at a time.

In the working in these Load-mines, the loose earth oft-times falleth down to the loss of a mans life; like wise the unfavory damps are very prejudicial unto them. Tynn passeth through many persons hands.

Before the Tynn is brought to perfection, it passeth through divers hands; for after it is dugg up, and brought above ground in the Stone, it is broken in pieces, then it is carried to the Stamping-Mill to be broke smaller; and if the stones are over-moist, they are dryed by the fire in an iron Grate, or Cradle. From the Stamping-Mill it passeth to the Crazing-Mill, which bruiseth it to fine sand: but in stead of the Crazing-Mill, they now oft-times use wet Stampers; then they wash the earth from the Tynn. This done, every Owner carrieth his proportion to the Blowing-house, where the same is melted, and cast into pieces of 3 or 400 pound weight, and the Owners mark set thereon; and the last business to be done, is the conveying it to the place of coynage. Towns for coynage, and the times.
The Towns especially priviledged for the Coynage of Tynn, are Truro, Helston, Listwithiel, and Liskerd; and the times of Coynage are twice in the year; viz. about Midsomer and Michaelmass. Officers.

The Officers deputed for the management of coynage, are Porters to bear the Tynn, Peizers to weigh it, also a Warden, Steward, Comptroller, and a Receiver to keep the Accounts. The measures for the Tynn.
The black Tynn is measured by the Gill, the Topliss, the Dish, and the Foot, and conteineth a Pint, a Pottle, a Gallon, and towards two Gallons. The Tynners immunities.

The Tinners by their Charter have great Priviledges and Immunities granted them; as keeping of Courts called Stannery Courts, where all Controversies, where in either Plaintiff or Defendant dealeth in black or white Tynn, are decided, and not in any other Court, either to sue, or be sued.

The chief Officer is called the Warden of the Stannery, who supplyeth the place both of Judge for the Law, and a Chancellor for Equity. The Goal for the Stannery causes is kept at Lothwithiel, once every three weeks. See Carews Description of Cornwall, page 77.

Cornwall, as an entire Estate, hath at divers times enjoyed sundry Titles, of a Kingdom, Principality, Dutchy, and Earldom, as Mr. Carew in his Description of this County, pag. 77. doth at large treat of. And the eldest son of the King, whether by birth, or death of his elder Brother, without creation, is Duke of Cornwall Religious Houses.

Here were in former times dispersed in this County several Religious Houses, as Priories at St. Germains, Bodman, and Tywardreth. Nunneries at St. Martyn. Fryeries at Launston, Truro, and Bodman. Hospitals. Colledges at Peryn, Burien, and Crantock. And Hospitals at Heston.
And in the time of Paganism, here was said to be built a Temple by one Cunedeg, and dedicated to Apollo. Castles, and Forts.
In this County were several ancient Castles and Forts, most of which are now reduced to ruin, being said to be raised by the Danes. Towns Corporate.

Here are several Borough and Towns Corporate, as St. Austle, Bodman, Bossiny, Camelford, Foy, St. Germains, Grampond, Helston, St. Ives, Kellington, Launceston, Liskerd, Listwithiel, East Low, West Low, St. Mawes, Newport, Penryn, Saltash, Tregony, and Truro. Its Division.

This County is severed into nine Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp; which said Hundreds are divided into four divisions of the Justices of the Peace, and the usual and convenientest places of assembly for the East division is Liskerd; for the South, Columbe; for the West, Helston; and for the North division, Camelford; And for the general assembly for the whole County, Bodman. number of Parishes.

In these nine Hundreds, there are numbred 161 Parish Churches, and for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, hath entercourse of traffick with twenty three Market Towns, of which in order. Its chief places. Launston.

Launston, or Launceston, anciently tearmed Lanstaphadon, by interpre. tation St. Stephens Church, seated on a branch of the Tamer, and on the pitch of a pretty Hill, which of two Boroughs, Downevet and Newport is grown (as it were) into one Borough, by the joyning of the Parishes of St. Thomas to St. Stephen. It is a large Town Corporate, where the Assises are held, is a Town of good Trade, well inhabited; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well frequented and served with provisions. The Government is committed to the care of a Major, and his Brethren: and amongst other immunities, it sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. Near adjoyning to this Town is an ancient Castle, seated on a great eminency, and environed at the top with a treble Wall, where there was a Colledge of Chanons, and secular Priests; The lower part now compriseth a decayed Chappel, a large Hall, and a place made use of for the common Goal. A little without the Town standeth the old Priory. And although Newport is thus fallen to decay, yet ceaseth it not to send Burgesses to Parliament. Liskerd.

Liskerd, scituate in a level, a Town Corporate, and governed by a Major, eight Magistrates, a Recorder, with other Sub-Officers; hath an eminent Free-School, the ruins of an ancient Castle, which once was of great note, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and is a large, well inhabited and frequented Town, whose Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with corn and all provisions; and the Inhabitants drive a very great trade for Yarn every Market-day, which they vend to Exeter, and other parts, to their great profit. Bodman.

Bodman, seated betwixt two high Hills in a Bottom, which rendreth it very unhealthful to the Inhabitants, especially to new commers. It chiesly consisteth of one long street; and the many decayed houses witness it to have been once very populous, large, and of a good account. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major and his Brethren, electeth Parliament men, and was once one of the priviledged Towns for the coynage of the Tynn; and here the Bishop of Cornwall held his See, until the Danish Pirates (who fired the Pallace) forced them to remove to St. Germains; and upon the removal thereof, here was a Priory and a Fryory. The Town at present is large, well built and inhabited, and hath a very considerable Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Pieces of Antiquity.

In the Parish of St. Cleere, not far from Liskerd, is a piece of Antiquity
called Half-stone, being two stones which seemeth to have been broken or cut asunder, which are, or were curiously hewed and wrought, with an inscription of strange characters upon them. And not far distant from these stones in an open Plain, are certain other stones somewhat squared, and fixed to the ground, being placed upright in a due distance; and these stones bear the name of the Hurlers: And almost adjoyning to these stones, is a heap of Rocks called the Cheese-wring, as formed like a cheese. Listhyel, of old Uzella.

Listhyel, or Listwithiel, the ancient Uzella of Ptolomy, which stood in former time upon a high Hill, where the old Castle Lestormel sheweth its ruins. This Town is seated on the River Foy, not far from its fall into Foy haven, which formerly brought up Vessels to the very Town, but its channel being now choaked up (by reason of the Tynn-mines) is a great obstruction to its Trade, yet as a Town Corporate (though but mean to what it was) 'tis governed by a Major and his Brethren, and electeth Parliament men. It hath its part in the coynage of the Tynn; but the Goal for the whole Stannery, and the keeping of the Courts is only here kept. It hath likewise the conveniency of a Market on Fridays, which is but small. Castle of Lestormel.

Nigh unto this Town, now standeth the ruins of that once large, strong, pleasant and stately Castle of Lestormel (under whose subjection this Town formerly was) being the seat of the Dukes of Cornwall. Foy.

Foy, so called from its Haven, or Arm of the Sea on which it is seated, being strongly fortified, fenced, and guarded at the entrance of the Haven with Block-houses; and in former times was a place very considerable for shipping and traffick, being said to have had belonging to its Port at one time, sixty sail of ships, and was renowned sor Sea-fights. Its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very good for corn and provisions.
A little before Foy the land openeth with a large and sandy Bay, which receiveth the over-flowings of the Sea, which with the Village adjoyning is called Trawardreth. West Looe.

West Looe, scituate betwixt Hills, and on a navigable Creek, near the south Sea, over which it hath a fair Bridge, susteined by many Arches, which leadeth to East Looe, more commodiously seated, but not of so much antiquity; where there is an indifferent good Market on Saturdays. East LooeThey are both Towns Corporate, and send Burgesses to Parliament; and the chief benefit arising to the Inhabitants of these Towns is their fishing. The Town towards the Sea, for its further security, is fenced with a garretted wall. St. George's Isle. Almost opposite to the Barred Haven of Looe is St. George's Isle, of a very small circuit, where in the season of the year, a very great abundance of Sea Fowl, or Sea Pyes, breed upon the Stroud, where they lay and hatch their Eggs without the trouble of building of Nests. Saltash.

Saltash, seated on the descent of a steep Hill, consisting of three streets, which are clean washed from filth by every showre of rain. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major, and nine Aldermen; enjoyeth large immunities, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. 'Twas formerly a large and well frequented Market Town, whose Market is on Saturdays, but of late much decayed to what it was; yet its Inhabitants gain well by trasfick, but principally by Mault, and good Beer. Trematon Court.

Not far from Saltash in the Parish of St. Stephens is Trematon Casile, once a place of great note, in which is kept the Trematon Court, wherein all sorts of causes within the said Fee are tryed, as also the Prison. St. Germains.

St. Germains, once the largest Town in the County, being the See of a Bishop, and a place well frequented and inhabited, and the rather by reason of
its Fishing Trade. It is at present a small Borough Town, having the election of Parliament men, and a Market on Fridayes, not very considerable. Here was in former time a Cathedral, once a stately Fabrick with two Towers; now made use of for their Church and adjoyning to the said Cathedral is a Priory, at present kept in good repair. Stratton.

Stratton, scituate in a good soil, betwixt two Rivulets which here unite themselves, and at a small distance fall into the Sea at Beeds Haven. It hath a Market on Tuesdays, which is well served with corn and provistions. And the Inhabitants reap a good profit from their Gardens and Orchards, and that chiesly for their Garlick. Camelford.
Camelford, seated on the River Camel, a Town Corporate, governed by a Major, and other Sub-officers; sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and its Market, which is on Fridayes, is but indifferent.

Upon the River Camel, not far from Camelford, was fought a sore conflict between King Arthur and his treacherous Nephew Mordred, wherein the one received his death, and the other his mortal wound. TintagilCastle.

Not far from Camelford on the North shore, is seated Tintagil Castle; more famous for its antiquity, then note-worthy for its present Estate; yet its ruins shew it to have been once a place of good repute. See Carew's Deseription of Cornwall, page 121. Half the Buildings were raised on the Continent, and the other half on an Isle, which formerly were joyned together by a Bridge; but now severed by the overthrow of the steep Clifts on the farther side, which though it shut out the Sea from his wonted recourse, hath added much strength to the Isle. On the top of the Hill (which now serveth to feed Sheep and Coneys) was anciently a Chappel, and a Hermits cave: The farthest point of this Hill is called Black-head, and is a place not unknown to Seamen. In this Castle (as 'tis reported) the noble Arthur was begotten by the renowned Uter Pendragon: and under the Isle runneth a Cave, through which at full Sea, a Boat may be rowed, but not without some horror and amazement to the Passenger. Padstow.

Padstow, a Haven Town on the North coast of this County, hath the election of Parliament men: Its Market is on Saturdays, which is well served with corn and provisions, and is a place of some Trade; and the rather for its commodious scituation with Ireland, from which it is distant not above 24 hours sail, which makes it to be better inhabited then otherwise it would be, its great obstruction being its unsafe Haven. Wade-bridge.
Farther within the Land is Wade-bridge, being the fairest and strongest Stone-bridge in the County, susteined by about twenty Arches. St. Colombe.

St. Colombe, seated on the top of a Hill, on the bottom of which is a River, which at a small distance falleth into the Sea. It hath a very good Market for corn and provisions on Thursdays. At this Town the Justices of the Peace for the South division ordinarily meet. Michell.
Nigh unto St. Columbe is Michell a mean Borough Town, which hath the election of Parliament men. Grampond.

Grampond, on the River Valle, amean Town Corporate, but of great antiquity, sending Burgesses to Parliament; and hath a Market on Saturdays. The Inhabitants here drive a considerable Trade for Gloves here made, for which it is of good note. Tregnye.

Tregnye, seated on a Creek of Falmouth Haven, a place much decayed, yet as a Town Corporate, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. It hath a Market on Saturdays; and was formerly strengthened with a Castle, which is now decayed.
Roseland.
Roseland, a certain circuit of fertile ground, which conteineth several Parishes; feedeth great flocks of Sheep; and here is Falmouth Haven. Falmouth Haven.

Falmouth Haven, very commodious for Ships, and so large that 100 sail of Ships may safely ride at Anchor. At the entrance of the said Harbour lyeth a craggy Rock, which the Inhabitants call Crage, but is no wayes disadvantageous to shipping; For at low water it sheweth it self, and at Flood it is known by a Pole affixed thereon. And if Falmouth Haven be compared with that of Plimouth, it is observed that the Creeks of Falmouth are coasted with steep Shoars, whereas Plymouth is with plain, which rendreth it more delightful for prospect; and Falmouth the more safe for ships to ride in. Falmouth lyeth more in the way of Trade to wind-driven ships than Plymouth; but Plymouth hath a more commodious out-let from its Catwater, for Saylers bound to the Westwards, and from Hamoase, for those that would sail to the East, then Falmouth. And this Haven with those of Plymouth and Milford (which deserve the first place) are the chiefest in the Kingdom. Falmouth Town.

The Town of Falmouth is now very large, to what it was formerly, (for about fifty years since, there was not above two or three Houses,) and doth now much encrease in its Buildings. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major and Sub-officers; is a place of good Trade, is well resorted unto by shipping, where there is a Key intended shortly to be built. And hath a Market on Thursdays, which is very considerable for corn and provisions. Pendennis-hill. St. Moze.

On the West-side, and at the very entrance of this Haven, there riseth a Hill called Pendennis, on which there was a Castle erected by order of King Henry the Eighth, for the better security of the Coast, being a place of good strength, as is St. Moze, or Maudit, on the other side of the Haven, but of a lower scituation. Truro.

Truro, the present head Town in the County, seated on a Branch of Falmouth Haven, which here divideth it self into two streams, and almost encircleth its streets. It is a fair, large, well inhabited, frequented, and traded Borough Town, priviledged with a Majoralty, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; hath the benefit of coynage of the Tynn, is the place where the Western Sessions are held; And its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well provided with all Provisions. Penrin.

Penrin, a very considerable Town, scituated also on a Creek of Falmouth Haven Westwards, a Town Corporate, which hath the election of Parliament men. Here are kept weekly three Markets, viz. on Wednesdayes and Fridays, being for corn, and on Saturdayes for Provisions. Helston. In the Lowe are excellent fish taken.

Helston, on the large (though not long) River Lowe; between which and the Sea, there is a great breach or bar of Sand. It is a well seated, inhabited, and frequented Town Corporate, governed by a Major and Aldermen, electing Parliament men; And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with provisions; and the two Saturdays before Christmass, are very great Markets, which may be reckoned as Fairs. Godolphin-bill.
Not far from this Town is Godolphin-hill, sufficiently known for its good Tynn Mines. Market Jew.

Market Jew, scituate on a Bay or arm of the Sea, called Monts Bay, very dangerous for shipping. The Town is but mean, and hath a small Market on Thursdays.
St. Michaels Mount.

Not far distance from this Town is St. Michaels Mount; called the Hoar-rock in the Wood, severed from the main Land, by a sandy Plain, of a slight shot in breadth, which at Ebb-water may be passed over on foot. This Mount proudly raiseth its self to a great eminence; at the entrance of which, is an open Plain of some largeness, which ending where the Hill beginneth, brings you to a winding and craggy Path, which leadeth to the top, which is a small Plain; the greatest part of which was taken up by an old Fort. It containeth lodgings for the Captain and the Souldiers: and hath a Chappel for Devotion. A little without the Castle, in a craggy place, is a seat called St. Michaels-chair. Monts-bay. Under this Mount extendeth a Bay, called Monts-bay, being an indifferent good Road for small Vessels to ride at Anchor in. Main-Amber Rock. Nigh unto which is a strong Rock, called Main Amber, which lyeth as it were mounted on others of a smaller size, with so equal a counterpoise, that it may be stirred, but not moved out of its place. Penzance.

Penzance, seated on Monts-bay, and an inlet thereof, a very good traded Town; and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is very considerable, and well served with all provisions, especially Fish in great plenty. This Town suffered much by the Spaniards at their landing in these parts, in Anno 1595, who almost quite destroyed it by sire, with some other places near adjoyning. St. Ives.

St. Ives, or St. Ithes, so called from one Ila an Irish woman, who here lived a religious life. It is a Town Corporate, Governed by a Major, Justice, and twelve Aldermen, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. Its scituation is on a Bay so called, which lying open, and not being able to shelter it self from the impetuous Waves, which the North Sea powreth in upon it, makes it to be not much frequented, except by Fisher-men, for the taking of Pilchards, and other Fish, which are here taken in great plenty; yet hath it two Markets weekly, on Wednesdays and Saturdays. Fenlet-pcint.

Having thus given you a brief account of its chief places within Land, my next business shall be to set down those of most note on its Sea-coasts, beginning on the South-shoar towards Plymouth in the East, and then the first place that offereth it self to view is Penlet- point. Causam-bay. Then Causam-bay, an open and safe Road, much frequented by Fishermen, during the season for the taking of Pilchards. St. Nicholas Isle.
In the mouth of the Harbour lyeth St. Nicholas Isle, which although very small, yet is exceeding strongly fortified, and is subject to the Commander of Plymouth Fort, near adjoyning. Ram-head.
Ram-head, a Promontory so called, on the top of which is a little vaulted Chappel, which serveth for a Sea-mark. Sythes-bay, with other Maritime places.

Sythes-Bay. St. Michaels Isle. Talland-point. Black-bittle-point. Foy-haven already treated of. Trewardeth-bay. Guin-Rock. Dudman a well known Fore-land to Sea-men. Gumdrath-bay. Cary-bay. Falmouth-haven already treated of. Helford-haven
Helford-haven, which would be esteemed good, were it not for its vicinity to Falmouth. Nass-point. Lezard-point.

The Nass-point, where the Land thrusteth it self forth into a Promontory; at the South-west point thereof is the Lezard, a place sufficiently known to Sea-men; and along the Shoar, it beareth the name of Goon-hilly Downs.
Pendannor point.

Fetching a compass more Westwards, these places present themselves to view. St. Michaels Mount. Pendannor-point, St. Michaels Mount and Bay already taken notice of; near unto which is St. Clements Isle, a very small place, not far from the Shoar. Lands-end. Then Lamorny point, next the Lands-end, which is the most Western part of this County and Kingdome, a place sufficiently known to Seamen. Also Whitland-Bay, and the Isles of Breland, Carragloufe, and Gull-rock, all three very small, especially the two last, which are seated near the Shoar. St. Ives Bay. Gudreny Isle. Beeds-haven.

Then going Northwards, the first place of note is St. Ives Bay, already treated of: Near unto which is a small Island, called Gudreny Isle. Next we come to Padstow-haven, and then to Beeds-haven, where the Coast of this County endeth.

div1.n: CUMBERLAND: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div1.head: CUMBERLAND: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers.

figure.head: A General Mapp of the Countie of Cumberland

div1.p: CUMBERLAND, a County far engaged Northwards; hath an Air of a sharp temperature, and were it not for those high Hills, which break off the Northern and Western Storms, it would be more penitrating. Its fertility. It is very mountainous, and therefore inclined to sterility; nevertheless it is not without many fertile Valleys, which bear good cropps of corn; and interlaced with rich Meadows: On its Mountains are fed great flocks of Sheep, and other Cattle. Its Metalls. In the bowels of the earth are rich Mines of Copper in great plenty; also those of Brass, Black-lead, Coal, and some of silver, from which said Metals the Inhabitants reap good profit; and the Sea and large Meers do plentifully furnish them with excellent wild Fowl and Fish; and from the Muskle they take Pearl, which they sell to the Lapidaries. Its Manufactures.
And besides these commodities, this County produceth several Manufactures; amongst which heretofore Fustians, and now Linnen-cloth, and course Broad-cloths in great plenty. Its Form and extent.

The form of this County may not unaptly be resembled to a Crescent, whose two points or ends, are South and North, and from the extremity of the one, to wit, Millum Castle in the South, to that of Hamiford in the North, is about 55 miles; and its breadth from Kelloplaw-hill in the East, to the Irish Sea in the West, about 40; which makes its circumference to be about 168 miles. Its bounds.

Its bounds are on the East, Northumberland and Durham; on the South, Westmoreland and Lancashire; on the West, the Irish Sea, where it resembleth a Bow bent; and on its North part of Scotland, with some part of Northumberland. Its Mountains

The Mountains of most note, are Black-coum, a high Mountain in Millum, which may be seen from Talkhill in Staffordshire. Hardknot, a high and steep Mountain, in the top whereof were discovered huge stones and foundations of a Castle, not without great wonder, considering that it is so steep and upright, that it is hardly to be ascended. Wrey-nose, a great Fell, on the top whereof (by the High-way side) are placed three stones, called the Shire-stones, each of which doth stand, within a foot of another, in a
several County, viz. in Lancashire, this County, and westmoreland. Skiddow, a great Mountain, which riseth up to such a height, with two heads like unto Parnassus, and with a kind of emulation beholdeth Scruffel in Anandale within Scotland, that from these two Mountains, according as the misty Clouds arise, or fall, the people thereabouts inhabiting make their Prognostication of the change of Weather, and commonly sing this note: If Skiddow hath a Cap, Scruffel wots full well of that. Cross-fell, a very high Mountain, on which Snow is often seen after Midsomer; and from this Hill runs a ridge of Fells to Poltross, and so to Lamiford, the most Northern part of this County. Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, amongst which, Dudden which divides this County from Lancashire; Eske, Irt, Myte, which three last fall into the Sea at Raven-glass; Calder, End, Egre, Greata, Derwent, which emptieth it self into the Sea at Workington; Coker, which joyneth with the Derwent at Cockermouth; Elne, Waver, Wampool, Eden the greatest River in the County; Canda and Patteril, which two joyn with Eden at Carlisle; Sarke, which divides England from Scotland; Eske, Leven, Irthing, and others, which empty themselves into the Sea, either alone, or conjoyned with others. Lakes and Meres.

Here are several Lakes and Meres; of which those of most note are Denocke-water, Eskdale-water, Wasdale-water, Lows-water, Withburne-water, Derwent-water, Basingthwaite-water, and Buttermere-water. Ancient Inhabitants.
The ancient Inhabitants known to Ptolomy were the Brigantes; and after the Saxons gained the power, it became part of the Kingdom of the Northumbers. The Picts wall.

This Shire, of all others in England, sheweth the most Roman Antiquities; for being in the confines, or utmost limits of their possessions, it was alwayes secured by their Garisons, and defended with that admirable Wall, called the Picts-wall, first built by Hadrian the Emperour with Turffs and Stakes, and afterwards much strengthened, and raised from Sea to Sea by Severus the Emperour; and lastly in the declension of the Roman Empire for their further security, against the incursions of the raging Picts, it was made of stone 8 foot broad, and 12 high, extending it self about 100 miles, runing through vast Mountains, and over-steep crags and high Hills; and on which, at the end of every mile were built Towers, or Watch-houses, where Sentinels alwayes stood: and some of this wall in many places is yet standing not only in this Shire, but also in Northumberland, through which it ran. But before this wall, Julius Agricola made one, which he fortified with Holes and Garisons in that narrow space of ground that lyeth between Eden, Borough-Fryth, and Dunbretton-Fryth, which afterwards was often strengthened, and at last became as aforesaid. Its Castles. And this County being thus continually frequented with their Legions and Souldiers in the time of peace, or after Victories gained, they erected many Monuments and Altars, with Inscriptions to their Idol Gods, to declare to posterity their noble Atchievements: many of which in whole, or in part, are to be seen at this day. And the County being thus in the confines of Scotland, made it to be exceedingly strengthened with Castles; for besides its publick ones, which are said to be about 25, the houses of the Nobility and Gentry are generally built Castle-wise, and so called; but of late they built their houses of a newer form. Religious Houses.

The places here consecrated to Religious uses were chiesly those at Carlisle, Leonard-coast, Wetherall, Holme, Daker, Monkshall, St. Bees, Calder, Seaton, and Armethwaite.
Its Ecclesiastical and Temporal division.

This County, according to its Ecclesiastical Government, is divided into the Diocesses of Chester and Carlisle; the South part thereof called Copeland, (viz. between the Rivers Dudden, and Darwent) is within the Arch- Deaconry of Richmond in Chester Diocess: and all the rest of the County is within the Diocess of Carlisle. It is also divided into several Deaneries, which are again subdivided into many Parishes. And according to its Temporal Government it is severed into five Wards, there being no Hun- dreds in this County, as also Durham, Northumberland and Westmoreland, as being freed from all charges of Subsidies, until the reign of K. James, by reason of the great charges in border service. The names of the said Wards are Cumberland-ward, Aller dale-ward above Derwent, Allerdale-ward below Derwent, Leth-ward, and Eskdale-ward; and in these Wards are several Constablewicks, in all which are numbred 58 Parish churches, besides divers chappels of Ease, many of which are as large as Parishes, and hath intercourse of Traffick with 15 Market Towns; of which said number 5 or 6 are of no long continuance. Cumberland-Ward.
Places of chief note in this Ward, are Carlile.

Carlile, or Carlisle, a City of great antiquity, being in the time of the Romans in a very florishing condition; and upon their departure, it suffered much by the Scots and Picts; but in the dayes of Egfrid King of Northumberland it was walled about; then was it again defaced by the Danes, and lay dejected for the space of about 200 years, till at the length William Rufus began to look upon it, and built here a Castle, and setled a Colony of Flemings to secure this Coast: After him, Henry the First his Brother. and Successor, placed here an Episcopal See; and thus by degrees it began to regain some of its pristine glory, and is now dignified with an Earldom, which at present is in the person of the Right Honourable Charles Howard Earl of Carlisle, Lord Lieutenant of the said City and Counties of Cumberland and Westmoreland, &c. It is a City no less pleasantly then commodiously seated at the influx or meeting of several Rivers, which doth encompass it, except towards the South; for on the East it hath the River Peterill, on the West Caud, and on the North the channel Eden, which receiveth the others, and after a small course dischargeth it self into the Sea. And besides these natural fences for its further strengh and security (as lying near to Scotland) it is fortified with a strong and large Castle, scituate on the West side of the City, which K. Richard the Third repaired, where the present Governour, Sir Philip Musgrave Bar. resideth, and with a strong Cittadel, together with divers Bulwarks on the East-side built by K. Henry the Eighth, which are now gone much to decay: And to add to its further strength, it is begirt with strong walls built of squared stones. This City is fair, its houses well built, and beautisied with a cathedral Church, seated almost in the midst, which exalteth it self to a good height, and adds a great splendor to it, being a structure of curious Workmanship, especially the uppermost and newest part the other being much defaced by the Parliament, Forces, for the building up of Guard-houses for the Souldiers in Garison. Its temporal Government is committed to the care of a Major, 12 Aldermen, 2 Bailiffs, and other Sub officers; amongst its immunities which it enjoyeth, it sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; is a place of a good trade, chiefly for Fustians, is well inhabited; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very considerable for corn, wool, with several other commodities, and provisions in great plenty. This City (and generally the whole County) was very loyal to their Soveraign in the late wars, chearfully enduring a long and sore Siege, and when they yielded it was upon honourable tearms.
Eurgh.

Not far from carlisle Westward, at Burgh upon the Sand (where there was a station of the Romans) within the very Fryth, where the salt water ebbeth and floweth, the English and Scots (as 'tis reported) fought at full Sea with their Fleets, and at the Ebb, with their Horse and Foot, which proved a bloody Conflict; where King Edward the First lost his life. Wigton.
Wigton, seated amongst the Moors, a small Town, and of very little account, having an inconsiderable Market on Tuesdays. Wetherall.

Wetherall, or Wedderell, where there was a little Abbey or cell, first founded at the instance of Stephen first Abbot of St. Maries at York, Anno 1086. by the Earl Randall Meschiens, who gave this Manour, and other Lands thereunto. And after the dissolution of Abbeys, this Priory was given by King Henry the Eighth to the Dean and Chapter of Carlisle, newly erected by him. Boulness.

More reguarding the Sea, and on the other side of the Picts-wall is Boulness, now a small Village, but raised out of the ruins of the ancient Town Blatum, or Blatum-Bulgium of the Romans, which by the tracts of streets and ruinous walls, do declare it to have been once of good account. Allerdale-Ward above Derwent. Cockermouth.

Cockermouth, seated somewhat low, between the Rivers Derwent and Cocker, which almost encompass it, over which are two good stone Bridges: The Town is seated on two Hills, upon one of which standeth the Church, a fair building; and upon the other a large, strong, and stately Castle, which formerly belonged to the Earl of Northumberland. It is a Borough Town, hath the election of Parliament men: Is dignifyed with an honour, called the Honour of Cockermouth; and every Christmass Quarter the Sessions are here holden. It is an indifferent long Town, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a good trade, especially for course Broad cloaths here made; is graced with fair buildings; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is esteemed the best in the County for corn, next unto Perith. And here is a custom at their Fairs holden at Whitsontide and Martlemass, for the hiring of servants, to which end all such as want servants, or services, do hither come; the like custom is observed at Perith, and most of the Market Towns in the County. White-haven.

White-haven, seated on a Creek of the Sea, at the North end of a great Bergh or rising Hill, which is washed with the flood on the West-side, where is a great Rock, or Quarrey of hard white Stone, which gives name hereunto; and which with the help of a great Wall of stone secures the harbour, which is made by a little River which falls into the Sea, where small Barks may enter, and be defended from the Tempest, and Winds, and where they may conveniently lade and unlade their commodities. It is of late become a Market Town, which is kept on Thursdays, being much improved in its buildings, and is well frequented, and inhabited by Tradesmen, especially by Fishermen, and those that are related to Sea-affairs, who drive a good trade to Ireland, Scotland, Chester, Bristoll, and other parts; having several Vessels belonging to the Town, whose chief trade is for Salt and Coals here plentifully digged up, which they export to the parts aforesaid, and in exchange bring several good commodities, having here a Custom-house. Egremont.

Egremont, seated not far from the Sea, and on the Banks of a River, over which it hath two Bridges; It is a Borough Town, but hath lost the
priviledge of sending Burgesses to Parliament; It hath a good Market on Saturdays. Upon a sharp-copped Hill, William Meschians built a Castle, and therein seated himself, which gave name to this Town. And after the King had given him the Barony of Copeland, and that he had built this Castle, he changed the name into the Barony of Egremont. Ravenglass.

Ravenglass, a Maritime Town, couched betwixt the Rivers Irt, Esk, and Mite, which with the Sea doth encompass three parts of it, and is a good road for shipping, which makes it to be of some trade, having several Barks and small Vessels belonging to it. Some will have this Town called in old time Avenglass, as one would say, the Blew River: and the Inhabitants talk much of King Eveling, that here had his Court and Royal Palace. It is a well built Town, and hath a Market every Saturday. Bootle.
Bootle, or Bowtell, seated near the Sea, not far from Lancashire, in the Barony of Millum, and on the side of a Hill; a small Town, and hath a very inconsiderable Market on Wednesday. Irton.

Irton, seated on the River Irt, where in the Muscles, after they have (with a great kind of yawning or gaping) sucked in the dew, which they lust after to conceive by, bring forth Pearls, which the Country people get, and sell at easie rates to the Lapidaries. Calder-Abbey.

Calder Abbey, so named from the River Calder on which it is seated, now reduced to ruins; first founded about the year 1134, in the reign of Henry the first, and was augmented by the charity of several persons, amongst the rest by Sir John le Fleming Kt. who lyeth there interr'd, whose Tomb in part is yet to be seen, being almost eaten up by the devouring teeth of time. An ancient Fort near Beckermett.

In the Manour of Beckermett there is a Mount, or Hill, whereon there is yet to be seen the ruins of a notable Fort or Castle, of an oblong square, the dimensions whereof (though now much less then what they were at first, by reason of the shrinking and falling of the earth, and being altered by plowing) are yet as followeth; viz. the length of the Castle within the Ditch, is about 100 yards, and the breadth near 90; on either side of the Ditch, there is yet visible a great bank of earth, and the Ditch at the top is about 12 yards broad, and the depth about 4; the main entrance into this Fort, was at the Eastend, with another at the West end, opposite to which, and near adjoyning, there is a little round Hill (now called Cony-garth) of about 12 yards in height, and 6 in breadth at the top, which was made use of as a Watch-tower, as having a fair prospect over all the adjacent Country and Sea. This Fort by the Country people is called Caernarven-castle, and supposed to be a Fort of the Britains. Caernarvan-Castle. This Manour, ever since the Conquest, hath belonged (and still it doth) to the family of the Flemings, the present owner being my worthy and honoured Friend, Daniel Fleming of Ridale in Westmoreland, Esquire. St. Bees.

St. Bees, anciently a Parish Church erected, and dedicated to the honour of an Irish woman, named by some Writers Begoth, who led sometimes there a solitary life, and unto whose holiness are ascribed certain vain Miracles; as the taming a wild Bull, and the procuring a mighty deep Snow in Summer; whereupon the Town was first called Kirby-Begoth, which with the Church and Rectory, were given to the Abbey of St. Maries at York, by William de Meschiens then Lord of Egremont Barony, and made by him a cell of York Abbey. Moresby.

Moresby, or Mauriceby, formerly a good road for ships, which might be made so again with charge. This was (probably) a Roman Fort, there having been found many Roman Antiquities, Vaults, and Caves, which the Country people tearm Picts-holes. Workington.

Workington, seated on the South-side of the River Derwent, near its influx
into the Sea, over which said River there is a fair Stone-bridge, called Workington-bridge. It hath a very good Haven for Ships; and here is very good fishing for Salmons, of a considerable yearly value. Allerdale-Ward below Derwent. Keswick.

Keswick, scituate in a Valley hemmed in with Hills, and the Mountains called Derwent Fells, (wherein, at Newlands, and elsewhere, are good Copper-mines) and not far from this Town is dug up Black-lead or Wadd, in great plenty. In Derwen-water, which is a great Lake, are three small Isles, viz. Vickers, St. Herbots, and Ramshome, where the Lord of the Isle hath a fair House: And in one of these Isles, 'tis said that St. Herbert lived an Hermetical life. This Town was well known many years ago, by reason of the said Mines of Copper, and much inhabited by Mineral men, where they had their Smelting-houses, near the side of the river Greta, which with its forceable stream, and their ingenious inventions, served them in notable stead for easie Bellow-works, Hammer-works, Forge-works, and Sawing of boards, to the admiration of the beholder. And though these Smelting-houses were within the memory of man so numerous, that they resembled a little Town, yet now there is not one house standing, which hath occasioned it to be much poorer then formerly it was, and less inhabited and frequented, now conteining but one long street. It hath a Market on Saturdays chiefly for Meal and Flesh. Ireby.

Ireby, seated in a Valley, and at the Spring-head of the River Elne, or Ellan, where, according to some Authors, in old time the Baccary Tigrienses kept their standing guard; and the many Roman Statues, Altars, and Inscriptions that are here oft dug up, do sufficiently shew its antiquity. It is at present a good Town, conteining the higher and the lower, and hath the accommodation of an indifferent Market for corn and provisions on Thursdays. Abbey Holm, or Holme Cultrum

Abbey Holme, or Holme Cultrum, so called from an Abbey built here by David the first King of Scots, and called Abbey de Ulmo, and Holme Cultrum. It is a small Town, seated on the arm of the Sea, and hath a very mean Market on Saturdays. Blennerhasset.
Blennerhasset, seated in a Valley, and not far from the River Elne, a small Town, and hath a mean Market newly erected on Saturdays. Wulstey Castle, or Ulstey.

Wulstey Castle, or Ulstey, heretofore a Fortress, build by the Abbots of Holme- Cultrum, near unto that Abbey for a Treasury, and place of surety to lay up their Books, Charters, and Evidences, against the sudden Invasions of the Scots, wherein (as 'tis said) the secret works of Michael Scot lye in conflict with mothes; which said Michael professing here a Religious life, was so wholly possessed with the study of the Mathematicks, and other obstruse Arts, that the common people took him for a Necromancer, and believed him to work Miracles. Leeth-Ward. Perith.

Perith, or Penrith, which in the British Language signifies the Red-head or Hill, the soil, and stones there being of a reddish colour. It is seated under a Hill called Perith Fell, and near the Rivers Eimont and Lowther; Eimont on the South-side, which divides the County from Westmoreland; and Lowther on the West-side, where near Lowther-bridge is to be seen that round trench of Earth, called Arthurs round table. It was once strengthened with a Castle, which before its demolishment, was repaired
in the Reign of Henry the Sixth, out of the ruins of a Roman Fort, called Maburgh in Westmoreland, near adjoyning. The Town at present is large, well built, and inhabited by Trades-men, especially by Tanners, and accounted the second in this County, although neigher a Borough nor Town Corporate, yet it is made use of for the keeping the Sessions for the County. It is adorned with a fair Church, and a large Market-place, which on every Tuesday is very much resorted unto, and served with Corn, living Cattle, several Commodities, and all sorts of Provision, especially towards the end of Summer, there being then (according to report) killed, and vended in one Market day, near 400 Beives. Kirkoswald.

Kirkoswald, consecrated to St. Oswald, lyeth on the River Eden, and on a Hill; a small Town, and of late made a Market-town, which is kept on Thursdays, being for the present of no great account. Here hath been a fair Castle, now reduced to ruin. Aston-more.

Alston-more, anciently Alderston-more, scituate on a Hill; at the bottom of which runneth the River Tine, over which there is a Stone-bridge; and hereabouts is good store of Lead-ore dug up. It is a large stragling Bailiffwick Town, and hath a little Market on Saturdays. Dacre Castle.

Dacre Castle, seated near the River Dacor; of note, for giving Title to the Right Honourable Francis Leonard Baron Dacres, &c. and for that it had a Monastery: and here it was that Constantine King of Scots, and Eugenius King of Cumberland, yielded themselves and their Kingdoms unto Athelstane King of England, on condition to be protected by him. Salkeld.

Salkeld, on the River Eden; where, as a trophy of Victory, were erected 77 great Stones, of about 10 foot a piece in height, of which one is 15 foot high; and these are now called Long Megg, and her Daughters; and within the said Circle are heaps of Stones, under which (as 'tis reported) lye the bodies of slain men. Esk-dale Ward. Brampton.

Brampton, not far from the Picts wall, and on the River Irthin, where in the declension of the Roman Empire lay the first band of the Tungri that came out of Germany; and a Company of Armaturæ, under the General of Britain. It is at present a small (though ancient) Market-town, which is kept on Tuesdays. And hard by this Town, on the top of a high Hill, is a fortified Trench, called the Mote. Long-town.
Long-town, an indifferent Market-town, which is kept on Thursdays. Netherby.

Netherby, seated near the River Kirsop, and in the Barony of Gisland, at present a small Village; but by the great and strange ruins of buildings, it seemeth to have been an ancient City of the Romans, and supposed to have been the æsica, wherein the Tribune of the first band of the Astures kept watch and ward in old time against the Northern Enemies. Wheatly Castle.
At Wheatly Castle, in the said Barony of Gisland, is to be seen the footsteps of a very great and ancient Town of the Romans, which was strongly fenced about.

div1.n: DERBY, OR, DERBYSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORILANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: DERBY, OR, DERBYSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORILANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Darby with its hundreds

div1.p: DERBYSHIRE, called by the Saxons, Deorbyscire, seated near the middle of England, but inclining towards the North. Bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the River Erewash, which severeth it from Nottinghamshire; on the South-east with the River Trent; and on the South with the River Mease, which said Rivers divide it from Leicestershire; on the West with the Rivers Trent and Dove, which separate it from Staffordshire, as doth the River Goyt from Cheshire; and on the North by Yorkshire. Extent.

Its extent from Sherbrook in the east, to Shallcross in the West, is about 26 miles; and from Stretton in the fields in the South, to Beighton in the North, is about 34, which makes its circumference to be about 130 miles. Temperature.
The Air is temperate and good, though something cold upon the Peak Mountains. Fertility.

The Soil is generally fruitful, especially the South and East parts, which are generally enclosed and improved, yielding good Corn and Grass; and hath also great store of Coal, and Iron-stone. The North and West parts are very hilly and stony, and not so fertile, except it be in Lead-ore, in which it abounds, yet not without some rich Valleys: and on the Hills are bred very good (though not very large) Sheep, in great abundance, which supply the wants of many other Counties: In the North-west, Oats are their chiefest Grain, of which they make their Bread, and sometimes their Beer, but in other parts hath plenty of all sorts of Grain. This County hath been well wooded, but the Iron-works, Lead-mines, and Coal-delfs, have destroyed much of it. For Fuel, it is not beholding to wood, being so well stored with Coal, insomuch that it supplies the defects of many neighbouring Counties, as Leicester, Northampton, Rutland and Lincoln, whose Inhabitants
frequently bring Barly to sell at Derby, and load themselves back with Coals. Materials for building.

For building it affords store of Free-stone, or durable Greet-stone, good clay for Brick, black and gray Marble, which is very durable, and polishes well; also Alablaster, and in many parts Lime-stone, which is not only usefull in building, but for manuring the ground. Mill-stones. Grind-stones. Syth-stones.

Hear are great Quarries, out of which Mill-stones are got, also Grindstones, and Syth-stones, which imploy many hands in working up, and are dispersed over great part of the Nation. And in some parts of this County Stibium is also found. Lead.

But of all Lead, which is the principal Commodity, and more plentifull here then in any part of the known World, which for excellency yieldeth to none, and the great Trade here driven for it, doth cause Land to lett, and Goods to sell at better rates than in any of the neighbouring Counties. Ancient Inhabitants.

The Inhabitants that possessed these parts before the Invasion of the Romans, according to Ptolomy, were the Coritani, which P. Ostorius Scapula, Lieutenant in this Province under Claudius the Emperour, brought into subjection; and when their Empire declined, it fell into the hands of the Saxons, and was part of the Kingdom of the Mercians.
It is observed, that the River Derwent severeth this County into East and West; on the East side is Coal generally found, and on the west Lead. Tiken-hall Pots.
At Tiken-hall are made great store of earthen Potts, which are carried to Boston in Lincolnshire, and thence dispersed into several Countries. Parks.
This County, before the late Wars, had near about 30 Parks, well stored with Deer, many of which do yet continue. Rivers.

It is very well watered with pleasant and fruitful Rivers well stored with Fish, which are passed over by about 21 Stone-bridges. And amongst which the Trent, Derwent, Dove, and Wye are the chlef. Fish. The greatest plenty of Salmon is in Trent, but that in Derwent is preferred before it by some curious Palates; and the Salmons here taken are sent to London. Bridges.

The most remarkable Bridges are, First, Burton, which divides this County from Staffordshire, over the River Trent, being susteined by 35 large Stone Arches; and at this Bridge, Edward the second put to flight Thomas Earl of Lancaster, and many of the Barons, about the year 1322. Secondly, Swarkeston-bridge over the same River, which is reputed to be near a mile in length, but much of it is rather a Cause-way, then a Bridge. Thirdly, St. Maries-bridge over the Derwent at Derby. And fourthly, Monks-bridge over the Dove, where passeth the Roman high-way, called Ikneld-street, which goeth from Southampton in Hantshire, and to Tinmouth in Northumberland. Mineral waters. Buxton-well.

In this County are many Mineral waters, as Buxton-well, where in the compass of 8 or 9 yards, issueth out of a Rock 9 Springs, of which 8 are warm and one very cold; and these waters are esteemed very good for the effecting divers Cures, as doth appear by a Book which treateth thereof: They are very pleasant to bath in, which makes them much frequented, especially by the Northern Nobility and Gentry, and would be much more, were there better conveniencies of lodging and entertainment. Kedlastonwell.

In Kedlaston Park is a Well much like the Sulpher-well of Knaresborough in Yorkshire; and is said to have cured the Leprosie; It is good for old Ulcers, and hath been much frequented and taken both inwardly & outwardly. Quarndon springs.

At Quarndon, about a mile and a half from Derby, are also two Springs, which are much of the nature with Tunbridge in Kent, and the Spaws in Yorkshire, being as strong of the mineral, and as effectual in the operation, but want nothing to make them famous but a Spaw Doctor, and some discreet Patients, that will drink them regularly.
Stanly Spring.

Not many miles distant at Stanly, is another Spring of the same nature, but not so strong. There are also several other Mineral waters about Wirksworth; amongst which there is a warm Spring, and a cold Spring, so near together, that you may put one hand in the cold, and the other in the warm.

This County is divided into six Hundreds, whose names appear in the Mapp; in which are numbred about 106 Parish Churches, several of which being of a very large extent, and have within them Chappels of Ease. Religious Houses.
Here were formerly several Religious Houses, as in Derby, Chesterfield, Dale, Darley, Beauchief, Bredsall, Repton, Gresly, Lake, Iveley, and Barrow, &c. Hospitals.
It hath several Hospitals and Almes-houses for the relief of the poor, as in Derby, Chesterfield, Ashbourne, Wirksworth, Bakewell, Crumford, Morley, Chanddesden, &c. Free Schools.
Also several well endowed Free Schools, as at Derby, Repton, Chesterfield, Ashbourne, Wirksworth, Dronfield, Tideswell, Bakewell, Shurland, Ashford, Duffield, Horteshorne, Stavely, &c. Castles.

It was fortified with several strong Castles, as at Melborne, Codnour, Bolsover, the Castle in the Peak, Horston, Duffield, Tapton, Gresley, Mackworth, &c. all which, except Bolsover, are now quite demolished. Markettowns.

This County is within the Diocess of Coventry and Litchfield; and agreat part within the Dutchy of Lancaster, and Honour of Peverell. And for the conveniency of vending its Commodities, hath nine Market Towns within its self, besides Sheffield, Rotheram, Mansfield, Kegworth, Ashby de la Zouch, Burton on Trent, and Uttoxceter, all bordering upon the County. Derby.

Derby, the Shire Town, by the Saxons called Northworthig, and by the Danes, Deoraby; conveniently seated on the Derwent, from whence it takes its name, over which it hath a goodly Stone-bridge; where also a small Brook arising Westwards, runneth through the Town under nine Bridges, before it entreth into the Derwent; and on the said Bridge, called St. Maries, is seated a once fair stone Chappel, which beareth the same name. This Town suffered much under the cruel hands of the Danes, who here had their rendezvous; but at length that victorious Mercian Lady Ethelfleda, by a suddain and forceable surprise expelled them, became Mistress thereof, and repaired it, so that in the time of Edward the Confessor it had 143 Burgesses. It is at present a very large, populous, well frequented, and rich Borough Town, (few inland Towns equalising it) numbring five Parish Churches, of which that of All Saints is the fairest, whose Tower-steeple, built at the only charge of the young men and maids about the reign of Q. Mary, for height and beauty is equalled by few in the Nation, in which are eight tuneable Bells. In this Church are several Monuments; as that of the Countess of Shrewsbury, who built here an Hospital for the relief of twelve poor people; and another of the Countess Dowager of Devonshire, being a stately Tomb of black and white Marble for her Husband and her self. In this Town are several Religious Houses, as St. Hellens, St. James's, and St. Leonards: It is a place of a good Trade, chiefly for Barley, which they make into Malt, and sell again in Lancashire, Cheshire, and the North of this County. The Town is dignified with an Earldom, who at present is the Right Honourable Charles Earl of Derby, Baron Stanley, Strange, and Lord of the Isle of Man; here is a fair Hall lately built of Free-stone at the Counties charge, where the Assises are constantly kept. The Government of this Town is at present committed to the care of a Major, nine Aldermen, fourteen Brethren, and fourteen Common Councel, a Recorder, Town- Clark, &c. doth enjoy extraordinary large immunities; its Inhabitants being
freed from the payment of Toll at London, a priviledge which the Londoners are not exempted from here. It also giveth its Vote in Parliament by two Burgesses; and its Market is on Frydaies, which is very great for Cattle, Corn, and all Provisions, besides small Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays. Derwent navigable. The trade of this Town and County might be much advanced, if the River Derwent was made navigable; which might easily be done, it wanting but six miles of the River Trent, which would convey Lead, Marble, Stone, and such like ponderous Commodities; and is something of note for its excellent Ale, called Derbyshire Ale. Chesterfield.

Chesterfield, (that is a Dale encompassed with crags and rocks) pleasantly scituate between two small Rivers, and for the most part on the South side of a little Hill in a good soil. It is a Town of great Antiquity, although its old name is quite lost; and glorieth much in being made a free Borough by King John at the request of his Favourite William Brewyer, to whom he gave it, and is now dignified with an Earldome, which at present is in the person of the Right Honourable Philip Earl of Chesterfield, Baron Stanhop of Shelford, &c. Nor is the Battle to be forgotten, which was fought hard by this Town, betwixt King Henry the Third and his rebellious Barons; in which Robert de Ferrers, the last Earl of Derby of that Family, was taken Prisoner, and stript both of Estate and Honour, nothing being left him but his life. It is beautified with a fair and large Church, in which are several Monuments. It hath a Free School for the education of Youth, and Almes-houses for relief of the poor; and of late, the Sessions for the Peace are here held for the North part of the County. It is a Town that hath large immunities and priviledges granted unto it by King John, and several succeeding Kings and Queens; and is at present governed by a Major, six Aldermen, a Recorder, six Brethren, twelve Counsellors, two Chamberleyns, with other Sub-officers. Here are weekly two Markets, the one on Tuesdays, formerly held in the old Market-place, but long since neglected; and the other on Saturdays, which is kept in the large new Market-place, being very considerable for Corn, Lead, and all Country Commodities. Alfreton.

Alfreton, (thought to be built by King Alfred) pleasantly seated on a pretty Hill, a Town not very large, nor its Market, which is on Mondays considerable, except for the great quantities of Bread here sold. Wirksworth.

Wirksworth, so called from the worth of the Lead works; It is seated in a Valley, near the Spring-head of the River Ecclesbourn, a pretty large and populous Town, and begins to be well built. It is beautified with a fair Church, and hath a Free School and Almes-houses; As also a great Market on Tuesdays for provisions and Apples, but chiefly for Lead, being the greatest Lead-market in England, where the Lead Merchants have their meeting for the sale thereof.

It is scarce imaginable how many thousands of men, women, and children in this County, have their maintenance from Lead; as Miners, Washers, Smilters, Carriers, Merchants and others. The Miners have Laws, Customs, and Priviledges peculiar to themselves, which were confirmed to them by several Acts of Parliament; and near the Town there are several Smelting-Mills. Ashbourne.

Ashbourne, scituate between the River Dove and Compton (over which is a Stone-bridge) and in a rich soil; It is a pretty large Town, & hath a Market on Saturdays, which of late is much decayed, many Families being extinct, or removed: some will have the reason to be, through the many Attorneys thereabouts
Peverel Courts abouts residing, and its being within the Peverel Courts; but let the reason be what it will, through its declension Wirksworth is now become considerable. Bakewell.

Bakewell, by the Saxons called Badecanwell, where K. Edward the elder erected a Borough: It is seated on the River Wye amongst Hills, is an indifferent large Town, but a larger Parish, conteining seven Chappels, and is a peculiar freed from all manner of Episcopal Jurisdiction. It hath a good Market on Mondays for Lead and other Commodities. Eolsover.

Bolsover, a pretty Castle highly elevated, and in good soyl, and air, thought to be a strong Garison of the Danes, where there are two huge Ditches or Trenches yet to be seen. The Town is reasonable large, its Houses indifferent well built, hath a Market on Friday; and is of some note for its excellent and well glased Tobacco-pipes here made. Dronfield.
Dronfield, seated in a Bottom, a pretty Market Town on Thursdays; and hath a Free School. Tideswall.

Tideswall, lowly scituate, & not far from a Well that is said to ebb and flow, from whence it may probably take its name. It is an indifferent Town, beautified with a fair Church, & a Free School; and hath a Market on Wednesdays. Chapple in the Frith.
Chapple in the Frith, seated in the utmost confines of the Peak near Cheshire, formerly a Market Town, but now disused. Winster.
Winster, a place where there is a meeting for the sale of Provisions on Saturdays, but is no Market Town. Other places of note in this County. Melborne Castle.
Melborne Castle, now demolished, formerly belonging to the Kings of England, wherein John Duke of Burbon, taken captive at the Battle at Agincourt, was kept a Prisoner for 19 years. Repton.

Repton, a Colony of the Romans (called Repandunum, by the Saxons Repandun) was once the Palace, and burying place of æthelbald, and divers others of the Mercian Kings: It was much infested, and almost quite destroyed by the Danes. Here was also a Priory founded by a Daughter to Robert Earl of Glocester; and at present this place is famous for its eminent Free School. Tickenhall.
Tickenhall, a Town famous for making of Earthen Pots, and for the great store of excellent Lime-stone.

Near Burton, or Burton-wells, within the compass of 8 or 9 yards issueth out of a Rock 9 Springs, of which 8 are of a warm temperature, and one very cold. These run from under a square building of Free-stone, which at the distance of about 60 paces, receiveth another hot Spring from a Well enclosed with stones called St. Anns; nigh unto which another very cold Spring arising; and these waters are esteemed very good for the effecting divers cures. The Peak.

Not far from this place is the Peak, abounding in Lead, and not without veins of Antimony, Quarries of Mill-siones and Whet-stones, wherein are divers strange things, or rather wonders to be seen, as the Devils Arce, Eldenhole, and Pools-hole: the chief wonder is the vastness of the height, length, and depth of these Caves; and the strange irregularities of the Rocks within the water that comes from the Devils Arce, which is said to ebb and flow, as doth the ebbing and flowing well not far distant. In Pools-hole, the water falling down is congealed to a kind of a white brittle shining-stone. Mam Torre.

div1.n: DEVONSHIRE: BEING Part of the DANMONII and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: DEVONSHIRE: BEING Part of the DANMONII, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.
div1.p: DEVONSHIRE, far engaged Westward, and of a sharp, and healthful Air; a Country, called by the Cornish Britains, Devinan, that is, the Country of low Valleys, by reason that the Inhabitants for the most part dwell in the Vales. Fertility, and Commodities

It is much inclined to Hills, in many places well clothed with wood, and generally very barren, and ungrateful to the Husbandman, without great pains and charges in manuring it, which they do by putting thereon lime and rags, but principally a certain Sand which they have from the Sea-shoar, which causeth as great fertility, as dung in other places; so that the farther the ground lyeth from the Sea, the greater is the charge and trouble to manur it therewith. But although it is for the generality thus barren, yet is it not without many fertile places; as about Exeter, Barnstable, the South Hams, and elsewhere. Its sterility is also recompenced by the rich mines of Tynn and Lead, as also by the great plenty of Herrings, Pilchards, and other Fish taken on its Sea-coast, from which the Inhabitants reap good profit. Its Commodities.

The chief Commodities this County produceth, besides its Tynn, Lead, Pilchards, and Herrings, are Wools and Clothings, the best and finest Kersies in the Kingdom being here made; also good store of Serges and Bone-lace, made in and about Honiton, all which finds good vent at London, and elsewhere. It is also plentifully provided with Flesh, Fish, and Fowl, and is not without some Mines of Silver, though not worth the working; and on the Rocks of Dartmore the Loadstone is frequently found. Its Bounds. Its Rivers.

This Shire hath for its Eastern bounds the Counties of Somerset and Dorset; for its Western, the River Tamar, which severeth it from Cornwall; and on all other parts, the Sea; to wit, on the South the British, and on the North the Severn; by reason of which it is exceedingly well watered with good Rivers, as the Ex, Tamar, Tave, Tawe, Pline, Dart, Turridge, Tinge, Plime, Culme, and Ottery, most of which give, or take their names from Towns so called which are seated thereon; and through the commodiousness of the Seas, is well inhabited, having great store of good and well frequented Maritime and Inland Towns. Extent

Its extent from Thorncombe in the East, to Hartland-point in the West, is about 54 miles; and from Salcomb in the South, to Lynton in the
North 56, which makes its circumference to be about 200 miles. Dignified with an Earldom.
This County is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which is now in the person of the Right Honourable, William Earl of Devonshire, &c. Ancient Inhabitants.
The ancient Inhabitants known to the Romans, were the Danmonii, which afterwards became part of the Kingdom of the West-Saxons. Religious Houses.
Religious Houses in this Shire were at Exeter, Torbay, Kirton, Tavestocke, Hartland, Ford, Axminster, and Barnstable. Its division.

This County for its division, is severed into 33 Hundreds, in which are 394 Parishes, and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, is traded unto by above 30 Market-towns. Its chief places are Exeter.

Exeter, a fair, sweet, and well compacted City, no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the top of an easie ascent, and on the Eastern bank of the River Ex, from whence it took its name, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge. It is a City of considerable account and trade, being much inhabited, and resorted unto by Merchants and Trades-men, having several Ships and Vessels belonging unto them, so that although seated in a barren soil, yet no want of provisions are found. Ptolomy called this City Isca; Antoninus, Isca Danmoniorum; the Welch, Pencaer; and we at present Exeter, from the River Ex on which it is seated. It is a place of a good largeness, conteining within its Wall and Ditches about a mile and an half in circuit; in which, and in its Suburbs (which are large) are numbred 15 Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral or Minster, founded by King Athelstane in honour of St. Peter, which by Edward the Confessor was made a Bishops See, which he removed hither from Crediton or Kirton) being a fair and beautiful strcture, adorned with curious stone Figures. To this Diocess belongeth the Counties of Devon and Cornwall, and for Ecclesiastical Government, hath four Arch-deacons; viz. of Cornwall, Exeter, Barnstable, and Taunton. The Walls of this City were first built by King Athelstane, on which were placed many Watch-towers, and gives entrance into the City by five Gates; near one of which, to wit, the East-gate, standeth a Castle called Rugemont, sometimes the Palace of the West-Saxon Kings; and after them, of the Earls of Cornwall, which commands the whole City and Territory adjacent, and hath a most pleasant prospect into the Sea. This City was formerly so strong and well furnished with Britains, that they held out against the Saxons 465 years after their first entrance, and was not wholly gained until Athelstane became Monarch of the whole, who then peopled it with his Saxons, and much added to its beauty by many fair buildings: but since that, it hath oft-times suffered much affliction; for once was it spoyled, and grievously harazed by the merciless Danes in Anno 875, then in Anno 1003, it was ruinated from East to West, by Swane King of Denmark, since which it hath been four times besieged; the first, by Hugh Courtney Earl of Devonshire, in the civil Wars betwixt York and Lancaster; then by Perkin Walbeck, that counterfeited Richard Duke of York; also by the Cornish Rebells; and lastly by the Parliaments Forces in the late unhappy troubles, who surrounded it on all sides, except towards the Sea: and Mr. Fuller in his Worthies of England observeth, that when they were thus closely besieged, and began to want provisions, great flocks of Larks were daily taken in that part towards the Sea, which much relieved their wants: But these calamities are not comparable to the damage it susteined by the Damms or Wears, that Edward Courtney Earl of Devon- shire caused to be put into the River, which so choaked up the River, that all Vesscls are still forced to lade and unlade their goods at Topesham, about three miles distance; nevertheless it is at this day in a shourishing condition, and enjoyeth ample immunities; sendeth Burgesses to Parlia-
ment; is honoured with an Earldom, which at present is in the Person of the Right Honourable John Earl of Exeter, &c. is governed by a Major, 24 Aldermen or Brethren, with a Recorder, Town-Clark, and other Sub-officers; and hath two very considerable Markets weekly, viz. on Wednesdays and Fridays for provisions, and Serges in great abundance. Plymouth.

Plymouth, seated on the River Plime, and near the Tamer, at both their insluxes into the Sea; which from a poor fishing Village, (by reason of its commodious Haven and excellent Port) is become a very fair, large, well inhabited and frequented, resembling rather a City then a Town, although it containeth but two Parish Churches; and is a place of great importance to the Kingdom, not only for his Majesties, but for Merchants ships to anchor in, where they may ride free from the danger of the Sea or Enemies. It is also a place of great strength, being defended by a powerful Fort; and its Haven is strongly fortified on both sides, and hath on the South side a Pier; and in the midst of the Havens mouth lyeth St. Nicholas Isle, being of a great strength both by nature and Art, with a Chain to lock over as need shall require; and to add to its further strength, here is lately raised, at the charges of our Soveraign King Charles the Second, a Citadel, on which are mounted many pieces of Ordnance, and well manned. St. Nicholas Istle. It is a Borough, or Town Corporate, governed by a Major, Aldermen, and Common-counsel, hath the election of Parliament men, enjoyeth a great trade for most Commodities; and its Markets, which are on Mondays and Thursdays, are extraordinarily well served with all sorts of provisions, as also hath living Cattle.
