From this Port the black Prince, with the Earls of Warwick, Oxford, Suffolk, and Salisbury, with the Lord Chandos and others, put forth to Sea with a Navy of 300 Vessels, for the landing (and maintaining his Fathers right) in France; and after his great victory at Poictiers, he returned hither with the captive French King, and divers of his Nobles. Also from this Port Sir Francis Drake and Mr. Candish began their Voyages for the discovery of the West-Indies, or unknown parts of the World: likewise here it was that the Lord Howard, High Admiral of England, in Anno 1588. vanquished the Spanish Navy; and indeed this Port is a general reception for ships, as well those out-ward bound, for the taking in of fresh provisions for their Voyages, as for those inward bound to pay their welcome to their native soil. Plimpton.

Plimpton, or Plimpton St. Maries, scituate on a branch of the Plime, once fortisied with a Castle, which now is ruinous; It is a Borough town, which electeth Parliament men, and hath a mean Market on Saturdays. Modberry.
Modberry, an indifferent good Town, seated in a bottom between two Hills; and hath a good Market for Cattle and Provisions on Thursdays. Kingsbridge.
Kings-bridge, seated at the Spring-head of a small River, which soon after falleth into the Sea; a mean Town, but hath a very great Market for provisions on Saturdays. Doabrook.
Doabrook, adjoyning to Kings-bridge, but on the other side of the River; a small Town, but hath a very considerable Market for fat and lean Cattle on Wednesdays. Dertmouth.

Dertmouth, on the banks of the River Dert, near its fall into the Sea, where it hath a commodious Haven, which doth occasion it to be a good Port-town, well inhabited, frequented, traded unto, and furnished with shipping. It is a very ancient Corporation town, which is taken out of several Parishes, is governed by a Major and his Brethren; amongst its immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament,
and in former times was much richer then now it is; yet is it a large and well built Town, conteining three Churches; and its Market, which is on Fridays, is very well served with provisions. Totnes.

Totnes, seated on the Dert, and on the descent of a Hill; a Town of great antiquity, and of much more fame then now it is, when King John granted unto them the power of electing a Major for their chief Magistrate, and King Edward the First enlarged their immunities: at which time it was fortified with a Castle. Yet doth it retain several of its priviledges, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and is governed by a Major and his Brethren. The Town is large, consisting of one long street, and hath a very great Market on Saturdays for all live Cattle, Corn, Mault, and Provisions both flesh and fish.
The Shoar or Strond adjoyning, was in ancient time called Totenese, where (according to the British History) Brutus the Founder of the British Nation first landed. Ashburton.

Ashburton, scituate under the Moore, and in a rich soil; a large Brough Town, composed of several streets, beautisied with a fair Church, electeth Parliament-men, and hath a very good Market for corn, cattle, sheep, and provisions on Saturdays. Newton-Abbot.
Newton-Abbot, seated betwixt two branches of the River Teynge, not far from the Sea: a good Town, and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is well served with cattle, corn, and provisions. Teignmouth.
Not far from this Town is Teignemouth, seated at the mouth of the Teigne, where the Danes first landed, killed the Governour, and committed their outrages. Chidlay.
Chidlay, near the Teigne, a good Market-town for corn and provisions on Saturdays. Moreton.
Moreton, or Moreton-Hampsteed, seated on a Hill near Dartmore; an indifferent large Town, and hath a good Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions, and very considerable for yarn. Okehampton.

Okehampton, a Major-town, seated betwixt the River Okement, and a branch thereof; is governed by a Major, Burgesses, Recorder, and Subofficers; electeth Parliament men; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is of good note for corn, provisions, and yarn. Tavestock.

Tavestock, scituate on the Tavey, or Teave; a Town in former time very flourishing and famous for its once stately Abbey, so pleasantly seated amongst Groves and Rivers. It is at present a Borough Town, which gives its vote in Parliament by two Burgesses, and hath a great Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Houlsworthy.
Houlsworthy, seated between two little branches of the Tamer; a large Town, which harh a good Market for corn and provisions on Saturdays. Hatherlay.
Hatherlay, a small Town, near the River Towridge, and a branch thereof; whose Market, which is on Fridays, is not very considerable. Torrington.

Torrington magna, seated on the River Towridge; a good large Town, which gives the Title of Earl of Torrington, to the Right Noble Christopher Duke of Albemarle, &c. The Market which is here kept is on Saturdays, which is well served with corn, living cattle, and provisions. Harton. Hartland.

Harton, scituate near the Severn Sea, where it maketh a Promontory, called in former times Hercules Promontory, and now Herty-point; which Town, with Hartland near adjoyning, was famous in old time for the reliques of St. Nectan, in honour of whom here was erected a little Monastery, founded by Githa Earl Goodwines wife, as being perswaded, that through his merits her Husband the Earl escaped the danger of the Sea.
Bediford.

Bediford, anciently Bytheford, commodiously seated for the reception of Vessels on the Towridge, over which it hath a large Stone-bridge of arched work, consisting of 24 Peers, and so high, that a Vessel of 50 or 60 Tuns may pass under it; which accommodation doth make it to be a Town of good account, and trade, being large, well inhabited; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is well frequented and served with corn and provisions. Ilfarcombe.
Ilfarcombe, seated on the Severn Sea, where it hath a good Road for ships. It is an indifferent Market-Town. Combe Martin.
Combe Martin, also on the Severn, where it hath an inlet which runneth through the Town, which is but small, as is its Market. Barnstable.

Barnstable, commodiously seated on the River Tawe, over which it hath a large Bridge. It is a very fine Borough-town, which electeth Parliament-men; is a place of some trade; and its Market, which is on Fridays, is of good account for cattle, corn, and provisions. South Moulton.
South Moulton, scituate on a small River called Moul, which falleth into the Tawe. A pretty good Town, and hath a considerable Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions, &c. Chulmleigh.

Chulmleigh, seated on the Dert, which fetching a compass like a Bowe bent, doth encompass three parts of it. The Town is but small, nor its Market very considerable, although much encreased to what it was. Bowe.
Bowe, near the Spring-head of a River which falleth into the Tawe, a pretty small Town, but hath a very inconsiderable Market on Thursdays. Baunton.
Baunton, on a branch of the Ex, near the confines of Somersetshire, a small Town. Tiverton.

Tiverton, anciently called Twiford-town, scituate on the Ex, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, where the River Leman falleth in. It is a large Town Corporate, which sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is governed by a Major, twelve Burgesses, and other Sub-officers: a place in former time of greater account then now it is, yet is it of good esteem for its Clothings here made, by which the Inhabitants drive a confiderable trade; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very well served with provisions. Bradnidge.
Bradnidge, an ancient Major-town, seated near the River Culme, at present no Market-town, but before the damage it susteined by the late fire it was of some account. Columpton.
Columpton, scituate near the Culme, where it hath a Bridge; a fine Town, and hath an indifferent good Market on Saturdays. Crediton.

Crediton, seated betwixt two Hills, and in a rich soil; of note for being the birth place of Winefred the Apostle of the Hussians, Thuringers, and Frisians of Germany, which were converted by him to the Faith of Christ; as also for being the ancient See of the Bishop, which was thence removed to Exeter. It is a place of a pretty largeness, being composed of two Towns, the one called the East-town, and the other the West; is beautified with a very fair Church built Cathedral-wise, to which belongeth a Free School, which hath twelve Governours, who by a Patent from Queen Elizabeth were incorporated, and have the disposing of the Tythes, and payment of the Ministers of this Town, Exminster, and the Hamlet of Sandford. It also enjoyeth a good trade for its Serges here made, is weel inhabited; and its Market, which is on Saturdays for corn and provisions, is esteemed one of the best in the County.
Sidmouth.

Sidmouth, seated on the Sea-shoar, a small Fisher-town, which formerly, before its Haven was choaked up with sands, (as are Seaton and Budley near adjoyning) was also a good Port Town, and of some account. Its Market is but small. Ottery.

Ottery, or Otiery St. Mary, scituate on the River Otter, and on the side of a Hill, a small Town, which is beautified with a fair Church; and hath a very good Market for provisions on Tuesdays. Culliton.
Culliton, seated on a good River, not far from the Sea, an indifferent Town; and hath a good Market on Thursdays. Honiton.

Honiton, not far from the River Otter, where there is a Bridge, and on the Road from Exeter to London. It is a Borough Town, which is but indifferent, hath the election of Parliament-men; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great for Corn and Provisions. Axminster.

Axminster, on the edge of the County towards Somer setshire, and on the River Ex, over which it hath a Bridge. A Town in former Ages of great renown for the Tombs of the Saxon Princes, who were slain in that bloody Battle at Brunaburgh, and brought hither. It is at present an indifferent large Town, and hath a good Market on Saturdays. Places of note to Seamen on the British Sea, beginning Westward, are

Plymouth-haven already treated of; nigh unto which are Penlet-point and Ramhead, which are both in Cornwall. Yalmemouth. Armouth. Hope- key. St. Michaels Mount. Bult-point. Salcombe-haven. Combes-point. Dartmouth-haven. Bery-point. Tor-bay, a very safe Road and Harbour for ships. Exmouth-haven; and Austerton-point. Places of note to Seamen on the Severn Sea.
Hartland-point, or Hercules Promontory already treated of. Portlidge- mouth. Barnstable-bair. Cryde-bay. Bagg-point. Moort-bay; and Moortstone.

div1.n: DORSETSHIRE: BEING The DUROTRIGES of Ptolomy and part of the ancient KINGDOM OF THE West-Saxons
div1.head: DORSETSHIRE: BEING The DUROTRIGES of Ptolomy, and part of the ancient KINGDOM OF THE West-Saxons.
div1.p: DORSETSHIRE, seated in the West of England, in a good and healthful Air. Bounds. It hath for its bounds, Hantshire on the East; the British Sea on the South; Devonshire and part of Somersetshire on the West; and the Counties of Wiltshire, with part of Somerset on the North. Extent.
Its length from East to West is about 44 miles; its breadth, where broadest, about 24; and makes in circumference about 150 miles. Divisions.

It is severed into five Divisions; viz. Shafton, Blandford, Sherborn, Dorchester, and Bridport; which are again subdivided into 29 Hundreds, the names of all which, are set down in the Mapp: and in these Hundreds are numbred 248 Parish Churches. Parishes. Soil.

Though the Air of this County be good and healthful, yet is not the soil barren, but rich and fertile, a thing seldom in cident to good and wholesome Airs. The more Northern part (which is divided from the South, almost by a continual ridge of high Hills) is somewhat flat, and was in foregoing Ages wholly Forests; neither is it in this our decaying Age altogether destitute of Timber Trees and Woods. It aboundeth with good Pastures and feeding for Cattle, and is watered with fine streams, which take their courses through rich Meadows; which inducements have invited many of the Gentry of these parts to dwell there; although in the Winter season they reap more profit then pleasure; for then this flat Country is very subject to dirt and foul wayes, which inconvenience the South part is free from, which consisteth altogether of Hills or Downs, which are all overspread with innumerable stocks of sheep, which proveth no small profit to the Inhabitants. Great profit arising by their sheep. Valleys here are divers, but not large; in which (for the most part) the Towns and Gentlemens Houses are seated, the better to avoid those sharp blasts which this Southern part is subject unto, by reason of its being wild and destitute of Woods. Their Corn-fields seldom deceive the Husbandmans expectation; and adjoyning to the Rivers are rich Meadows, though not in so great plenty, as in the North part, which is more for pleasure then profit.
Its Rivers.

It is a Country generally well watered with sweet Rills and swift runing Brooks, which passing through the Plains and Valleys, do at last, in a most loving manner, unite themselves; and of their many branches make two big bodied streams, viz. the Frome and the Stower; which with the Sea do plentifully furnish the Inhabitants with excellent Fish and Fowl. Its Commodities and Trade.

Many are the Commodities of this Shire, according to the several places: but the chiefest and most general are Cattle, Sheep, Corn, Wool, Wood, Hemp, Tobacco-pipe clay, Free-stone, &c. Their Cattle and Sheep the Grasiers drive fat to London, for that they feed more than the Country can utter; likewise their sheep are found very profitable to the owners by their Fleeces, of which the Clothiers make Kersies, which are transported into France, and elsewhere; and with their corn the Merchants furnish their ships to New-found-land. And for the better support of their Traffick, they have several good Haven Towns seated on their shoar, as Lyme, Waymouth, Pool, &c. Its ancient Castles and Religious Houses.

This County was in former times strengthened with eight strong Castles; and beautified with many fair Monasteries and Religious Houses, most of which are now brought into so many heaps of ruin, like that old decayed Castle of Badburg, which was invironed with a tripple Trench, and had been sometimes the seat of the West-Saxon Kings. Its ancient people.

The ancient people of this County were the Durotriges, who lived under the Government of the Romans: afterwards, when the Saxons had made themselves Lords of this Kingdom, it fell under the jurisdiction of the West-Saxons, whose Kings often resided at Corfe, a Castle in the Isle of Purbeck; but the Normans driving them out, did possess their places. It is at present throughout well inhabited with Gentry, which for the most part are of an ancient descent, and by their frequent matching amongst themselves, are generally allied to one another.

This County is well garnished with abundance of useful and delightful Towns, and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, hath intercourse and trassick with eighteen or nineteen Market-towns, many of which are of good account. Dorchester.

Its chief places are Dorchester, a Town of great antiquity, well known to the Romans, where they had their station, as may appear by the great quantities of Roman coyns, and Rampiers there often digged up; and was a place of a larger circuit then now it is, which is manifested by the circuits of its then walls (first thrown down by the Danes) the ruins of which in some places are yet standing. This Town is pleasantly seated on the South side of the River From; and on the Roman Cawsie, called Foss-way. It is at present the chief Town of the County, and neatly compacted, with well built Houses, hath three fair Streets, and as many Parish Churches; its Inhabitants gain well by clothing and other Merchandize: And its Market, which is on Saturday, is very considerable, and well provided with corn, slesh, sheep, and other living Cattle; as also with Mercenary wares usually sold in great Markets, &c.

It is a Town Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, eight Aldermen, out of whom the Bailiffs are elected, a Recorder, two Clarks, two Sergeants, and other subservient Officers; hath the election of two Burgesses; is the place where the Assises are kept; hath an eminent Free School for the education youth, and an Almes-house for the relief of poor people. And is of chief note for giving Title to the Right Honourable Henry Pierrepont, Marquess of Dorchester, &c.

Not far from this Town on the South side, is a small plat of ground (which
now beareth corn) raised about thirty paces higher then the rest of the Plain, and compast about with five Trenches, containing (according to Speed) about five Acres, and is called by the Country people, the Maiden castle, having entrance into it but only at the East and West, and is said to have been some Fort of Defence for the Roman Garison. The ancient Fort of the Romans. Weymouth and Melcombe Regis.

Weymouth, seated on the River Wey at its fall into the Sea, opposite to which on the other bank standeth Melcombe, or Melcombe Regis; an ancient Borough, between whom and Waymouth arose a great controversie, both enjoying the like priviledges and immunities of the Haven, which lyeth in the very bosome of them, insomuch that each took the overthrow of the other; but at length, by their continual suits, having wearied the Lords of the Council and Judges, they were by Act of Parliament, in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, incorporated into one body, and governed by one Major, with Aldermen and other Sub-officers; and immediately upon which they conjoyned themselves together by a fair Bridge of Timber now in being; yet still they send each of them two Burgesses to Parliament. Both these Towns have risen from small beginning, through the conveniency of the Harbour; neither of them, until of late years, having a Parish Church. Weymouth at present hath but one chief street, which for a good space lyeth open to the Sea; and on the bank thereof riseth a Hill of such steepness, that the Inhabitants are forced to climb up to their Chappel by sixty steps of Stone, from whence there is a fair prospect of the Town and Haven, which lyeth under it; and from the other side, Weeke its mother Church, she weth it self. Melcombe on the other side the River, much surpasseth Weymouth for conveniency of scituation, standing on a Flat, and affordeth room for Buildings, having a Market-place, good streets, and yards for their Wares, which hath invited most of the Merchants to reside on this side. And these Towns thus united, gain well by traffick into Newfound-land, France, and elsewhere: And their Markets, which are on Tuesdays and Fridays, are well provided of all necessaries. Isle of Portland.

Not far from Weymouth Southerly, lyeth the Isle of Portland, so called from one Port a noble Saxon, (as Cambden noteth.) It is an Isle, or rather a Peninsula, so made by the Beech which runneth from Abbots-bury, and is of great strength, as well by Nature, as by Art, being environed with inaccessable Rocks, except at the very place of landing, where there is a strong Castle, called Portland Castle, built by King Henry the Eighth, and opposite almost to it on the Lands side towards Waymouth is another, called Sandfoot Castle; which two command all ships which pass into the Road. Portland and Sandford Castles. The whole Isle, when got to the top of these craggy Rocks, sheweth it self in a Flat, and is in compass about seven miles. The ground is very good for corn, and indifferent for pasturage, but so destitute of wood and other fuel, that the Inhabitants are necessitated to dry their Cow-dung, and burn it. On the South side standeth the only Church in the Isle, (bearing its name) so near the Sea, that for its secure preservation from its furious Waves, they have been forced to wall the Church-yard-banks to an incredible height. And here Portland Race she weth it self, which is the meeting of the two tydes, with so great striving and beating of the Waves, that it is very dangerous for Barks to pass over it, though in the calmest season. This Isle is not destitute of fresh water, hath plenty of corn, sheep, and cattle, and affordeth excellent Quarries of stone for building, in such great plenty that they make use of it for their fences. This Isle gives Title to the Right Honourable Thomas Weston Earl of Portland, &c. Abbots-bury.
Abbots-bury, seated within half a mile of the Sea, an ancient, but poor Town, where there was a Monastery, and hath a small Market on Thursdays.

From this Town to Portland runneth a Beech or Chesell by the Sea shoar, being so made by a bank of Pibble-stones: And this Beech, which is the royalty of Coll. Giles Strangways, is worthy of note for its great quantities of Swans belonging to the said Col. Strangways. Lime.

Lime, or Lime Regis, seated on the banks of the Sea, a well known Haven-town, so named from Lyme a little River, which disclosing its self not far of at Uplyme, passeth through the midst of this Town, and falleth into the Sea. Its a place of great antiquity, yet arrived to no great height of name or Estate, until the Reign of King Edward the First, who enfranchised it, granting to it both the liberties of an Haven, and a Borough; after which time it became a flourishing Town, and the rather for the conveniency of the Cobb, which is a secure Harbour, that the Inhabitants by their industry have made in the Sea for ships to ride in, which is carefully looked after, and kept in good repair. It is a large Town, built on both sides of the River, over which it hath a Bridge; is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major, (who of late years, during his Majoralty, is a Justice of Peace) besides other Officers for his Assistants, and sendeth two Burgesses to Parliament. It is a place of a good trade, and its Markets are well frequented. Charmouth the landing place of the Danes.
Near unto Lyme at Charmouth, a small Village, twice did the Danes land their forces, when they went to subdue this Isle. Lambarls Castle.

On the edge of Breklade-park, adjoyning to Marshwood, riseth a Hill of a great eminence, fortified at the top with Trenches, which the neighbouring Inhabitants, called Lambarts Castle, near the top thereof is a hole, of which the Country people will tell many Fables. Marshland. St. White a Virgin Martyr.

In Marshland are seated several Towns, amongst which is White-church, so called from one St. White a Virgin Martyr, whose Well the Inhabitants will shew you not far off in the side of a Hill, where she lived a holy life, and in honour of her this Church was so called. Chidiock,
Chidiock, seated near the Sea, a thorough-fair Town, well known to western Travellers, and much inhabited by Saylers and Fishermen. Birdport.

Birdport, seated low and dirty, between two Rivers, which not far off joyning with a little Rill, afford a fit place for an Harbour, which was so in former times; but now quite choaked up with Sands. This Town in the time of Edward the Confessor was of good account, and boasteth now of its antiquity more then of its beauty and largeness, conteining but one Church. It is a Borough and Town Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, &c. hath the election of two Burgesses, and is a good Market-town, and chiefly affordeth Hemp. This Town, by an especial edict, was the only place appointed for the twisting of Cordage and Ropes for the Navy of England, as well in respect of the adjoyning soil, yielding great store of excellent and good Hemp, as for the skill of the people in twisting it. Bemyster.
Bemyster, seated on the River Bert, a pretty Market-town. Evershot.
Evershot, a small Market-town. Cerne Abbas.

Cerne Abbas, memorable in former ages for a rich, fair, and flourishing Abbey of Black Monks which stood their, first built by St. Augustin, afterwards Arch-bishop of Canterbury, now reduced to ruin; adjoyning to which Abbey was seated the Town, which (as most Abbey Towns) is now but mean, especially to what it was, yet hath it an eminent Market on Wednesdays for corn, sheep, live cattle, &c. This Town is seated in a dry bottom, watered with a fine Rivulet, and in a Champain Countrey affording great delight, both for the Hawk and Hound. Middleton.

Middleton, or Milton Abbas, an ancient Town, but poor and meanly built, eminent only for an ancient and now decayed Abbey, and hath a small Market on Monday.
Sherborne.

Sherborne, fairly seated and well watered, which for largness, frequency of Inhabitants, and quick Markets, which are weekly on Thursdays and Saturdays, which are very well furnished with corn, flesh, living cattle, sheep, &c. gives place to none in these parts. And that it was a place of great esteem in the Saxons time is most likely: for Ina their King, in the year of our Lord 704. erected here a Bishops See, under whose jurisdiction he appointed the Counties of Dorset, Wilts, Somerset, Devon, and Cornwall; but upon the translating the See to Salisbury, the Cathedral and Bishops Palace was left to the Monks, and soon after it grew to be an Abbey of good note and wealth, and upon the desolution of the said Abbey (the Church being not long before but newly built) was purchased by the Towns-men, for the effecting of which they pulled down two other Churches, and added more beauty unto it, so that for fairness and elegant buildings, it surpasseth any there abouts; at the East end thereof standeth a very fair Free-School, first built and endowed by King Edward the sixth; and not far from thence is a very fine Almes-house built by Richard Beachampe Bishop of Salisbury. This Town is divided into two parts, that lying near the Castle (which is now ruinated) is called Castle-town, and both governed by two Constables, which are yearly chosen. Shaftbury.

Shaftbury, or Shafton, in the Northern verge of the County towards Wiltshire, very loftily scituate on a high Hill, in form of a full bent Bow; it is very destitute of water, which for ordinary uses is brought on horses backs from the foot of the Hill, but this inconveniency is recompenced both by the benesit of a most serene and healthful air, as also a long and delightful prospect. This Town is said to be first built by King Alfrid, where he had his Palace, which afterwards became a most fair and rich Monastery, and well endowed with great revenues and priviledges. It was much resorted unto by reason of the body of K. Edward the Second (who was kept a prisoner at Corfe, and at length being murthered, was here interred, who being esteemed a Martyr, and canonized a Saint, had his Shrine so visited, that the very Town for a time was from him called Burgus St. Edward. In this Town Canutus the Dane, that first swayed the English Scepter here ended his dayes. It had, when in its glory, ten Parish Churches, which are reduced to three, which are indifferent good; and conteineth about 500 houses, which are built of Free-stone, with which the Hill aboundeth; and is a fair and well frequented thorough-fare Market-town, which is on Saturdays, being very considerable for corn, flesh, living cattle, and other Country Commodities, far exceeding all the adjacent Market-towns. It is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honourable Anthony Earl of Shaftsbury, Chancellor of the Exchequor, under Treasurer of England, one of the Lords Commissioners of his Majesties Treasury, and one of the Lords of his Majesties most Honourable Privy Councel, &c. is governed by a Major, and 12. Aldermen, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. In this Green, the Monday before the Fair, the Inhabitants by their Charter are obliged to carry into the said Green, a thing the Inhabitants call a Besome, being a frame of wood richly adorned with gold, jewels, and ribbon, which is carried by one of the Serjeants, the Major, and the rest of his Brethren, attending it with Musick, Dancing, and other Pastimes, at which time the Inhabitants, also (as a homage due for their water to the other Parish) present the Lords Bailiff with a Calves-head raw, bread, beer, and a pair of Gloves. Sturminster-Newton-Casile.

Sturminster, or Sturminster-Newton- Castle, a mean Town, but seated in a rich Vale, and on the River Stower, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, leading to Newton-Castle, eminent for the relicts of an ancient Castle near adjoyning, which was the seat of the West-Saxon Kings Is a small Market-town for corn and other conveniencies on Thursdays.
Blandford.

Blandford, or Blandford Bryan, a fair, large, and well compacted Market- town, pleasantly seated on the Stower, and near unto the Downs, well inhabited, neighboured with Gentry, and of a good trade. The Town is governed by two Bailiffs, yearly chosen out of the Aldermen. Its Market, which is on Saturdayes, is well provided of all things, but chiefly with corn, sheep, and living cattle. On the other side of the River, which is passed over by a Bridge, is seated St. Mary Blandford. Cranblorne.

Cranborne, well watered, and finely seated for pleasure, having a Chase which extendeth its self almost to Salisbury. It is a Town of great antiquity, being the seat of Alward an English Saxon of noble birth, who there built a little Monastery, in which he was buried. It is a Market-town on Wednesdays, but of no great account. Wimborne-Minster.

Wimborne-Minster, seated in a fertile soil, on the River Stower, and a branch thereof; a Town of more antiquity then beauty, yet is it a large and well frequented and inhabited Market-town, which is on Fridays. In former time it was a place of good account, beautified with a goodly large Church or Minster, and with a Nunnery thereto adjoyning, built in the year of our Lord 712, by Lutle Burga sister to Ina King of the West-Saxons, who being desirous to live a religious life, sued a divorse from her Husband King of Northumberland, and betook her self to the Monastery: and upon the desolution of the Monastery, a fair and large Church, with a high Spire-steeple, and a Bell-tower was erected in the room thereof, and in lieu of the Nuns were placed Prebendaries; governed by a Dean now also gone. On Goodfriday there is a great Market for Cattle, which so continueth for seven weeks after. Harley-wood.

Between Cranborne and Wimborne-Minster, is a Wood called Harley, from which, and the two aforesaid Towns, ariseth this Proverb, That when Harley is hareless, Cranborne whoreless, and Wimborne poorless, then the world will be at an end. Poole, a good Haven-town

Poole, enclosed on all parts with the Sea, except on the North, where it admits entrance only by one gate. This Town, from a few Fishermens houses in the reign of Edward the Third, grew to be a Market-town of a good trade, and by reason of its large and safe Harbour, encreased so that Henry the Sixth granted unto it the priviledge of a Haven, and licenced the Major to wall it in; then began the Inhabitants to abound in wealth, and to beautifie it exceedingly with fair buildings; and to free themselves from subjection unto the County, they purchased a priviledge of a County: and so from a mean Hamlet belonging to Canford, seated on or near the River Stower (which is the fairest River, and best stored with Fish of any in the County) it became a Town and County incorporate, and hath the election of Burgesses: But at present much of its pristine glory is lost, insomuch that its Houses begin to decay, and complain for want of Inhabitants. It hath two indifferent good Markets weekly, viz. on Mondays and Thursdays.
In the very mouth of this Haven is Branksey, a little Isle with a Blockhouse in it; and on the South of it lyeth two very small Isles, called Bursey and St. Elyns. Bere Regis. Woodbury-fair.

Bere, or Bere Regis, a very poor Town, with a small Market on Wednesdays, chiesly eminent for a Fair kept near unto it on Woodbury-hill. This hill is fortified at the top with double Ditches, formerly a station of the Romans. Warham.

Warham, esteemed the ancientest Borough-town in the County, seated between two Rivers, the From and Biddle, at their falling into Luckford-lake, where it had a good harbour for ships, & was a very considerable large place conteining several Churches, which are now reduced to three, and was environed with a strong wall, defended by a Castle, and inhabited with rich
Burgesses; but its often shocks of ill fortune by fire and sword hath so oppressed it, that now only the shadow of its ancient glory remaineth; for its Castle is wholly ruinated, its Haven choaked up, most of its Churches demolished, and amonst them the Priory of black Monks. The Town doth at present send Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by a Major; and its Market is indifferently well frequented. Frampton.
Frampton, a small Market-town on Thursdays, seated pleasantly on a good River, which affordeth excellent Trouts and other fish. Lulworth-Castle.

Lulworth-Castle is esteemed the best seat in the whole County, as well for beauty and fairness, as a pleasant scituation, and prospect into the Sea, having the accommodation of a large Park, well furnished with Deer. This Castle is honoured with the presence of the King in his western Progresses. Isle of Furbeck.

The Isle of Purbeck, or rather the Peninsula, so called, lyeth in length about 10 miles, and in breadth about 5; seated in the South-east part of the County. In this Isle are seated several Towns, as appeareth in the Mapp, amongst which is Corfe-Castle, seated on a River, in a barren soil between two Hills, upon one of which standeth the Castle. Carfe-Castle. It is an ancient Boroughtown, governed by a Major and Barons, is endowed with many priviledges, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliamet; it hath a small Market every Thursday. The Castle belonging to this Town (which was so called) had great immunities granted unto the Lords thereof; as free Warren-chase over all the Isle, Seawrecks, freedom from the Lord Admiral of England, &c. And in this Castle was King Edward the Second confined by the Queen and her Mortimer.

div1.n: DURHAM: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient of Northumbers
div1.head: DURHAM: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of Northumbers.
div1.p: DURHAM, a Bishoprick, and County Palatine by prescription, far engaged Northwards, and of a sharp and piercing Air; but through the plentifulness of Coals in these parts; the Inhabitants keep such good Fires, that the cold is not so offensive unto them. Its Soil.

It is of a different soil, the Eastern part being Champain, the Southern most fertile, and well Inhabited; and the Western hilly barren, and thin of Woods and Towns; but is recompenced by the store of Coals, Lead, and Iron Mines. Its extent and form.
This County Palatine is in form Triangular, and extendeth from East to West, about 30 miles; and from South to North almost as many; making its circumference to be about 107 miles. Its bounds.

It is almost encompassed with water, for on the East it is washed with the German Ocean, and the River Tees, which falleth into it, being also its Southern bounds, and severeth it from the County of York; on the West with Westmoreland and Northumberland; and on the North with the Rivers Derwent and Tine, which divide it also from Northumberland. Its ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants known to Ptolomy were the Brigantes, in the time of the Saxons made part of the Kingdom of the Northumbers; at first a Province belonging to the Deirians, and enjoyed by Ella their first King; afterwards it was invaded by the Danes, as the rest of the Kingdom was, and in the end became possessed by the Normans.

This Bishoprick, together with the Counties of Cumberland, Westmoreland, and Northumberland, after their subduing by the Normans, were for some time scarce inhabited, and in after times, through their vicinity to the Scots, were frequently annoyed, and for that reason were exempted from Subsidies until the Reign of King James, as being put to great charges and trouble in preserving the Country from them. Durham formerly called St. Cuthberts Patrimony.

In former times this County was called St. Cuthberts Patrimony, from one St. Cuthbert, the sixth Bishop of Lindisfarne, a small Isle on the Coast of Northumberland; (which venerable Bede the famous Saxon Historian, who was born at Jarrow in this County, taketh notice of) who was said to lead
his life so holy, that he was enrolled amongst the English Saints; and had in so great veneration, that our Kings, Nobility, and Gentry, not only out of their Devotion went to visit his Tomb, believing his body lay uncorrupted, but also gave large possessions to the Church, and endowed it with ample immunities: and such were King Egfred, ælfred, Guthrun the Dane, Edward, and Athelstane Monarch of England, and Canute the greatest Zelot of them all: And this Cuthbert was the only raiser of Durham; which William the Conquerour, from a Bishoprick made a County Palatine, and enlarged its priviledges, insomuch that the Bishops thereof have had Jura Regalia between the Rivers Tine and Tees. St. Cuthbert the raiser of Durham. And the Inhabitants have pleaded the priviledge of not passing in service of War over the Rivers Tees, Tine, and Derwent, whose charge (as they alledged) was to keep and defend the Corps of St. Cuthbert, and tearmed themselves St. Cuthberts holy werk-folks. Its division. Its Castles.

It is divided into four Wards, viz. Chester-ward, Darweton-ward, Easington-ward, and Stockton-ward; in which are numbred 118 Parishes; is strengthened with six Castles, viz. Durham, Aukland, Raly, Bramspeth, Lumley, and Witton; and is traded unto by six Market-towns, whose names are as follow. Durham.

Durham, called by the Saxons, Dunholm, and by the Normans, Duresme; a City of good antiquity, dignified with the See of a Bishop, and of note for being the burial place of St. Cuthbert its raiser. It is no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on an easie ascent, and almost encompassed by the River Weare, over which it hath two large and spacious Stonebridges, which gives entrance into it built by William the Conquerour, which with its Wall, together with its strong and spacious Castle (of late made use of for the Bishops Palace) seated on the highest part of the Hill, and as it were between the two Bridges, makes it to be a place of a good strength. This City is fair and neatly compacted, conteining six Parish Churches, besides its Abbey or Cathedral, and its streets are well ordered, but its Suburbs are stragling. It is a place much inhabited and frequented by the Gentry of these parts, enjoyeth a good trade, and its Shop-keepers are well furnished with Commodities. It is beautified with fair buildings both publick and private, amongst which are its spacious Market-place; but above all its Cathedral, a large Structure, dedicated to St. Cuthbert, not much unlike Westminster-Abbey, and hath a lofty Towre in the midst, with two Spires at the West-end; adjoyning to which are the Houses of the Dean and twelve Prebends, fine buildings. The late Bishop, Dr. Jo. Cosins, expended vast sums in the re-edifying and beautifying of his Palaces at Durham, and Bishops Aukland, as also in the erecting of Hospitals, and a Library plentifully furnished with Books. This City hath its chief Market on Saturdays, which is well served with provisions, &c. Nevils Cross, a bloody Battle fought.

At Nevils Cross near Durham, on the 20 th of October, 1346. a bloody Battle was fought between the English and the Scotch, where David Bruce King of Scots, with divers of his Nobility and Gentry were taken Prisoners; the King being taken by one Copland, a man of a mean degree, but for his good service was made a Knight Baneret, and had the yearly pension of 200 l. during his life. Hartle-pool.

Hartle-pool, commodiously seated on the Seashoar (which encompasses it except towards the West) and surhounded with Rocks and Hills. It is an ancient Town Corporate, governed by a Major and Sub-officer, and was of greater account then now it is, being at present (though indifferent large) yet poor, and its Market disused; and were it not for its Harbour which is good, it would be less frequented.
Sunderland.

Sunderland, scituate on the Sea-shoar, at the mouth of the River Weare; a Town not large, nor its Market, which is on Fridays, very considerable; yet is it a place of a good trade for Sea-coal; and is also of some note for giving Title to the Right Honourable Robert Earl of Sunderland, Baron Spencer of Wormlayton; &c. Gates-head.

Gates-head, seated on the Tine, and so near to New-castle, that it may pass for its Suburbs. It is a Town of great antiquity, being one of the Roman Stations, and kept by the second band of the Thracians. Jarrow.
Near adjoyning to this Town is Jarrow, the birthplace of the venerable Bede, where there was in ancient time a Monastery. Tinemouth-haven.
And not far from Jarrow is Tinemouthhaven, a place of some note. Bishops-Aukland.

Bishops-Aukland, built by Anthony Beck; pleasantly seated on the side of a Hill, and between the River Weare, and the Rivulet Gaunless; of chief note, for its Castle which is the Bishops Sommer-Palace, now beautifully repaired; for its Chappel, which for curiosity of building, comes little short of any in England; and for its Bridge. The Market is here kept on Thursdays, which is indifferently provided with corn and provisions. Binchester.

Not far from this Town is Binchester, which in former times was a City of good account, called Benovium, and was a station of the Romans, as appears by the Romish Coyns there often dug up. Stainthorp.
Stainthorp, or Staindrop, seated on a branch of the Tees amongst Parks; a small Market-town, and hada Collegiate Church. Raby-Castle.
Near unto this Town is Raby-Castle, which Canute the Dane gave to the Church of Durham, with the Lands about it. Barnard-Castle.

Barnard-Castle, scituate in a bottom, and on the River Tees, and adjoyning to Marwood-park; an indifferent Town, of chief note for Stockings here made; and hath a small Market on Wednesdays. Darlington.

Darlington, seated in a Flat, and on the River Skerne, which falleth into the Tees: A Town of a good largeness, consisting of several streets, hath a spacious Market-place; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is very considerable, and well furnished with corn, living cattle, and all sorts of provisions. The Hell-kettles.
Near unto this Towns are three Pits, called the Hell-kettles, being exceeding deep, whose water is somewhat warm, and are said to come by an Earth-quake. Stocton.

Stocton, seated on the Tees, near its fall into the Sea, a place of a great trade for vending end exporting of corn and butter to London, and other parts: It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Major and Sub-officers, is well inhabited, and by reason of its commodious Port, it enjoyeth a good trade.

div1.n: ESSEX: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons
div1.head: ESSEX: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Essex with its hundreds

div1.p: ESSEX, a County very populous, and of a large extent, being from Haidon in the West, to Harwich in the East, something above 40 miles; and from Burbrock in the North, to Thurrockgray in the South 5; and makes in circumference 146 miles, or thereabouts. Its form is somewhat circular, except towards the East part, where it shooteth it self forth into the Sea, with several Promontories. Its Bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the German Ocean; on the South with the Thames, which severeth it from Kent; on the West with the Counties of Middlesex, Hartford, and Cambridge; and on the North with Suffolk, from which it is separated by the River Stower, as it is from Middlesex by the Ley. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, the Sea sending forth several of her branches, as the Stower, Blackwater, (where those excellent Oysters called Walfleet Oysters are caught) Crouch, Ley, &c. in all which are great plenty of Fish. Its fertility.

The soil may be esteemed fertile, and abounding in Grain, (though in some places it is sandy and barren;) and hath rich Pastures, which feed store of cattle. It is well clothed with wood, and hath variety of Parks; Is blest with a temperate and healthful Air, except towards the waters, which are somewhat aguish. Its Commodities.

It affords several good Commodities, as Cloths, Stuffs, Hopps, Butter, Cheese, Gun-powder, Cattle, Wood, Oysters, and principally Saffron (the dearest Commodity that England produceth) from which the Inhabitants reap good profit.
From the Isles of Foulness, Wallot, Osey, Northly, Horsey, Mersey and Canvey, are taken great abondance of Fish and Fowl. Ancient Inhabitants.
Its ancient Inhabitants known to Cæsar, were the Trinobantes; which name being lost when the Romans left the Land, it became part of the Kingdom of the East-Saxons.

This Shire in former times swarmed with Monks, where they had their Monasteries in several places; as at Colchester, Maldon, Waltham, Dunmow, Titley, Leege, Prithewell, Uggshall, Chelmesford, Earls-coln, Walden, or
Saffron-walden, Hatfield-Bradock, Hatfield-Peverel, St. Osiths, and elsewhere, all which were endowed with fair revenues, and continued in a flourishing condition, till suppressed by King Henry the Eighth. It is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which is now in the Person of the Right Honorable Arthur Capell Earl of Essex, &c. Its division.
It is divided into twenty Hundreds, in which are numbred 415 Parish Churches, and hath the conveniency of 21 Market-towns. Its chief places. Colchester.

Its chief places are Colchester, a City of great antiquity, being said to be built by Coilus the British Prince, 124 years after the birth of Christ, as appears by the pieces of ancient Coyn here often digged up. And here Lucius, Helena, and Constantine the first Christian King, Empress, and Emperour in the world, received their first breaths. It is a Town no less pleasantly, then commodiously seated on the South-side of the River Colne (from whence it took its name) about six miles from the Main, and on the ascent of a Hill, stret ching it self from East to West. It is begirt with a wall, having six Gates for entrance, and three Posterns in the West wall, besides nine Watch-towers. 'Twas once beautified with about fifteen Parish Churches, many of which are now reduced to ruin, and not made use of; and here were seveal fair structures, now much ruinated, as are its Inhabitants much impoverished, by the disloyal party in the late deplorable times: yet is it a place of good trade for Says, Bays, and other the like Draperies which are here made; and is of some note for the great quantities of excellent Oysters here taken. In this Town resideth abundance of Dutch, where for Divine Worship they have their Church. It is governed by two Bailiffs, twelve Aldermen, who are clothed in Scarlet, a Recorder, Town-Clark, with Sub-officers; is endowed with several immunities, hath the election of Burgesses; and for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, hath weekly a Market on Saturday, which is well served with provisions. Within this Town, towards the East, is mounted an old Castle, within the ruins of a Trench conteining about two Acres in circuit. St. Osith.

Not far from Colchester is St. Osith, a small Town, but of ancient note for the Virgin Osith, noble by birth, who wholly addicted her self to the service of God, and was stabbed to death by the Danish Pirates; and in memorial of her, she was honoured as a Saint by our Predecessors, who here built a house of regular Canons. Harwich.

Harwich, a strong Haven, or Sea-port- town, made so as well by Nature as Art, having three parts of it fenced about by the Sea, and the River Stower, whose strength was much augmented by Queen Elizabeth. The Town is not large, but well inhabited and frequented, especially by those that have relation to Sea affairs; and the rather by reason of its safe and commodious Harbour for Ships and Vessels to anchor in, it being oft- times (as occasion requireth) the station of the Navy Royal, which makes this Town to enjoy a good trade: and one advantage more it hath, as being the ready passage to Holland, and where the Packet-boats are kept for the same purpose; and the greatest inconveniency that this Town affordeth its Inhabitants, is the brackishnes of the waters, occasioned by its propinquity to the Sea; which defect they are forced to be supplyed with from remoter places. It is a Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. A fight between the English and the Danes.
Nigh unto this Town, in the mouth of the Stower, was a great and memorable Naval fight in Anno 884, between the English and the Danes. Isle of Horsey. The Ness.

About four miles Northwards from Harwich, is the Isle of Horsey, and about two miles further is the Ness, a Promontory well known to Seamen.
Gyants teeth here found.
And on this Shoar two Gyants teeth were found of a prodigious bigness; which by some were esteemed rather the teeth of Elephants then Men. Manytre.
Manytre, seated on the banks of the Stower, an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Maldon, of old Camulodunum.

Maldon, a Town of great antiquity, being the seat of Cunobelin King of the Trinobantes about the birth of Christ, who governed the East part of this Isle, and brought it under the Romans subjection, planting here a Colony; at which time it was a City of good repute, and called Camulodunum. This Town, Queen Bodicia in revenge of her wrongs, laid flat to the ground, at the time she stirred the people against Nero, with the slaughter of about 70000 of the Romans; sacking, firing, and destroying the said Colony. See Cambden, fol. 448. And this slaughter (as Cambden noteth) was foretold by sundry Prodigies. For in their Senate-house unusual noises were heard; In the Theater, howlings; Their Image of Victory placed up in the City was turned backwards, and fallen down; Houses were seen under water, and the arm of the Sea below it overflowed the banks, and its water resembled the colour of blood. Isles of Northey and Osey. This Town is seated on an arm of the Sea, about six or seven miles from the Main, before which lye two small Isles called Northey and Osey. Its Haven is commodious, and the Town for its largness, having one street about a mile in length, and for the number of its Inhabitants, may deservedly be numbred with those of the first rank in this County, (and is in Records named the Burgh of Maldon) having large immunities granted unto it, amongst which it hath the Election of Parliament men; is governed by two Bailiffs, six Aldermen, eighteen Brethren, a Recorder, High Steward, &c. and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is very considerable for fish and fowl, and well served with provision.
In the parts adjoyning to this Town are good pastures, which feed store of Cattle, especially sheep, of whose milk they make Cheese. Ithanchester.

Not far from Malden, on the utmost Promontory stood an ancient City of the Romans, called Ithanchester, where the Fortenses with their Captain in the declination of the Roman Empire kept their Station or Guard, for the security of these parts against the Saxon Rovers; nothing of which is now remaining, save the ruins of a thick wall, where many Roman coyns have been found. And out of the ruins of this City was raised St. Peters upon the wall. Witham.
Also not far distant from Maldon is Witham, a fair thorough-fare Town, built by King Edward the Elder, in Anno 914. Cogshall.

Cogshall, scituate on the River Blackwater, or Pant, over which it hath a Bridge; being in former time well known for a Priory of Cluniack Monks, built by King Stephen. The Town is large, and hath a good Market for provisions, &c. on Saturdays. Braintre.
Braintre, seated on a Hill, a large Town, and hath a good Market on Wednesdays for corn and provisions. Haulsteed.
Haulsteed, seated on the River Colne, which hath a good Market on Fridays for corn and provisions. Walden.

Walden, or Saffron-walden, a large, fair, well inhabited, and frequented Town, seated on an ascent, amongst pleasant fields of Saffron, which here grow in a plentiful manner, from which the owners reap good profit. It is a town Corporate, (being so made by K. Edw. the sixth) doth enjoy several immunities, and is governed by a Treasurer, two Chamberlains, and the
Commonalty. In times past it was famous for a Castle of the Magnavilles, now reduced to ruin; and an Abbey adjoyning where the Magnavilles Founders thereof were buried. It hath a great and considerable Market kept on Saturdays, which is sufficiently stored with corn and all provisions; and by the grant of Maud the Empress, here was a Market kept on Sundays, but long since discontinued. Audley-end.

Not far distant from this Town, is that stately house Audley-end, seated low, and well accommodated with water, built by the Right Honourable Thomas Howard Earl of Suffolk, then Treasurer of England; A House, which may deservedly be esteemed no wayes inferiour to those of the first degree in the Kingdom, now belonging to his Majesty King Charles the Second. Thaxted.
Thaxted, a large Major-town, but its Market, which is on Fridays, is but small. Dunmow.

Dunmow of Dunmaug, an ancient and large Town, (where Juga in Anno 1111 founded a Priory) no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on an easie ascent; and hath a good Market for corn and provisions on Saturdays. Hatsield,
Hatsield, or Hatsield Bradock, seated on a branch of the Lea, nigh unto which is a Forest so called, hath a small Market on Saturdays. Chelmesford.

Chelmesford, scituate in the Road, and between two Rivers, over which are Bridges for the conveniency of passage; It is a fair, large and well frequented Town, where the Assizes for the County are usually held; and hath a very great Market for corn, provisions, &c. on Fridays; and here Malcome King of the Scots, erected a Religious House for the service of God. Raleigh.

Not far from this Town are seated the Isles of Wallop, and Fowlness, that is, the Promontory of Fowls, which hath a Church in it, and when the Sea is at the lowest Ebb, it is passable over on Horseback. Canvey Isle.
Also not far from Raleigh lyeth a small Isle, called Canvey Isle, lowly seated, of a rich soil, and feedeth good store of sheep. Hornden.
Hornden, scituate on a small River, which at a little distance falleth into the Thames, where it beareth the name of the Hope, hath a Market on Saturdays, which is not very considerable. Tilbury.

Nigh unto this Town Southwards is Tilbury, seated on that part of the Thames called Tilbury-hope, a small Town, or rather Village, but of good antiquity, being the seat of Bishop Chad, who in Anno 630. brought into the Pale of the Church the East-Saxons. Billerakey.
Billerakey, scituate on a Hill, a good Market- town on Tuesdays for corn and provisions. Brentwood.

Brentwood, or Burntwood, seated on a Hill, and on the high Road, a place of good antiquity, where Isabel Countess of Bedford, Daughter to King Edward the Third, built a Chappel to the memory of St. Thomas of Canterbury. It is a good and well inhabited Town, and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is well served with provisions, &c. Casaromagus an ancient City of the Romans.

Some Authors are of opinion, That nigh unto Brentwood stood the ancient and eminent City of Casaromagus of the Romans; but if so, it is long since worn away, not leaving so much as any of its Ruins to testifie the same.
Rumford.

Rumford, a large, thorough-fare, and well frequented and inhabited Town, seated in the liberty of Haveril, which enjoyeth large Immunities, being an ancient retiring place of the Kings, to which (as 'tis said) St. John Baptist sent a Pilgrim with a Ring to Edward the Confessor. This Town of Rumford is of chief note for its great Swine-Market on Tuesdays, but for corn and provisions, which it is plentifully served with, it hath a Market on Wednesdays. Barkin.

Barkin, scituate not far from the Thames, on the River Roding, and in a very unhealthful Air; of chief note for its Nunnery founded by Erkenwalt Bishop of London; a place of no great account, and hath a small Market on Saturdays. Waltham Abbey.

Waltham, or Waltham Abbey, so called from its Abbey, seated on the River Ley, where it formeth several eights, or small Isles, and in a large Forest so called, well stored with Deer, and other Game; It is a Town of some note, and hath a Market on Tuesdays. Copt-hall.

Nigh unto this Town is Copt-hall, or Coppicehall, so called from woods thereabouts; a fine uniform Pile of building, delightfully seated on an eminence, and in the midst of a Park, first erected at the charge of the Abbot of Waltham, now the seat of the Right Hon. Lionel Earl of Middlesex, &c. Epping-street.
Eppingstreet, not far distant from Waltham, a Town of good account, and hath two great Markets weekly, on Thursdays for cattle, and on Fridays for all sorts of provisions. Chepping-Onger.
Chepping-Onger, a small but well seated Town, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays.

div1.n: GLOCESTER: BEING Part of the DOBUNI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: GLOCESTER: BEING Part of the DOBUNI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.
div1.p: GLOCESTERSHIRE, a pleasant, healthful, and fertile County, yielding plenty of corn, and fruits in such great abundance, that the High-wayes, and Lanes are beset with Apple, Pear, and Plumb-trees, which grow naturally without in- grafting, and are of an excellent taste; also here are (and formerly were) a great many Vineyards, of which good wine was made. Here are fed abundance of cattle, and great flocks of sheep, (especially about Coteswold) whose wool is so much esteemed by strangers for its fineness; and of this wool the Inhabitants make great quantities of Cloth, which finds vent throughout all England, and divers foreign Countries. Its natural Commodities

The principal Commodities that this County produceth, are Corn, Wool, Cloth, Iron, Steel, Wood and Timber, Fruits, Sider, and formerly Tobacco, before it was prohibited the planting. Its chief Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, amongst which are the Isis, Stroud, Churne, Avon, Wye; and above all the famous River Severn, which for broadness of chanel, swiftness of stream, (even like unto a whirl-pool, raising up the sands from the bottom, winding and driving them upon heaps, and oft-times overflowing her banks, proving troublesome to Vessels) and for plentifulness of Salmon, and other excellent Fish, may deservedly be numbred with any River in England of the first ranck. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds the Counties of Warwick and Oxford; for its Southern, those of Wilts and Somerset; for its Western, those of Monmouth and Hereford; and for its Northern, that of Worcester. Its extent.

Its extent from Lechlade in the East, to Huntsham in the West, is about 26 miles; and from Bristol in the South to Clifford in the North, about 48; and in circumference about 138 miles. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants were the Dobuni; but betwixt the Rivers of Severn and the Wye, part of the Silures, or Inhabitants of South-wales were seated. And when the Saxons became Masters of the Coun-
try, it was allotted to the Kingdom of the Mercians. Its division.

It is, or may be divided into four general parts, in which are thirty Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp, in which are numbred 280 Parish Churches, and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, hath 25 Market-towns.

The Part lying Eastward riseth up with Hills, and is called Cotteswold, which graiseth abundance of sheep, whose wool is exceeding fine: the middle part lyeth low, and watered with the Severn, which maketh it a most fertile Plain; and the part Westward on the further side of the Severn, is overspread with wood, beareth the name of Dean Forest, and affordeth excellent Timber-trees for the building of ships. Great store of Iron is made in this Forest, where there are divers Furnaces and Forges for the working the same. Religious Houses.

Places set apart for Religious uses in this Shire, were at Tewkesbury, Glocester, Barkley, Circester, Deorhurst, Minching, Kinswood, Winchcombe, and Hales; which last was built with no small charge by Richard Earl of Cornwall, King of the Romans, wherein himself and his Lady were interred. Their Son Edmond brought out of Germany the blood of Hales; supposed (as falsly said) to be part of that which Christ shed upon the Cross, which made this place of Hales to be sufficiently thronged with Pilgrimes to pay their worship to the same. This County is very populous, well replenished with Gentry, and filled with good Towns, the chief of which are as followeth. Bristoll.

Bristoll, seated between the Avon and the Froom, which five miles from thence falleth into the Severn; the River Avon dividing it into two parts, as the Thames doth London and Southwark, but joyned together by a fair Stone-bridge, so covered with Houses, that passing it, it seemeth rather a street then a Bridge; and also in two Counties, to wit, one and the greatest in this County, and the other in Somersetshire, but it will owe subjection to neither, being an entire County incorporate of its self, enjoying large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and governed by its peculiar Magistrates, as a Major, Court of Aldermen, two Sheriffs, and other Sub-officers, which are clothed in Scarlet, as the Magistrates of London, and other eminent Cities of this Kingdom. This place, by the ancient Britains was called Caerdernant-Badon, that is, a sweet and delightful City, and indeed its scituation and buildings, as well publique as private, doth make it true, being adorned with many fair and well built Edifices, and is of far more beauty then antiquity. Its streets are so neatly ordered, (by reason of the River Avon, which runeth through it, together with the common sinks and shores under ground) that no filth or ordure is to be seen to anoy its Inhabitants: and for the better keeping the streets clean, they imploy no carts but instead thereof make use of sledges. It is a City of a large extent, conteining eighteen Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral dedicated to St. Austin, founded by Robert Fitz Harding, son to a King of Denmark, who stored it with Regular Canons; at present a fair structure, which hath six Prebenas, and was made an Episcopal See by King Henry the Eighth, and hath a well furnished Colledge. In the East-end of the City stood a Castle built by Robert, Consul of Glocester, bastard son to Henry the First, wherein King Stephen was kept a Prisoner by Maud the Empress, which Castle was demolished by Oliver Cromwel, and now built into streets, called Castle- street, and Castle-green. It is dignified with the title of an Earldom, which belongeth to the Right Honorable George Earl of Bristol, &c. It is begirt with a wall, and further defended Fortifications. Its Port is
good; and its principal Key stands on the Froom, which at Spring-tides doth flow about 40 foot, bringing in ships of a very great burthen; and by reason of its commodiousness for shipping, is a place exceeding well inhabited and frequented by Merchants and Trades-men, the one driving a very considerable trade to most parts of the known world; and the other as great within Land, to Wales, Shropshire, and other Counties; and for which cause, together with its plentifulness of all sorts of provisions, which its Markets (which are kept on Wednesdays and Saturdays) abound with, next after London, this City may justly claim priority of all others in England.
It is of note for its Bristol stones, taken out of St. Vincents Rock near adjoyning; as also for its hot Well of a medicinal nature at the bottom of the Rock. City of Glocester.

Glocester, a City of good antiquity, built by the Romans, where they planted a Colony to people it. It lyeth stretched out in length on the Severn, over which it hath a fair Bridge, and pleasantly seated on an easie ascent, the streets descending every way from the Cross; and beautified with a handsome Colledge, and many neat buildings: The City is not large, but well inhabited and frequented, enjoying a good trade; is the See of a Bishop, to which belongeth a Dean and six Prebends. And for Divine Worship hath twelve Churches, besides its Abbey or Cathedral, dedicated to St. Peter, which was raised out of the ruins of an ancient and fair Church, built by the vertuous Edelfled sister to King Edward the Elder, wherein she was afterwards interred. This Church is at present a fair and beautiful building, consisting of a continued Window work; where lyeth, under a Monument of Alablaster, the body of the unfortunate King Edward the Second, who at Barkley-Castle was barbarously murthered by the cruelty of Isabel his wife: And here lyeth the body of Lucius the first Christian King. It hath large Cloysters, and an excellent whispering place. It was once strengthened with a wall, (except on that part which is seated on the River) now reduced to ruin. It was first won from the Britains by Cheulin the primier King of the West-Saxons, in Anno 570. After which it greatly flourished under the Mercians; where Ofrick King of the Northumbers, by the permission of Ethelred King of the Mercians, founded a most stately Monastery of Nuns, whereof Kineburgh, Eadburgh, and Eve, Queens of the Mercians, were successively Prioresses each after the other. This City is a County within it self, is governed by a Major, two Sheriffs, twelve Aldermen, a Recorder, and other Sub-officers, enjoyeth large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is well furnished with Commodities, and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well provided with all provisions, and very great for corn and cattle. A'ney Isle.

Nigh to this City is a place called Alney Isle, so made by the Severn, in which Edmond Ironside King of the English-Saxons, and Canutus the Dane, after many conflicts, and bloody battles, in single combate hand to hand here fought; and in the end agreed to part the Kingdom, which they joyntly governed, till Treason took away the life of King Edmond, and left the Dane sole Monarch. Circester.

Circester, or Cirencester, seated on the River Churn, over which it hath a Bridge, and in the Woulds, very commodious for Mills. It was a City of great account in the time of the Romans, whose ruinous walls (yet to be seen) which conteined two miles in circuit, as also the Roman Coyns, Checker-work pavements, and engraven Marble-stones, that have oft been digged up, sufficiently evidence its fame and antiquity. And here the Consular-port, or Foss-wayes of the Romans met, and crossed each other.
This City was taken from the Britains by Cheulin King of the West- Saxons, at which time he brought Glocester under his subjection; afterwards it was possessed by the Mercians, and so continued untill the coming of the Normans: but it was sore afficted by the merciles Danes, who raged in these parts, under the command of Gurmund, who (according to report) by a stratagem in tying fire to the wings of Sparrows, it was consumed to ashes, which did occasion it to be called afterwards the Sparrows City. Never since which firing it hath been inhabited according to its extent, the Town now not conteining one fourth part, the remainder being made use of for Pasture grounds. It had an Abbey said to be built by the Saxons, which was afterwards repaired by King Henry the First for black Canons, and also was strengthened with a Castle, both which are long since demolished. As to the present state of this City it is a Borough-town, enjoyeth large immunities, electeth Parliament men, and hath two considerable Markets every week; on Mondays, chiefly for corn, and on Fridays for Wool, Yarn, and provisions. Tewksbury.

Tewksbury, of good account for making of Woollen-cloth, and for the best Mustard in the Kingdom. Noted in times past for its ancient Monastery founded by Dodo the powerful Mercian, in Anno 715, where he kept his Royal Court: but most memorable for that bloody Battle here fought in Anno 1471, between the house of York and Lancaster, where (as Cambden noteth) the Lancastrians received a total overthrow; in which conflict many were slain, more taken prisoners, and divers beheaded; where the young Prince Edward, the only Son of King Henry the Sixth, (who was about the age of twelve years) had his brains dashed out in a most shameful manner, and their power so weakened, and courage so abated, that they never after came into the Field against King Edward the Fourth. It is a fair and large Borough, or Town Corporate, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is commodiously seated on and between three Rivers, the Severn, Avon, and the Swilyat, over which are as many Bridges, is well inhabited, and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well provided with corn and cattle. Lemington.
Not far from Tewksbury is Lemington, where the Romans had a station, which is testisied by the pieces of Roman Coyn there ploughed up. Campden.
Campden, or Camden, which gives Title to the Right Honourable Baptist Noel, Viscount Camden. A Town of good account, and hath a small Market on Wednesdays. Winchcombe.

Winchcombe, seated near Sudley Castle and Park, where Kenulph King of the Mercians erected an Abbey; and on the same day he hallowed it, he released Edbricht a King of Kent, whom he kept as his Prisoner. It is seated in a deep Bottom, is, or lately was of note for its planting of Tobacco, and hath a small Market on Saturdays. Stow on the would.
Stow on the would, seated bleakly on a Hill, and destitute of wood and water; a small Market-town on Thursdays, and but meanly inhabited. Cheltenham.
Cheltenham, seated on a branch of the Severn, a small Town, but hath a good Market on Thursdays for corn. Newent.
Newent, scituate on or near a branch of the Severn, a mean Town, and hath a small Market on Fridays. Blackley,
Blackley, seated on a branch of the Severn, hath a Market on Wednesdays. Newnham.

Newnham, on the West side of the Severn, a Town Corporate, governed by a Major, and twelve Aldermen, and hath a Market on Fridays.
Dean Magna,
Dean Magna, so called from the Forest of Dean, wherein it is seated, an indisferent good Town; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is well served with corn and provisions. Panswick,
Panswick, commodiously seated both for a sweet Air, and the conveniency of wood, water, and stone for building, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Stroud,

Stroud, scituate on the River so called, where it hath a Bridge, on the banks of which are placed abundance of Cloth or Fulling-mills: It is a well built Town, whose houses for the most part are of stone; hath a good Market, chiefly for provisions and yarn, on Fridays, and is of chief note for making and dying of Cloths. Leonards Stanley.
Leonards Stanley, not far from the Stroud, a small Market-town on Saturdays. Minching-Hampton.
Minching-Hampton, seated on the Cotes- would; a small Town, where there was formerly a Nunnery, and hath an indifferent Market kept on Tuesdays. Tetbury.

Tetbury, on the edge of the County towards Wiltshire, an indifferent good Town, whose chief Magistrate is a Bailiff. It is beautified with a fair Market-house, enjoyeth a great trade, and its Market, which is on Wednesdays for Corn, Cattle, Cheese, Mault, Yarn, Wool, Provisions, and all other things, is esteemed one of the best in these parts. Barkley.

Barkley, honoured with a Barony, and gives Title to the Right Honourable George Lord Barkley, &c. It is seated on a branch of the Severn, hath a small Market on Tuesdays; and is a place of good Antiquity, where there was formerly a Nunnery, of which Mr. Cambden relateth a fine story of a Confederate of the Earl of Goodwins, who got the Lady Abbess, and divers of the Nuns with child, and then did the Earl relate the same to the King, who procured the Lady Abbess and the Nuns to be turned out, and then begged it for himself. Dursley.

Dursley, seated on, or near a branch of the Severn, formerly strengthened with a Castle, which is now more then ruinous; The Town is good, is much inhabited by Clothiers, and hath a small Market on Thursdays. Wotton under-Edge,
Wotton under-Edge, as seated under the Hills, a good Major-town, much inhabited by Clothiers, and hath a good Market on Fridays. Horton.
Horton, a Town of no great account, nor is its Market, which is on Tuesdays. Wickware.
Wickware, a poor Major-town, but well seated, and hath a small Market on Mondays. Chipping Sodbury.

Chipping Sodbury, scituate in a bottom of the Downs, and in the Road; an indifferent good Borough-town, which hath a very great Market for cheese on Thursdays, which is also well served with corn and provisions. Marshsield.
Marshsield, seated on the Cotes-would, a small Town, whose Market is on Tuesdays. Durham.

Near unto this Town is Durham, a small Town, but remarkable for that Ceaulin the Saxon slew three Princes, or eminent Lords of the Britains, Condidan, Commeail, and Fariemeiol, with some others, and for ever dispossessed the Britains of this Countrey. Thornbury
Thornbury near the Severn, a Major-town of some account, and hath a small Market on Saturdays. Fairsield.
Fairsied, not far from Thornbury, hath a new erected Market on Thursdays, which in time is like to be of some note.
Having thus given you an Account of the Market-towns of this County, in the next place a word or two of the Forest of Dean. Forest of Dean.

The Forest of Dean lyeth in the West side of the County, from which it is divided by the Severn; a place of a large tract of ground, extending it self in length about 20 miles, and in breadth about 10, within which are numbred three Hundreds, 23 Parish Churches, one Castle, one Abbey, three Market-towns, and one Major-town, and the Common (thereof besides the Purleus and Abbey-woods) is said to contain 32000 Acres of ground. This place was about forty years since so woody, that men durst not pass thorow it in great winds. Here are store of Iron-mines, Coal-mines, or Delfs, which run North and South into other Counties; also great store of stones for many uses, and some of a very great largeness, said to be about eight or nine foot in length, es pecially about Stapledge-hill, which is the most noted Hill in the Forest, being about a mile and a half in length, and a mile in breadth; a place yet sufficiently well clothed with wood, and is the receptacle of wild Beasts and Fowl of sundry sorts: nor is it destitute of water, for in the West there ariseth three Springs of water, which soon fall into one Brook, and drive several Mills; also on the North side are many Fountains, which drive the Iron-mills; nor are the East and South parts deficient of fresh Springs, in all which are taken excellent fish.

div1.n: HANTSHIRE, Or the COUNTY of SOUTHAMPTON: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: HANTSHIRE, Or the COUNTY of SOUTHAMPTON: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.
div1.p: HANTSHIRE, a County of no large extent, being in length from Christ-church in the South-west, to Silchester in the North, about 46 miles; and in breadth from Petersfield in the East, to Tidworth in the West, about 30, which makes its circumference to be about 154 miles; besides the Isle of Wight, which is part of this County, which alone is 60 miles in circuit. Its Bounds.
It is bounded on the East with Sussex and Surrey; on the South with the British Seas; on the West with the Counties of Dorset and Wilts; and on the North with Berkshire. Its fertility. Commodities

It is of a fertile soil for corn, hath rich Pastures which feed store of Cattle; enjoyeth a temperate Air, and is well clothed with wood; it affordeth plenty of Iron, which is here wrought from the Mines; also wool, of which they make abundance of Cloths and Kersies, likewise excellent honey; and for all Commodities of the Sea it is well accommodated, having several good Ports or Havens. Its Rivers.
It is well watered with Rivers, the chief amongst which are the Avon and the Test. Religious Houses.
For Religious worship this County had several Houses; as at Southampton, Winchester, Christ-church, Titchfield, Beaulieu, Whorwell, Hyde, Redbridge, and Rumsey. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants before the Romans on the North, were the Segontians, which submitted to Julius Cæsar; and on the South the Belgæ and the Regni, who were subdued by Plausius and Vespatian the Romans.

And for the further security of this County, here were along the Shoar several Castles, as Hurst, Southampton, Porchester, Calshot, Worth, St. Andrews, and the South-castle, besides some Block-houses, or Bullwarks. And
within land those of Malwood,Winchester, and Odiam, a place so strong, that in the reign of King John, thirteen English men defended the Fort for fifteen dayes against the powerful affault of Lewis of France. New Forest.

In this County is New-Forest, formerly called Yiene, being about 30 miles in compass; in which said tract William the Conquerour (for the making the said Forest a Harbour for Wild-beasts for his Game) caused 36 Parish Churches, with all the Houses thereto belonging, to be pulled down, and the poor Inhabitants left succourless of house or home. But this wicked act did not long go unpunished, for his Sons felt the smart thereof; Richard being blasted with a pestilent Air; Rufus shot through with an Arrow; and Henry his Grand-child, by Robert his eldest son, as he pursued his Game, was hanged amongst the boughs, and so dyed. This Forest at present affordeth great variety of Game, where his Majesty oft-times withdraws himself for his divertisement.

It is severed into forty Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp, in which are numbred 253 Parish Churches; and is traded unto by 18 Market-towns, besides those in the Isle of Wight, which I shall anon treat of. Winchester.

Winchester, called by the Britains, Caer Gwent, and by the Romans, Venta Belgarum; a City of great antiquity, being built by King Rudhudibras about 900 years before the birth of Christ; In the Romans time it was of note for being the place where the rich embroideries were made for their Emperours: In the time of the Saxons it was twice consumed by fire, and by them rebuilt, and made the Royal Seat of the West Saxon Kings, and the chief Episcopal See; and here did Egbert and Elfred, their most renowned Monarchs, receive their Crowns and regal Scepters; and here K. æthclstane erected six houses for his Mint: But the Danes over-runing all, this City sufficiently felt their fury in the reign of King Ethelbright; and in the time of the Normans, after its misfortune by fire, it was repaired, and honoured with the keeping of the publick Records of the Kingdome; and lastly it was sore oppressed in the time of the civil Wars of Maud and Stephen; but in the reign of King Edward the third, it began to raise up its drooping head, and was by him appointed the Mart for Wooll and Cloth. This City is also famous for being the Sepulcher of so many Kings and Queens: amongst which, those of most note were Egbert in Anno 836. King Ethelwolfe son to Egbert, in Anno 857. Elfred the Founder of Oxford, in Anno901. Elswith Queen to Elfred, in Anno 904. King Edmund in Anno 924, with his sons Elfred and Elsward. King Edred in Anno 955. King Edwy in Anno 956. Emme in Anno 1032, with her Danish Lord Canute, in Anno 1035. Hardicanute; son to Canute, in Anno 1042. And to conclude, Richard and Rufus of the Normans, in Anno 1100. It is a City pleasantly seated in a Valley, betwixt Hills, and on the banks of a delightful River, which after about ten miles course falleth into an arm of the Sea, on which Southampton is seated.
