As to its extent, it is a place of about a mile and an half in circuit within the walls, which gives entrance into its Suburbs by four Gates. It is a fair City, and garnished with good buildings, both publique and private, though not without waste, and unbuilt ground within its walls; for Divine worship, hath at present but five Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral dedicated to the holy Trinity, a large and beautiful Structure, wherein are interred those Kings and Queens before named; adjoyning to which are the Prebends houses: other buildings of note are the Bishops Palace, called Woolvey-house. A fine Hall where the Assizes and Sessions are kept for the County; in which said Hall hangeth up King Arthurs round table, which is kept as a Monument. Without the City in the Suburbs is
a fair Colledge, called Winchester Colledge or School, Laving a Warden, Masters, and an Usher, and is endowed with liberal maintenance. It is a place well inhabited and frequented; and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well provided with all sorts of provisions, especially that on Saturdays.
It is dignified with the Title of a Marquess, which at present is invested in the person of the Right Honorable John Paulet, Marquess of Winchester, &c.

The Bishops of Winchester are Chancellors to the See of Canterbury; and successively Prelates of the noble Order of the Garter. This Diocess conteineth (besides this County, with the Isle of Wight) Surrey, and the Isles of Jarsey and Garnsey. It hath two Arch-Deacons, the one of Winchester, and the other of Surrey. St. Crosses Hospital.

Near unto Winchester is St. Crosses Hospital, pleasantly seated on a fine River, and endowed with liberal maintenance for the relief of twelve poor men, called Brothers, having a Master, Steward, and Sub-officers; and here, according to the institution of the House, bread and drink is given to all Travellers that will require the same. St. Mary Magdalens-hill.
On St. Mary Magdalens-hill, within a mile of this City was an Hospital, now ruinous. Southampton.

Southampton, commodiously seated on an Arm of the Sea, capable to receive ships of a considerable burthen to its Keys, which are fair and very convenient for the lading and unlading of goods: the opportunity of which hath made it to be a place of a good trade, and well inhabited by Merchants, and Shop-keepers. The Town is well built and large, numbring five Parish Churches, besides an Hospital called Gods-house, wherein the unfortunate Richard Earl of Cambridge, who was beheaded for Treason lyeth enterred; and for its security is fenced about with a double Ditch and strong walls, on which are several Watch-towers, and hath seven Gates for entrance; And the better to secure its Haven, here was built a strong Castle, which time hath reduced to ruin, seated on so great an eminence, that it cannot be ascended but by steps. This Town is said to be raised out of the ruins of the ancient Clausentum of the Romans, where they had a strong Fort, the better to secure the South-coast of these parts from the Saxons. And here it was that the powerful Canute, caused his Chair to be placed on the Sea-shoar, and proudly commanded the Waves not to approach him, or come upon his Land, but being disobeyed, he acknowledged God the Supream Lord and Governour, and in a religious devotion gave up his Crown to the rood at Winchester. It is at present a Town and County of it self, governed by a Major, Bailifss, and Burgesses, enjoyeth large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which at present is in the person of the Right Honorable Charles Palmer, Earl of Southampton, and Baron Limrick, &c. and its Markets on Tuesdays and Thursdays, are not very great, except for provisions. Portsmouth.

Portsmouth, at present one of the best Garisons and Sea-port-towns in England, by reason of its commodious scituation, which makes it to be a place exceedingly resorted unto by shipping; and is one of the usual places or stations for the Navy Royal, where his Majesty hath his Store-houses, and Docks for the building and equipping his ships; which adds no small benefit to the Town, which is large, well built, very populous, enjoyeth a good trade, and is well provided with all necessaries; amongst which, hath store of courteous women, who are much visited by the hot and eager Seamen. This Town is seated in the Isle of Porsey, so made by the Sea, and its
two arms, which on the North part are conjoyned by a River, over which is a Bridge, which giveth entrance into the said Island; And being a place. of such great concernment, it is exceedingly fortified, having two strong Castles, the one seated on the one side, and called South-castle; and the other on the other, and called North-castle; with other Fortifications and places of strength, the better to secure the ships in the Road or Haven. It is a Town Corporate, governed by several Magistrates, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. The Inhabitants of late have found out a Spring of fresh water, which is very serviceable unto them; and since the new buildings and pavement of the streets, the Town is esteemed much more healthier. Here are weekly two Markets, on Thursdays and Saturdays, which are very considerable for provisions. Haling Isle. Thorney Isle.
Eastwards of Portsmouth are the Isles of Haling and Thorney, both which have their Towns so called. Hanant.
Hanant, seated near Haling Island, once a small Market-town, but now disused. Petersfield.
Petersfield, scituate on the Road from London to Portsmouth, a pretty handsome Town, and hath a small Market on Saturdays. Alreston.

Alreston, couched betwixt Hills, and near the Great Pond so called, sufficiently stored with fish and wild-fowl. It is an old and ill built Town, but indifferent large, and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is very considerable, especially for sheep and provisions. Alton

Alton, a well wooded Town, seated on the Road, and on a small River. The Town is pretty large, but poor, and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is very great for provisions, where also are sold good store of living cattle. Odiam.

Odiam, seated on the Road, a Borough Corporate, in former time belonging to the Bishops of Winchester; and of note for being the place where King David the second of Scotland was kept a prisoner; the Town is not large, but its Market, since it was changed from Fridays to Saturdays, is pretty well served with provisions. An ancient Castle or Fortress.

Near unto Odiam stands the remains of an ancient and once strong Castle, where, in the Reign of King John, thirteen English men for fifteen dayes kept out the Dauphin of France and his Army, who sorely assaulted it.
And near adjoyning to this Town is a Park, through which runneth a fine River which driveth several Mills. Basingstoke.

Basingstoke, scituate on a small Brook well stored with Trouts, and on the Road, being a great through-fare Town for the Western parts. It is a Town Corporate, and governed by a Major, seven Aldermen, as many Burgesses, a High Steward, a Recorder, &c. and the Market is kept on Wednesdays, which is very good for corn, especially barley.

On the other side of the Brook, was solitarily seated an ancient and fair Chappel, dedicated to the Holy Ghost, in the Roof of which was lively portraied the Prophets, Apostles, and Disciples of Jesus Christ, which said Chappel is now reduced to ruin. Basing-house.
Not far distant is Basing-house, once a stately and beautiful Structure, but suffered much in the late unhappy wars. Silchester.

Silchester, a place of great antiquity, said to be the ancient City of Vindonum, and built by Constantius son to Constantine the Great, whose monument was seen in the City; and also another Constantine did here put on the purple Robe against Honorius; and here the warlike Arthur was crowned. It was a place of a large extent, conteining within its walls about 80 Acres of ground, and became dismantled by the Danish Rovers.
Kingsclear.
Kingsclear, in former times the residence of the Saxon Kings; seated in the Woodlands, a small Market-town on Tuesdays. Burghclear.
Burghclear, seated under a high Hill, on the top of which is a warlike Rampier yet to be seen, where there is now a Beacon. Andover.

Andover, a large Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men; seated by a River, and on the Road, being a great thorough-fare Town for the Western parts; and hath a very great Market on Saturdays. Stock-bridge.
Stock-bridge, a thorough-fare and Borough- town, which hath the election of Parliament men. It had formerly a Market, which is now disused. Rumsey.
Rumsey, seated on a fair River, a large and ancient Town, much inhabited by Clothiers; and its Markct, which is on Saturdays, is very well served with all provisions. Ringwood.
Ringwood, a Town of some account in the time of the Saxons, seated near the Sea, and on a River; a large Town, and hath a great Market on Wednesdays for cattle, corn, and provisions. Christ-church.

Christ-church, scituate betwixt two Rivers, and on an arm of the Sea; In the time of the Saxons it was fortified with a Castle, and beautified with an ancient Church of Prebendaries. It is at present a good Town, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath a good Market. Lemington.
Lemington, seated on a Hill near the Sea, hath the election of Parliament men, and a Market on Hurst-castle.
Not far from this Town is Hurst-castle, which is seated in the extream point of a neck of Land which shooteth it self forth into the Sea, reguarding the Isle of Wight. Whitchurch.
Whitchurch, an ancient, though poor Major and Borough-town; which hath an inconsiderable Market, and electeth Parliament men. A Description of the Isle of WIGHT. Its scituation.

THE Isle of Wight, part of the County of Hantshire, and in the Diocess of Winchester, is seated in the British Seas, and may seem to have been joyned to Hantshire; for from Hurst-castle, which is seated on a languet of Land which runneth forth into the Sea, it is not above a mile to the Western part of this Isle, and from Portsmouth not above six. And its Southern part lyeth opposite to France, from which it is distant about 35 Leagues. Its form.
The form of this Isle is long, being about 20 miles in length, and where broadest 12; and hath about 60 miles of Sea-coast. See Mr. Cambden.

This Isle became subject to the Roman Scepter by Vespasian, whilst he served as a private Souldier under the Banner of Claudius Cæsar: afterwards it was subdued by Cerdic the English Saxon; then Wolpher King of the Mercians brought it to his obedience, and gave it to his God-child Edelwalch, King of the South-Saxons, who afterwards being slain, and Aruandus the petty King of the Island made away, Cadwalla King of the West- Saxons joyned it to his Dominions, and barbarously murthered almost all the native Inhabitants; and in the end it became under the civil Government of the County of Hantshire. Mr. Speed.
Mr. Speed saith, that in Anno 1176. it rained a showre of bloud for about two hours in this Isle. The air and fertility.

It is blest with a healthful and delightful Air; and is of a fertile soil both for Corn and Pasture, every way answering the Husbandmans industry and expence; and hath plenty of Conies, Hares, Partridges, Phesants, Sea-fowl, and other Game; and for excellent fish may compare with
any Country whatsoever: and in brief, it wanteth nothing either for delight or profit, except wood, and that they are supplyed with from Hant- shire; yet is it not altogether destitute thereof, its Northern parts being supplyed therewith. Commodities
The Commodities which this Isle affordeth, are corn, cattle, fish, sea-fowl, and wool, which is esteemed very good and fine. Its strength.

It is a place of a great strength, being fortified both by Art and Nature; for besides its Castles, Block-houses, and Forts, together with a strong Militia, under the command of the Governour for his Majesty, which is ready upon beat of Drum, it is fenced about with a ridge of craggy Rocks and Cliffs, with dangerous banks; amongst which those of most note to Seamen are the Needles, the Shingles, Brambles, and the Mixon, &c. Its Churches.
It is very populous, and garnished with 36 Parish Churches. Its chief places are Newport.

Newport, in former time called Medena, or the new Burgh of Meden, from the division of the Country, which is divided into East, and West Meden. A large, populous, well frequented and Major-town; and at present, the only Market for the Isle is kept here on every Wednesday and Saturday, which are very considerable for provisions, corn, cattle, and other commodities. It is seated within four miles of the Sea, and on a navigable Creek for small Vessels to the very Key, which doth much facilitate its trade. This Town hath the election of Parliament men, and is dignisied with the Title of an Earldom, the present Earl being that Right Honorable Montjoy Blunt, Earl of Newport, &c. Carisbrook-castle.
Not far from this Town is Carisbrook- castle, seated in the midst of the Isle; said to be founded by Whitgar the Saxon, where in former time stood a Priory; and at Quarre a Nunnery. Yarmouth.

Yarmouth, scituate in the Western part, and on the Sea-shoar, with which and its arms, it was almost encompassed; and is of late made a perfect Isle by cutting off the neck of the Peninsula at the Eastern part, and hath three strong Fortifications raised, with a draw-Bridge; and the West end is defended by a powerful Castle on the Key. It is a fair Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men; and the Houses well built, which for the most part are of Free-stone, and covered with slate, and is much beautified by the late additional walls and fortifications near the Castle, and other parts of the Town. Here was formerly kept a Market which is now disused. Brading.
Brading, formerly a Market-town. Newtown.
Newtown, about a mile and an half from the Main, where it hath an Haven so called. It is a Major-town, and fendeth Burgesses to Parliament. Sandowncastle.
Sandown, seated in the South-east part of the Isle, and on a Bay so called.

The Cowes at the entring in of the Creek which goeth to Newport, being a place very eminent for the harbouring of ships. Cowes. Several rocks about the Isle. About this Island, are several other small ones, or rather Rocks, as those called the Black-rock, and the Mixon, being a knot in the North-east point; then those of the Don Mosse, Challorne, and Atherfield rocks in the South part; also in the West those of the Gosse, Chalk-rocks, and Warden; and on the North part between it and Portsmouth, are as dangerous Sands, as those called the Brambles, Nomans-lands, and the Horse.

div1.n: HARTFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons
div1.head: HARTFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons.
div1.p: HARTFORDSHIRE of a circular form, making two Diameters almost of an equal Longitude, and cross each other in the center; for the one giving the length from Stansted in the East to Putnam in the West, 25 miles; and the other from Totteridge in the South to Roiston in the North 27; making the whole circumference to contain near about 130 miles. Its bounds.
It is bounded on the East with Essex; on the South with Middlesex; on the West with the Counties of Buckingham and Bedford; and on the North with Cambridgshire. Its soil and fertility.

It is blest with a sweet and wholsome Air; and as to its soil, is for the most part chalky, although the upper crust in the South and West parts (for the most part) is of a red earth, mixed with gravel; nevertheless, by reason of the White marle under it, is found to yield good wheat and oats: but of its own nature it is most apt to bear Wood and Coppices. The North part of the shire hath dirty wayes, and is apt to bear wheat, barley, and other grain, especially in the Vale of Ringtayl, or Ringdale. The Vale of Ringtayl very fertile. It is well stored with Parks and many pleasant and ancient seats of Gentry, commonly called Beryes, which are Manour-places, Court-houses, or Halls: and for ancient Towns, there is scarce its fellow in England that can shew so many in so little room. Its Meadows. It hath plenty of Meadows and Pastures, which feed good store of cattle, the best of which are about the River Lea; those about Rickmandsworth, being generally cold and moist. Its Rivers.
It is well watered with fresh and delightful streams, the principal whereof are the Lea, Stower, Stratford, Redburne, Flamsted, or Verlamsted, Colne, &c. Ancient Inhabitants.

The Inhabitants that possessed these parts before the coming in of the Romans, were the Trinobantes, and the Cattieuchlanians, or Cassians; and was afterwards part of the Kingdom of the East-Saxons. Its Hundreds Markettowns. and Parithes.

This County is subdivided into eight Hundreds, as doth appear in the Mapp; in which are seated 120 Parish Churches, besides 15 Chappels of Ease; and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants for the uttering of their Commodities, hath 18 Market-towns, most of which are of good account,
and the rather for its being so great a thorough-fare to and from London Northwards. The division of the Shire by the Justices.

The Justices as well for the ease of themselves, as the common people, have divided the County into three parts, for the diciding of matters of small concernment; one division includeth the hundreds of Hartford, Braghing, Odsey, and Edwinstree, and meet at Hartford or Hodsdon; another hath the hundreds of Caishoo and Dacorum, and meet at Welwine or Stevenedge; and the other hath the hundreds of Broadwater & Hitching, & meet at S. Albans.

But for matters of the greatest concernment, the Justices meet all at Hartford, where the common County Goal is kept. For Ecclesiastical government this shire belongeth in part to the Diocess of London, and part to Lincoln. Its chles places. Hartford.
The chief places in this County, are

Hartford, seated on the Lea, which is said to have yielded passage for shipping, even to the walls of its Castle, but now scarcely receiveth small boats. It hath been of greater state, estimation, and beauty, then now it is, and had five Parish Churches, two of which are now decayed being rob'd of its pristine glory, by the turning the High-way through Ware; yet is it the shiretown, where the County Goal is kept, and as a Borough-town hath the election of Parliament men. It is governed by a Maior, 9 Burgesses, 16 Assistants, a High Steward, who is alwayes a Noble man, a Steward of the Court of Record, Town-clark, & 2 Sergeants; and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is well frequented. The Town was defended by a once strong Castle, built, as 'tis said, by K. Edw. the elder, and had also a cell of S.Alban Monks here established by Ralph Lindsey a Noble person, both which are long since reduced to ruin by the scourge of time, as well as divers other famous, and richly endowed Religious Houses, which in former times have gorgeously adorned this County. It is honored with the Title of Marquess, being one of the Titles appertaining to his Grace the Duke of Somerset. St. Albans. Raised from the ancient City of Verolam.

St. Albans, seated on the river Coln, a Town of good antiquity (raised from the ruins of that famous City Verolam, which I shall anon take notice of) and was so called from one Alban a Citizen of Verolam, by blood a Roman, who here suffered martyrdom in the time when Dioclesian went about to extirpate the Christian Religion out of this Land, being first converted from Paganism to the Faith of Christ by Amphibal; and in honour of him the Monastery of St. Albans was also founded, which hath been enlarged by sundry Abbots of this place: and such were the priviledges of this Town, that the King could make no secular Officer over them, but by their free consent. They were freed from the ducies of Toll through England; they made Justices of Oyer and Terminer, also Bailiffs and Coroners within themselves; they had Goal and Goal delivery within the Town, which yet it keepeth, having one Goal for the Town, and another for the Liberty. It is at present a fair, large, well inhabited and frequented thorough-fare Borough and Market-town, enjoying several immunities, electeth Burgesses, and is governed by a Maior, 10 Aldermen, a Steward, a Chamberlain, and other Sub-officers. It is divided into 4 Wards, in every of which it hath a Constable, and two Churchwardens; and for Divine worship hath three Parish Churches. It is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, enjoyed at present by the Right Honorable Henry E. of St. Albans, Lord Chamberlain of his Majesties Houshould. Is also of note for its once stately Abbey, built by Offa King of the Mercians, whose Church is yet standing, which was purchased by the Inhabitants at the price of four hundred pound, and at present made use of for a Parish Church, in which lyeth interr'd the bodies of many Nobles there slain, in the contention between the Houses of York and Lancaster; also here lyeth buried the famous Traveller Sir John Mandevile lively formed in marble.
And here is, or was, a Font of solid brass brought out of Scotland, in which the Scottish Kings children were wont to be baptized. In the North- west end of this Town was formerly a stately Castle called Kingsberry, whose ruins do yet appear. And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with provisions, &c.

In and about this Town have been fought several bloody Battles, two of which are more remarkable; the first on the 23 th of May, 1455, by Richard Duke of York, and his Consorts the Earls of Warwick and Salisbury, and the Lords Faulconbridge and Cobham, against K. Henry the Sixth; in whose defence, the Duke of Somerset, the Earl of Northumberland, and the L. Clifford, with the slaughter of about 5000 more, besides abundance wounded, and taken prisoners; amongst which was the King, who with an Arrow was wounded in the neck, and after taken and brought to London, where a reconciliation was made; and in this conslict, of the Dukes party about 600 were slain. The other Battle was on Shrove-sunday, at a place called Bernet, or Brentes field, by Q. Margaret, against the Dukes of Norfolk and Suffolk, and the Earls of Warwick and Arundel, who kept with them the King her Husband by constraint, where the Qu.gained the day, and received the King with great joy. Ancient City of Verolam.

The City of Verolam formerly spoken of, was of great antiquity, esteem, and beauty in the time when the Romanss wayed the English Scepter; as doth appear by the Pillars, Pavements, arched Vaults, Idols, and Romish coyns, frequently raised out of their obscure Dens by the laborious husbandman. It was a City enfranchised, and endowed not only with the aid of the Romans by a Mint, but with several other priviledges: also the Inhabitants for the most part were of the ancient British line, who deserving well at the hands of the Romans, were made Municipes (as it were free Citizens) o Rome, having their Laws, Orders, and Officers free amongst them, and permitted to live under their aid and protection, until it was (by the fury of the Saxons and Danes) sack't and subverted; so that of a proud City it became a Chaos, or heap of stones: and within its ruinous walls now groweth Liquorish, or Corn. And by this City passed Watling-street, which was one of the great Roads of England, which went from Dover into the North. High-Barnet.

Barnet, or high-Barnet; a large, dry, and pleasant Town, highly seated, and on the Road; of some account for its good and medicinal waters, as also for its Swine- Market on Mondays, which makes it to be well frequented, and hath in it several good Inns. Here was fought a bloody battle between the Competitors of the houses of York and Lancaster on an Easter-day, in which Edward the Fourth became the Victor. Watford,
Watford, seated on the Colne, a large and well inhabited Town, whose Market, which is on Tuesdays, is well frequented, affording all necessaries, especially corn in great plenty. Langley Abbey.

Not far from Watford is Langley Abbey, belonging to the Abbots of St. Albans; wherein was born Nicholas, surnamed Break-spear, who was afterwards Bishop of Rome, and called Pope Hadrian IV; a man of so proud a spirit, that he had his stirrup held by Frederick the Roman Emperor; he was the first that taught the Norwegians the Christian Faith, and ended his dayes by an untimely death. Kings-Langley

Not far from Langley Abbey is Kings-Langley, where K. Richard II. and Q. Anne his wife, with many of the Nobles, kept a royal Christmass; and when the King deceased was here interr'd, but afterwards removed to Westminster Abbey. Here Edmond D. of York was born, and also afterwards interr'd. Rickmansworth.
Rickmansworth, seated also on the Coln, very low and waterish; an indifferent Market-town on Saturdays. Hemsted.

Hemsted, seated on hills, and on a branch of the Colne, a Market-town on
Thursdays; of some note for being the place where Richard King of the Romans ended his dayes. Berkhamsted.

Berkhamsted, a Market-town on Mondays, chiefly for Mault; here was formerly a Castle of good account, built by the Normans: It hath a fair free School founded by Jo. Incent Dean of St. Pauls, a native of this place. And here it was that the English Nobles met in Councel for the shaking off the Normans yoke.
Tringe, a small Market-town on Fridays. Tringe. Hatsield.

Hatsield, once dignified with a Royal house of the Kings, which now belongeth to the Right Honorable the Earl of Salisbury; and is a place of great delight and recreation by reason of its Parks, and other places of pleasure, which for scituation, contrivance, building, prospect, air, water, and all other accommodations is inferiour to none in England; hath a Market on Thursdays. Hodsdon.
Hodsdon, a fair Town, seated in the Road, and on the River Lea, and hath a well frequented Market on Thursdays. Theoballs.

Not far from Hodsdon, but more near unto Waltham- Abbey in Essex is Theoballs, one of the Kings royal seats, pleasantly scituate amongst delightful walks, gardens, groves, and springs; first built by Sir Will. Cecil, and afterwards beautified by his Son Sir Robert, both Lord Treasurers of England. Ware.

Ware, a large, well frequented and inhabited thorough-fare Town, seated on the River Lea; a place well known to many for its great Bed, and its River, which is cut from thence to London, where it serveth many hundreds of Families with the conveniency of water. This Thown began to be most famous in the reign of K. John, at which time it became a thorough-fare Town. Its Market on Tuesdays is well frequented, and provided of commodities. Sabsworth.
Sabsworth, formerly a Market-town on Wednesdays, but discontinued since the making of Stortford. Bishops Strotford.

Stortford, or Bishops Strotford, seated on the side of a Hill; a very large, fair and well inhabited and frequented Market-town, full of Inns for the giving entertainment to strangers. And its Market, which is on Thursdays, is well resorted unto, and provided with commodities. On the East side of the Town, there is the ruins of a Castle, called the Castle of Waymour, standing in an Isle upon an artificial Mount very steep, and though of a small circuit, yet seemeth to have been of great strength, and within it is a dark and deep Dungeon, called the Convicts prison, which doth denote some great priviledges to belong unto it in former time; it was spoiled and laid flat by King John. Puckeridge.
Puckeridge, a thorough-fare Town. Stoudon.
Stoudon, hath a small Market on Fridays, lately erected. Buntingford.
Buntingford, a large Hamlet, and a good thorough-fare Town, which hath a Market on Mondays Hitching.

Hitching, seated near a great wood, called Hitch-wood, whose Inhabitants make great store of Mault, hath a very good Corn-market on Tuesdays, and is governed by a Bailiff and four Constables. Baldock.

Baldock, a considerable large Town, seated between the Hills in a chalkie soil fit for corn, of chief note for the many Maulsters here residing; yet its Market, which is on Thursdays, is but small. Stevenedge,
Stevenedge, a pretty thorough-fare Town, which had formerly the benefit of a Market on Fridays. Totteridge.
Totteridge, a Town much frequented by the Londoners, who have beautified it with many good houses. Barkway.
Barkway, formerly a Market-town on Fridays, but now disused. Royston.

Royston, a famous Market-town which is kept on Wednesdays for Corn and Mault here made; being seated in a fat soil, and between hills in a bottom. The Town is large, part of which standeth in Cambridg shire, & is well inhabited, frequented, and full of Inns.

div1.n: HEREFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the SILVRES and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: HEREFORDSHIRE: BEING Part of the SILVRES, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A generall Mapp of the County of Hereford with its Hundreds

div1.p: HEREFORDSHIRE, which takes its name from Hereford its chief Town; is a Country every where exceeding fertile, producing excellent Grains in great plenty, and intermixed with rich Pastures, which feed store of cattle, especially sheep which are found very profitable unto the Inhabitants by their wool. It is well clothed with wood, and refreshed with rivers; and in a word, it wanteth for nothing that may be said necessary for the use of man: and for wheat, wool, and water, it yieldeth to no County in England. Fruits. Syder.

All Fruits grow here in great plenty, and of their Apples they make such a great quantity of Syder, that besides what they use themselves (it being their general drink) of late years the Londoners (finding its excellency) do much drink (of that which is made of an Apple called a Red-streak,) so that it is become a considerable commodity. Its Rivers.
Its chief Rivers are the Wye, Munow, Wades, Doire, Lugg, Froom, &c. Its bounds.
The bounds of this County Eastwards, are Worcestershire and Glocestershire; Southwards, Monmouthshire; Westwards, those of Radnor and Brecknock; and Northwards, that of Shropshire. Its extent.

Its extent from Cowley in the East, to Knyll in the West, is about 24 miles; and from Llanruthall in the South, to Oversapye in the North, about 23; which makes its circumference to be about 102 miles. Castles.

Before the Conquest, this County was part of Wales, and was then secured by several Forts; and so scon as it became an English County, it was well strengthened with Castles, having no less then 28, most of which have now nothing to shew except their ruins. Ancient Inhabitants.

Its ancient Inhabitants were the Silures, a stout and warlike people, who sorely perplexed the Romans for nine years space, through the noble valour and exploits of their Commander Caractacus. And when the Saxons became Lords of the Land, it made part of the Kingdom of the Mercians. Religious Houses.
It was also well stored with Religious Houses, which were at Acornbury, Barron, Clifford, Dore, Ewayot, Hereford, Kilpeck, Lemster, Linbrook, Manemue, Peter-church, Wigmore, &c.
It is severed into eleven Hundreds, in which are numbred 176 Parish Churches; and hath intercourse of Traffick with eight Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Hereford.

Hereford, raised out of the ruins of the ancient Arconium, (now called Kenchester, which was shaken to pieces by a violent Earthquake) about three miles distant Eastwards, which was a place of good account in the time of the Romans, as hath sufficiently appeared by the four square paving stones of Checker-work, the Roman coyns, and other pieces of antiquity there often dug up. This City is no less pleasantly, then commodiously seated amongst delightful Meadows, and rich Corn fields, and almost encompassed with Rivers, to wit, the Wye, and two others, over which are two Bridges; and for its defence, it had once a strong and stately Castle, built by the Normans, which time hath now ruinated. It is a large place, numbring six Parish Churches, (two of which in the late unhappy wars were demolished,) and beautified with good buildings, both publick and private; amongst which are the Bishops Palace, the Colledge, the Prebends Houses, and Cathedral, first founded by Milfride a petty King of that Country, in honour of Ethelbert King of the East-Angles, who was treacherously murthered at Sutton (where King Offa had his Palace) by the procurement of Quendred King Offa's wife, his intended Mother-in-law, at such time when he made courtship to her daughter, where his body was interred. And this Cathedral, by Cruffith Prince of South-wales, and Algar an Englishman, in their Rebellion against King Edward the Confessor, was consumed by fire; which was rebuilt by Bishop Remelin, and by his Predecessors, beautified to what it is at present; to which now belongeth a Bishop, Dean, Chancellor, six Canons, twenty seven Prebends, with a Chanter, Treasurer, twelve Vicars coral, besides Deacons, Quiresters, and other attendants.

Here is an Hospital liberally endowed, for the maintenance of twelve poor people, which had like to have gone to ruin, had not the care of William Gregory Esquire, and Mr. Humphrey Diggs been great. This City enjoyeth large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by a Maior, six Aldermen, a Common Council, which with the Maior and Aldermen makes up 31, besides a Recorder, Town-clark, and other Sub-officers. It hath been dignified with a Dukedom, then an Earldom, and at present gives Title to the Right Honorable Leicester D'Evreux Viscount Hereford, &c. And is a place well served with provisions, having weekly three Markets, on Wednesdays, Fridays and Saturdays, which are of considerable account; that on Fridays being for cattle, sheep, and hoggs; and the other for grain, and tities, which are sent to London and elsewhere. Gilden-vale.
South-westwards from Hereford is Gilden-vale, so called from the fertility of the soil and pleasant scituation. Ross,

Ross, commodiously seated in a fertile soil, on the banks of the Wye; a fair Town, which by King Henry the Third was made a free Borough; Its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very great for corn, cattle, and provisions, being much resorted unto by the Inhabitants of Glocestershire and Monmouthshire. Lidbury.

Lidbury, anciently called Ledbury under Malvern, from Malvern-hills near adjoyning; a fine well built Town, seated in a rich claiey ground, and much inhabited by Clothiers, who here drive a good trade: Its Market is on Tuesdays, which is well served with corn, cattle, and provisions. Bramyeard.
Bramyeard, scituate on a rising ground, a small Town, and hath an indifferent Market for corn, cattle, &c. on Mondays. Lemster.

Lemster, which as Cambden noteth, was called Leon Minster, and Lions
Monastery, from a Lyon (as some would have it) that appeared to a religious man in a vision. It is a large, ancient, and pleasant Town, seated in a rich soil, and on the river Lugg which runneth through it, over which are several Bridges. It is governed by a Bailiff, a Recorder, Justices of the Peace, and 24 of the Chamber or Common Council; and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. The greatest fame that this Town at present hath, is the fine wool which the sheep in the Towns adjacent bear, known by the name of Lemster wool, which the Inhabitants call Lemster ore; and is also noted for its fine wheat and flowre, as Webley is for its good Ale. The Market is on Fridays, which is of good account for corn, cattle, sheep, wool, hops, provisions, &c. Pembridge.
Pembridge, a small Town, seated on the River Arrow; whose Market on Tuesdays is very inconsiderable. Kyneton.

Kyneton, also scituate on the Arrow, a pretty large and well built Town, whose Inhabitants drive a good trade for narrow cloths. Its Market is on Wednesdays, which is the best in the County for corn, cattle, provisions, and several commodities. The Wednesdays before Easter, Whitsontide, and Christmass, are very considerable for corn, living cattle, leather, home-made cloth both linnen and woollen, and all sorts of provisions, insomuch that they may rather be tearmed Fairs then Markets. Webley.

Webley, or the honour of Webley, anciently belonging to Theodore de Verdun who was Lord thereof; an ancient Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men: This Town formerly enjoyed a good trade, which of late is less considerable by the growth of its neighbouring Town, Kyneton. It is indifferently well seated, and hath a small Market on Thursdays. Things of remark in this County. Marcle-hill, how it removed. See Cambden,620. Speed.

Mr. Cambden and Speed make mention of Marcle-hill, That it removed in Anno 1571, for three dayes space, above 400 yards from its place, carrying with it about 26 Acres of ground; which rupture was not done without a great noise, horrour and amasement to the neighbouring Inhabitants; overwhelming Kinnaston-Chappel, Trees, and all that it met with. Bone-well.
Not far from Richards Castle, in the North part of the County is Bonewell; a Spring wherein are alwayes found the bones of small fishes, but not so much as a finn to be seen. Wergins-Meadow.

Between Sutton and Hereford, in a common Meadow called the Wergins, were placed two large stones, at the least of three Tuns weight, and there placed for a water-mark; the one erected upright, and the other laid athwart. And these stones, in the late troubles about the year 1652, were removed about twelve score paces distance, and no man knew how; which doth occasion the people to say, That they were done by the Devil. And when they were again set in their places, nine yoke of Oxen were required to draw one of the stones. Kinchester. A Vault of the Romans.

At Kinchester, formerly Arconium, about the year 1669, was found in a wood a great Vault, wherein were tables of plaster of Paris, the Vault paved with stone, many pieces of Roman coyns being dug up, with large bones, leaden pipes, several vessels wherein were ashes, supposed to be the Urns of the Romans; with several other vessels, for what use, not known.

div1.n: Huntingtonshire: BEING Part of the ICENI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Huntingtonshire: BEING Part of the ICENI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of Huntington shire with its hundreds

div1.p: HUNTINGTON, a County of a small extent, being from Erith in the East, to Keeston in the West, scarce 15 miles; and from Tetworth in the South, to Fletton in the North, not above 20; so that its circumference is said not to exceed 67 miles. Its bounds.

As to its bounds, it is severed on the East with Cambridgshire; on the South with Bedfordshire; on the West with Northamptonshire; and on the North by the River Avon, which also divides it from the County of Northampton. Its fertility.

It is generally of a fertile soil, both for corn and tillage, garnished with delightful Hills; and towards the East, where it adjoyneth on the Fens, hath rich pasturage, which are imployed in grazing and fatning of cattle. In former time it was very woody, being accounted a Forest, and afforded excellent Game. But in the beginning of the Reign of King Henry the second it was disforested; yet is not destitute of wood, nor do the Inhabitants find any want of fuel, the Rivers serving them with Coals, and the Moors with Turfs, especially that part towards the Fens. Its Rivers.
It is well watered with Rivers, the chief of which is the Owse, which divideth it self into several streams. Religious Houses.
This County had in it several Priories and Religious Houses, as at Huntington, Ramsey, Stonly, St. Neots, Hintchinbrook, and elsewhere.
It is divided into four Hundreds, in which are numbred 79 Parish Churches, and is traded unto by five Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Huntington.

Huntington, pleasantly seated on a rising ascent, and on the North banks of the River Owse, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, which leadeth to Godmanchester. It is a Town of great antiquity, and was once very populous and large, numbring no less then 15 Parish Churches, which are now reduced unto four; and in the reign of the Conquerour was severed into four Wards, and had a Mint for coynage. By Charter of King John, this
Town had a peculiar Coroner, received the profit of Toll and Custome, had the election of Burgesses for Parliament, and was governed by two Bailiffs, a Recorder and Town Clark; and at present is incorporated by the name of a Maior, twelve Aldermen, and Burgesses; and is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which at present appertaineth to the Right Honorable Theophilus Earl of Huntington, &c. Here was a Castle said to be built by the Conquerour; also an Hospital dedicated to St. John Baptist; a Priory of black Chanons, dedicated to the blessed Virgin; and a Nunnery at Hinchingbrook near adjoyning, which yields Title of Viscount Hinchingbrook to the Right Honorable the Earl of Sandwich, where he hath his Country Seat. This Town at present is a place of a good trade, hath a free Grammar School; is well inhabited and frequented, and the rather as being a thorough-fare Town from London, Cambridge, and other Southern parts of England, into the North, and into Scotland: As also for being the place where the Assizes for the County are held, and where is kept the County Goal: And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very well served with provisions. Godmanchester

Godmanchester, aliàs Gumecester, opposite to Huntington, on the other side of the Owse; a very great Country Town, and an ancient Borough, incorporated in the Reign of King James by the mame of two Bailiffs, twelve Assistants, and Commonalty of the Borough of Godmanchester. It is seated in a rich and fertile soyl, yielding great plenty of corn; is very well inhabited, amongst which there are more able Yeomen and Farmers, then in any Town in England; insomuch that they make their brags, that they have received the Kings of England (as they have passed by in their Progress) with 180 Teems of good Horses, bedeck't with trappings and other their Rustick ornaments, with so many Ploughs, to shew their Husbandry. St. Ives.

St. Ives, a fair, large and ancient Town, seated on the Owse, over which is a fair Stone-bridge, so called from one lvo a Persian Bishop, who (as 'tis reported) about the year 600, travelled through England preaching the Gospel, and here ended his dayes; whose Body in a short time after was removed by the Religious persons to Ramsey Abbey. The Market is on Mondays, which is well served with provisions, and is of chief note for living cattle. Here was an ancient Priory, which is now much decayed, yet the habitation of a Gentleman. St. Neots.

St. Neots, or St. Needs, so called from Neotus a Monk of Glastenbury, a man no less holy then learned, whose body was translated from Neotstoke in Cornwall hither; and in honour to him (as Mr. Cambden noteth) Alfrick converted the Palace of Earl Elfride unto a Monastery, which soon after the coming in of the Normans, was liberally endowed by Roisia, wife to Richard Earl of Clare. It is a large and well built Town, beautified with a neat Church, which hath a fine Steeple, and is commodiously seated on the River Owse, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge which leadeth into Bedfordshire. Its Market is on Thursdays, which is very well provided with Provisions; and through the commodiousness of the Owse, the neighbouring Towns are from hence furnished with Coals. At Aileweston medicinal waters.

A little beneath St. Needs at Aileweston, or Hailweston, are two Springs, the one fresh, and the other somewhat brackish; and the one is said to be good against the Leprosie and Scabs; and the other against the dimness of the eye-sight. Kimbolton.

Kimholton, a pretty fair Town, seated in a bottom, and on the confines of this County reguarding Bedfordshire. Gives title of Baron to the Right Honorable the Earl of Manchester, whose Mansion is called the Castle of Kimbolton; and hath a Market on Fridays.
An ancient City.

Cambden, taketh notice of an ancient, though small City, seated on the banks of the Nen near Walmsford, which by Henry of Huntington was called Caer-dorm, and Dormeceaster, but quite destroyed before his time: and this City was thought to be the Durobrivae, which Antonine the Emperour speaketh of; for besides the ancient coyns, and other remarks of Antiquity, there leadeth to it directly from Huntington a Roman-port-way; and a little above Stilton, a high bank sheweth it self, which was called Erming-street; which street runneth through a four-square Fort, whose North-side was fenced with walls, and on all other sides with a Rampire of Earth. Ramsey.

Ramsey, seated in the Fens amongst rich grounds both for tillage and pasturage, and near the Meers of Ramsey and Whitlesey, which, with the Rivers that plentifully water it, affords excellent Fish; and Wild-fowl in great plenty are taken, which the Inhabitants buy at easie rates. It is a good Country- town, having a Market on Wednesdays. Ramsey-Abbey This place in former time was of great fame for its Abbey, founded in the year of Grace 969 by E. Aylwin, dedicated to God, our Lady, and St. Benedict, and by Oswald of York replenished with Monks from Westbury: and being the Shrine of two martyred Kings, Ethelbright and Ethelred, and of St. Ino the Persian Bishop; it became to be a place so wealthy, that it was called Ramsey the rich; and enclosing to themselves a large circuit of Land and Water, which they called the Seignory of Baleuc, or Bandy, they began to affect popular command, and by Soveraign grant enjoyed regal Liberty, and had place in Parliament; and then was Broughton the head Town of their Barony; and in this great glory it continued until its desolution by Henry the Eighth. Yaxley.
Yaxley, seated near the fenny part, having a Fenn so called. It is an indifferent Town, and had a Market,which is now disused, or so slenderly. frequented, that it is not worth the taking notice of.

div1.n: THE COUNTY, AND ANCIENT KINGDOM OF KENT
div1.head: THE COUNTY, AND ANCIENT KINGDOM OF KENT.

figure.head: A Mapp of Kent with its Laths and Hundreds

div1.p: KENT, a County of a large extent, being from Dover South- eastwards, unto Deptford Westwards, about 60 miles in length; and from St. James 's in the Isle of Grange Northwards, unto Bromhill Southwards, about 34; making in circumference about 150, or 160 miles. Bounds.
It is on all parts encompassed by the Thames, and the narrow Seas; except towards the West, and South-west by the Counties of Surrey and Sussex. Fertility.

It is (though hilly) generally of a rich and fertile soil, plentifully provided with corn and other grains; also with store of cattle, fish, fowl, and fruits, which are esteemed the best in England. It is also sufficiently furnished with wood for fuelling, and good Timber-trees, except towards the East, where it is more Champain. Air.

The Air, though not very serene (by reason of the vapours arising from the Sea and Rivers, that do in a manner begirt it) yet is it temperate and good, except in the Weald and Marshes. Its temperature.

The Inhabitants distinguish this County, as it lyeth Southeast- wards from the Thames, into three parts; the upper lyeth upon the Thames, and is esteemed healthful, but not wealthy; the middle, both healthy and wealthy; and the lower, wealthy but not healthy, as lying low and moist in the Marshes, and by consequence very aguish. Kent boasteth of several things above other Counties. Gavel-kind.

This County may boast it self in being the first of the Kingdoms of the Heptarchy, and having aparticular King to its self (a thing that no other County in England had;) neither was it ever subdued by conquest, but yielded upon Articles to the Normans; and to keep their ancient customs; one of which is that of the Gavel-kind, by which they are not so bound by Copy-hold, Cultomary tenure, as in other parts of England, but as it were Free-holders, having some part to live upon: For Lands in this nature
ture are equally divided amongst the male children; and for want of males, amongst the females; and by vertue of which they are at age to enter upon the same at fifteen years old; and it is lawful for them to sell, or make over the same without the consent of the Lord. Also the Son ( though of a convicted Father for felony or murther) succeeds him in such kind of Lands. They also glory, that their Kings and Commons amongst all the Saxons, were the first Christians: for it is said that Lucius, who was the first British King in this Isle, built a Church within the limits of Dover- castle to the service of Christ, and for its maintenance endowed it with the Toll of the Haven.

In the time of Julius Cæsar the people were the civilest of all the Britains, and then governed by four Kings, under Vortigern the Britain by Guorong his Lieutenant, from whom the said King gave it to Hengist the Saxon, in love of his daughter rowen, who endeavouring to gain the sole regality obteined (in a battle fought near Crayford) a great Victory; insomuch that he deemed himself sole Lord thereof; yet afterwards the valiant Britain gave him battle at Aylesford, in which both Catigern and Horsa, brethren to both the Generals, were slain, and the Saxons again forced to their allotted station (to wit, the Isle of Thanet) from whence, during the life of Vortigen, they durst not attempt further.

Hengist made this a Kingdom, which he, and his Successors did enjoy 320 years, then Egbert King of the West Saxons subdued it, and joyned it to his own; in which state it remained, until the time of the Normans, who possessed it upon composition as aforesaid. This County hath felt the heavy hand of war, and suffered great changes.

This County hath sufficiently felt the burthen of civil broils and dissensions, not only under the Saxons, and Danes, (which alone were intollerable) but likewise since the conquest of the Normans, as in the Barons Wars, in the time of Henry the Third; also by Watt Tyler that grand Rebel in the reign of Richard the Second; again in the reign of Henry the Seventh at Blackheath, where the Cornish Rebels were vanquished: and lastly, it hath been a fellow sufferer with divers other Counties in the late unhappy troubles, in the paying their duties to their Soveraign. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, many of which are Navigable; as the Thames, which washes its Northern parts; the Medway, which in a manner divideth the shire in the middle, and is the station for his Majesties Navy Royal: beside, ten others of considerable account, which opening with several Creeks and Havens are found commodious for ships to ride in, of which four bear the name of Cinque-ports, viz. Dover, Sandwich, Rumney, and Hith; and on the banks of these Rivers, which are crossed by divers Bridges, are seated several good Towns. The beauty and riches of Kent.

This County is enriched with two Cities and Episcopal Sees, is strengthed with several Castles, graced with four of the Kings Palaces, beautified with many splendid buildings, well replenished with Gentry; sufficiently stored with safe Roads and secure Harbours for ships, plentifully garnished with good Towns; is a place of a considerable trade, affording corn and other grains, cloth, and several draperies, fullers-earth, madder, slax, iron, wood, fruits, as apples, pears, cherries, &c. Its trade. in great plenty; and by reason of its vicinity to France, is well known and frequented by strangers. Bailiwicks in Kent.

As to its Division, it hath fourteen Bailiwicks; to wit, in the East division of the County, 1 Milton, 2 Scray, 3 Chart and Longbridge, 4 Bridge and Petham, 5 Eastry, 6 Stowting, and 7 Shipway; and in the West division 8 Sutton Bromley, 9 Sutton Dartford, 10 Hoo, 11 Eyhor, 12 Lowy of Tunbridge, 13 Twyford, and 14 Seven hundreds.
Franchises and Liberties.

There are also seventeen Franchises and Liberties which have Courts of Record, to hold Plea of all Actions real, personal, and mixt; which are as followeth: 1. The Arch-bishoprick of Canterbury. 2. The Liberty of the Dean of Canterbury. 3. The Liberty of the Cinque-ports. 4. The Liberties of Ashford. 5. Of St. Augustine. 6. Of Eleham. 7. Of Graves-end, and Milton. 8. Of the Dutchy of Lancaster. 9. Of Liming. 10. Of Maidstone, 11. Of Queen-borough. 12. Of the Bishop of Rochester. 13. Of the City of Rochester. 14. Of Romney-marsh. 15. Of Sevenoke. 16. Of Wrotham; and 17. of Wye. Corporations

The Corporations are fourteen, of which nine are in the Cinque-ports; viz. 1. Dover, 2. Feversham, 3. Folkstone, 4. Fordwich, 5. Hith, 6. Lydd, 7. New-Romney, 8. Sandwich, and 9. Penterder: And in the Foraign five; viz. 10. Graves-end, and Milton, 11. Maidstone, 12. Queen-borough, 13. Rochester, and 14. Romney-Marsh. The Sessions of the Peace; where, and when holden.

The East Division of this County hath in it yearly two general Sessions of the Peace holden at the Castle at Canterbury, which are commonly on Twelf-tide, and the Tuesday before St. James's day. And the West division hath also two Sessions of the Peace, which are usually holden at Maidstone, the one on Tuesday after Easter-weak, and the other on Tuesday after Michaelmass. The division of this County.

As to its Topographical division it is severed into five Laths, which again are subdivided into 64 Hundreds; in which are numbred four hundred and odd Parishes, and hath for the accommodation of its Inhabitants 28 Market-towns, which I shall take notice of as they lye in each Lath; and first with that of Sutton, adjoyning to the County of Surrey. SVTTON-LATH. Lath of Sutton

The Lath of Sutton, or Sutton at Hone, is bounded on the East with that of Aylesford; on the South with the County of Sussex; on the West with Surrey; and on the North with the Thames. It is divided into two divisions of Justices of the Peace, and hath in it eight Hundreds Its chief places are Sevenoke.

Sevenoke, a Town of good resort, whose Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with corn and other provisions. This Town (as several would have it) was so called from its exceeding great Oaks, which now are hewed down. Here is an Hospital and a Free-School, founded by one William Sevenoke, Lord Maior of London, in Anno 1418, who was a foundling in this Town, and from thence took his name. Dartford.

Dartford, seated on the River Darent, not far from its influx into the Thames, which gives good advantage to the Town, in the conveying their goods to London, which makes its Market (which is on Saturdays) to be very well stored with corn and other commodities, and much frequented by Corn-chandlers, Mealmen, &c. The Town is large, and as scituate in the high Road, is well accommodated with Inns and Houses of entertainment. In the reign of King Richard the Second, in Anno 1381. Tylers impious rebellion began here, occasioned by an abuse which a Collector of the Pole- money offered to the Daughter of John Tyler, a Tiler of this Town, who was the Head or Captain of the rebellious crew, and called Jack Straw, the story of which is sufficiently known in History. Bromley.
Bromley, seated on or near the River Ravensbourne, an indifferent good Market-town on Thursdays for provisions. Woolwich.

Woolwich, seated on the River Thames, a Market-town on Fridays, but very inconsiderable, scarce worth the name of one. But is of note for its
Dock for the Royal Navy, which makes its to be well frequented by those that have relation thereunto. St. Mary Cray.
St.Mary Cray, scituate on a Brook called Cray, which hath a quick stream, and in a Woodland Country; hath a very inconsiderable Market on Wednesdays. Greenwich,

Greenwich, a large and very pleasant Town, scituate on the banks of the Thames, being well inhabited and frequented by Gentry, and ennobled with a once stately Palace of the Kings, a place of good antiquity, whose Foundations were first laid by Humphrey Duke of Glocester, and enlarged and beautified by several succeeding Kings: and out of the ruins of this Structure, there is now erecting a stately Pile of building. And adjoyning to this Palace is a small, but pleasant Park, which affords a delectable prospect; and here it was that Queen Elizabeth, with divers other Princes did receive their first breaths. Black-heath.

Adjoyning to Greenwich is Black-heath, a place of signal note, where the Danish Camp lay; and here have been several bloody conflicts; viz. that of Jack Straw already treated of ; also that of Jack Cade and his Allies, in the reign of Henry the Sixth; and that of Michael Joseph the Blacksmith, and the Lord Audley, in the reign of Henry the Seventh. Deptford.

Deptford, another large Town, consisting of the upper and the lower, also seated on the banks of the Thames, amongst rich and low Meadows, and on the confines of the County towards Surrey; a Town well inhabited and frequented by Sea-men; and is of most account by reason of its Docks and Store-bouses for Ammunition, &c. for the Navy Royal. Eltham.

Eltham, seated on the South-side of Shooters-hill amongst Woods, a Town nearly scituated, and well inhabited by Gentrey; It was honored with a Palace of the Kings, said to be built by Antbony Beck, Patriarch of Jerusalem; who afterwards gave it to Queen Elianor, wife to King Edward the First; and the only reason of its decay was its vicinity to Greenwich, which is a place of greater delight. Swans-combe
Swans-combe, of chief note for being the place where the Kentish men obteined of William the Conquerour the enjoyment of their ancient customs and Franchises, on condition of a peace. Otford,

Otford, seated on or near the River Darent, a Town of good antiquity; and here it was that Canutus the Dane pitched his Tents, and where King Edmund (surnamed Ironside) fought him, and put him to flight, with the loss of about 5000 Danes: and also here Thomas Becket had his seat, and resided, of whom many stories are told. Westram.
Westram, seated on the Darent, and in the confines of the County towards Surrey; hath a very considerable Market on Wednesdays. Speldherst.
Speldherst, of note for its famous waters so much resorted unto, and drank in the Sommer season, known by the name of Tunbridge-wells. AYLESFORD-LATH. Lath of Ayles-ford described.

The Lath of Aylesford is of a large extent, reaching from North to South, and lyeth between the Laths of Scray and Sutton. It is severed into fifteen Hundreds, is divided into three divisions of Justices of the Peace; and hath for its chief places, Rochester. For the further description of the Bishoprick, see Heylin p.136

Rochester an ancient City, and once of a larger extent then now it is, being (through the often shocks of ill fortune, as well by fire, as by the Mercians, Danes, and West-Saxons) at present contented with a narrow compass, having (within its walls) but one principal street; which extendeth it self to a good length, and the houses are well built, and inhabited by Trades-
men, and Inn-Keepers. It is no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the banks of the Medway, over which it hath a stately Stone-bridge susteined by divers Arches, which leadeth to Stroud, a good, fair, and well inhabited Town. This City is dignified with an Episcopal See; and its Cathedral first erected by Ethelbert King of Kent, and by him dedicated to St. Andrew; since its repairs it is a fair Structure, and hath a Dean and six Prebendaries. It is the least (though ancient, next to Canterbury) Diocess of England, conteining part of this County, in which there is but 98 Parishes, of which 36 are Impropriations.

This City is also dignified with an Earldom, the present Earl being the Right Honorable Jo.Wilmot, Earl of Rochester,&c. The government of this City is committed to the care of a Maior, and a Court of Aldermen, with other Sub-officers, is endowed with several immunities; and, as all Cities, it hath the election of Burgebes. Here is an Almes-house for the relief of all poor Travellers (provided they are not Proctors) for a night. Its Castle, which is now reduced to ruin, was a place of great importance and strength, being said to be built by the command of Julius Cæsar to over awe the Britains. And the Inhabitants do at present drive a good trade, and its Market, which is on Fridays, is well served with provisions. Chetham.

Adjoyning to this City (as may be now said by reason of its vicinity) is Chetham, also seated on the banks of Medway; a long thorough-fare Town, which is well inhabited by Sea-men, and those that have alliance thereunto: and the more, as being the station of the Navy Royal, and where there is a stately Dock for the building and equipping of his Majesties ships. Graves-end.

Graves-end, scituate on the banks of the Thames, a place of great resort, as being the common landing place for strangers and Seamen in their passages to London; as likewise the accustomary place for taking of shipping, and the ready road to France, which doth occasion it to be well furnished with Taverns,Inns, and Houses of Entertainment: and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well provided with Victuals, yet all things want for no price. And here is seated one of the Block- houses, the other being opposite unto it in the County of Essex; which said Block-houses are kept continually guarded, and provided with Ammunition, the better to secure the passage up the River of Thames.Block- houses. North-fleet.

Nigh unto Graves-end is North-fleet, seated also on the banks of the Thames; a small Town, where there is a Market kept every Tuesday after Easter-tuesday, until Whitson-tuesday, but not very considerable. Maidstone.

Maidstone, also seated on the Medway, which with a branch it sendeth forth, severeth the Town. It is a large, fair, sweet, populous, and well frequented Market-town, being the Shire-town; and enjoyeth several priviledges which were granted its Inhabitants by King Edward the Sixth, and confirmed by Queen Elizabeth; being a Borough-town, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and here is one of the Prisons for the County, and where they keep their Sessions and Assizes. In this Town, for the education of youth, is a Free-School; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very considerable, and well provided with corn and all sorts of provisions. Places of most note and ornament in this Town, were (if not are) the Bishops Palace, the Golledge, the House of the Brothers of Corpus Christi, and the Bridge. Lenham.

Lenham, seated on an eminence, a Market-town on Tuesdays, which is not very considerable; and here at a place called Sandway, upon every Tuesday after Allbolland-day, until Christmab, is a Market kept for the sale of Bullocks.
Aylesford.

Aylesford, scituate on the River Medway, over which it hath a Bridge; and here Vortimer King of Britain, fought with the Saxons; in which Battle Catigern, brother to Vortimer, and Horsa brother to Hengist, Commander of the Saxons, in a single combat slew each other; and in memory of Catigern, the Britains caused to be erected a Monument of Stone, which is vulgarly now called Kits Cothouse; adjoyning to this Town was a Religious House of Carmelite Fryers. Malling.
Malling, scituate near unto Compherst-wood, hath a Market on Saturdays; and here Gundulphus erected an Abbey of Women, which he dedicated to the blessed Virgin Mary. Wrotham.
Wrotham, seated in a plain, but neighboured by Hills, a Market-town on Tuesdays. Tunbridge.

Tunbridge, scituate on a branch of the Medway, over which it hath a Bridge, and is said to take its name from its many Bridges. It is a well frequented Market-town, which is on Fridays, affording corn, and other provisions; and is of chief note for the healthful waters near adjoyning already spoken of, which are much visited by the Gentrey in the Sommer season. SCRAY-LATH. Lath of Scray.

The Lath of Scray runneth from North to South the breadth of the County, and possesseth the middle part thereof; It is divided into sixteen Hundreds, hath two divisions of Justices of the Peace. And its chief places are Feversham.

Feversham, seated not far from the Isle of Shippey, so made by the River Medway, which with the Sea encircleth it; out of which said River there cometh a Creek up to the Town, by reason of which it is well frequented by Hoyes, and such like small Vessels, which here drive a good trade, it being the principal Port-town for all this part of Kent. The Town is large, well built, and inhabited by Trades-men, Inn-keepers, and Victualers: and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well frequented and provided with provisions. This Town was honoured by being the burial place of King Stephen, and Queen Maud his wife, and Eustace his son, in the Abbey which by him was caused to be erected. Queenborough.

Queenborough, seated in the Isle of Shippey; a Town of great antiquity, of which it boasteth more then of its beauty, wealth, or extent, being on all accounts but mean; yet doth it still enjoy its ancient priviledges, being a Borough-town, electing Parliament men, and is governed by a Maior and Court of Aldermen, which commonly for riches and wit are not over-burthened. This Town, for its defence had a (once strong) Castle, built by King Edward the Third, for the better security of the passage up the River Thames, at that time that he went to wage war against the Crown of France, the ruins of which said Castle are yet remaining; wherefore the better to secure the passage up the Medway to Gillingham, and Chatham, where the Navy Royal rideth, at a place called Shyre-ness, is lately built by order of his present Majesty, a very strong and powerful Fort. Isle of Shippey

The Isle of Shippey is about 21 miles in circumference, is exceeding fertile, and feedeth great flocks of sheep, from whence' tis said it took its name. This Isle was much harased by the Danes, as also by the followers of the Earl Goodwin and his sons. And besides Queenborough, there are several Towns seated thereon, as Minster, Eastchurch, Warden, Leysden, Elmeley, &c.
Milton.
Milton, or Midleton, seated on a Creek near the wells which severeth it from Sheppey, a place of good account in the reign of Edward the Confessor; and hath a Market on Saturdays. Sittinborne.
Sittinborne, not far from Milton, a thorough-fare Town, being well accommodated with Inns and publick Houses. Wye.
Wye, seated on the Stower, over which it hath a Bridge, in former time a place of good account, as it is at present; and hath a Market weekly on Thursdays. Ashford.

Ashford, not far from the banks of the Stower; hath a Market on Saturdays, which is well frequented: And in this Town is Kept a Court of Record upon every Tuesday three weeks for Actions, wherein the Debt or damages do not exceed twenty Marks. Appledore.
Appledore, seated on a good River called the Rother, not far from its influx into the Sea, where it saluteth Rye, a Town in Sussex. It hath a Market on Tenderden.

Tenterden, a member of the ancient Town of Rhy, made so by King Henry the Sixth; in whose time this Town and Hundred was first Incorporated; and the election of the Bailiff, and afterwards of the Maior is in the Town-hall. The Steeple of this Church is note-worthy for its fair, lofty, and good building, which in former times, before the Goodwin sands were, was made use of for the hanging a Beacon to direct Seamen. It hath a Market on Fridays. Cranbrook.
Cranbrook, a large and well frequented Market- town on Saturdays, esteemed the best in these parts, which for the conveniency of the Market people and Inhabitants, is now paved. Gouldherst.
Gouldherst, or Goodherst, not far from Cranbrook; hath a Market on Wednesdays. Smarden.
Smarden, scituate on a River, a Town of no great account, as is its Market which is on Fridays. Tong.

Tong, a place of good antiquity, where Hengist the Saxon built a Castle, which was thus occafioned. Vortiger King of Britain, being at wars with the Northern people of this Isle, sent for this Hengist, by whose assistance he gained the Victory, who being unwilling to leave so good a Country behind him, requested leave of the King to stay; and that he might have but so much ground to build a Habitation on, as might be enclosed within the compass of a hide of Leather; which request seeming very small, the King willingly granted: but Hengist craftily, for the enlargement of his Habitation, caused the said Hide to be cut into as small thongs as could be possible, and within the compass thereof he built a Castle, and called it Thong-castle, from whence the Parish took its name; the ruins of which said Castle is yet to be seen; but the story being sufficiently known, I shall say no more. Thong-castle. SHEPWAY-LATH. Lath of Shep-way.

The Lath of Shepway lyeth South of that of St. Pugustine, and is washed on the East, or rather South-East and South by the Sea: It is subdivided into thirteen Hundreds, hath only one division of justiccs of the Peace; and for its chief places hath Hyth.

Hyth, once a place of note, as being one of the Cinque- ports, but now not much frequented, by reason of the Seas unkindness in forsaking it, and its Haven being choaked up; yet doth it still retain its priviledges, as other Cinque-port Towns do; and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is indifferently furnished with provisions. This Town, before its severals
shocks of ill fortune, by the Seas unkindness, the Pestilence, and the Fire, was very large, conteining four Parish Churches: And here are yet two Hospitals, which are both under the government of the Maior and Jurats of the Town. Rumney.

Rumney, another of the Cinque-port-towns: seated in a Marsh so called, of about fourteen miles in length, and eight in breadth; now more famous for the fertility of the Marsh in the grasing of cattle, then for the goodness of the place, by reason of the Seas leaving it, as also for its unwholsome Air; yet doth it still enjoy the priviledges of other the Cinque- ports. At the time of the Conquest this Town was in a flourishing condition, having in it twelve Wards, five Parish Churches, a Priory, and an Hospital. The Town is not large, nor the buildings good, yet is it the chiefest Market-town in the Marsh, which every Thursday is indifferently well served with provisions. Lidd.

Lidd, a member of the Cinque-ports, and is the chief Market-town in Wey-marsh; which said Marsh doth adjoyn to that of Rumney, and by many held the same: And in this Marsh are Denge-marsh, and Wayes- end places well known to Mariners. In the Beach, at the East-side of this Parish, is a great heap of stones, which the Inhabitants say was the Tomb of Crispin and Crispianus, who were there buried. It hath a Market on Thursdays. Folk stone.

Folkstone, once a flourishing Town, and of a large extent, conteining five Parish Churches, which are now reduced to one. It is a Maritime town, and a member of the Port of Dover; is incorporated by the name of a Major, Jurats, and Commonalty, enjoying several immunities; and hath a Market on Thursdays. And nigh unto this Town is Sangate-castle. Eltham.
Eltham, hath a Market on Mondays. St. AVGVSTINES LATH. Lath of St. Au-gustine.

The Lath of St. Augustine hath for its Northern and Eastern bounds the Sea; and for its Southern and Western, the Laths of Shepway and Scray. It is divided into twelve Hundreds, hath one division of Justices of the Peace; and for its chief places hath Canterbury.

Canterbury, a City of great Antiquity, being built, as Authors aver, 900 years before the birth of Christ. It was made famous by Augustine the Monk, who wrought the conversion of the Saxons, and built a magnificent Church for the worship of God, and dedicated it to the name of Christ, which name it still retains, although a long time it was called St. Thomas, in honour of St. Thomas Becket there slain: wherein lyeth interr'd the Bodies of eight Kings, as also of Thomas Becket, so reverenced by the Romanists. And this Church is now the Cathedral, being a large and superb Structure, not inferiour to St. Pauls at London, when in its pristine grandure and splendour. And under this Church, like unto St. Faiths which was under St. Pauls, is a Church made use of by the French or Walloons, which inhabit in this City (which are many, and drive the considerablest trade for their Stuffs there made.) It hath two lofty Towers, which much add to the prospect of the City, and within its bounds or limits are several fair Edifices belonging to the Dean and Prebends, as also a Free-School, called the Kings School. This City is encompassed with a Moat and Wall, on which are (or were)
several Citadels, or Watch-towers, built of Free-stone, without which are its Suburbs; in which, and within the City are numbred 14 Parish Churches It is dignified with an Episcopal See, Primate of all England, and hath under it 21 Suffragan Bishops; and within its particular Diocess, which conteineth part of the County of Kent, are 257 Parishes, of which 140 are Impropriations; the present Lord Bishop is his Grace, Gilbert by Divine Providence Lord Arch-bishop of Canterbury, &c. It is governed by a Maior, Court of Aldermen, and hath a Recorder, and other Sub-officers, that Keep their Sessions for the negotiating of the affairs of the City. The Inhabitants are well provided with provisions, which are here had at easie rates; for besides what is sold daily in its Shambles, it hath weekly two Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, the latter of which is the most considerable. It is beautified with a fair Market-place, over which are Rooms made use of by the Maior and Aldermen. It is also graced with several good buildings, and its streets are well ordered. This City hath been honoured with the Coronations of King John, and Queen Isabel his wife; with the mariages of King Henry the Second, and King Edward the First; and with the Interments of Edward the black Prince, King Henry the Fourth, and Queen Joan his wife. And besides several immunities that it doth enjoy, it hath the election of Parliament men. But many are the distasters that this City hath met with, having oft-times suffered under the flames of a raging fire, with other shocks of ill for tune, which hath much eclipsed its grandure and beauty; yet is it well inhabited and frequented by Trades-men, who drive a considerable trade, especially for their Stuffs. Dover.

Dover, very commodiously seated on the Sea, which together with its strength, as well by Nature as Art, (being loftily scituated between high Cliffs, commanding both Sea and Country adjacent, and defended by a strong Castle, and other Fortifications;) also the commodiousness of its Haven; for being one of the Cinque-port-towns; for giving Title to the Right Honorable Jo. Carew Earl of Dover, &c. and for its short. and ready passage into France (being about 20 miles) makes it a place of considerable note. It also enjoyeth a good trade; and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well frequented and furnished with provisions. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Maior and other Officers; hath several large immunities, as other Cinque-port and Towns Corporate have; and was once of a far larger extent then now it is, having seven Parish Churches, which are reduced to two. Its Castle. The Castle (built by Julius Cæsar) is esteemed a place of great importance, being strongly guarded; In which were formerly two Chappels, a Colledge of Chanons, several streets, and a Market kept. At the West part of the Peere is a Fort called Archliff-Fort, where anciently was a House of the Knights Templers (long fince destroyed) and in the Cliff under the Castle, is a Fort called Motes Bulwark. At the other side of the Castle-hill is a Tower or Light-house, made use of for direction of ships, called Breden-stone; and by some the Devils drop of Morter. Places along the Coast.
Along the shoar going to wards Sandwich, are St. Margarets-bay, Kingsdown, Walmer Castle, Deal Castle, and Sandown castle. Sandwich.

Sandwich, another of the Cinque-port-towns, being incorporated; and amongst its immunities electeth Burgesses. It is a place of good strength, being on the North and West sides fortified with walls; and on the other parts fenced with a River, Ditch, and Rampier; but by reason of the ill-commodiousness of the Harbour, is not well frequented; yet hath it two Markets every week; viz on Wednesdays and Saturdays. About the year 850, at this place, Etbelstone younger son to King
Eghert gave the Danes a fignal overthrow, and took nine of their ships. And amongst several the misfortunes this Town hath had, it was once spoiled by the Danes, and twice was it burnt and sacked by the French. It is honored with the Title of an Earldom, and the present Earl thereof being the Right Honorable Edward Earl of Sandwich. Richborough.

Nigh unto this Town is Richborough, once of good account, but now a small Town. And on the Sea-coast are these places; viz. Small Downs, Pepper Nass; and more Northwards Hope-bay, and Gregston-bay; places not unknowh to Seamen. Isle of Thanet.

The Isle of Thanet doth here present its self, which is about 9 miles long, and about the same breadth, at the broadest: It is very populous, and plentifully stored with provisions, especially corn. Is of some note for being the place where the Saxons, at their coming to help the Britains, flrst landed: here did also land St. Augustine the Monk, when he came to preach the Gospel unto them. Maritime places of note. And here are seated several Towns; as St. Johns, St. Nicholas, Monkton, Mynster, St. Peters, St. Lawrence, &c. and on the North shoar of this Isle are these places, North-foreland, Whit-nass, Fair-nass, Rocking-stairs, Margarets-bay, Nayland-point, Westgate-bay, New-haven, &c. From this Isle the Right Honorable Nicholas Earl of Thanet receives his Title. Deale.

Deal, a member of the Town and Port of Sandwich, seated nigh the Sea, where Julius Cæsar landed; and is strengthened by a Castle built by King Henry the Eighth, which is placed on the Sea side. Fordwich.

Fordwich, also a member of the Port of Sandwich, incorporated by the name of a Major, Jurats, and Commonalty of the town of Fordwich. It is seated on the River Stower, over which it hath a Bridge, and is note worthy for its excellent Trouts. Reculver.

Reculver, a Sea-town, well frequented by Fishermen; and here Ethelbert the first King of Kent had his Palace, and did reside. Its Church is worthy to be took notice of for its lofty spired Steeple, which serveth for a Sea-mark, and was formerly of better esteem then now it is, where lyeth interr'd (as'tis reported) the body of Ethelbert the second King of Kent. Whitstable.
Whitstable, a small Town, but much frequented by Fishermen and Hoymen; this being the best Port-town (next to Feversham) for Canterbury, from which it is distant not above five or six miles.

div1.n: LANCASHIRE, BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div1.head: LANCASHIRE, BEING Part of the BRIGANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County Palatine of Lancaster with its Hundreds

div1.p: THE County Palatine of LANCASTER, for the generality is of an unfertile soil as to the Moorish part; yet hath it sufficiency of all necessaries for the use of man; and is well stored with corn, coals, grass, flax, living cattle, and Oxen the fairest that England produceth, with all sorts of provisions, both flesh, fish, and fowl in great plenty. The East part is very mountainous, and full of stony and craggy hills which are barren, and bare of Wood, being the habitation of Foxes, Coneys, and some Otters; amongst which Hills these are of chief note, viz.Furness Fells, Riving Pike, and Pendle-hill, which are of an exceeding great height, especially Pendle-hill, which seemeth to touch the clouds; and where groweth a Plant which they call Cloudsbery.
