Its Hills. But where the ground is plain and champain, it is very grateful to the Husbandman; except some moist and unwholsome places which they call Mosses, which are of the nature of the Irish-boggs, from which the Inhabitants are supplyed with a sort of fewel called Turff; and in these Mosses they also oft-times digg up several Trees of Oak and Firr, which serveth them as well for building as firing: and of these Mosses, those of Chatmoss, Pillin, the Mosses of Leyland and Darby hundreds are of chief note, being many miles in compass. Mosses. The Air.
The Air is serene and sharp, yet very healthful, so that the Inhabitants live to a great age. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the Counties of York, and part of Darby; on the South with the River Mersey, which severeth it from Cheshire; On the West with the Irish Sea; and on the North with the Counties of Cumberland and Westmoreland. Its extent.

It extendeth it self in length from Halwood in the South, to Brathey in the North, about 57 miles; and in breadth from Denton in the East, to Formby by Altmouth in the West, about 31; and in circumference about 170 miles. Its Rivers.

It is very well watered with Rivers, the chief of which are the Mersey,
sey, Irwell, Roch, Irke, Dugless, Yarrow, Ribell, Derwent, Codar, Brockwyre, Lune, Keere, Kent, Dudden and others; which (with the Sea, into which they fall, together with the Meers) plentifully serve the Inhabitants with fish. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants were the Brigantes, who were brought under the Roman subjection by Claudius the Emperour; and when the Saxons had to do in this Land, it became part of the Kingdom of the Northumbers. Religious Houses.

Religions Houses in this County (which were fair Structures and richly endowed) were those of Whalley, Lithorn, Cockersand, Furnes, Cartnell, Penwortham, Burstogh, Holland, the cell at Lancaster, and the Fryer Minors at Preston. Its division both Ecclesiastical and Temporal.

This County according to the Ecclesiastical Government thereof, is all in the Diocess of Chester; and is divided, (that is, all the South part) into the Arch-deaconry of Chester; and the North part into the Arch-deaconry of Richmond; and in these are several Deaneries.

For Temporal Government it is divided into six Hundreds; one of which, to wit Furness Fells, is severed from the rest of the County, by an arm or Bay of the Sea so called. And although there are but 61 Parishes in the County, yet is it very populous, the Parishes being large, conteining within them several Chappels of Ease, which may be reckoned with Parisbes in other Counties. And amongst these Parishes there are 27 Market-towns, many of which are large, well frequented, and traded unto: whose names are as followeth. Lancaster.

Lancaster, pleasantly seated on the South-side of the River Lone or Lune; over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, susteined by five Arches; a place of good antiquity, where a Company of the Longovicarians, under the Lieutenant General of the Britains, kept their stations; and where the Fryery stood, pieces of Roman Coyn have oft-times been dug up, upon which place 'tis said the ancient City stood which was destroyed by the Scots. It is a place at present indifferent large, conteining several well ordered streets, and well built houses; yet hath it but one Parish Church, which is large and fair, being seated on the side of a high Hill, on the top of which standeth the Castle, now made use of as a Prison for the County, both for Debtors and Malefactors, and where the Assizes are alwayes kept for the County; yet is it not a Town much frequemed, nor inhabited by Tradesmen, but chiefly by Husbandmen, as lying in a good soil. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Maior, two Bailiffs, twelve Brethren, twenty four Burgesses, two Chamberleyns, a Recorder, Town-Clark, &c. and amongst its immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. Statute Merchants are here acknowledged before the Maior and Clark of the Statutes for the time being. The chief ornaments in this Town are its Church, Castle, Bridge, and Market-house, or Town-hall, where the Maior and his Brethren keep their Courts: And its Market is on Saturdays, which is well provided with provisions, especially sish, and chiefly with Salmon, Corn, and Cattle. Manchester.

Manchester, seated between the Rivers Irke and Irwell, and upon a stony hill; and near adjoyning at Colyhurst are good Quarries of stone dug up. It is a Town of great antiquity, called by Antonine the Emperour Mancunium, and was a Fort and Station of the Romans. It is at present a large, beautiful, and well inhabited Town, much resorted unto, and enjoyeth a considerable trade for most commodities, but chiefly for its linnen and woollen cloths; as also for its Cottons, known by the name of Manchester-cottons, which are held in great esteem: It is also much inhabited by Sempsters and Mercers. The chief ornament of this Town is its Colledge, its Market-
place, but above all, its Collegiate Church which is very ornamental, and beautified with a small Quire of excellent workmanship. It is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which at present is in the person of the Right Honorable Robert Montague Earl of Manchester, &c. And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very considerable for the abovesaid commodities, as also for provisions. Salford.
On the banks of the other side of the River opposite to Manchester is Salford, a pretty large place, with a Chappel of Ease. Alparke.

Near adjoyning to Manchester, in a Park belonging to the Earl of Darby, called Alpark, (where Medlock falleth into Irwell) is the ground plot of an ancient four-square Fortress, which is called Man-castle. Rochdale.
Rochdale, seated on the River Roch, and in a Vale; bath a very considerable Market on Tuesdays chiesly for cloth, stockings, corn, and living cattle. Bury.
Bury, a Market-town of no great account on Thursdays. Boulton.

Boulton, seated on the River Irwell, a fair and well built Town, with broad streets; hath a Market on Mondays, which is very good for cloth and provisions; and is a place of great trade for Fustians. Colne.
Colne, fcituate on a little Hill, near the Eastern confines of the County; hath a good Market on Wednesdays for cattle, provisions, &c. Burnley.
Burnley, seated not far from Colne, hath a good Market on Tuesdays for cattle and provisions. Clitheroe.

Clitheroe, seated not far from Pendle-hill, an ancient Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men. It is governed by two Bailiffs, and is famous for White-lime, and a Castle, which was the seat of the Lacies Earls of Lincoln. It hath a good Market on Saturdays for cattle, yarn, and provisions. Whalley.
Not far from Clitheroe is Whalley, once famous for the Monastery founded by the Lacies. Haslingden.
Haslingden, a very small Market-town on Wednesdays. Blackborne.

Blackborn, so called from the Brook or Rivulet of Blackwater which runneth through it, and is seated near the River Derwent. It is a good Town, and hath a great weekly meeting, by some called a Market for cattle, corn, and provisions on Mondays. Warington.

Warington, seated on the River Mersey, over which there is a curious Stone-bridge which leadeth to Cheshire; It is a very fine and large Town, which hath a considerable Market on Wednesdays for linnen-cloth, corn, cattle, provisions, and fish, being much resorted unto by the Welch-men; and is of note for its Lampres. Newton.
About three miles from this Town is Newton, a Borough-town which sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. Leigh
Leigh, a small Market-town, and of mean account. Prescott.
Prescott, hath an indifferent Market for corn, cattle, and provisions on Tuesdays. Lerpoole.

Lerpoole, or Leverpoole, commodiously seated on the River Mersey, which spreadeth it self like a Pool. It is a Corporation and Borough-town; and amongst other its immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. It is a place well inhabited and traded unto by Merchants and Shopkeepers, and is of late beautified with good built houses; and the more for its commodious Haven, and convenient passage to Ireland. It hath a considerable Market on Saturdays for live cattle, corn, and all provisions. Orms-Kirk.

Orms-kirk, or Orms-church, scituate near the River Douglass, and not far from the large Mecr of Merton. It is a very fair Town, and hath a very good Market on Thursdays for corn, cattle, sheep, horses, fish, fowl, and other provisions.
Merton-meer.

Not far from Ormes-kirke, is Merton-meer or Pool, about 20 miles in circuit, within which are three small Islands. And this Pool or Meer emptieth it self one way into the River Douglass, and by another Rivulet falleth into the Sea at North-meals. Great Eccleston.
Great Eccleston, scituate near the River Wyre, whose Market (if any) is so inconsiderable, that it is not worth the taking notice of. Wigan.

Wigan, a large and well built Town Corporate, governed by a Major, Bailiffs, and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men; and hath StatuteMerchants acknowledged before the Maior, and Clark of the Statutes for the time being; and his Majesty, for its loyalty, hath honoured it with a Sword. It is seated on the River Douglass; hath two Markets weekly on Mondays and Fridays, for meal and other provisions; and the Town is of a good trade, and much inhabited by Braziers, Pewterers, Dyers, Weavers of Ruggs, Coverlets, and Ticking for bedding; and is most famous for fewel, especially for the choicest coal in England, called Caunell.
Night to this Town, by the River Douglass, the noble Arthur (as 'tis reported) obteined a memorable Victory against the Saxons, and put them to flight. A burning well.
And near unto this Town is the strange and wondred at Burning-well. Chorley.

Chorley, seated near the spring-head of a Brook or Rivulet called Chor, not far from the River Yarrow. It is but a small Town, yet its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is well furnished with yarn and provisions. Kirkham.
Kirkbam, seated not far from the River Rible, or rather an arm of the Sea so called: it is beautified with a fair Church; and hath a very small Market on Tuesdays. Preston.

Preston, a great, fair, and well inhabited and frequented Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men; seated on the North side of the Rible, over which it hath a very fair Stone-bridge. In this Town are held the Court of Chancery, and offices of Justice for the County Palatine of Lancaster; and is incorporated by the name of a Major, Bailiffs, and Burgesses; is governed by a Major and 24 Common-councel-men; and the Courts of Justice within the same, are held before the Major, Bailiffs, and Steward. And here are Statute-Merchants acknowledged before the Maior, and Clark of the Statutes for the time being. It hath a very large Marketplace, and the other streets are very open, large, and evenly paved, and the houses well built. At several ends of the Town are Almes-houses for the poor to dwell in. And for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, here are weekly three Markets, viz. on Wednesdays, Fridays, and Saturdays which is the chief, being considerable for corn, all sorts of living cattle, linnen- cloth, all sorts of provisions, and several other commodities in great plenty. Rible-chester.

Rible-chester, not far from Preston, so called from the River Rible, on which it is seated; which though a small Town at present, was in the time of the Romans esteemed by many a City of great account, whose many Statues, pieces of coyn, heathen Altars, pillars, inscriptions, and other pieces of Antiquity here oft-times dug up, have sufficiently testified the same. Garstrange.
Garstrange, or Gasting, seated upon the River Wire, an indifferent good Town, and hath a great Market for corn, cattle, yarn, and fish on Thursdays. Poulton.
Poulton, scituate in the Fild near the River Wire; hath a good Market on Mondays for corn, fish, and other provisions. Cartmell.

Cartmell, seated amongst the Hills called Cartmell-fells, not far from the Sea, and near the River Kent. It is beautified with a very fair Church, built Cathedral wise in form of a Cross; and was (as 'tis said) the Church which belonged to the Priory called Kertmele Priory. The Market, which is on Mondays, aboundeth with corn, sheep, and fish, especially with a fish called Flooks or Flounders.
ulverston.

Ulverston, commonly called Ouston, scituate between the branches of a River, which at a small distance looseth it self in the Sea, or an arm thereof near Leven-sand. It is an indifferent good Town, and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is well served with corn, sheep, fish, and provisions. Dalton.

Dalton, seated also in the lower Furness, in a Champain Country, on the Spring-head of a River, and not far from the Sea. Here is an ancient Castle now belonging to his Grace Christopher Duke of Albemarle, &c. wherein is kept the Records, and Prisoners for Debt for the Liberty of Furnes. It hath a Market on Saturdays, which is plentifully furnished with corn, cattle, fish, and fowl. Furness-Abbey
Not far from Dalton is Furness Abbey, a Monastery of Cistertian Monks. Isles of Walney, Barrow, Foulney.

Further Westwards are Walney Isle, old Barrow Isle, Foulney Isle, and the Pyle of Foudrey, once a strong Fort seated on a Rock, but now quite ruinated. Pile of Foudrey. Here is an excellent Haven, which was made use of by the Earl of Lincoln, the Lord Lovell, and Martin Swart, rebells against King Henry the Seventh, by landing their men; and which was made use of by the Earl of Darby in Anno 1651. for his Majesties service, by disbarking himself and men there. The Island of Foulney is so fertile, that the grass thereof doth constantly in February and March feed sheep fat for slaugher; which is attributed to the dung which the vast number of Sea-fowl that resort thither do make. Hornby.

Hornby, seated between the branches of the River Lune, in which there is the ruins of the Seat of the Lord Morley and Mounteagle, a very fair Castle; It is beautified with a handsome Parochial Chappel; and the Market, which is on Mondays, is now much decayed, and very small. Hawkes-head.

Hawkes-head, placed in a hilly and woody Country, hath a little Market for the sale of provisions, wool, and yarn on Mondays: And in this Town there is a Free Grammer-School, endowed by Edwin Sands Arch-bishop of york, who was born near unto this place. Wimandermeer, Coningwater.

Not far from this Town are two large Meers, or waters called Wimander Meer, and Conington, or Thurston-water; both which are of a great length, breadth and depth, and are well stored with Pikes, Pearch, Trouts, Eeles, and Charrs, which last is a sort of fish only taken in Winder-meer-water in Westmoreland. Black-rock.
Places along the Sea-shoar beginning Southwards, are first the Black-rock, not unknown to Sea-men. Fourness-fells.

Sunder land-point, beyond which more Northwards is Fourness-fells; a very great Bay, which doth sever the Liberty of Fourness-fells from the rest of the County, on whose shoars are large shelves of Sand called Levell-sands; and Kent-sands, which doth much repulse the impetuous waves of the raging Sea. And at the point Westward is seated Foulney- Isle; nigh to which is the Pool of Foudray, Oldbaro Isle, both small Islands; and then Waltney-Isle, which is of a long, but narrow form.

div1.n: LEICESTERSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORITANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: LEICESTERSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORITANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Leicester

div1.p: LEICESTER, a Champain Country, and of a different soil, the South-east part being exceeding fertile for all sorts of Grain, especially Pease and Beans; and hath rich Pastures, which feed store of cattle and sheep, whose wool for its fineness is had in great esteem; The North-west part is generally barren, and in some places rocky and stony; and about the Forest of Charwood (where is Bardon-hill) is store of Lime-stone, wherewith they manure their ground; and the South-west, and North-east parts, are of a good soil both for tillage and pasturage.

It is but thinly clothed with Wood, especially in the South and East parts; which defect is sufficiently supplyed by the great plenty of Pit-coal, digged up in the Northern parts, which being hilly is called the Would, and breedeth abundance of cattle. Its Bounds.

It hath for its Eastern bounds the Counties of Rutland and Lincoln: for its Southern, Northamptonshire; for its Western, Warwickshire, where runeth Watling-street-way; and for its Northern, the Counties of Darby and Nottingham. Its extent.

Its extent from Sewstern in the East, to Orton in the West, is about 27 miles; and from Cathorp in the South, to Lockington in the North, is about 23; and makes in circumference about 196 miles. Its Castles and Forts.

It hath been strengthened with divers Forts and Castles, as at Leicester, Mountsorell, Shilton, Whitwike, Donington, Groby, Hinkely, Segrave, Thorpe, Melton, and Burrow, an ancient Fort of the Romans. Religious Houses.

Here were also many Religious Houses and Colledges; as the Abbeys of St. Mary de Pratis in Leicester, Croxton, Gerendon, and Oweston. The Priories of Kirby Bellere, Launde, Bredon, Bradley, Charley, and Hinkley: The Nunneries of Langeley, and Grace dieu; and the Colledges of Sapcott, Nosely, and St. Maries the great, and St. Maries the less at Leicester. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, which afford good convenience to the Inhabitants, the chief amonst which are the Sour, anciently called the Leir, from a Town thereon seated; Trent, Wreke, Welland, Sence, and Eye. Its ancient Inhabitants.

The Inhabitants that possessed this County were the Coritani; and in the time of the Saxon Government, made part of the Kingdom of the Mercians.
Its division.
It is severed into six Hundreds, in which are numbred about 200 Parish Churches, and hath intercourse of traffick with twelve Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Leicester.

Leicester, pleasantly seated in a rich soil, healthful air, and on the banks of the Stour or Sour (of old called Leir) which washes its Northern and Western parts, over which are two Bridges; It is a place more famous for antiquity then beauty, being said to be built by King Leir 844 years before the birth of Christ, and called Caer-Lerion, wherein he placed a Flamin or High Priest, to serve in the Temple of Janus, by himself there erected, and where he was buried, if Jeffrey ap Arthur saies true; but more certain it is, that it was in great request in the time of the Romans; and that here was erected an Episcopal See by Ethelred King of the Mercians in Anno Christi 680, but soon translated elsewhere, which did much impair the beauty of the City, which lay in a languishing condition until the noble and virtuous Lady Edelfled in Anno 914. took compassion on it, and not only reedified her buildings, but also encompassed it with a strong Wall; and in a short time after it became a place of so great a trade, that Mathew Paris called it a wealthy City. But in the reign of K. Henry the Second, it was sore overpressed with sundry and grievous calamities, and was dismantled of her Walls, Fortifications, and Castle, which was large and strong. But the Author of these miseries (to wit, Robert Bossu the crouch-back, Earl of this shire) for the expiating his horrid crimes, built the Monastery of St. Mary de Pratis, wherein he became a regular Canon, and for 15 years offered up his prayers to God for pardon of his sins. With the like devotion Henry the first Duke of Lancaster, built an Hospital for 110 poor people, with a fair Collegiate Church, and liberally endowed it, wherein he lyeth interr'd. As to the present state of Leicester, it is a Borough, and Town Corporate, governed by a Maior, Aldermen, and Sub-officers; is dignified in giving Title to the Right Honorable Robert Sidney, Earl of Leicester,&c. and is the only Town in the County that hath the election of Parliament men. It is indifferent large, conteining three Parish Churches, hath several good buildings, is well inhabited; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with corn, provisions, and Countrey commodities. Crouch-back Richard slain at Redmore near Bosworth

From this Town it was that crouch-back Richard set forth with great pomp and force to Redmore near Bosworth, where on the 22 of Aug. 1485. in a bloody battle there fought (for the deciding the differences betwixt the houses of York and Lancaster) he was slain, yielding both himself, and the success of the day to the victorious Henry of Richmond, who was proclaimed King in the field; and the next day the body of the said Richard was brought back in ignominy, being cast cross a horses back naked and torn, and as meanly buried in the Gray Fryers of Leicester, which being afterwards destroyed, the Sepulcher wherein he lay (which was a stone chest) now serveth in an Inn for a drinking trough for horses. Hinckley.

Hinckley, seated near Watling-street, on the edge of the County towards Warwickshire, and in a good soil; It is beautified with a fair and large Church which hath a lofty Spire-steeple; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is very well served with corn, cattle, horse, swine, provisions, and most sorts of Country commodities. Bosworth.

Bosworth, or Market-Bosworth, loftily seated on a Hill, and in a fertile soil for corn and grass; an ancient Town, whose Market, which is on Wednesdays, is but small; yet is it still of note for the bloody battel fought betwixtKing Richard and Henry of Richmond at Redmore near adjoyning, as before noted; which place is now known by the name of King Richards field.
Ashby de la Zouch.
Ashby de la Zouch, seated between two Parks, and near unto Darbyshire; a Town of some account, and hath a very good Market on Saturdays. Cole-overton.
Near unto this Town is Cole-overton, of note for its Pitt-coals, which are here had in great plenty. Loughborow.

Loughborow, pleasantly seated amongst fertile meadows, near the Forest of Charwood, which is well clothed with Wood, and on the banks of the Sour, over which it hath a Bridge; It is a good handsome Town, adorned with fair buildings, and a large Church; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very considerable for corn, cattle, sheep, and provisions. Mont-sorell.

Mont-sorell, or Mont-soar-hill, seated on a great eminency, and near the River Sour, where there is a Bridge for the conveniency of passage: and in times past it was of great renown for its Castle seated on a steep and craggy Hill, long since demolished. It is at present an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Mondays. Barrow.
At Barrow near adjoyning, is digged up excellent Lime, much commended for its binding. Melton-Mowbray

Melton-Mowbray, scituate in a fertile soil, and on the banks of the River Eye, which almost encircleth it, over which are two fair Stone-bridges. The Town is indifferent large, the Houses well built, and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very considerable for corn, cattle, hoggs, sheep, provisions, &c. being esteemed the best in the County, next to Leicester. Burton Lazers

Near unto this Town is Burton, or Burton- Lazers; so called from a famous Hospital or Spittle there founded about the time of the first coming in of the Normans, by a common contribution over all England, for the cure of the Leprosie, which then sorely infected the Kingdom. Veromentum, now called Burrow.

Mr. Cambden maketh mention of the ancient City of Veromentum that stood in these parts, highly seated; whose ruinous Walls which enclosed about 18 Acres of ground (now made use of by the Husbandman) sufficiently speak it to have been a place of good account in the time of the Romans, where they had their Temple; and out of the ruins of this City, Burrow, or Burrow-hill, is said to have been raised. Waltham on the would.
Waltham on the would, a pretty good Town, and well seated in an who som air; but its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very inconsiderable, and in a manner disused. Billesden.
Billesden, scituate in a Bottom; a little Town, and hath a very mean Market on Fridays. Life-hill.
Nigh unto this Town is Life-hill, a place of a great eminence, and enjoyeth a large and pleasant prospect; on the top of which is placed a Beacon. Hallaton.
Hallaton, seated in a rich soil; a very small Market- town on Thursdays. Harborow.

Harborow, an ancient and pretty good Market- town, seated on the River Welland, which severeth it from Northamptonshire; Its Market is on Tuesdays, which is of good account for corn, cattle, and provisions. Lutterworth.

Lutterworth, seated in a good soil, and on the River Swift, which after a small distance falleth into the River Avon in Warwickshire; It is an indifferent Country Town, beautified with a large and fair Church, which hath a neat lofty and Spire-steeple; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is well served with corn and Country commodities. Clebrook.

Nigh unto this Town is Clebrook, raised out of the ruins of Cleycester, which was an ancient and flourishing City, and had a Senate of Aldermen in it; whose antiquity doth appear by the pieces of Roman coins, four-square stone, &c. often plowed up. Nigh to this place was the station Benones or Venones of the Romans.

div1.n: LINCOLNSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORITANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: LINCOLNSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORITANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Lincolne, with its divisions & Hundreds: or Wapontacks

div1.p: LINCOLN, a County of a large extent, stretching its self in length from Sutton in the East, to Ganesbrough in the West, about 35 miles: and from Stamford in the South, to Barton in the North, about 55; making in circumference about 180 miles. And in form, this County may not unaptly be compared to a bow bent, whose Eastern part thrusteth it self into the Sea, and receiveth several inlets. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the German Ocean; on the South with the Counties of Cambridge, Northampton, and Rutland; on the West with those of Leicester, Nottingham, and york, from which it is separated by the Rivers Dane and Trent; and on the North with the River Humber, which disjoyns it also from Yorkshire. Its soil. Its Rivers.

The soil is of a different temperature, the Western and Northern parts being exceeding fertile and pleasant, having rich pastures, which feed store of cattle, and bearing good crops of corn; and the Eastern and Southern parts are fenny, barren, and more unfit for corn; but in recompence thereof hath fowl and fish so plentifull, that 'tis reported about 3000 Mallards (besides other sorts) have been taken at one draught with a Net: And for fish it hath as great plenty, by reason of its Sea-coasts and others. The Air.

The Air upon the South and East parts is thick and foggy, occasioned through the fenny grounds; and the Eastern part thrusteth it self forth into the Sea, and receiveth several of her Salt-water inlets and sands, which are not safe for the Traveller. Commodities
The chief commodities that this shire affordeth, are corn, cattle, fish, fowl, flax, wool, Alablaster, &c. Religious Houses.

Religious Houses were at Lincoln, Crowland, Grymmisby, Markeby, Grenfeld, Leyborne, Newncrsby, Alvingham, Elsham, Newstead, Torkesey, Syxhill, Staynsfeld, Bryggerd, Thornholme, Fosse, Nuncotton, Axholme Isle, Hevings,
St. Michaels near Stamford, Spalding, Goykewell, Kirkested, Swyneshead, &c. Its parts.

It is severed into three principal parts, viz. Lindsey, Holland, and Kesteven; which are divided into thirty Hundreds, in which are numbred 631 Parish Churches: and for the benefit of the Inhabitants, is traded unto by 31 Market-towns, many of which are of good account, which I shall take notice of in each part. LINDSEY Part or Division. Lindsey Part.

Lindsey, the most Northern part, so named from its chief City Lincoln, whose ancient name, according to Bede, was Lindissi. This part is a sort of Island, which for extent exceedeth the other two, and is severed from that of Kesteven (which lyeth South) by the River Witham and the Fosse-dike, which was cast up, and scoured at the charge of King Henry the First, for the space of seven miles from the said River Witham, unto that of Trent; for the further ease and benefit of the Inhabitants of Lincoln, for the conveying their Goods by water. This Part giveth Title to the Right Honorable Robert Bertue, Earl of Lindsey, &c. And the chief places in this division, are Lincoln.

Lincoln, pleasantly seated on the side of a Hill, and on the River Witham, which divideth it self into several streams, and waters the lower part of the City, over which are divers Bridges for the accommodation of the Inhabitants in their passage to and fro. This City hath had the change of several names, Ptolomy and Antonine called it Lindam; Beda, Linde- Collina; the Normans, Nichol; and now Lincoln. It is a City of great Antiquity, and hath been far more magnificent and spacious, whose ancient ruinated places witness the same; being said to have had for Divine worship 50 Churches, which now are reduced to 15, besides its Cathedral or Minster. It was a place of great strength and fame in the time of the Britains; and (according to Dooms-day-book) it conteined 1070 Mansions, and 900 Burgesses, with twelve Lage-men, having sac: and soc: and in the time of the Normans (according to William of Malmesbury) it was one of the best peopled Cities in the Island, and enjoyed a great trade both by Sea and Land, whose flourishing condition did occasion Remigins, then Bishop of Dorchester to remove his Episcopal See hither. And here King Edward the Third ordained his Staple for the Mart of Wools, Leather, and Lead. Nor is it to be forgot that Vortimer, that noble and warlike Britain, who so often repelled the Saxons, did here end his dayes, and was interr'd, though contrary to his command; having thoughts that if he were buried in the Sea-shoar, his very Ghost would protect the Britains from the Saxons. But this City hath not been without its calamities. In the time of the Saxons, Arthur enforced thence their Host; the like did King Edmund Iron-sides to the Danes; who had made fore havock thereof. On the fifth of September, 1140 here was a great Battle fought by Robert Earl of Glocester, and Ralph Earl of Chester, against King Stephen, in the defence of Maud the Empress, in which the King was taken Prisoner, and laid in Irons in Bristoll. Here was also a fore Battle fought on the 19 of May; 1217. betwixt King Henry the Third and his disloyal Barons, who aided Lewis, Danphin of France; in which the King gained the day, and took divers of them Prisoners. It suffered also forely by fire, which very much defaced and consumed its buildings; and by an Earthquake her Foundations were shaken and much weakned; wherein its fair Cathedral, dedicated to the Virgin Mary and All Saints, first built by Paulinus Arch-bishop
of York, was shevered in pieces, which was by Remigius rebuilt; and being not long after defaced by fire, was for the most part repaired, and beautified by Bishop Alexander, and finished to what it now is by Hugh of Burgundy, and other succeeding Bishops. And notwithstanding these sad misfortunes, it is at present a large City, well inhabited and frequented, enjoyeth a good trade; and its Markets on Fridays is well served with provisions, the best Families in the neighbouring County sending in their Servants many miles to buy fish and flesh; and its shops are well furnished with commodities. It is dignified with an Episcopal See, where the Bishop hath his Palace, and whose Diocess at this day is the greatest of any in England, both for Jurisdiction and Shires; numbring within its said extent 1255 Parishes, of which 577 are Impropriations, and hath, under the government of its Bishop, six Arch-deacons, Viz. of Lincoln, Bedford, Buckingham, Huntington, Leicester and Stow. It is also dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which at present is invested in the person of the Right Honorable Edward Fines, Earl of Lincoln, &c. Its Cathedral or Minster, as now standing, is one of the fairest and stateliest in all England; and so loftily elevated, that it meets the Travellers eye Southwards about 30 miles, and Northwards about 50, whose floor equalleth the height of many Churches in England; and in one of its Steeples is a Bell (which they call Tom of Lincoln) so large, that it requireth about 15 or 16 able men to raise and ring it. This City is governed by a Major, two Sheriffs, twelve Aldermen who are clothed in Scarlet; besides a Recorder, Town Clark, four Chamberleyns, a Sword-bearer, four Sergeants at Mace, &c. enjoyeth ample immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and is a County of it self, whose Liberties extend about 20 miles in compass, and is called the County of the City of Lincoln. Torkesey.

Nigh unto this City, and where the Foss Dike entreth into the River Trent, is seated Torksey, now a little Town, but in former dayes very famous and large, conteining 200 Burgesses; and enjoyed many priviledges on the condition, that they should carry the Kings Embassadors whensoever they came this way, through the Foss Dike, in their own Barges along the Trent, and transport them as far as York. Ganesburgh,

Ganesburgh, or Ganesborow, commodiously seated on the Trent near the Sea; of note in former times for being the place where the Danish Tyrant Suene Tiugs-Kege was stabbed to death by an unknown hand, as a just reward for his many outrages committed in the Country. It is a large and well built Town, of a very considerable trade; and hath a very good Market on Tuesdays for cattle and provisions. Kirton.
Kirton, seated on the edge of Lincoln-heath; a very good Town, which hath a considerable Market on Saturdays for provisions. Sidnacestor.
In this part stood formerly the ancient City of Sidnacestor, once the See of a Bishop, but now not so much as its ruins are to be seen, nor any memory left thereof. Burton.
Burton, or Burton Stather, scituate on a Hill, and on or near the Trent; a small Town, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Isle of Axholme.

The Isle of Axholme is in this part, made so by the Rivers Trent, Dun, Idell and others; and extendeth it self in length from South to North about ten miles, but in breadth not half so much; in which said circuit are seated several Towns. The flat and lower part of this Isle towards the Rivers is moorish ground, and yieldeth a sweet shrub,calledby them Gall. Also in the moorish parts, great and tall Firr-trees have been in parts adjacent digged up: and the middle part, which is a rising ground, is fertile and produceth great store of Flax, and not without the Alablaster-stone.
Barton.

Barton, seated on the River Humber, where there is a considerable Ferry or Passage over into yorkshire, which said Ferry doth add a good advantage to the Town, which is large and stragling; and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Glamford Bridges.
Glamford Bridges, scituate on the River Ankam, an indifferent Town; but hath a good Market on Thursdays for cattle and provisions. Grimsby magna.

Grimsby, or Grimsby magna, seated within half a mile of the River Humber, or rather the Sea, and in a flat and marshy rich ground, fit both for Tillage and Pasturage. It is a Town Corporate, enjoyeth several immunities, hath the benefit of a Port-town, and keepeth Courts for the determining causes, punishment of petty Theft, sending Burgesses to Parliament, &c. and is governed by a Maior, twelve Aldermen, a Recorder, two Justices of the Peace, a Town Clark, two Coroners, two Bailiffs, two Chamberleyns, &c. The Maior keeping his Courts weekly on Tuesdays, and the Bailiffs on Fridays. It was formerly a very large Town, conteining two Parish Churches, and enjoyed a good trade, occasioned by its commodious Haven, which being now choaked up, it hath lost much of its trade and grandure, it now contenting it self but with one Church, which for largeness giveth place to few Cathedrals in England; yet hath it several streets, and its houses are well built. Here was formerly an Abbey dedicated to St. Augustine and St. Olive; also a Nunnery consecrated to St. Leonard, and two Priories and two Chantries, all which are now reducd to ruins, and in their places houses erected. In the time of King Henry the Second, it had a Castle for the security of its Port, which is likewise decayed. This Town had formerly the benefit of two Markets weekly, the one on Wednesdays, and the other on Saturdays, but at present that on Wednesdays is sufficient for the Inhabitants, which is indisferently well provided with provisions. Binbrook.
Binbrook, seated in a Bottom, a very small Town, but hath two Parish Churches; and a Market very inconsiderable on Wednesdays. Thong Caster.
Thong Caster, or Castor, seated on the side of a Hill, a well compacted Town; and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is very considerable chiefly for cattle, sheep, and swine.

This Town is of note for its ancient Castle so called, said to be built by Hengist the Saxon, after he had beaten the Picts and Scots by favour of Vortiger, who granted him so much ground as an Ox-hide would compass cut into thongs, within which he erected the Castle. Salesleet.
Saltleet, a small Maritime-town of little account; but of chief note for being a place frequented by the Gentry in the Sommer season, for the eating of fish. It hath an indifferent Market on Lowthe.

Lowthe, seated on or near a River; a very large, well built, and inhabited Town Corporate, governed by a Warden and seven Assistants; and hath weekly two Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, that on Wednesdays being the chief, and is very well frequented, and considerable for cattle, horses, swine, corn, and all sorts of provisions. Market Rasen.
Market-Rasen, scituate on a branch of the River Ankone, which affordeth good Eeles; a small Town, and hath a well resorted Market on Tuesdays, chiefly for corn and provisions. Alford.

Alford, seated on a small Brook, which runneth through part of the Town, which is neatly compacted and well built; and hath a Market on Tuesdays, which is well served with provisions, and small quantities of corn.

Not far from this Town is Silesby or Selby, where King Henry the First received his fist breath.
Waynfleet,

Waynfleet, seated not far from the Sea in a Fenny part, and on a Wash or Dike, which falleth into the Sea, as also into the River Witham near Boston; a well compacted Town, and hath an excellent good Free-School founded by William of Waynfleet, who also built Maudlin Colledge in OXford: Its Market, which is on Saturdays, is but indifferent, except for fish, for which it is of good account. Burgh.
Burgh, seated in the Marsh, a small Town, and hath a mean Market on Thursdays. Spilsby.
Spilsby, scituate on the side of a Hill, an indifferent Town; whose Market, which is kept on Mondays, is very considerable both for corn and cattle. Bullingbrook.

Bullingbrook, seated at the Spring-head of a River which falleth into the Witham, and on a low ground, an ancient Town; and of note for its Castle built by William of Romara, Earl of Lincoln; but more famous for being the birth place of King Henry the Fourth (surnamed Henry of Bullingbrook) and hath ever since his time been one of the honours of the Crown of England. It is also dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which at present is in the person of the Right Honorable, Oliver Earl of Bullingbrook. The Town is but indifferent, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Hardley.
Near this Town is Hardley, the burial place of Queen Elianor, wife to K. Edward the first. Horn-Castle.

Horn-Castle, seated on the River Bane, where another River brancheth forth, or falleth in, so that three parts are encircled with water. It is a large and well built Town, and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is very considerable for corn, sheep, hoggs, and all sorts of provisions. Market-Stanton.
Market-Stanton, seated on a small Hill, a Town of little account; and hath an inconsiderable Market on Saturdays. Tatershall.

Tatershall, seated on the Bane, near its joyning with the River Witham, and in a Fenny part; a small Town, but in former time of note for its Castle; And its Market, which is on Fridays, is but small. KESTEVEN DIVISION. Kesteven part.

The next of the three Parts or Divisions of this County is Kesteven, which Athelward calleth Ceostefnewood; being Northwards of Linasey part, and Westwards of that of Holland: Its chief places are Stamford,

Stamford, seated in the edge of the County near Northamptonshire, and on the River Weland, now made navigable, which afordeth no small advantage to the Town, and adjacent places; its Inhabitants driving a considerable trade, especially for Mault, which is here made in great plenty; as also for Free-stone, which they have from Ketton Quarry. It is a Town of good antiquity, from whence the Roman High-street, or High-Dike, leadeth to the North; and was of note in thereign of Edward the Third, at which time there was a Colledge for the Professors of the Arts and Sciences, which hath been long since discontinued upon the Students removal to Brasennose Colledge in Oxford, at which time it was in great repute, and enjoyed large immunities, many of which it still keepeth, as the election of Parliament men, &c. and is governed by a Maior, Aldermen, Recorder, and Sub- officers. The Town is at present fair and large, conteining several streets; and for Divine worship hath six Parish Churches, being beautified with several fair buildings, begirt with a Wall, is well inhabited and frequented, and its Markets, which are on Mondays and Fridays, are well frequented and furnished with commodities, affording corn, living cattle, and all sorts of provisions in great plenty; but that on Mondays is but small. The Town is
dign ified with the Title of an Earldom, which is at present in the person of the Right Honorable Henry Grey, Earl of Stamford. Market-Deeping.

Market-Deeping, or Deeping, seated not far from Stamford, and also on the River Weland, in a fenny ground, where Richard de Rulos, Chamberlain to William the Conquerour, for the hindring its overflowing, raised its banks, and built thereon divers Tenements, insomuch that it became a great Village. It is at present an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Thursdays. Bourn,

Bourn, seated at the head of a Spring called Burnwellhead, which produceth a River which runeth through the Town, which is of note for being the place where King Edmond was crowned. It is a large Town, and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is very good for corn and provisions.
Here was formerly a very good Castle, which now is ruinous. Swinsted-Abbey.
Not far from Bourn is Swinsted-Abbey, one of whose Monks, named Simon, poysoned King John. Folkingham.
Folkingham, seated on the side of a Hill, a very ancient Town, formerly of good account, now much decayed, and its Castle ruinated; it hath a small Market on Thursdays. Grantham.

Grantham, scituate on the River Witham, a Town of good account, and well resorted unto; beautified with a School for the education of Youth, built by Richard Fox Bishop of Winchester; and a fair Church, whose Spire exalting it self to so great an eminence, that it seemeth crooked to the eye of the beholder. It is a Borough-town, governed by an Alderman, and twelve Justices of the Peace; hath the election of Parliament men; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very large, and well served with sheep, corn, mault, and all sorts of provisions. Harlaxton.

Not far from Grantham at Harlaxton, about 150 years since was found by a Plough-man a Golden Helmet, of an antick fashion, supposed to be the Helmet of some chief Commander of the Romans; which was presented to Katherine of Spain, Wife and Dowager to K. Henry the Eighth. Great Paunton.

Great Paunton, seated on the River Witham, over which there was a Bridge; a Town which boasteth of its antiquity, more then of its present beauty, where oft-times are digged up Pavements of the Romans, wrought in checkered work. Belvoir-Castle.

Belvoir-Castle, seated in an angle, or nook of the County near Leicestershire, in a delectable Vale, called Belvoir-Vale, yet highly elevated, and enjoyeth a fair prospect; built by Robert de Todeneie a Norman, of a noble extract, who also began a little Monastery near adjoyning. About this Castle is found the stones called Astroites, star-like, pointed with five beams or rayes, in former time of great esteem, for that they were held to give Victory to the wearer thereof. Sleaford.

Sleaford, seated on a River so called, a very large, well built, and inhabited Town, formerly strengthened with a Castle, whose ruinous Walls are yet standing. Its Market is on Mondays, which is great for cattle, sheep, corn, and provisions; and the Monday after Twelf-day, called Ploughmonday, the Market is so considerable, that it may be reckoned for a Fair. HOLLAND Part or Division. Holland Part.

The next and last of the three Parts or Divisions of this County is Holland, which may be divided into the higher and lower; the latter of which being Fenny, and was formerly much more pestered with waters, then now it is, since the draining thereof by the cutting of the Chanels: and then did it abound with fish and fowl, which the Inhabitants were good gainers
by, as they are now by the Grain, especially the Rape-seed, which is become a considerable commodity with them. This Part giveth the Title of an Earldom to the R t. Hon. Robert Earl of Holland. The chief places in this Part, are Boston.

Boston, commodiously seated on both sides of the River Witham, over which it hath a fair high Wooden-bridge; and being near its influx into the Sea, is a place of considerable account, being well frequented and inhabited, and enjoyeth a good trade. It took its name from one Botolph a holy and devout Saxon, who at Icanhoe (as Authors aver) had a Monastery. It is a fair and large Town, of good antiquity, enjoyeth several immunities, hath the election of Parliament men; and as a Borough or Town Corporate, is governed by a Maior, twelve Aldermen, Burgesses, a Recorder, &c. Its Market-place is fair and spacious, as also its Church, whose Lanthorn or Tower exalteth it self to a great height, and serves as a Land-mark to Sailers, and Wayfaring men, being, according to report, the best built Tower in the world: And its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are very great, especially for provisions, both flesh, fish, and fowl, which are had at easie rates. Kirkton.

Kirkton, scituate on a sandy ground rising in that flat Country; a Town so called from its Church, which is a fair Structure, built in the form of a Cross, with a broad Steeple in the middle, like a Cathedral; and indeed all Holland hath very fair Free-stone Churches, though all that Country never produced a stone. This whole Township is very large, and is divided into 4 Hamlets or Vintins; viz. Kirkton, Willington, Kirkton-meers, Kirkton-Skeldike and Kirkton-Holme: This Town is famous for the best tasted Pippen, called the Kirkton Pippen. It was formerly a good Market-town, but now disused. Crowland.

Crowland, or Croyland, a Town of good note amongst the Fenny people, but much greater in times past, for its famous Abbey founded by æthelbald King of the Mercians in Anno 716. It is seated very low, and amongst deep Fenns and miry ground, so shut up, that there is no access to it but by the North and East side, and that by narrow Cawsewayes, not admitting of Carts; insomuch that the Inhabitants have a Proverb, That all the Carts that come to Crowland, are shod with silver. It is seated in a manner like Venice; and its streets, which are three, are severed each from other by mater-courses runing between, and on the banks (which are raised up, & preserved by Piles) are set Willow-trees; and next the Church is a place planted with Aldars. Their cattle are kept a good distance from the Town, and when they go to milk them, they go in small Skerries or Boats. The chief riches of this Town is gained by fish and fowl which they here take in the Pools, or watery places in exceeding great plenty, which doth occasion the Town to be well inhabited. Here is a small Market on Spalding.

Spalding, a fair and pretty Town, where Aujou gave an ancient cell to the Monks of Angiers in France. It is seated very waterish, and enclosed with Rivulets, Drains, and a Navigable River, which doth occasion it to have a very good trade, having several Vessels and Barges belonging unto them. Its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very good for corn, cattle, and provisions.

From this Town to Deeping, which is 10 miles, Egelrick Abbot of Crowland, afterwards Bishop of Durham, for the accommodation of Travellers, made a Cawsey of Wood and Sand through the deep Fenns, and called it Elrich-road, long since washed away. Holbech.
Holbech, seated in a Flat, amongst Dikes; an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Thursdays. Dunington.
Dunington, also scituate in a Flat, and waterish like Spalding; an indifferent Town, and hath a Market on Saturdays, very considerable for the great quantities of Hemp and provisions here sold.

div1.n: MIDDLESEX: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons
div1.head: MIDDLESEX: BEING Part of the TRINOBANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Midlesex with its Hundreds

div1.p: MIDDLESEX, so called from its scituation, as lying between the East-Angles and West-Saxons. It is a County of a small extent, being in length from Stratford-Bow in the East, to Colebrook in the West, about 19 miles; and in breadth from Hampton Court in the South, to South-mims in the North, about 16; which makes its circumference to be about 80 miles. Its bounds.

It hath for its Eastern bounds the River Lea, and the Meer Ditch, which separates it from Essex: for its Southern, the Thames, which parts it from Surrey and Kent; for its Western, the River Colne, and the shire Ditch, which divides it from the County of Buckingham; and for its. Northern bounds, Hartfordshirc. Its fertility.

It is blest with a sweet and wholesome Air; and for fertility of soil, may compare with any shire in England, both for tillage and pasturage; especially in that part called the Vale, which runneth from Heston almost to Harrow on the hill, taking within its compass Northold, Southold, Perivale, Norcote, Gernecote, Hayes, &c. Its Hills.

And although this County is in a manner a Flat, yet hath it several Hills, which exalt themselves to a good eminency; the chief amongst which are those of Harrow-hill, Hampsted, Highgate, the Chyldes-hills, and the ridge of Hills which sever the North-west part of the County from Hartsordshire.

It is every where sufficiently garnished with fair and comly buildings of the Nobility, Gentry, and Citizens of London, where they have their residences; but above all, with the Palaces of his Majesty, which I shall have occasion anon to treat of. Its particular Government.

As to its Spiritual, or Church Government, it is under the Bishop of London, who, next to the two Arch-bishops, hath the precedency of all Bishops; and the Diocess doth contein the Counties of Middlesex, Essex, and part of Hartfordshire, wherein are numbred 623 Parishes, of which 189 are
Impropriations; and hath a Dean, called the Dean of St. Pauls, and five Arch-Deacons, viz. of London, Middlesex, Essex, Colchester, and St.Albans. And whereas all other Counties within this Kingdom (for the most part) have a particular Officer annually chosen by his Majesty, called a Sheriff, this (by Charter made by King John) is under the Maior of the City of London, who doth annually choose two Sheriffs, who are to be accomptable to the City for all matters apperteining to the said office; and do alwaies keep their Sheriffdoms within the Walls of the said City.

Its chief Rivers are the Thames, the Lea, and the Colne, the former being at present the most famous River in the Kingdom; and the two latter, in former time, were of greater note then now they are, being said to give passage to ships to Hartford and St. Albans.
This County is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which is in the person of the Right Honorable Lionel Cranfield, Earl of Middlesex. Its Hundreds and Towns.

It is severed into six Hundreds, the names of which are set down in the Mapp, in which are seated 73 Parish Churches, (besides those of London) as also several Chappels of Ease, many of which may well deserve the name of Parishes, as Uxbridge, which belongeth to Hillington; Brentford, which belongeth to great Eling; Hounslow, part of which belongeth to Heston, and the other part to Thistleworth; and Hamersmith, which belongeth to Fulham. And amongst these said Towns and Parishes, are numbred four Market-towns, viz. Brentford, Stanes, Uxbridge, and Edgware; besides those of London and Westminster, which are several. Very populous.

It is every where exceeding populous, and that by reason of the famous City of London, the Metropolis of the Kingdom herein seated; which, after I have described the places of most note in the County, I shall give a description of. Its chief places. vxbridge.

Uxbridge, a fair, large, well inhabited and frequented Town, governed by two Bailiffs, two Constables, and four Headburroughs; It hath a Market on Thursdays, which is very well furnished with corx and all provisions; and by reason of being seated on the high Road from London to Oxford, hath divers good and well accommodated Inns, and Houses of Entertainment. Stanes.

Stanes, seated on the River Thames, over which it hath a Bridge, which leadeth into Surrey; and on the West Road of England, so called (as some would have it) of the Stakes called Conway-stakes, which were by the Britains sixed in the Thames, for the better preventing Julius Cæsars Army to pass over the River. And here is Runing-Mead, where as Cambden noteth, the Barons of England assembled in Anno 1215, to require of King John their liberties. This Town hath a small Market on Fridays. Hampton Hampton Court

Hampton, scituate on the banks of the Thames, of chief note for being dignified with a Royal and magnificent Palace of the Kings, called Hampton Court. (pleasantly seated by two Parks well stored with Game) first built by Cardinal Wolsey, in oftentation of his great Riches, and afterwards enlarged by King Henry the Eighth; now conteining within it several large inner Courts, which are enclosed with fair buildings, in one of which is a stately Fountain. Kingston-wick
Not far from this Town is Kingston-wicke, which is joyned unto Kingston a large Market-town in Surrey, by a fair Wooden-bridge. Istleworth.
Istleworth, or Thistleworth, a fair, large, and pleasant Town, seated on the banks of the Thames, well inhabited by Gentry, and beautified with well built Houses. Sion-house

Nigh unto which is Sion, or Sion-house; a large Structure, now belonging to the Countess of Northumberland; but in times past was a Monastery, so named
of the most holy Mount Sion, which King Henry the Fifth, (as Cambden noteth) when he had thence expelled the Monks Aliens, erected to the honour of our Saviour, the Virgin Mary, and St. Bridget of Sion, for Religious Virgins, where he appointed so many Nuns, Priests, and Lay-brethren, as in number did equal our Saviour, his Apostles, and Disciples; with a fair allowance for their livelyhoods. And on the other side of the Thames opposite to Sion, he erected another for the Carthusian Monks, named Jesus of Bethlehem. Brentford,

Brentford, seated on the Western Road, and on a Creek of the River Thames, from which it is not far distant; part of which, o wit, old Brentford, is seated thereon: It hath a well frequented Market on Tuesdays, which is considerable for corn and all provisions. Near unto this place Edmond Ironside assaulted the Danes, which he had driven from the Seige of London, and there put many of them to the Sword. Hounslow.
Hounslow, not far from Brentford, seated in a Heath so called; a thorough-fare Town, which is well provided with Inns. Hamersmith.
Hamersmith, scituate on the Road, and on the banks of the Thames; a large Town, and well inhabited with Gentry, where they have good and fair built houses. Fulham.
Not far from which is Fulham, also seated on the River Thames, (which is the Parish to Hamersmith;) a good Town, and well inhabited by Gentry. Chelsey.
Chelsey, also scituate on the Thames; a small Town, but hath many good built houses, which are the Seats of Gentry. Kensington.
Kensington, a thorough-fare Town, not meanly inhabited, nor its Houses ill-built, being graced with the Seats of divers Gentry, and persons of Honour. Hampsted.
Hampsted, scituate on a great eminence; as is Highgate.
Highgate, near adjoyning, and in an healthful Air, enjoying a fair prospect of London; both Towns well resorted unto by Gentry and Citizens, where they have pleasant Habitations. Edgware.
Edgware, a small Town and hath a mean Market on Thursdays. Islington,

Islington, seated on a small ascent, which for its vicinity to London, may be said to belong thereunto; a Town much resorted unto by the Citizens of London, where they have their Country-houses, as they have at Hornsey, Tottenham-high-cross, Muswell-hill, Edmondton, Enfield, and elsewhere. But to proceed to London. London.

London, (as Mr. Cambden noteth) is the Epitome, and glory of all Britain, was the Seat of the British Empire, as now the Royal Chamber of our Kings. About the building of this City, Writers do much differ, for some will have it to be built by Brute the Trojan; which, others say, is meerly fabulous: but all agree that it was re-edified by King Lud, in Anno mundi 5131, who called it Luddestown. Its scituation

This noble City is seated on a gentle rising Bank, in a healthful Air, and no less pleasantly then commodiously on the River Thames, where it formeth a Crescent, or Bow ben; and in its hasty course towards the Sea, payeth its duty to her, dividing it into two (but unequal) parts, which are again joyned together by a stately Bridge, supported by nineteen great Arches, all of Free-stone, and so furnished and covered with fair Houses of Trades-men, that it is thought rather a Street then a Bridge.

Nigh unto this Bridge towards the Tower, is the Custom-house, a curious Pile of building, and very fit for such a concern.
Its Wall and Gates.

This City is begirt with a Wall, first built (as 'tis said) by Constantine the Great, at the suit of his Mother Helena, to which for entrance it hath seven principal Gates; to wit, Westwards, Ludgate and Negwate, both which serve for Prisons; the first for such Debtors as are Freemen of the said City; and the last for Malefactors both of the City and County; as also the County Goal for Debt: Northwards, those of Aldersgate, Cripplegate, Moregate, and Bishops-gate; and Eastwards; Algate: There were also formerly two others towards the South, viz. Billing sgate and Douregate, or Dowgate; that of Billingsgate being now a well frequented Wharf or Key for Oyster-women, Fish-wives, Orange-women, and the like rabble, by reason of the small Vessels that here come to vend, and unlade their (such like) commodities. But now, as contemning bondage, this City hath enlarged her self on all sides with spacious Suburbs; insomuch that she hath joyned her self to another City, to wit,Westminster, which name is now swallowed up, it being called under the general name of London. But a word or two of the City of Westminster in particular. Westminster described.

Westminster, which according to Mr. Norden, in his Description of Middlesex, was formerly called Thorney, or Dorney, and was an Isle encompassed with the Thames, which divided it self; and one branch passed between Charin-cross and King-street through St.James's Park, including Toot-hill; which said Isle was so called, for that it was then overgrown with bryers and thorns; but in the time of King Lucius (according to some Authors) it was cleansed, and the Foundation of the great Temple of S. Peters was laid; which was raised out of the ruins of a fonner dedicated unto Apollo, where the Trinobantes, or Troinovantes did sacrifice Bulls, Bullocks, Staggs, and such like beasts to Diana Tauropolia, whom the Gentiles called the Queen of Heaven. Temple of St. Peters, formerly the Temple of Apolle And this Temple of St. Peter was destroyed by the Danes; and again re-edified by Dunstan Bishop of London, in the year of Christ 960; where there was a Monastery for twelve Monks. This City or part of London is the noblest, and is taken up by the King, the Nobility, Gentry, and such as depend on the Court and Law. The Limits of this City end at Temple Barr, where the Liberty of London beginneth; and is sufficiently graced with fair and beautiful Houses and Palaces, both publick and private.Temple of st. Peters, formerly the Temple of Apollo. Its chief buildings. Whiteball.

The chief amongst which are, First, The Palaces of the King, viz. Whiteball and St. James's (to which is joyned a small, but delightful Park, so called, in which is a Pal Mal, said to be the best in Christendom) the first being the residence of his Sacred Majesty, whose Walls are washed by the Thames; and the other of his Royal Highness James Duke of York. Westminster Hall.

Secondly, The Courts of Judicature, and Houses of Parliament, now known generally by the name of Westminster-hall, which was anciently the Palace of the Kings of England; a large Structure. Westminster Abby.

Thirdly, Its Collegiate Church of Westminster, which was formerly the Temple of St. Peter, as aforesaid; and now renowned for the Chappel adjoyning to it, built by King Henry the Seventh, being a most magnificent and curious Edifice, beautified with the stately Tombs of the Kings and Queens, together with many of the Nobility of England; and renowned for the inauguration of our Kings and Queens; and now is a Collegiate Church, consisting of a Dean, and twelve Prebendaries.
Fourthly, Somerset-house, a large and stately Structure belonging to the King, reguarding the Thames.
Fifthly, the New Exchange, a place well stored with Shop-keepers. And

Sixthly, The several Houses of the Nobility; as Wallingford-house, the Seat of the Duke of Buckingham: Northumberland-house, the Habitation
of the Countess of Northumberland. York-house, to the Duke of Buckingham; Salisbury-house, to the Earl of Salisbury; Worcester-house, to the Marquess of Worcester. The Savoy, formerly an Hospital, now the habitation of several Families, where they have their houses apart; and here is his Majesties Wardrobe kept: Arundel-house, to the Duke of Norfolk; and Essex-house, to the Duke of Somerset: all which, except Wallingford-house, are pleasantly seated on the River Thames. Then Exeter-house, lately made use of by the Doctors of the Civil Law; Bedford-house, the Seat of the Earl of Bedford; with divers others too tedious to name. And thus much for Westminster, which was so called by reason of its Western scituation from London; in former times there being a Monastery on Towerhill, called Eastminster.
The Eastern part of Suburb of this City of London, is taken up by those that have relation on the Sea. Its extent.

And the whole City thus taken, is now of a great extent; being in length from Blackwall in the East, to Tuttle-fields in the West, above six miles; in breadth one, two, and in some places three miles; and is said to make in circuit about fourteen or fifteen miles; in which extent are numbred about five hundred streets and lanes, and is said to contein according to computation, about 75000 dwelling houses, most of which, especially of later years, are fair and superb buildings: And by the great number of houses, the Inhabitants may be guest at, which without doubt are exceeding numerous. London for divers rea-sons, may compare with any City in the world.

Its Southern part is washed with the Thames, which by a safe and deep Channel beyond the Bridge, brings to its Walls, ships of a considerable burthen, which daily unlade their rich commodities. It is a City of sufficient Fame for its great trade and commerce with all Nations in the known world: and if we consider its riches, jurisdiction, bounds, and populousness; its good Government, the ingenuity of its Inhabitants in Letters, Arts, and Manufactures, together with their skill in Martial affairs; its strength, (not in its Walls, but men) being able to bring into the field, upon a sudden occasion, about 100000 stout fighting men; and its Antiquity being more ancient then Record beareth, but generally said to be built by Brute, as aforenoted: It may deservedly be numbred with any City of the highest rank in the world. Inns of Court and Chancery.

The Inns of Court and Chancery belonging to this City are twelve: of which four are large, and called the Inns of Court, viz. the Inner and Middle Temple (heretofore the Habitation of the Knights Templers, and so called in relation to Essex-house, also belonging to the Knights Templers, and called the Outer Temple, as seated without Temple-barr) Lincolns Inn formerly belonging to the Earls of Lincoln, and Grays Inn to the Greys; and these Inns are taken up by the Benchers, Baresters, and Students at Law, who for their civil and orderly Government, have strict Rules and Orders observed amongst them: The Inns of Chancery are those of Cliffords Inn, Clements Inn, New Inn, Staple Inn, Bernards Inn, Furnivals Inn, Lyons Inn, and Thavies Inn; all which are inhabited by Attorneys, and Solicitors at Law. There are also two other Inns, which are called Sergeant Inn, where the Judges and Sergeants only have their lodgings. Charterhouse

And besides these Structures, in the North part of the Suburbs are several others; as the Charter-house, or Suttons Hospital, a large and fair building, being one of the noblest Hospitals in the Kingdom, in which are constantly maintained eighty old men, and forty boyes, who have generous education bestowed on them, and from thence disposed of either to the University, or to Trades, as their capacities do best suit with. This noble
Hospital is endowed with a liberal revenue, insomuch that besides the food ( which is very good ) and their Gowns, the old men have the yearly pension of 7 L. per annum. And according to the constitution of the said Hospital, none are to be admitted in, but such as are unmarried. And that this Hospital should be well looked after, besides the Master, there are from time to time a certain number of grave and discreet person chosen out of the Nobility and Gentry as Overseers, amongst whom the King is alwayes one; and upon the death of any of the old men, each of the Overseers takes his turn to put in one in the room of the deeeased. But the King hath the putting in of two to the others one. Guildhall

In the CIty are fair Structures; as First, Guild-hall, where the Court of Judicature are held, and where the Lord Maior, Aldermen, and Common Councel meet for the negotiating of the affairs of the City; whose Hall is much adorned by the Pictures of the King, Duke of York, and the Judges. Gresham Colledge.

Secondly, Gresham Colledge, given to the City by Sir Thomas Greasham, who for the encreasing of Learning instituted there Professors of Divinity, Law, Physick, Astronomy, Geometry, and Musick, with the allowance of liberal Salaries for their pains in the studying and reading Lectures upon the said Ssciences, for the advancement of Learning amongst the Citizens.
Thirdly, Its Free-Schools.
Fourthly, The Dukes Theatre in Dorset or Salisbury Court. Doctors Commons.
Fifthly, Doctors Commons, the habitation of the Civilians, who for dyet and lodging live in a Collegiate manner, communing together. Heralds Office

Sixthly, The Heralds Office, or Colledge of Heralds, who by their Charter have several immunities granted unto them, and is an Office of great concernment, being for the preserving of Genealogies of Families Coats of Arms, the Marshaling and Ordering of Coronations, Funerals, Interview, Feasts of King and Princes, Cavalcades, Shews, proclaiming of Peace and War, and whatsoever doth concern honour. This Office consusteth of an Earl Marshall, three Kings at Arms, six Heralds, and four Pursuivants at Arms. The present Earl Marshall is the Right Honorable Henry Howard, Earl of Norwich, &c.

The three Kings are, I. Sir Edward Walker Kt. who is Principal, and entituled Garter King at Arms, whose office is to attend the Knights of the Garter at their Solemnities, to Marsbal the funerals of the Nobility,&c. 2. Sir Edward Bysh Kt. who is Clarencieux, whose office is to marshal, and dispose the Funerals of the Gentry inhabiting on the South side of the River Trent; he also maketh his visitation in the said parts, ot sett down the Pedigrees, to distinguish their Arms, and to grant and confirm Arm and Ensigns armorial to Gentlemen. And 3.William Dugdale Esquire, who is Norroy, and whose office is the same with that of Sir Edward Bysh, for the Gentry inhabition on the North side of the Trent.

The six Heralds, whose office is to wait at Court, to attend publick solemnities, proclaim Peace and War, &c. are distinguished by the names of 1.Windsor, 2.Richmond, 3.Chester, 4.Somerset, 5.York, and 6.Lancaster.
The four Pursuivants are Rouge Dragon, Rouge Crob, Portcullice, and Blew Mantle. Colledge of Physicians

Seventhly, The Colledge of Physicians near St. Pauls, a fine new built Structure, who by their Charter have large priviledges granted unto them, whereby no Physician ought to practice Physick in London, or within seven miles compass, without their Licence, nor in any part of England, if in case he hath not taken his degree in Oxford or Cambridge. They have also
power to punish Offendors by fine or imprisonment, to administer an Oath, to make By-laws, to purchase Lands, to search the Shops of Apothecaries, to see if their druggs and compositions are good, and well made. They are exempted from serving on Juries, Parish offices, or from bearing of Arms; and further, any Member of the Colledge (if he pleaseth) may practice Chirurgery. In this Colledge there is a President, four Censors, and eight Elects, to whom the management of affairs of the said Society are committed. Royal Exchange.

Eighthly, Its Royal Exchange, a stately Structure, now said to be the best in the known World, built quadrangular of Free-stone, with a lofty Tower at the South entrance: and above stairs are about one hundred and ninety Shops, sufficiently furnished with all sorts of rich Goods. Its Halls.
Ninthly, Its Halls for the several Companies; amongst which are many fair and large Structures, especially those erected since the fire of London. St. Pauls.

Tenthly, Its Cathedral of St. Pauls, seated on the highest ground in all the City, said to be built by Ethelbert King of Kent, about the Year 610, in a place where stood a Temple dedicated to Diana, and afterwards enlarged by Erkenwald the fourth Saxon Bishop thereof; and that old Fabrick being almost destroyed by fire, Mauritius another Bishop of London, in Anno 1083 began, and finished a great part of it; and in the end it became a once spacious Edifice, being about two hundred and thirty yards in length, forty six in breadth, and thirty four in height; and the Steeple from the plain ground to the Summit, was about 174 yards; but this building hath now nothing left to boast of, save its ruinous foundation walls. The Tower.

Eleventhly, Its Tower, a place of a large extent, and indifferent strong, being encompassed with walls, and a ditch or mote which receiveth the Tides: It is furnished with an Armory, or a Magazine or Arsenall of warlike Munition both for Sea and Land service; and according to the observation of some, it conteineth a Kings Palace, a Prison, an Armory, a Mint, Wardrobe, and Artillery; each having their peculiar Officers for the management of the affairs. And for buildings, it resembleth a Town, having a Parochial Church, exempted from all Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction of the Archbishop; and hath thirteen Hamlets (though in several Parishes, belonging unto it, whose trained Bands are obliged to assist the Lieutenant upon all occasions. The present Lieutenant is the Honorable Sir John Robinson Alderman, Knight and Baronet. Its house of Correction.
Twelfthly, Its Houses of Correction for Vagabonds, and Persons of a loose life and conversation; the most noted being Bridewell. Hospitals.

Thirteenthly, Its Hospitals, as St. Bartholomews for the sick and wounded; Christ-church for Blew-coat Boyes and Girls, with divers small ones for ancient people, being either the gifts of particular men, or are maintained by particular Companies. Sessions-house.
Fourteenthly, Its Sessions-house for the trying of Malefactors, which is a curious building.
This City is the See of a Bishop, and to its Cathedral already treated of, doth belong a Dean, Chapter, Treasurer, and thirty Prebendaries. London ruined by the Danes, and rebuilt by K. ælfred.

This ancient and famous City, when under the Government of the Britains, Romans, and Saxons, was destroyed by the merciless Danes, and left as a desolate Widow; but ælfred King of the West-Saxons,
having reduced the whole Land to one Monarchy, honourably repaired it, and again re-peopled it, and committed the custody thereof to his son in Law Alhered, Earl of Mercia; after whose decease, It, together with all other the possessions belonging to the said Earl, returned to King Edward, surnamed the Elder: and so it remained in the Kings hands, being governed under him by Port-Graves, or Port-Reves, that is, Keepers or Governours. And these Port-Graves in divers Records are called Vicecomites, Viscounties, or Sheriffs, a Title under the degree of an Earl.

In the first of King Richard the first, the Citizens obteined to be governed by two Bailiffs or Sheriffs; and after that they obteined to have a Maior for their principal Governour; the first of which was Henry Fitz- Alwyn a Draper, who was by the said King Richard appointed and constituted Maior to the 15 th of King John, which was 24 years. Its division and government.

The City within the Walls and Freedom is divided into twenty six Wards; and the Government thereof committed to the care of as many grave Citizens of good repute, which are Aldermen, each of which hath the over- seeing of his several Ward. And besides these Aldermen, there are two Sheriffs, which are annually chosen, as also a Lord Maior, who according to his degree, and seniority of being Alderman after Sheriff, is by the consent of the Citizens, (that is, the Livery-men of each Company) yearly chosen, and these are clothed in scarlet Gowns, and wear gold chains; and as Coadjutors, every Alderman hath his Deputy of the Ward, as also Common Councel-men. And these are the Governours of the City, who by their Charter have large immunities and priviledges granted unto them, which have been consirmed and enlarged by most of the succeeding Kings and Queens; as the making of Acts and Ordinances, so as they are not repugnant to the Law of the Nation, and detriment of the King.

A List of the names of the Lord Maior, Aldermen and Sheriffs, that for this present Year 1672. have the fatherly care and government of this Honorable City; with the names of the Wards to which they belong.

The Right Honorable Sir Robert Hanson Kt. Lord Maior and Alderman of Bassishaw Ward, Sir Richard Chiverton of the Ward of Bridge without, Kt. Sir Thomas Aleyn of Algate Ward, Kt. and Baronet, Sir John Frederick of Coleman-street Ward, Kt. Sir John Robinson of Tower-street Ward, Kt. Baronet, and Lieutenant of the Tower, Sir John Lawrence of Queen-hith Ward, Kt. Sir Thomas Bludworth of Aldersgate Ward, Kt. Sir William Peak of Billingsgate Ward, Kt. Sir William Turner of Castle-Baynards Ward, Kt. Sir Richard Ford of Lime-street Ward, Kt. Sir Samuel Starling of Portsoken Ward, Kt. Sir George Watermam of the Ward of Brides within, Kt. Sir William Hooker of Cornhill Ward, Kt. Sir Robert Vyner of Langborne Ward, Kt. and Baronet, Sir Joseph Shclden of Bishops-gate Ward, Knight, Sir Denize Gawden of Dowgate Ward, Knight, Sir Thomas Davis of the Ward of Farenton without, Kt. Jo. Forth of Cripple-gate Ward, Esquire, Sir Francis Chaplyn of the Vintrey Ward, Knight, Sir John Smith of Bread-street Ward, Kt. Sir James Edwards of Candle-wick Ward, Kt. Daniel Forth of Cheap Ward, Esquire, Patience Ward of the Ward of Farenton within, Esquire, Sir Robert Clayton of Cordweynors Ward, Knight, Sir John Moore of Walbrook Ward, Knight, Sir William
Prichard of Broad-street Ward, Kt. and Sheriff, and Sir James Smith Kt. and Sheriff.

Thus these Wards from time to time have held their several Aldermen, until either death, or other occasion of remove happens, and then others are elected in their places. And the Lord Maior liveth in great state, grandure, and authority, keeping an open House for the entertainment of Gentlemen, is attended with good store of City Officers; and when he goeth abroad, is clad in Scarlet, and hath his Mace and Sword carried before him.

This City, for Divine worship, before the late dreadful, and never to be forgotten Conflagration (which began between one and two of the Clock on Sunday morning, being the 2. of September, 1666. and continued until Wednesday following, in which time two thirds within its Walls and Freedom were consumed) had 125 Parish Churches, which are now reduced to a fewer number, divers small Parishes being added to others; and most of the Houses are re-built, with fair hopes of a speedy finishing, and with far greater beauty and stately building then before. Its Markets.

The Inhabitants of this City of London (including all the buildings within that large tract of ground already taken notice of) are sufficiently furnished with provisions; for besides the several Shambles dispersed up and down, there are these Markets; viz. Westminster-Market, St. James's- Market, newly erected, Southampton-Market, also of no long continuance; Clare-Market, belonging to the Right Honorable Gilbert Earl of Clare, at present as considerable as any in London for variety of provisions, both flesh, fish, and fowl, and of as great a resort; Newgate-Market, Cheapside-Market, Leaden-hall-Market, and Ratcliff-Market, being a small meeting since the fire of London.

Then for sale of live cattle, at Smithfield are weekly three Markets, viz. if on Mondays and Wednesdays for fat Oxen, Sheep, and other cattle; and on Fridays for the like sorts of cattle, and horses in great abundance, insomuch that it is esteemed the most considerable of any in England. Its commodities and trade.

The chief trade of England being here found, which cannot but be great, if we consider that the customs amount to above 300000 l. per annum. I shall give a small glance thereon, as to the commodities, coyns, weights, and measures.

The commodities are those aforesaid, together with several manufactures of cloth, silk, and stuff; also bats, stockings, ribons, haber dasbery wares, shoos, leather, pewter, shot, guns, with several other commodities; for which they receive oyls, wines, fruits, spices, calicoes, druggs, precious stones, gold, silver, pearl, civet, musk, salt-peter, grograins, turkey carpets silks, cloth of gold and silver, satins, velvets, diaper, cambricks, hollands, hopps, sope, pot-ashes, firrs, deals, masts, cordage, pitch, tarr, rosin, clap-boards, iron, lattin, steel, flax, hemp, wax, tallow, furrs, hides, caviare, glass, glasses, paper, allom, rice, aniseeds, with abundance of other commodities, too tedious to name, which our Merchants again transport to other places, serving one Country with the commodities of another. The Coyns.
