The coyns here and throughout all England, as well gold as silver, are several, and of a different value; but all reduced to pounds, shillings, and pence.

The Gold coyns are divers, as pieces of 22 s. 20 s. 15 s. 11 s. 10 s. 9 s. 5 s. 4 s. 4 s, 4 d. 2 s. 9 d. &c. and those of different stamps, according to the King or Queens reign in which they were coyned; and divers of these are so scarce, that they are seldom made use of, and the rather by reason of the new coyned gold, called Guinies, of 20 s. and are 10 grains
lighter then the old 20 s. pieces, a Guiney weighing five peny weight, and 10 grains; and these pieces of gold are of no set value, but sometimes higher and lower, according to the plenty or scarcity thereof, but commonly pass at 21 s. or 21 s. 6 d. the piece.

The Silver coyns are also divers, but all reduced as aforesaid to pounds, shillings, and pence; where note that 12 pence make a shilling, and 20 shillings a pound, which said 20 s. is the 1/3 of a pound Troy, from which said weight our coyn is made. The pieces of coyns now currant are 5 s. or crown pieces, which contein 60 d. and is an ounce weight; also half crown pieces, pieces of 13 pence half peny, like wise shillings conteining 12 pence; then 6 pence, the half of a shilling; groats, the 1/3 of a shilling; also pieces of 3 d. 2 d. and 1 d. Here are also imaginary coyns, as nobles and marks; a noble being 6 s. 8 d. and a mark 13 s. 4 d. Likewise here passeth for the convenient change of money for trivial affairs, copper pieces of a small value, as half-pence and farthings. The Weights.

The Weights are two, viz. Troy, and Avoirdupois; where note that 24 grains make a peny weight, 20 peny weight an ounce, and 12 ounces a pound Troy; and from this pound wet measures are derived; where note, that a pint is a pound; and by this weight gold, silver, silk, bread, pearl, precious stones, &c. are weighed. By the Avoirdupois weight is weighed, butter, flesh, lead, iron, tynn, fruits, and generally all garbled commodities; and this weight is reduced into several Denominations; as tuns, hundreds, quarters, pounds, ounces, and arams; where note, that 16 drams make an ounce, 16 ounces a pound, 28 pound a quarter, 4 quarters a hundred, and 20 hundred a tun. The Measures.

The measures are three, viz. dry, liquid, and long; the dry are those in which all sorts of dry commodities are measured, as corn, coal, salt, &c. and of this measure there are also several denominations; as a pint, quart, pottle, gallon, or half peck, peck, half bushel and bushel, which conteineth 64 pints; and two pints make a quart, two quarts a pottle, two pottles a gallon, or half peck, two gallons a peck, four pecks a bushel land measure, and five pecks a bushel water measure, eight bushels a quarter, nine bushels a Fatt of coals, five quarters a wey, ten quarters a last, and twenty lasts a combe.

Liquid measures are those in which all liquid substances are measured, as wine, oyl, beer, ale, &c. of which a gill is the least, next the quarter, half pint, pint, quart, pottle, and gallon, which is four quarts; and eight gallons make a firkin of ale, and nine gallons a firkin of beer, two firkins a kilderkin, two kilderkins a barrel, which is 36 gallons, 42 gallons a tirce, 63 gallons a hogshead, two hogsheads a butt or pipe, and two butts or pipes a tun. But note that the Wine measures are of a less content then the ale, for four gallons ale-measure, make five gallons wine-measure.

Long measures are those by which all cloth, both linnen and wollen, tymber, stone, glass, land, &c. is measured; of which an Inch (which is esteemed the length of three barley corns) though subdivided into lesser denominations, as half inches, quarter inches, and the like) is the least, and 12 inches makes a foot, 3 foot a yard, which may be divided into sixteen parts or nayls; 3 foot 9 inches is an ell, 6 foot a fathom, 51/2 yards, or 161/2 foot make a rod, pearch, or pole; 40 rods, pearches, or poles, a fur long; 8 furlongs an English mile, which is 320 poles, or 1760 yards, or 1056 paces, at 5 foot to the pace, or 5280 feet, or 63360 inches.
Of weights and measures used in particular Commodities; viz.
A Foder of Lead is 191/2 C; a Load is 36 Formells, or 175 stone, and a stone is 5 5/8 li.
A fagat of steel is 120 li. a barrel of gad-steel is 180 li.
A stone of glass is 5 li. and 24 stone is a seam.
A last of herrings is 12 barrels, every barrel 12 C. and every C. 120 herrings.
A last of powder is 24 firkins, every firkin weighing 100 li. neat, and the empty firkin 12 li.
A load of timber is 50 foot of square timber, that is a foot in length, breadth and thickness.
A stack of Wood is 31/2 foot in height, and 12 in length.
A fagot of Wood ought to be 3 foot in length, and 14 inches about besides the band.

Billets ought to be 3 foot and 4 inches in length; and the single billet must be 71/2 inches about, the cast billet 10 inches, and the two cast billets 14 inches about. Billets of a cast must be nicked within 4 inches of the end; and billets of two casts within 6 inches of the middle.
A full sack of coals is three bushels.
Forty skins of furrs, as martins, sables, jenets, &c. make a timber. Of lambs, cats, coneys, kids, &c. five score make the C.
Ten hides makes a dicker, and 20 dicker a last.
A rowle of parchment is 5 dozen.
Twenty quires of paper make a ream, and 10 reams a bayl; and in all reams the two outside quires, called cording quires, are of little value, as being damaged, and broken sheets of paper.
Ling, cod-fish, haberdine, &c. are 124 to the C.
Twenty five Eels is a strike, and 10 strikes a band.
A lath should be five foot long, 2 inches broad, and half an inch thick.
A plain Tile must be 101/2 inches in length, 61/2 inches in breadth, and 3/4 of an inch in thickness.
Roof tiles must be 13 inches in length, with a good and equal proportion of breadth and thickness.
A pan or paving tile must be 10 inches square, and 11/4 inch thick.
A brick must be 9 inches long, and 4 inches broad, and 2 inches thick.
Nails are sold by the 1000, and 120 to the C.
A truss of hay is to weigh 56 li. and 36 trusses make a load.
A truss of straw must weigh 25 li. and Co trusses make a load. Things requisite for the making a compleat City.

To the making a compleat City, there are several principal parts or helps required for the supportation thereof, and without which it cannot stand; to wit, First, Husbandry and Artificers for the providing food and rayment for its Inhabitants. Secondly, Arms and Amunition for its defence. Thirdly, The Priesthood, for the performing the Worship of God. Fourthly, Judges, Counsellors, &c. for the administration of Justice. And fifthly, Traffick, which, except Religion and Law, oft-times supplies the defect of all the rest, bringing Riches for its management of publick and private affairs. Wherefore seeing that the benefit a City or Land enjoyeth by Traffick, is of such concernment; and that this City of London is in a large measure blest there with, and plentifully provided with eminent Merchants and Trades-men, I think it very necessary to give a short account of the several worthy Companies of Merchants and Trades-men, especially those incorporated as stems and branches of traffiok and commerce. And first with the Muscovy Merchants. Muscovy Company of Merchants.

The RUSSIA, or MUSCOVY COMPANY of Merchant Adventurers for discovery of new Trades, was first incorporated in the beginning
of the reign of King Philip and Queen Mary, upon the discoveries of Lands, Territories, Signiories, and Isles by Seas lying Northwards, Northeastwards, and North-westwards from England; and was afterwards confirmed by Act of Parliament in the eighth year of Queen Elizabeth so that now they enjoy several immunities and priviledges, as to raise arms for the subduing of Countreys in the limits aforesaid, and to enter thereon, and to set up the English Standards; to make Acts and Ordinances for the good of the said Society, (provided they are not repugnant to the Laws of England) to punish Offenders by fine or imprisonment, to use a common Seal, to bear a Coat of Arms, &c. And the benefit that this Kingdom receiveth from this, and other Companies of Merchants, is by the commodities by them exported and imported. Commodities exported and imported.

The commodities that this Company exporteth, are woollen-cloths of all sorts, both drest and dyed, kersies, bayes, cottons, perpetuances, fustians, Norwich-stuffs, lace, thread, lead, tynn, pewter, allom, copper, much defective wines and fruits, not fit to be spent in this Kingdom, together with most sorts of English commodities. And for these and the like they import pot-ashes, tarr, cordage, cable-yarn, tallow, wax, isinglass, several sorts of hides in the hair, goat-skins undrest, cordovants, tan'd-hides, hoggs-brissels, raw silk, corn, linseed, slood, bever-wool, and wombs; several sorts of rich furrs, seal-skins, ruberb, castorum, agarick, train-oyl, flax, hemp, linnen, caviare, salmon, stockfish, cod-fish, &c. The Government of the Company.

This Worshipful Company. or Fellowship of Merchants is governed by a Governour, four Consuls, and Assistants consisting of twenty four, who are annually on the first of March chosen out of the said Fellowship: and for this present year 1672. the management of the said affairs are committed unto the care of Jo. Jolliff Esq; Governour; Benjamin Albyn Esq; Mr. Daniel Edwards, Mr. Thomas Davies, and Mr. Charles Caryll Confuls; Mr. Thomas Hancox Treasurer, Charles Thorold Esq. Henry Spurstow Esq. Samuel Moyer Esq. John Gould Esq. Mr. Francis Pargiter, Mr. Richard Adams, Mr. George Dickons, Mr. John Ashby, Mr. Benjamin Glanvile, Mr. Benjamin Coles, Mr. Edward Lewes, Mr. Samuel Meverell, Mr. James Young, Mr. George Carew, Mr. Heritage Lenten, Mr. Henry Mordant, Mr. Edward Grace, Mr. Thomas Andrews, Mr. Edward Vickers, Mr. George Cooke, Mr. George Grove, Mr. John Porter, Mr. Edmond Davenport, and Mr. John Cowper Assistants Turkey Company of Merchants.

The LEVANT or TURKEY COMPANY of Merchants, which by their discovery, made the first trade into the Signory of Venice, and then into the Dominions of the Grand Signior, and including the trade of the East-Indies, which as then was undiscovered unto us by Sea, their Goods being brought upon Camels and Ass-negroes to Aleppo, and other parts of Turkey: but since the discovery of the Indies by Sea, the East-India Company doth somewhat eclipse the trade of this Noble Fellowship for those commodities. Commodities exported and imported.

The commodities at present by them usually exported, are cloths both drest and dyed, at the least 30000 peeces yearly, kersies, lead, tynn, iron, steel, wire, pewter, furrs, pieces of eight, sugar, bides, elephants-teeth, brasil, red and white lead, indico, logwood, couchaneil, callicoes, spices, and several Indian commodities. And for these they import the raw silks of Persia, Damascus, Tripoli, &c. also chamblets, grograins, grograin-yarn, mohairs of Angor, wools, cottons, cotton-yarn of Smyrna and Cyprus, galls of Mosolo and Toccat; the corrans and oyls of Zant, Zeffalonia, Morea, &c. The druggs of Egypt and Arabia; also Turkey carpets, cordovants, box-wood, rhubarb, wormseed, sena, cumminseed, and several other rich commodities.
The priviledges of the Turkey Company.

This Company of Merchants was first incorporated in the reign of Qu. Elizabeth, and since consirmed by her Successors, and have several immunities and priviledges granted them, as making of Laws and Orders for the well government of the said fellowship, power of deciding controversies which arise in the said Company as to their trade, giving of oaths, imposing of fines, or imprisoning of Offendors according to their discretion, the using a seal, and bearing a coat of Arms, &c. The Government. And for the better management of the said trade, they are governed by a Governour, Deputy-Governour, and Court of Assistants, consisting of eighteen, who are in the Month of February annually chosen by a general consent out of the Members of the said Company, and these meet, and keep Courts, monthly, weekly, or as oft as their occasions require, for the carrying on of their trade, as by appointing, electing and sending over Consuls, Vice-consuls, Factors, &c. to such places where their Factories are kept, as at Constantinople, Smyrna, Aleppo, Cyprus, and elsewhere. Governours of the Company.

The management of the affairs of this Honorable Company is for this present year 1672. committed to the care of John Jolliff Esq. Governour, John Buckworth Esq. Deputy-Governour, Charles Thorold Esq. Treasurer, Tho. Vernon Esq. Husband, Sir Samuel Barnadiston Baronet, John Langley Esq. Samuel Moyer Esq. Benjamin Albyn Esq. John Prestwood Esq. Mr. John Harvey, Mr. John Morden, Mr. Gabriel Roberts, Mr. Richard Young, Mr. Richard Morice, Mr. Richard Onslow, Mr. Thomas Pilkinton, Mr. Daniel Morse, Mr. Henry Hunter, Mr. Peter Houblon, Mr. Richard Uvedale, Mr. Henry Griffith, and Mr. Richard Poulter Assistants. East-India Company.

The EASTINDIA COMPANY, first incorporated in the reign of Queen Elizabeth, and since confirmed, with several other priviledges added to their Charter by the succeeding Kings, so that now they have as ample immunities as any Corporation of Merchants whatsoever. This Company is managed by a joynt stock, which makes them potent, eminent and rich; and is found several wayes to be very advantageous to the Kingdom, as in their building of good ships, in the imploying, and maintaining of thousands, not only in their ships, but also in their Plantations and Factories, to whom they allow good Salaries; and according as they are found industrious and ingenuous, they are raised to a higher degree, with a great Salary; the like may be said of their Servants here at home. Again, they are found very beneficial to this Nation, by the great trade they drive in the Exporting and Importing so many, and so great quantities of rich commodities, having the trade of India, Persia, Arabia, and China. Commoditles exported and imported.

The commodities which are exported, are pieces of eight, dollers, broad- cloths, perpetuances, powder, elephants-teeth, lead, amber, looking-glasses, Scisars, knives, beads, bracelets, feathers, corall, quick-silver, virmillion, allom, brimstone, &c. And for these and the like commodities they import all sorts of spices, also cotton, cotton-yarn, callicoes, pintadoes of several sorts, tamarinds, sanders, spicknard, bezar-stone, alloes, myrrhe, rhubarb, opium, frankincense, cassia, borax, calamus, mirabolans, green-ginger, sugars, sugar-candy, camphir, sandal-wood, benjamine, musk, civit, ambergreese, rice, indico, silk both rawand wrought into several fabricks, salt-peter, several sorts of precious stones, pearls, mother of pearl, christal, cornelian rings, agats, porcelain, cabanets, lacque, copper, china-roots, tea, sanguis-draconis, china-wares of sundry sorts, with divers other commodities too tedious to repeat. The Government.

This worthy Company, for the better negotiation of their affairs, is governed by a Governour, Deputy-Governour, and Committee, consisting of twenty four, who about the midst of April annually are elected by the
Adventurers of the said Company, of which there must be eight new ones alwayes chosen; and these meet at their House in Leaden-hall-street generally weekly, and keep Courts for the vending their Goods, making of Dividends, viewing of the Accompts of their Presidents, Factors, Servants, &c. also for the sending over of Goods, Factors, and Servants, and raising of moneys for the management of their Plantations and Factories in the several parts of the Indies; as at Camboya, Bambay, Surat, Curwar, Baticale, Calicut, Fort St. George, Pentapoli, Musulepatan, Ougeley, Gonro, Bantam, Ormus, with several other Factories in the Isles of Asia. The Governours.

The Government of this Company is for this present year 1672, committed to the care of Sir John Banks Baronet, Governour, Nath. Herne Esq. Deputy-Governour, the Right Honorable George Lord Berkley, Sir John Robinson Kt. and Baronet, and Lieutenant of the Tower, Sir Samuel Barnadiston Baronet, Sir William Thomson Kt. Sir Francis Clarke Kt. Sir James Edwards Kt. John Jolliff Esq. Maurice Thomson Esq. Michael Davison Esq. John Bathurst Esq. rowland Wynn Esq. Benjamin Albyn Esq. Christopher Willoughby Esq. Charles Thorold Esq. Samuel Moyer Esq. Robert Thomson Esq. Mr. Christopher Boone, Mr. John Page, Mr. Thomas Canham, Mr.James Houblon, Mr. Edward Hopegood, Mr. John Morden, and Mr. Daniel Sheldon Assistants. East-land Company.

The EAST-LAND COMPANY, first incorporated in the Reign of Queen Elizabeth, and confirmed by King Charles the Second, and enjoyeth by their Charter ample priviledges, and as large a scope to traffick in, including the trade of the Kingdoms, Dominions, Dukedoms, Countreys, Cities, and Towns of Norway, Sweedland, Poland, with the Territories of the said Kingdoms; as also in Lettow, Liffland, and Pomerland from the River Odera Eastward; and likewise in the Isles of Findland, Eoland, and Berutholine within the Sound, &c. Commodities exported and imported.

The commodities which this worshipful Company exporteth, are woollen- cloths, perpetuances, Kersies, serges, Norwich-stuffs, cottons, lead, tynn, pewter, stockings, hats, gloves, together with several Southern and Eastern Commodities, as sattins, silks, spices, &c. And for these they import divers staple commodities, as deals, masts, timber, oars, clap-board, balks, bomsparrs, cantspars, pipe-staves, wainscot, and quarters; also slax, hemp, linnen-cloth, fustians, cordage, cable-yarn, pitch, tarr, tallow, hides, pot-ashes, wheat, rye, iron, lattin, copper, steel, wyre, quick-silver, rich furrs, buck-skins, train-oyl, sturgeon, stock-fish, mather, with several other good commodities. The Government.

For the management of the affairs of this Company, they are governed by a Governour, Deputy-Governour, and Court of Assistants, consisting of twenty four, who are annually elected out of the said Fellowship in the month of October, and meet and keep Courts, having ample immunities granted unto them.

The present Governour and Assistants are, Sir Richard Chiverton Kt. Governour, William Brunskell Esq. Deputy-Governour, Edward Lewes Esq. Treasurer, Edward Bilton Esq. Edward Smith Esq. Francis Asty Esq. John Dogget Esq. James Burkin Esq. Mr. James Whitehall, Mr. Nath. Tench, Mr. James Young, Mr. Randal Knipe, Mr.John Shorter, Mr. William Rivet, Mr. John Gould, Mr. Hugh Upton, Mr. William Nutt, Mr. Abraham Wessel, Mr. Peter Rich, Mr. Edward Harwell, Mr. Edward Bilton Junior, Mr. Thomas Warren, Mr. Henry Moody, Mr. Samuel Feak, Mr. Benjamin Ayliff, Mr. Charles Shorter, Mr. Oliver Westland, Assistants. Royal Company

The ROYAL COMPANY, or the Company of Royal Adventurers of
England, trading into Asrica; by their Charter granted by his present Majesty, have large immunities and priviledges granted them; as power to call and keep Courts, to make Laws, to punish Transgressors, by sine or imprisonment, to set forth Men of War, to defend their Factories and Forts, to appoint Governours over their Plantations, Forts, and Factories, that at any time hereafter shall be setled in any part of Africa, within the limits of the said Companies Charter, which is from Sally in South-Barbary inclusive, to Cape de bonna esperanza; and within the said limits all English ships are prohibited to trade, except such as are authorized by the Company: they have also power to raise Arms, train and muster military Forces, and to execute martial Law against any forraign Invasion, or domestick rebellion; but the Soveraign Right and Dominion over the same, is to be reserved to his Majesty, and to his Heirs and Successors. The Government.

This Noble Company is governed by a Governour, Sub- Governour, Deputy-Governour, and Court of Assistants, consisting of twenty four, which are chosen out of the Members of the said Company, and these have their Meetings, and keep Courts for the negotiation of their Affairs, at their House called the Affrican-house in Throckmorton-street, London. The Governours.

The names of the present Governours and Assistants are, His Royal Highness Governour, the Right Honorable Anthony Earl of Shaftsbury Lord Chancellor of England, Sub-Governour, John Buckworth Esq. Deputy- Governour; the Right Honorable John Earl of Craven, Sir Robert Vyner Kt. and Baronet, Sir John Banks Baronet, Sir John Shaw Kt. and Baronet, Sir Andrew King Kt. Sir Richard Ford Knight, Thomas Grey Esq. John Bence Esq. Charles Modyford Esq. Samuel Moyer Esq. Capt. Ferdinando Gorges, Mr. Jervis Cartwright, Mr. Samuel Dashwood, Mr. Thomes Farington, Mr. Edward Hopegood, Mr. John Jeffreys, Mr. Peter Proby, Mr. Gabriel Roberts, Mr. Benjamin Scutt, Mr. Thomas Vernon, Mr. Nicholes Warren, and Mr. Richard Young, Assistants. Commodities exported and imported.

The commodities fit to be transported by this HonorableCompany, are iron, copper, slesias, sheets, sayes, perpetuances, cowries, welch-plains;manillos, boysados, chiuts, romberges, corall, callicoes, niccanies, clouts, amber,powder, muskets, batteries of all sorts, turkey-carpets, brandy, strongwaters, spirits, ginghams, taffeties, beads of all sorts, buckshaws, knives, sworas, tallow, &c. And for these, and the like commodities are imported gold, elephants-teeth, hides, malegutta, or guiny-pepper, red-wood, amber-greese, with divers other good commodities, besides great quantities of Negroe slaves, for the supply of his Majesties American Plantations, to the great advantage of the Inhabitants, as well as of the Company.

And for the better Negotiation of their Affairs, they have already setled several Factories; as at Gambo, Rio Nuno, Rio Grande, Sierra Liona, Serbro, Cestos, Achin, Anta Cormenda, Cape Corso, Acara, Cormentine, Ardra, Benin, Callabar; and in time, through the succes, of good management, without doubt will have many more places.
An Account of the several Companies of London.
1. THE Company of Mercers was incorporated into a Society, or Brotherhood, in the 17. year of King Richard the Second.
2. The Company of Grocers, incorporated in the 20. of King Edward the Third.
3. The Company of Drapers, incorporated in the 17. of King Henry the Sixth.
4. The Company of Fishmongers, in the 28. of King Henry the Eighth, were united into one Brotherhood, being before two Companies, viz. the Stock-fishmongers, and the Salt-fishmongers.
5. The Company of Goldsmiths, incorporated and confirmed in the 16. of King Richard the Second.
6. The Company of Skinners, incorporated in the first of King Richard the Second.
7. The Company of Merchant-Taylors, incorporated in the 17. of King Henry the Seventh.
8. The Company of Haberdashers, incorporated a Brotherhood of Saint Katharine, in the 26. of King Henry the Sixth; and since confirmed in the 17. of King Henry the Seventh, and named Merchant-Haberdashers.
9. The Company of Salters, incorporated in the Third year of King Edward3.
10. The Company of Ironmongers, incorporated in the 3d. of King Edward the Fourth.
11. The Company of Vintners, incorporated in the reign of King Edward the Third.
12. The Company of Cloth-workers; incorporated in the year of King Richard 2
13. The Company of Dyers, incorporated in the 49. of King Henry the Sixth.
14. The Company of Brewers, incorporated in the 6. of King Henry the Sixth.
15. The Company of Leather-sellers, incorporated in the 6. of King Richard the Second.
16. The Company of Pewterers, incorporated in the 30. of King Edward the Fourth.
17. The Company of Barber-Chirurgions, incorporated in the reign of King Edward the Fourth.
18. The Company of Armorers, incorporated in the reign of King Henry the Sixth.
19. The Company of White-Bakers, incorporated in the 11. of Queen Elizabeth.
20. The Company of Wax-Chandlers, incorporated in the 2d. of King Richard the Third.
21. The Company of Tallow-Chandlers, incorporated in the 2d. of King Edward the Fourth.
22. The Company of Cutlers, incorporated in the reign of King Henry the Fifth.
23. The Company of Girdlers, incorporated in the 27. of King Henry the Sixth.
24. The Company of Eutchers, incorporated in the Third of King James.
25. The Company of Sadlers, incorporated in the reign of King Edward the First.
26. The Company of Carpenters, incorporated in the 17. of King Edward the Fourth.
27. The Company of Cordwainers, or Shoomakers, incorporated in the 17. of King Henry the Sixth.
28. The Company of Painters, or Painters-Stainers, incorporated in the 23. of Queen Elizabeth.
29. The Company of Curriers, incorporated in the 3 d. of King James.
30. The Company of Masons, incorporated in the 4 of King James
31. The Company of Plumbers, incorporated in the 9. of King James.
32. The Company of Inholders, incorporated in the 6. of King Henry the Eighth.
33. The Company of Founders, incorporated in the 12. of King James.
34. The Company of Embroiderers, incorporated in the 4. of Queen Elizabeth.
35. The Company of Poulterers, incorporated in the 19. of King Henry the Seventh.
36. The Company of Cooks, incorporated in the 12. of King Edward the Fourth.
37. The Company of Coopers, incorporated in the 16. of King Henry the Seventh.
38. The Company of Bricklayers and Tylers, incorporated in the 10. of Queen Elizabeth.
39. The Company of Bowyers, incorporated in the 21. of King James.
40. The Company of Fletchers, once a part of the Bowyers, but now a Company of themselves.
41. The Company of Blacksmiths, incorporated in the 20. of Queen Elizabeth.
42. The Company of Joyners, incorporated in the 30. of Queen Elizabeth.
43. The Company of Plaisterers, incorporated in the reign of King Henry the Seventh.
44. The Company of Weavers, incorporated in the 7 of King Henvy 6
45. The Company of Furriers, incorporated in the 3 d. of King James.
46. The Company of Scriveners, incorporated in the 14. of King James.
47. The Company of Bottle-makers and Horners, incorporated in the 3 of King Edward 7
48. The Company of Stationers, incorporated in the 3 d. and 4th. of King Philip and Queen Mary.
49. The Company of Marblers, held to be of the Fellowship of the Masons.
50. The Company of the Wool-packers, incorporated in the 5 of King H:8
51. The Company of the Farriers, incorporated in the 4 of King Ch:2
52. The Company of Paviers, incorporated in the 6 of King James
53. The Company of Lorinors, incorporated in the of King
54. The Company of Brown-bakers, incorporated in the 19. of King James.
55. The Company of Upholsterers, incorporated in the 16 of King James
56. The Company of the Turners, incorporated in the 2d. of King James.
57. The Company of the Glasiers, incorporated in the of King
58. The Company of Clerks, incorporated in the 17. of King Henry the Third.
59. The Company of Watermen, incorporated in the 7 of King H2
60. The Company of Apothecaries, incorporated in the 15. of King James, being before Members of the Grocers.
There are also some other Companies made by his present Majesty, King Charles the Second; but not very considerable as to matter of Trade.

div1.n: Monmouthshire: Being the Ancient HABITATION OF THE SILURES
div1.head: Monmouthshire: Being the Ancient HABITATION OF THE SILURES.
div1.p: MONMOUTHSHIRE, formerly a Welch County and by the Britains called Went-set and Wents-land, from an ancient City so named.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Mounmouth shire with Hundreds

div1.p: It is blest with a healthful and temperate air; and although very hilly and woody, yet is exceeding fertile; (especially the Eastern parts, which are not so hilly as the Western) the hills feeding abundance of cattle and sheep; and the Valleys bearing great crops of corn and grass; which fertility is much furthered by its being plentifully watered with so many Rivers, (which all fall into the Severn Sea) the chief amongst which are the Uske, Wye, Munow, Ebunith, Sroway, Rumney, and others. Its Bounds.

It hath for its bounds on the East the River Wye, which separateth it from Glocestershire; for its Southern, the Severn; for its Western, Brecknockshire, and the River Rumney, which parts it from Glamorganshire; and for its Northern limits, the River Munow, which disjoyns it from Herefordshire. Its extent.

Its extent from Rempney in the South, to Llantony in the North (which maketh its length) is about 24 miles; and from Chepstow in the East, to Blanagwent in the West, is not above 19, so that its circumference is not 80 miles. Castles and Religious Houses.
This shire hath been well strengthned with Castles; and had formerly divers Religious Houses, as at Caerleon,Chepstow, Gold-cliff, Monmouth, and Llantony.
It is severed into six Hundreds, in which are numbred 127 Parish Churches; and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, is traded unto by seven Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Monmouth.

Monmouth, no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the Rivers Wye and Munow, where they meet together, and do almost encompass it, over each of which is a Bridge: It was once fortified with a Wall and Ditch; and in the midst of the Town, near the Market-place, standeth (a once stately
but now ruinous) Castle, said to be built by John Baron of Monmouth, from whom it came to the house of Lancaster, and was the birth-place of the rehowned King Henry the Fifth, the Conquerour of France. It is a fair, large, well-built, inhabited and frequented Town; enjoyeth large immunities, and sendeth a Burgess to Parliament; is beautified with a goodly Church; and at the East-end is a most curious built Church, called the Monks-Church, the Monastery whereof Jeffrey Ap Arthur, or Arthurius Bishop of Asaph, (who was born in this Town) wrote the History of Great Britain. For Civil Government, this Town hath for its Magistrates a Maior, two Bailiffs, fifteen Common-counsellors, a Town-clark, and other Sub-Officers. Its Market, which is on Saturdays, is considerable for corn and provisions: and at present this Town is much honoured in giving Title to the Right Noble James Duke of Monmouth and Buckleugh, &c. Chepstow.

Chepstow, by the Britains called Castle- went, seated on the side of a hill, and on the banks of the Wye, near its fall into the Severn; a Town in former times very famous, and of great resort, being said to be raised out of the ruins of Venta Silurum, four miles distant, which was the ancient and chief City of the Silures, which flourished in the dayes of Antonine the Emperour: and as Mr. Cambden further noteth, this Town was fortified about with a Wall of a large circuit, and had a very spacious Castle, which was once fronted by a Priory, the better part of which being pulled down, the rest was converted to a Parish Church; and as to its present state, it is a large, well-built, inhabited and frequented Town, hath a fair and high bridge over the Wye; and its Market, which is on Saturdays; is very good for corn and provisions, and very considerable for Swine. Portskeweth.

Not far from Chepstow on the Severn is seated Portskeweth, where according to report, in ann. 1065, Harald erected a Eort against the Welch-men, which was in a short time by them overthrown under the conduct of Caradock. Sudbrook. Trinity Chappel.

Near adjoyning to Portskeweth is Sudbrook, whose Church, called Trinity Chappel, is seated so near the Severn Sea, that great part of its Church-yard is washed quite away; as is long since an old Fortification of the Romans, which was compassed with a triple Ditch, and three Rampiers, as high as an ordinary house, cast up in form of a bow, the Sea-cliff serving for the string. The Moor.

Farther Southwards lyeth a low and moorish tract of ground, called the Moor, which oft-times fuffereth much by the overflowings of the Severn Sea at high Spring-tides. And in the very point of this Mersh coast, where it shooteth it self forth into the Sea, is Gold-clyff, so called from the golden colour of the stones which lye thereabouts.Gold-clyff. And opposited to this Clyff, about the midst of the Severn, lyeth a small Isle, called Denny Island. Denny Isle. Carlion.

Carlion, or Caer Leon, once called Isca; and according to Girald in his Book called Itinerarium Cambriæ, it was an ancient and flourishing City of the Romans, where lay (by order of Julius Frontinus, for the over-awing of the Silures) the second Roman Legion called Augusta, hither brought out of Germany, under the conduct of Vespatian. And the ruins of its stately buildings, as Palaces, Temples, and Theaters, enclosed within fair Walls, the foundation of houses within and without its spacious Walls, the Waterpipes, Vaults, Hot-houses, Altars, and Roman coyns there oft-times digged up, do sufficiently evidence its Antiquity, and once stateliness. Here the Noble Arthur kept his Court, whether the Roman Embassadors repaired; also here it was that Dubritius resigned the Archiepiscopal honour unto David of Menevia, when the Metropolitan See was from hence thither translated. Aex. Alsebiensis. And according to Alexander Elsebiensis, in this City was a famous School or Col-
ledge for two hundred Philosophers, which were skilfull in Astronomy, and other Arts; which the rather seemeth to be true, for that Amphibalus, instructor to Saint Albon, was here born; and Julius and Aaron, two noble Protomartyrs of Great Britain, received here the Crown of martyrdom, and each of their bodies were here interr'd in a goodly Church dedicated unto them. But enough of its pristine glory: A word or two of its present state. It is commodiously seated on the Usk, over which it hath a large Wooden-bridge; the Town is pretty large, the houses for the generality well-built of stone; hath the ruins of a Castle yet standing; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is but indifferent. Newport.

Newport, also seated on the Usk, over which is a fair Bridge; which River soon after dischargeth it self into the Severn, where it hath a good Haven, bearing the name of the Town. This place is said to take its rise from the ruins of Carlion near adjoyning; It is an indifferent good Town, hath a good Market on Saturdays for cattle and provisions; and was of note for its once strong (but now demolished) Castle. Uske.

Uske, scituate on the River so called, over which it hath a Bridge, at which place the River Birthin looseth it self; It is a large Town, beautified with well-built Stone-houses; and hath weekly on Mondays and Fridays two very good Markets. Here was formerly a large and strong Castle, now ruinated; and according to Antonine, here stood the little City Burrium. Ragland-Castle.
Nigh unto this Town is Ragland-Castle, a fair house of the Marquess of Worcesters. Ponte-pool.

Ponte-pool, seated betwixt the hills, a small Town, of chief note for its Iron-mills, which is the only trade of the Town; and hath a new erected Market on Saturdays, which for the present is but indifferent. Abergavenny.

Abergavenny, by Antonine called Gobanium, is seated at the meeting of the Rivers Uske and Keveny; a place of good strength, being fortified with Walls and a Castle of great note in former times. The Town is large, the houses well-built, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a good trade for flannels, and straw-hats here made in great plenty; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very considerable for cattle, provisions, &c. Lanthony. S. John Baptists Chappel.

At a nook or angle of the County North-westwards, is Lanthony, seated on the River Hothny, and encompassed with Hatterell-hills, which proudly elevate themselves to a great eminence; and here stood a little ancient but well-built Abbey, dedicated to St. John Baptist, and founded by Walter Lacy, which was richly endowed with Lands by William Earl of Hereford: And in (or near) this place, formerly stood a poor Chappel of St. David the Arch-bishop, whose chief ornament was only wild Moss, and Ivy wreathed about it; which place, for its solitary scituation and remoteness from all noise of people, was esteemed the most fit place for Religious worship of any in the Kingdom.

div1.n: NORFOLK: BEING Part of the I C E N I and ancient KINGDOM of the East Angles
div1.head: NORFOLK: BEING Part of the I C E N I, and ancient KINGDOM of the East- Angles.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Norfolck with its Hundreds

div1.p: NORFOLK, a County which may not improperly be tearmed an Island, as encircled with waters; for on the East and North it is braced with the German Ocean, which liberally affordeth the Inhabitants fish; on the West it hath the Owse, and its branches, which severeth it from the Counties of Lincoln and Cambridge; and on the North, with the little Owse and the Waveney, which separate it from Suffolk.

It is a County of a large extent, being from Yarmouth in the East, to Wisbich in Cambridg shire Westwards, above 50 miles; and from Thetford in the South, to Wells in the North, about 30; so that its circumference maketh about 240 miles. Its Soil.

As to its diversity of soil, it may be comprised under two heads, viz. Champain and Woodland; yet commonly about the Towns, it is of a Clayey, chalkey, and fat earth, and not destitute of Wood; But the parts from Thetford to Burnham, and so Westwards; as also along the Sea-coast are esteemed Champain, affording plenty of corn; and also on the Heaths, great flocks of sheep are fed, as likewiseabundance of coneys have here their habitations: The Woodland part (so tearmed) as being better clothed with Wood, taketh up the rest of this County, and is chiefly imployed for grasing of cattle, yet not without corn-ground. Its Commoditics.

This County shareth plentifully in all English commodities; and chiesly in worsteds, stockings, and Norwich-stuffs: And on its Sea-coast are taken abundance of Herrings, which are found very beneficial unto the Inhabitants. The Air.
The air is sharp and piercing, especially near the Sea, and in the Champain part; which occasioneth a latter Spring and Harvest. Its ancient people.

The ancient Inhabitants were the Iceni, and thought to be of them that Cæsar named Cenimagni; Ptolomy, Siment; some Tigent. They were at first (as the rest of the Britains) barbarous; but since the coming in of the Normans, they have been esteemed civil. The latter Romans held it by two Garrisons; one at Branodunum, now called Brancaster; and the other at Gariannum near Yarmouth. Upon the entry of the Saxons, this, with
the County of Suffolk fell into the proportion of the Angles, and by Uffa, were formed into a Kingdom, and the succeeding Kings were called Uffines; but in anno 870 by Hugar and Hubba the Danes, it was ruinated; and the Danes inhabiting in these parts, built many of the Towns; and a great part of the present Inhabitants are risen out of their blood. The present Inhabitants are generally adicted to conrention, and will go to law with their Neighbours upon the least occasion; and 'tis observed, that even the Plough-man will cite the Statutes, and carry his Law-book in his pocket, which doth make good work for the Lawyers at the Assizes. Norfolk dignified with a Dukedom.

This County is honoured with the Title of a Dukedom, which is at present in the person of his Grace Thomas Howard Duke of Norfolk, Earl of Arundel, Surrey, and Norfolk, Baron Howard, Fitz-Allen, Matraviers, Mawbrey, Bruce and Clun. Its Rivers.

On the Sea-coast of this County are many good Harbours, and the Sea, together with the several commodious Rivers, as the Owse, Waveny, Yare, Thryn, &c. which it liberally sendeth forth, furnisheth them with excellent fish, and are of great use to the Inhabitants, in the transporting their goods from one place to another. Its populousness, Parishes and division of Hundreds.

It is generally well inhabited by Gentry, is very populous, and full of Towns and Villages, numbring 660 Parish Churches, which are the most of any County of England; and hath the accommodation of 27 Market- towns, divers of which are of good accont. It is also graced with one City, and severed into thirty one Hundreds, the names of which do appear in the Mapp.
The places of chief note in this County are, Norwich.

Norwich, a City of great splendor and antiquity; being formerly the seat of the East-Angles; but since which it hath sufficiently withstood the shocks of ill-fortune; for in the dayes of Edward the Confessor, by famine and sword, in defending the cause of the Earl Radalph against the Conquerour, they were consumed to about 5 or 600 before they yielded: In anno 1174 it was sacked, and spoiled by the Earl of Flanders and Hugh Bigod; In anno 1216, it was ruinated in yielding to Lewis the French against their Soveraign King John; In anno 1266 by the disinherited Barons; In anno 1348, the plague was so raging, that there died from July to January following (as 'tis reported) 57104 persons; In anno 1508 it was dismantled by the merciless fire; and lastly, this City suffered much by one Kett a notorious Rebel, being a person of no better extraction, then an ordinary Tanner; who pitched his Camp at Mussel-hill near adjoyning, and with a rabble of many thousands under his command, committed his outrages against this City, till at the length he was discomfited by the Militia of the City and County; and being taken was hanged on a Tree, where he encamped; which Tree to this day is called Ketts-Oak. And notwithstanding all these heavy calamities, it is at this day a fair, large, populous, and well frequented City enjoying a great trade, especially for its Stuffs, stockings, and other Manufactures here made (for the learning of which they are beholding to the Dutch which there inhabit) which finds vent not only throughout England, but also beyond Seas, which brings no small profit to its Inhabitants. This City is commodiously seated on the River Yare, which severeth it, but is joyned together by several Bridges, (which after it hath saluted Yarmouth, dischargeth it self into the Sea) as also in a pleasant Valley, but on an easie ascent. It is about a mile and an half in length, and almost of the like breadth, and is encompassed with a Wall) except on the side seated on the River) on which are many Turrets, and
hath for its entrance twelve Gates; and for Divine worship thirty two Parish Churches, besides Chappels. Its chief buildings are the Cathedral, dedicated to the blessed Trinity, a fair Structure, beautified with a lofty spire, which, after many calamities it suffered by fire, was at last repaired; then the Bishops Palace, the Palace of the Duke of Norfolk; the Market-house, the Cross, and the House of Correction made of Free-stone, and so curiously cemented, that no morter is visibly seen. Here is also an Hospital where one hundred poor men and women are maintained: yet is this City not without several thatched buildings, but so neatly wrought that they are no eye-fore to the Spectator; but of late there is an order made, that no house, either new built or repaired, shall be thatched, but tyled. It may not improperly be called an Orchard in a City, or a City in an Orchard, by reason of the pleasant intermixture of the houses with trees, so that the populousness of a City, and the pleasure of the Country meet together. This City was first governed by four Bailiffs, but by Henry the Fourth in Anno 1403, it was incorporated into a Majoralty, and made a County, whose limits extend to Eaton-bridge; It enjoyeth several large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, hath an Episcopal See, and conteineth within its Diocess the Counties of Norfolk and Suffolk, wherein are numbred 1121 Parishes, of which 385 are Impropriations; and hath four Arch-Deacons, viz. of Norwich, Norfolk, Suffolk, and Sudbury.

It is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which is at present in the person of the Right Honorable Henry Howard, Earl Marshal of England, &c. Its Markets are on Wednesdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, and those of Wednesdays and Saturdays, are very great, affording plenty of corn, live cattle, hoggs, and all sorts of provisions; together with quantity of leather, yarn, worsteds, &c. H'gham.
Near unto this City is Higham, a large Town, and chiefly inhabited by Tanners, who have their Habitations on the side of the River on which it is seated. Lynn.

Lynn, formerly Bishops Lynn, as apperteining to the Bishops of Norwich, and now called Lynn Regis, or Kings Lynn, seated in the Western part of the County, and almost at the influx of the Owse into that part of the Sea called the Washes. This Town is fair, large, and well-built, is an ancient Borough-town, of good antiquity, being by King John incorporated; and in the 17. of King Henry, in gratulation of their good service against the Outlawed Barons in the Isle of Ely, their Charter was enlarged, and several Franchisms granted unto them, as the election of a Maior, &c. and King Henry the Eighth added to their Charter twelve Aldermen, a Recorder, a Sword-bearer, and other Officers; with the election of Burgesses. This Town conteineth three Parish Churches; and for its defence is encompassed with a Wall, and a deep Trench; and through its streets commodiously run two small Rivers, which are passed over by about fifteen Bridges. It is well inhabited by Merchants and Trades-men, who drive a considerable trade, and the more by reason of its commodious Haven; yet is it much eclips't in its trade to what it had formerly, by reason of the stoppage of a Sluce upon the River Owse, which doth obstruct the current of Salt-water, so that the River is scarce Navigable to Cambridge. Its Markets are on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are very well provided with commodities, and resorted unto, especially that of Tuesdays. Mershland.

Nigh unto this Town, on the other side of the Owse, is a little Mersh Country, called Mershland, very subject to inundations, occasioned
by the overflowing of the tempestuous Ocean, which rendreth it very moist and aguish; but in recompence, is of an exceeding fat soil, and feedeth abundance of sheep and oxen. And in this Mersh are seated several Towns, which are very destitute of fresh water for their household uses, many of them being constrained to get a supply thereof at four miles distance: And of these Towns, those of chiefest note are Walpool, Walsoken, and Tilney; and all of them are garnished with fair Churches. Castle-Rising.

Castle-Rising, about three miles from Lynn, seated on the Sea, but its Haven hath been these many years filled up with sands, and rendred useless; which hath been the cause of its ruin, and its Markets to be disused, which before were of good account, Lynn now having made it self rich by her ruin. Yet is it a Borough-town, electeth Parliament men, and is governed by a Maior, and 12 Aldermen. Here is a very ancient Castle of good strength, belonging to the Right Honorable Henry E. of Norwich and Earl Marshal, who is created Baron of Castle-rising, from the Castle so called. And here is a very fair Almes-house for the relief of twenty four poor Widows, and a Governess, with large allowance for their maintenance, being the guift of the Ancestors of the said Earl. Seching.

Sech, or Seching, seated on a Navigable River for small Vessels, and amongst rich pasturage for cattle; here is a Market kept every Tuesday fortnight, and is very considerable for fat Bullocks, and much resorted unto by Butchers from several Counties to buy them. Yarmouth.

Yarmouth, scituate on the River Yare, at its influx into the Sea, where it, with the Sea on the other side, formeth a little languet of land. It is a place of great strength, as well by Nature as Art; for although it be almost encircled with water, (on the West-side with the River, which at low water is navigable, (being at least three fathom deep) over which it hath a Draw-bridge, and from other parts with the Ocean, unless in the Northpart, where the sirm land is) yet it is begirt with a strong Wall, upon which, besides its Towers towards the East (which reguardeth the Sea) there is cast up a Mount, which is well provided with pieces of Ordnances. This Town is an ancient member of the Cinque-ports, is esteemed the key of this coast; is large, and its houses well built, yet hath it but one Church, (but very fair, being beautified with a lofty spire, and so large, that it serveth for two Ministers.) In the time of K. Henry the Third it was made a Corporation under two Bailiffs, enjoying several priviledges, as sending Burgesses to Parliament, &c. It maintaineth a Peere against the Sea, at the yearly expence of about 2 or 3000 l. yet hath it no possessions, as most other Corporations have; but is a place well inhabited, and greatly resorted unto by Seamen, and the more as being the Port-town, and ready passage to Holland, for the Packet-boat and other Vessels: Also its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great, affording corn, plenty of fish, and all necessaries for food, and is a place of a considerable trade, especially for herrings taken in the Seas here adjacent in September, this place being esteemed the most considerable for herrings in all England, which draweth hither great resort of people to buy them, which is no small advantage to its Inhabitants; and in the spring, there is as great a fishing for Mackerels. Thetford,

Thetford, a Town of great antiquity, being said to be built out of the ruins of the ancient City Sitomagus, which by the merciless Danes was destroyed. It is at present a large Borough-town, having the election of Parliament men, with the enjoyment of other immunities, but not very well inhabited, especially to what it was; (yet here is kept the Lent Assizes for the County.) For in the time of King Edward the Confessor, there was accounted in it nine hundred forty seven Burgesses;
and in the time of William the Conquerour 720 Mansions, and the chief Magistrate was called a Consul, by which it may be concluded to be a Town of the Romans; and besides other Tokens of Antiquity, it hath a great high Mount, raited, and fenced with a double Rampire, which formerly was further strengthened with Walls. This Town is seated on the little Owse, over which it hath a Bridge which leadeth to Suffolk: It is now of chief note for its Company of Musicioners: And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well provided with corn and other provisions. East-Herlige.
East-Herlige, seated on a Rivulet, and hath a good Market on Tuesdays, chiefly for linnen-yarn, and linnen-cloth. New Buckenham.
New Buckenham, scituate on a Flat, once strengthned with a Castle, which is now demolished; and hath a small Market on Saturdays. Attleburgh,
Attleburgh, hath a late erected Market on Thursdays; and every Thursday Fortnight this Market is well furnished with fat bullocks and sheep, which brings a good advantage to the Town. Diss.
Diss, seated on the Waveney, and on the side of a hill; a pretty well known Market-town, which is on Fridays, for yarn, linnen-cloth, corn and provisions. Fulcham.
Fulcham, seated on a Common, a pretty considerable Town; and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Harlston.
Harlston, a Town of some antiquity; also seated on the Waveney, over which it hath a Bridge. It is a long dirty Town, yet hath it a good Market on Wednesdays for corn and other provisions. Windham.

Windham, seated in a dirty bottom, famous for the Albines Earls of Arundel, there enterr'd, some of which here erected a Priory, which afterwards was advanced to an Abbey; and upon the Steeple thereof, (which is of a great eminency) William Ket, one of the Captains of the Norfolk Rebels in anno 1549, was hanged up. This Town hath an indifferent good Market on Fridays for corn and other provisions; but chiefly for stockings, wooden- spoons, tapps, and spindles which are here made, and sold in great abundance, most of the Inhabitants, both men, women, and children making the same, by which they gain their lively hoods. East-Derham.

East-Derham, well seated, a considerable large Town, having many Ham- lets belonging to it; and its Market, which is on Fridays, is very well served with provisions, and aboundeth in woollen-yarn. Caster.
Not far from East-Derham is a Town called Caster, which was raised out of the ruins of the ancient and once flourishing City (for a small one) of Venta Icenorum. Watton.
Watton, seated in a Flat, and in the high Road; a long Town, and full of Inns, whose Market, which is on Wednesdays, is indifferent good. Swafham.

Swafham, seated on a hill, a large and well-built Town, full of Inns and Shopkeepers, who drive a good trade: And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very well furnished with corn, and all other provisions, being esteemed one of the chiefest Market-towns in the County. Downham.
Downham, seated low, and on the Owse, over which it hath a Bridge. A Market-town on Saturdays, which is well served with provisions. Snetham.
Snetham, scituate not far from the Sea, on a small inlet thereof; hath a very considerable Market on Fridays. Sherborn.

Nigh unto Snetham is seated Sherborne, of note for being the place where Felix the Burgundian brought these East English-men to the Christian Faith, and erected a Church for Divine worship. Burnham-Market.
Burnham-Merket, seated not far from the Sea; hath a good Market on Saturdays. Brancaster, old Brannodunum.

Nigh unto this Town is Brancaster, a small Country Town, raised out of
the ruins of the ancient Town Brannodunum, seated on the Sea-shoar; a place of good account in the time of the Romans, who had here their Garrison. Walsingham.

Walsingham, not far from the Sea, in former time much renowned for its Colledge of Chanons, and as much frequented by Pilgrims to pay their Devotions to our Lady the Virgin Mary, at the Chappel, where there are two Wells of continual springing water, called the Virgin Marys Wells, which at present are had in small esteem amongst the people. It was formerly a place of note for its good Saffron; and hath a Market every Friday, which is indifferently well provided with provisions.

In this Parish was not long since found by a Husbandnan cultivating his ground, about 100 pots of ashes, all within the compass of three roods of ground, supposed to be the Urns of the Romans. Fakenham.
Fakenham, seated on a hill, a good Market- town on Thursdays. Holt.
Holt, a well frequented Market-town on Saturdays. Clay.

Clay, seated on an arm of the Sea, where it sendeth forth two Riversor streams, though of no long tract, so that it is on three sides encompassed with waters; once a Market-town, but now discontinued. Wauburn-hope.
Not far from this Town is Wauburn-hope, so called from Wauburn a small Town near adjoyning. Cromere.

Cromere, a Maritime Town, which is well frequented, especially by Fishermen and Hoy-men, and hath a small Market on this Town is much decayed, and eaten up by the Sea-waves, there being formerly two Churches, one of which, with several of its houses, lyeth buried in the Sea. Repham.
Repham, seated in a Valley, hath a Market on here are two fair Churches now standing in one Church-yard, said to be built by two Sisters. Alesham.
Alesham, scituate on a River, a poor Town chiefly inhabited by Knitters, both men, women, and children; yet its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well frequented. Caston.
Caston, not far from Alesham, a Market- town on Tuesdays, which is well frequented. Worsted.
Worsted, seated in a Flat, of note for its Worsteds here first made; It hath a small Market on Saturdays. North-Walsham.
North-Walsham, not far from the Sea in a level, a fine Market-town on Thursdays, being well provided with corn, flesh, and other commodities. Hickling.
Hickling, also seated not far from the Sea, and in a Marsh-ground; hath a very inconsiderable Market. St. Bennets Abbey.

Not far from this Town is the ancient decayed Abbey of St. Bennet in the Holme, built by Canutus the Dane, which was after wards by the Monks so strengthened with Walls and Bulwarks, that it might be esteemed rather a Castle then a Cloyster; and had not a treacherous Monk betrayed it, William the Conqueror could not easily have gained it by assault; and to requite this his good service, he was afterwards hanged, (a fit reward for so base a service.) And the Bishop of Norwich still reteins the title of Lord Abbot of St. Bennets. Lucham.
Lucham, seated in a Common, a stragling Town, which had formerly a Market, but by reason of the great fire about thirty years since, the Market is disused. Places of note to Seamen.
Remarkable places to Seamen along the Coast of this County, are the Wash in the Western part; then Wayborn-hope in the North; and Winterton- Ness, or Point in the East, which is very coldly seated.

div1.n: Northamptonshire BEING Part of the CORITANI and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: Northamptonshire BEING Part of the CORITANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Northampton with its Hundreds

div1.p: NORTH AMPTONSHIRE, an Inland County, and almost scituate in the midst of the Kingdom; having on the East the Counties of Cambridge, Huntington, and Bedford; on the South those of Buckingham and Oxford; on the West Warwickshire; and on the North those of Leicester, Rutland, and Lincoln. Its form and extent.

Its form is long and narrow, being from Croughton near Brackley in the South-west, to Market-Deeping in the North-east in Lincolnshire, (where it is severed from this County by the River Welland) about 42 miles; and in breadth (where broadest) not exceeding 20; its circumference making about 120 miles. Its Fertility.

It is of a fat and rich soil both for tillage and pasturage, bearing excellent grain, and feeding great store of sheep and cattle, from which (being the general product of the County) the Inhabitants reap such good profit, (which hath encouraged them so much to grasing and tillage) that there is said to be less waste ground in this County, then in any other in England. Very populous.

It is blest with a temperate and healthful air, and generally very populous, and plentifully garnished with Towns, insomuch, that in many places twenty or thirty Steeples presents themselves at one time to view And amongst its Inhabitants, it is said to be honoured with the Seats of as many (if not more) of the Nobility and Gentry, as any County in the Kingdom, especially as to its extent. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, and fresh streams, amongst which are the Welland, the Nen or Aufona, the Owse, the Charwell, and others; all which have their Spring-heads in this County. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants, according to Ptolomy, were the Coritani, who were brought under the Romish yoke by Publius Ostorius Scapula, Lieutenant in Britain for Claudius the Emperour; and became afterwards part of the Kingdom of the West-Saxons. Religious Houses.

Religious Houses here were many, as at Barkley, Bruch, Catesby, Daventre,
St. Dewy, Finshed, Fotheringhar, Gare, Higham, Laffield, St. Michael, Northampton, Peakirk, Peterburgh, Pipewell, Sausecomb, Sewardesleg, Sulby, Wedon, and Withorp. Its division.

This County is severed into twenty Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp, in which are numbred 326 Parish Churches, and hath intercourse for traffick to eleven Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Northampton. See Speed and Cambden.

Northampton, pleasantly scituated on the River Nyne, which compasseth its Southand West parts, over which it hath two Bridges; a place of good antiquity, and once very large; but this, as almost all other places, felt the sore hand of the Dane, and other calamities: yet for circuit, and fair buildings, it may at present be ranked with many Cities in this Kingdom, numbring four Parish Churches within its Walls, which were strongly built, but now demolished; upon the West part of which (mounted upon a hill) standeth a large Castle, whose gaping chinks, and aged countenance doth dayly threaten the downfall of its ruinous Walls. It is a Town of a considerable trade; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great for cattle, corn, and provisions, as also for leather and shoos. The Government of this place is committed to the care of a Maior, two Bailiffs, twelve Magistrates, a Recorder, Town Clark, and other Sub-officers; it enjoyeth good immunities, hath the election of Parliament men; is honoured with the Title of an Earldom; which at present is in the person of the Right Honourable James Earl of Northampton, &c. Is the place where the County- Goal, and the Assizes are kept, and the general place for the Assembly of the Justices of the Peace for the County. Peterburgh.

Peterburgh, seated on the River Aufona or Nen (which is navigable for Barges) over which it hath a Bridge which leadeth into Hungtingtonshire, and in a Marsh-ground, where there was formerly an exceeding deep Gulph or Whirl-pool, which with great pains and diligence was made firm ground by Wolpher King of the Mercians, at the time when he laid the foundation of the Church. It is a City of great antiquity, and was of good account in the time of the Saxons, where the said King Wolpher, for the expiating his crime in the cruel murthering his sons Wolphald and Rufin, for being converted to the Christian Faith (to which he was some years after converted himself) in Anno 633, finished a most stately Monastery (sormerly begun by his brother) and dedicated it to St. Peter, from which the City took its name, being of old called Madeshamstede, and was a place of much fame. But in the time of the Danes tyranny it suffered great spoils, lying in its own rubbish, and quite forsaken for many years, till in the end Ethelwold Bishop of Winchester, (who chiefly devoted himself to pious uses) about the year 960, began to re-edifie it, gaining to him the helping hand of King Edgar, and Adulph the Kings Chancellor, who (as Cambden noteth) upon remorse of conscience, for that he and his wife in their sleep, had overlaid and smothered their child, (which was but a young Infant) expended all his Estate upon the re-edifying the same; and when it was thus rebuilt, he was the first Abbot thereof: and then was it in a most flourishing condition, and enjoyed ample priviledges, which so continued, until the reign of Henry the Eighth, who put an end to it, and all other Religious Houses in the Kingdom; and in its room erected a Bishoprick, and founded here a Chapter, consisting of a Dean and six Prebendaries, and allotting to the Diocess the Counties of Northampton and Rutland: It hath also an Arch-Deacon, who is entituled of Northampton; and here the Dean keepeth his Court for hearing of causes, and hath also a Goal. And thus from a Monastery, it is now become a Cathedral, which is a stately
Structure, the Fore-front carrying good majesty with it, it hath large Cloysters, and in the Glass-windows was (if not is) lively presented the History of Wolpher the Founder thereof. St. Mary's Chappel is a goodly large building, full of curious work, with a large Quire; and here lyeth interr'd the bodies of two unfortunate Queens, Katharine of Spain, and Mary of Scots. This City is a place of no great extent, haveing but one Parish Church, besides its Cathedral; its streets of late are indifferently well ordered, being formerly very dirty; its houses well built, and hath a spacious Market-place, in which is lately erected a well-built and graceful Market-hall, where the Sessions and Assizes for the Hundred of Nassaburgh are kept. It is a City that enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; Is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which at present is in the person of the Right Honorable, Henry Earl of Peterburgh; is a place of some account and trade, and the rather by reason of the Episcopal See here seated; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with provisions. The ancient City of Durobrivae.

Not far distant from Peterburgh westwards, was seated the ancient City Durobrivae, which by the English-Saxons was called Normanchester; which said City took up a great tract of ground on both sides of the River, and in both Counties; for according to Mr. Cambdens observations, Caster about a mile from the River, by its ancient checkered pavements there often digged up, seemeth to be part of the City; and in the Corn-fields adjoyning (which the Inhabitants call Normanton-fields) Roman coyns have oft-times been digged up. Normaton-fields. Also the two Road-wayes coming from this place, whose Cawseys are to be seen, the one called Forty-foot-way, and the other Long-ditch and High-street, sufficiently makes it to be a place of good account.Rode-wayes of the Romans. Oundle.

Oundle, pleasantly seated on the banks of the Nen, over which it hath two good Bridges; a well built uniform Town, beautisied with a fair Church, a Free-School, and an Almes-house, and hath a very great Market for cattle, corn, flesh, fowl, and other provisions on Saturdays. Fotheringbay-Castle.

Nigh unto Oundle Northwards, is seated Fotheringhay-Castle, environed on all sides with pleasant Meadows; a place of good note in former time, where Edward Duke of York, in the second year of the Reign of Henry the Fifth, founded a fair Collegiate Church, wherein himself, who was slain at the Battle of Agincourt, together with his Brother who lost his life at Wakefield, and his Wife Cicily Nevill had stately Tombs, which were spoyled, together with the upper part of the Church, in the Reign of Edward the Sixth. And at this Castle, Mary Queen of Scots was beheaded. Thrapston.
Thrapston, seated on the Eastern banks of the Nen, over which is a goodly fair Stone-bridge; It is a pretty good Town, and hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays. Higham-Ferrers.

Higham-Ferrers, scituate on an ascent, and also on the Eastern banks of the Nen, an ancient Borough and Town-Corporate, sending one Burgess to Parliament; is governed by a Maior, seven Aldermen, thirteen Capital Burgesses, a Steward, &c. was once graced with a fair Colledge, founded by Arch-Bishop Chichely, which building is yet kept in good Repair: And hath weekly two Markets on Thusdays and Saturdays, which are well resorted unto, but that on Thursdays is of late years either disused, or very inconsiderable. Here is a Free-Sohool for the education of youth; and an Almes-house for the relief of poor people; and was anciently strengthned with a Castle, whose ruins are yet to be seen.
Wellingborow.

Wellingborow, pleasantly seated on the ascent of a hill, and on the Western banks of the Nen, a large and well inhabited Town, which enjoyeth a good trade, is beautified with a fair Church and a Free-School; and hath a Market on Wednesdays, which is well served with corn and provisions. This place is of some note for its Springs of medicinal water, not far distant from the Town. Kettering.

Kettering, delightfully seated on an ascent, an indifferent well-built Town, where there is a Sessions-house for the Justices of the Peace of the County, this being a place where they sometimes assemble together. Its Market, which is on Fridays, is well frequented, and served with corn, cattle, sheep, hoggs, and provisions. Gedington-Castle.
Not far from this Town was (if not is) Gedington-Castle, where was erected a cross in honour to Queen Elianor. Rockingham.

Rockingham, seated on the Weland, which falleth into the Nen, a small Town; in former time of note for its Castle long since demolished; but is the habitation of the Right Honorable Edward Lord Rockingham, &c. Its Market, which is on is of no great account. Rothwell.
Rothwell, or rowell, scituate on the side of a hill, an indifferent Town, whose Market, which is on Mondays, is but small. Naseby.

Not far from Rothwell is Naseby, famous for somewhat more then the late bloody battel there fought, viz. that it is said to stand upon the highest ground in England; and in or near the said Town two considerble Rivers have their Spring-heads, to wit, the Avon and the Nen; also the highest Spring of the Weland (though not the furthest from the Sea) riseth in this field, which is very large, conteining near 4000 acres of ground. And in this field there is no sign of a fight remaining, except some few holes which were the burial places of the dead men and horses. Guilsborow.
Further West ward is Guilsborough, once a Fortress of the Romans. Daventrey.

Daventry, seated on the side of Borow-hill, a good Town, governed by a Bailiff, Aldermen, a Steward, and 12 Freemen; and hath a Market on Wednesdays, which is well served with horses, cattle, sheep, corn, and provisions.

Here was raised upon an high hill (which commandeth a fair prospect round about) a four-square Fort, on the East-side of which was a Mount, called Spelwell, as Mr. Cambden noteth, all which incloseth within a bank of earth cast up, about 100 acres of ground, where have been oft-times found Roman coyns. Wedon.

Not far from Daventrey is Wedon, or Wedon in the Street, a station of the Romans, and where there was a Monastery founded by the holy Virgin St. Werberg, daughter to King Wolpher, who had here his Royal Seat. Lilbourn.

About six miles Northwards from Daventrey is Lilbourn, which anciently was a Market-town, and now a small Village, where there hath been a Castle, of which nothing is now remaining, save a great Mount encompassed with very deep Ditches, when and by whom founded is not known. And about a quarter of a mile Westwards, upon an indifferent rising hill, there is a little round and high Mount, of which there are several conjectures made; some supposing it to have been an ancient Landmark; others, that it was raised as a Battery against the aforesaid Castle, as having a perfect view and command thereof; and others that it was a Tumulus of some eminent Commander of the Romans, for that it is near to the ancient Via Prætoria, or Street-way, and was a station of some of their Legions.
Towcester.

Towcester, scituate on the banks of a small River, and in a Valley, a place of good antiquity, which Mr. Cambden believeth to be the ancient Tripontium mentioned by Antonine the Emperour, (which took its name from three Bridges: For here the Roman Port-way, which in many places between it and Stony-stratford sheweth it self) is cut through by three Streams or Channels, which the Rivulet there divideth it self into. And about the year of our Lord 917, it was a place so strongly fortified, that it proudly resisted the furious affaults of the Danes. It is at present a small Town, but beautified with a fair Church, and hath an indifferent good Market on Tuesdays. Brackley.

Brackley, seated on the edge of the County towards Buckinghamshire, and on a Branch of the Owse; an ancient and large Town Corporate, conteining two Parish Churches, governed by a Maior and Aldermen, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, had formerly a Colledge, which now is made use of for a Free-School; and hath a Market on Wednesdays, which at present is but small; but in former time was famous, especially for its being (as it were) the staple Town in the County for Wool.

div1.n: Northumberland: BEING Part of the OTTADINI and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div1.head: Northumberland: BEING Part of the OTTADINI, and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Northumberland with the Isles of Farne & Holy Iland

div1.p: NORTHUMBERLAND, a County of a sharp and piercing Air, and much troubled with pinching frosts, boisterous winds, and deep snows in the winter, which would be more offensive to its Inhabitants, were it not for the great plenty of Sea-coal, here had at such easie rates.

It is a Countrey but thinly inhabited, which is occasioned through its near neighbourhood to Scotland; and its barrenness, being for the most part exceeding rough, hilly, and very hard to be manured; but in some parts towards the Sea, by the toylsome labour of the Husbandman, with the benesit of Sea-weed, it is of late years become indifferent fertile. But as the earth is thus sterile, the Rivers (which plentifully water this County) together with the Sea, furnish them with abundance of fish and fowl. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the German Ocean; on the South with the River Tine, which severeth it from the Bishoprick of Durham; on the West with Cumberland, and the Cheviot-hills, which parts it from Scotland; and on the North with the River Tweed, which also divides it from Scotland. Its extent.

Its form is Triangular, and extendeth it self from New- Castle in the South, to Barwick in the North about 43 miles; and from Warworth in the East, to Belkirk in the West, about 30; and in circumference about 145 miles. Great plenty of Sea-coal.

The chief Riches of this County are drawn from the Sea-coal, which is here in such exceeding great plenty, that it supplies the defect of London and other parts; many hundred sail of ships having yearly from hence their loading. Many places of Antiquity, for which see Mr. Cambden.

This County sheweth abundance of memorable Antiquities, as well along the Picts-wall, which traverseth the Southern part, as elsewhere; as pieces of Roman coyn, Inscriptions, with broken and unperfect Altars, which Mr. Cambden hath very learnedly taken notice of in his description of this Country; amongst which these are note-worthy: Wall-town, where Segebert
King of the East-Saxons was baptized in the Christian Faith by Paulinus, Halyston, where the said Paulinus baptized many thousands. Readsquire, a steep Mountain, where oft-times was the place of conference for the East- Marches. The Hermitage, about half a mile from Warksworth by the water, a Chappel cut out of a Rock without beams, rafters, or any piece of timber. The Altar is also hewed out of the same Rock; and here (according to report) a Hermit lived in a cell within the Rock, and that this Chappel was a place for his Devotion. Through the Picts-wall runneth the Tyne, which watereth two Dales, each having their hills so boggy with standing water on the top, that no horsmen are able to ride through them; and yet in many places there are great heaps of stones (called Lawes) which are supposed to be cast up in old time, in remembrance of some persons there slain. Busy-Gap, a place infamous for robberies. Risingham, seated on the River Rhead, a place of great antiquity, which according to report, God Magon (for a good space of time) defended against a certain Soldan, or heathcnish Prince. Battels fought.

Here have been several bloody battels fought; viz. at Otterburn, where Fortune favoured the Scots; at Alnwick, where William K. of Scots was taken Prisoner, and presented to Henry the Second: at Brumridge, where K. Athe lstan fought a pitched battel with great success against Anlafe the Dane, Constantine K. of Scots, and Engenius K. of Cumberland: at Flodden, where the English were Victors, in which James the fourth K. of Scots was slain: and at Dilston, where Oswald slew Cedwall the Britain in a pitched battel; and soon after from a lover of the Christians, became one, and professed the Christain Faith, and caused his people to be instructed in the Faith of Christ. Aucient Inhabitants.

The Inhabitants which possessed this County before the coming of the Romans (according to Ptolomy) were the Ottadini, and (according to Mr. Cambden) being brought under the English Saxons Jurisdiction, by Osca brother to Hengist, and by his son Jebusa, had first official Governours under the fealty to the Kings of Kent. After that, when the Kingdom of the Berenicii, by the Britains (called Guir-a-Brinaich, which signifieth Mountiners) was erected, that which reached from the Scottish Frith to the Tees, (being the best part) was subject to the Kings of Northumberland; who having finished their period, whatsoever lay beyond Tweed was accounted Scotland: Then was it yielded up to Eghert K. of the West-Saxons, who laid it to his own Territory. Afterwards by permission of K. Alfred, the Danes possessed it, who were in few years dispossessed and drove out by Athelstane, and soon after it was governed by Earls. Its division. Parishes.

This County is severed into six Wards, in which are numbred 46 Parishes, many of which are very large, having their Chappels of Ease; and for its defense hath several Castles; and for the accommodation of its Inhabi- tants, is traded unto by six Market-towns, which are as followeth. Newcastle.

Newcastle, seated on the rising of an hill, very uneven, and upon the North bank of the River Tyne, over which it hath a fair bridge which leadeth into the Bishoprick of Durham, where on the South side of the Tyne is Gateshead, which serveth as a Suburb to Newcastle. This Town before the Conquest, was called Monk-chester, as being (as 'tis said) in the possession of Monks; which name was changed to Newcastle, by Robert son to William the Conquerour, from a Castle there built by him. It is a Town and County of it self, being incorporated, and governed by a Maior, 12 Aldermen, a Recorder, and other Sub-Officers; and amongst its immunities hath the election of Parliament men. It is a place of a good largeness, numbring four Parish Churches, besides one in Gates-head; is beautified with good buildings; and by reason of its deep and secure Haven, is a place much inhabited and frequented by
Merchants and Trade smen, who drive a very considerable trade both by sea and land for all commodities, having several ships and vessels belonging to the Town; but is of chief note for its coal-trade, yearly lading therewith some thousands of ships both great and small. And here the Merchants have their Exchange or place of meeting, which is also made use of for the keeping of the Records of the Town, the hearing of Causes, &c. The Key where the ships ride is very commodious and good; nigh unto which on Sandy-hill, is the Custom-house. It is a place of great strength, for beside its Castle, now something decayed, it is begirt with a strong Wall, on which are many Turrets, and hath for entrance seven Gates. Here are weekly two Markets on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are both very considerable for all sorts of provisions.
This Town is dignisied with the Title of a Dukedom, which at present is in the person of the R. Noble William, Duke, Marquess, and Earl of Newcastle. Hexam.

Hexam, according to Beda, Hagulstadiensis, a Town in former times of great fame and beauty, which Etheldreda, wife to K. Egfrid, gave unto St. Wilfrid about the year 675, that he should exalt it with an Episcopal See; who built there a most stately Church, said to surpass all the Minsters in England. It enjoyed ten Bishops, the first amongst which was St. Eata the fifth Bishop of Lindisfarn; and being spoiled by the furious Danes, it was added to the See of York. It is scituate on the River Tyne, and is at present a good well- built Bailiffwick-town, having the accommodation of an indifferent Market for corn and provisions on Tuesdays: And may boast of its Abbey, which though at present decayed, was once very famous, as was its Church, before a great part thereof was pulled down by the Scots. Morpeth,

Morpeth, seated on the River Wensbeck, a very fine Town, being incorporated, governed by two Bailiffs, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is strengthned with a Castle; and hatha Market on Wednesdays, which is esteemed the best in the County, being sufficiently stored with corn, all provisions, and living cattle, which from hence are dispersed to divers parts of this Kingdom. Woller.
Woller, a small Town, scituate on the side of a hill, but hat a great Market for corn, &c. on Thursdays. Alnewick.

Alnewick, seated on the River Alne, of note for the bloody battel here fought betwixt the English and Scotch, as before is noted. It is an indifferent good Town, once strengthened with a large Castle, which is now something ruinous; near adjoyning to which is an old decayed Abbey, out of whose ruins there is now a fine house built. Its Market is on Saturdays, which is not great. Barwick.
