Barwick, commodiously seated betwixt the two Kingdoms of England and Scotland, but neither in Northumberland nor Scotland, although on the North or Scotish side of the Tweed, being a Town and County of it self. It is a place of great strength as well by Nature as Art, being almost encompassed with the Sea, and the River Tweed on which it is seated, and strongly fenced about with Walls, a Castle, and other Fortifications, the better to secure it, as being a place of such great importance unto England; for whensoever any discord hapned betwixt the two Nations before their union, this Town was sure to endure the brunts of ill fortune and incursions, having been oft-times possessed by the Scots, and as oft by the English, who have been possessors thereof from the reign of Edward the Fourth, and have so well strengthned it, that it is esteemed the strongest hold in the two Kingdoms. It is a Town Corporate, governed by a Maior, Bailiffs and Burgesses, and sendeth Members to Parliament. The Town is large and populous, the houses well bullt, enjoyeth a good trade, especially for Salmon and corn; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great, and well served with provisions, which are had at casie rates.
Here is a stately briage over the Tweed, snsteined by 14 or 15 Arches, being esteemed not much inferiour to any in England. Isles along the Coast.
Along the Coast of this County are the Islands of Cocket, Fern, and Holy Island. Cocket Isle.
Cocket Island, a small Isle near Wetherington- Castle. Farn Isle.

Farn Island, seated two miles from Bambrough- Castle, on the North-cast of which lyeth some small Islands, as Widopens, Staple Island, and Wambers. It is of a small extent, not exceeding fifteen miles in circumference.

The soil is much inclined to sterility, and very deficient of fewel, corn, and provisions, except fish and fowl. It is encircled with craggy Clifts; and hath an air very unwholsome, and subject to many diseases, occasioned through the misty foggs and exhalations drawn up from the Sea.
Here are not many houses, much less Towns or Villages, yet hath it a Tower or fortisied place about the midst thereof. Holy Island.

Holy Island, or the Isle of Lindisfarne, so called from the River Lied; it is seated not far from Barwick; and here the Monks oft-times retired themselves, as a solitary place fit for Devotion. Its form and extent.

The form of this Isle is long and narrow, running out with a neck of land towards Northumber land; and of no great extent, being from East to West about two miles and a quarter; and from North to South, not much above a mile. Its soil.

The soil is very ungrateful and unfit for tillage or pasturage, being rocky and full of stones, neither having hills for the feeding of sheep, good pastures for the grasing of cattle, or Valleys replenished with water, except one River which descendeth from a standing pond; the only accommodation of this Isle being fish and fowl.

And being thus barren, together with an unheal thful air, makes it to be a place thinly peopled, having but one Town, with a Church and Castle, under which there is a commodious Haven, defended with a Block-house. And in this Isle, according to report, Aidan the Scot in ancient time instituted an Episcopal See.

div1.n: Nottinghamshire: BEING Part of the CORITANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Nottinghamshire: BEING Part of the CORITANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of Nottingham shire With its Wapontak

div1.p: NOTTINGHAMSHIRE, blest with a wholsome and delectable Air, and of a different soil; the South-east part, by reason of its being watered with the Trent, and other fresh Streams falling into it, is most fertile, and apt to bear corn, and grass; and being of a clayey earth, is called by the Inhabitants the Clay part: and the Western, wherein is the Forest of Shirwood (famous for Robin Hood and his Companions) taketh up a good part of the County, which is plentifully cloathed with Wood, hath store of coal, and well served with Game; and the Earth being generally of a sandy temperature, is called the Sand part. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds Lincolnshire, from which, for a good distance, it is severed by the River Trent; for its Southern, Leicestershire; for its Western the Counties of Darby and York; and for its Northern also Yorkshire. Its extent.

It is of an oval form, doubling in length twice its breadth; for from Besthorp in the East, to Taversall in the West, it is about 19 miles; and from Steanford in the South, to Finnyngley in the North, about 38; and in circumference about 110 miles. Its ancient Inhabitants.
The ancient Inhabitants before the Romans, were the Coritani; and upon the coming of the Saxons, it became part of the Kingdom of the Mercians. Religious Houses.
Religious Houses in this County were at Blith, Lenton, Newsted, Nottingham both the Gray and White Fryers. Radford, Shelford, Southwell, Thurgarton, and Welbeck.

This County produceth a stone softer then Alablaster, but being burnt maketh a plaister harder then that of Paris, with which they floor their Upper Rooms, which being throughly dry, becometh exceeding hard and durable.
Its Rivers.
It is very well watered with Rivers, the chief amongst which are the Trent and the Idle, which liberally send forth their refreshing streams.

It may be severed into two divisions or parts, which are again divided into eight Hundreds or Wapontakes, in which are numbred 168 Parish Churches, and is traded unto by nine Market-towns, whose names are as fo.loweth. Nottingham.

Nottingham, pleasantly and conveniently seated on the River Leane (which at a quarter of a miles distance falleth into the Trent, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge; and another fair Stone-bridge over the Leane, besides two other Bridges over two Ponds, called the Cheney Eridges) and on a hill, enjoying a fair prospect. The Town is large, conteining three Parish Churches, is beautified with well-built houses, hath fair streets, a spacious Market-place; and on the West side of the Town it is defended by a Castle, which for magnificence, and delightful prospect, might formerly have been compared with the best in England, (but destroyed in the late Wars) and was a place of so great strength, that the Danes made it their Garrison, and so resisted the assaults of Burthred King of the Mercians, and Ethelred King of the West-Saxons, who brough a powerful Army against it, that finding with all their Force they could not batter the Wall, were constrained to break up their Seige. In the reign of King Edward surnamed the elder, it was walled about, but was dismantled thereof in the Wars betwixt King Stephen, and Maud the Empress, by Robert Earl of Glacester, at which time the Town suffered much by fire. It is a Town of great Antiquity, and amongst its places of remark, here are many strange Vaults, hewed out of the Rocks, especially under the Castle, which are discended by divers steps or stairs; on the walls of one of which was engraven the Story of the Passion of Christ, which is said to be cut by the hand of David, the second King of the Scots during his imprisonment there. Also Mortimers-hole, so called, as being the place where the Lord Mortimer was surprised in the nonage of King Edward the Third: and these have their several rooms and stairs artificially made; also in the hill are houses, having rooms, chimneys, winding-stairs, and windows, wrought out of the solid Rock. This Town is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which apperteineth to the Right Honorable Charles Earl of Nottingham, &c. It enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is governed by a Maior, six Aldermen, two Sheriffs, two Chamberleyns, a Town-Clark, and other Sub-officers. It is a place very well inhabited, enjoyeth a very good trade, for an Inland-town, for most commodities; is a place well frequented, and the rather as being the place where the County Goal is, and where the Assizes are held; and hath weekly three Markets on Wednesdays and Fridays, which are but small, and on Saturdays, which is very considerable for cattle, corn, provisions, &c. Bingham.
Bingham, seated in the Vale of Belvoir, a mean Town, and hath a small Market on Thursdays. Southwell.
Southwell, an ancient Town, hath a Collegiate Church, and a Market on Saturdays, which is but small. Newsted,
At Newsted, that is New-place, King Henry the Second, founded a small Abbey. Newark.

Newark, seated on the high Road to York, and on the Trent, over which it hath a Bridge, which leadeth into a small Isle; it is a good large Town- Corporate, governed by an Alderman and 12 Assistants, is well inhabited,
enjoyeth a good trade, having a Market on Wednesdays, which is of considerable account for corn, cattle, and provisions; and was once strengthned by a most beautiful Castle, built by Alexander Bishop of Lincoln, which is now reduced to ruins. Mansfield.

Mansfield, scituate in the Forest of Sherwood, a good large Town, graced with well-built houses; is a place well inhabited; hath a good trade for Mault; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very great for corn, cattle, mault, swine, and provisions. Worksop.
Worksop also in the Forest of Sherwood, of more account for the great store of excellent liquorice here growing, then for its Market on Wednesdays, which is but small. Tuxford.
Tuxford, seated in the South Clay; a mean Town, and hath a small Market on Mondays. Redford.

Redford, seated on the River Idel; an ancient Town-Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, six Aldermen, and a Steward, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath the accommodation of a great Market for corn and provisions on Saturdays. Blyth.
Blyth, seated on a River, an indifferent Town, which hath a small Market on Thursdays. Littleburgh.
Not far from Redford is Littleburgh, seated on the Trent, where there is a Ferry, which is much resorted unto for a passage into Lincolnshire.

div1.n: OXFORDSHIRE, BEING Part of the DOBUNI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: OXFORDSHIRE, BEING Part of the DOBUNI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Rutland with its Hundreds
A Generall Mapp of the County of Oxford With its Hundreds

div1.p: OXFORDSHIRE, fertile in corn and fruits; hath rich pastures, which feed store of cattle, is interlaced with pleasant hills, which are well clothed with Wood, wherein, and in the Downs, are found variety of Game, both for the hawk and hound, is blest with a sweet and healthful air, and is much inhabited by Gentry. Rivers.
It is well watered with fresh streams; the chief amongst which are the Owse or Isis, the Tame, Cherwell, Windrush, and Evenlode. Its bounds.

This County hath for its bounds, on the East, Buckinghamshire; on the South, the Isis or Thames, which separates it from Barkshire; on the West, Glocestershire; and on the North, the Counties of Warwick and Northampton. Its extent.

Its extent from Tame in the East, to Burford in the West, is about 25 miles; and from Caversham in the South, to Cleydon in the North, about 38; and in circumference about 130 miles. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants known to the Romans, were the Dobuni; and betwixt the bowing of the Isis, were seated the Ancalites, who hearing that the Trinobantes had put themselves under the protection of Julius Cæsar, sent their submission unto him; but afrerwards the Inhabitants of this County being very powerful, and willing to shake of the Roman Yoke of Servitude, they withstood Ostorius Scapula. Ostorius Scapula the Roman Lieutenant. After the Romans it became a part of the Kingdom of the Mercian Saxons, although sometimes the Northumbrians and the West-Saxons had the possession of some part thereof, for according to Beda, King Oswald gave the then flourishing City of Dorchester unto Berinus the West-Saxon Apostle, to be his Episcopal See; and the said Bishop hapning to preach at Oxford before Wulpher the King of the Mercians, (in whose Court Athelwold the South-Saxons heathenish King was then present) He with all his Nobles were converted to the Christian Faith, and there baptized, whereby Berinus was also the Apostle of the South-Saxons. Religious houses.

Here are divers Religious houses, the chief amongst which were Bruern, Burchester, Enisham, Godstow, Osney, and Tame, besides St. Frideswides, and several other Religious houses in the City of Oxford.
This shire is severed into 14 Hundreds, in which are numbred 280 Parish Churches, is traded unto by 12 Market-towns, and graced with a stately and beautiful City. oxford.

Oxford, the British Athens, and glorlous seat of the Muses, exceeding all other Universities in the known World, except her Sister Cambridge. It is a place of great antiquity, being said to be consecrated unto the Sciences in the time of the old Britains, and was hither translated (as a place more fit for so honourable an assembly) from Creek-lade a Town in Wiltshire. This City was a fellow sufferer with the rest of the Land, and shared in those common calamities brought by the Saxons and Danes, having little left to boast of, save the famous Monument of St. Frideswids Virgin Conquest, no other School being left standing but her Monastery; but these storms being blown over, King Elfred recalled the exiled Muses, and there built three Colledges for the Studies of Divinity, Philosophy, and other liberal Arts;and the better to invite Students, he sent thither his son Ethelward, which drew thither the young Nobles from all parts of the Kingdom, and then began it again to flourish, and by little and little to grow to what it is, being at present a fair and stately City, adorned with well-built houses, and beautified with divers curious Structures,as the Kings Palace, now the Manour-house, the 16 Colledges, 8 Halls, the Schools, wherein is a stately Library, and a stately Theater newly erected at the charge of Gilbert Lord Arch- Bishop of Canterbury; which said Colledges and Halls are richly endowed, and plentifully supplyed with learned Graduates and Students. It is also adorned with a Cathedral Church, called Christ-Church, a large Structure,anciently dedicated to St. Frideswide; is honoured with an Episcopal See, the Chapter consisting of a Dean, and eight Prebendaries, and for the Diocess hath one Arch-Deacon, which is of Oxford; It is also honoured in giving the Title to the Right Honorable Aubery Earl of Oxford. It is a City well seated both for pleasure and profit between the Isis (where it divides it self into several streams) and the Charwell, near its influx into the Isis, so that it hath three parts encompassed by the said Rivers, over which are several Bridges for the conveniency of the Inhabitants. The City is large, numbring 14 Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral; it enjoyeth ample immunities, keepeth Courts for all Actions without limitation of any, electeth four Burgesses, two for the Universitie, and two for the City, is very populous and well inhabited; hath weekly two Markets on Wednesdays, and Saturdays, which is the chief, and very considerable for provision both flesh and fish, and all sorts of grain, especially barley: And the City of late years, since the making the River Isis navigable for Barges to London, by the help of Turn-pikes, is become a place of a great trade, principally for Mault. Witney.

Witney, an ancient and large stragling Town, inhabited by abundance of poor people, who gain their livelyhoods by spinning and carding for the Clothiers who here reside, and drive a good trade for Blankets and Ruggs here made by them. The Town is seated on the River Windrush, hath the accommodation of a good Free-School for the education of Youth, where there is a fine Library; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is indifferently well furnished with provisions. Roll-rich-stones. Hock-norton. Scier-stane.

Not far from this Town, and near Enisham, is a Monument of huge and unwrought stones, called Roll-rich-stones, set in a circular compass, supposed to be there erected in memory of some great Victory obteined either by, or against Rollo the Dane, who in Anno 876 set footing in England, and in this County fought two sore and bloody battels, the one near Hock-norton, a Town of note for the rude behaviour of the people, and the other at the Scier-stane; but there have been some who fabulonsly have conceited them
to be metamorphosed from men, and that the highest of them all without the circle, should have been a King of England; also the other five placed on the other side Knights mounted on horse-back, and the rest, the Army. And in this track of ground is Whitwood-Forest, of a large extent. Whitwood Forest. Eampton.

Bampton, scituate near the Isis, a large Town, within a larger Parish, having several Towns or Villages belonging unto it; and for the further accommodation of the Parishioners, it hath a Chappel of Ease, to which belongeth three Vicars, which have liberal maintenance. Its Market which is on Wednesdays, is but small. Burford.

Burford, seated on an ascent, and on the River Windrush, which springeth out of the Cots-wold; a good, fair, and large Town Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, and other Sub-officers; and hath a well frequented Market for corn, cattle, and provisions on Saturdays. This Town is of chief note for its good Saddles here made. And nigh unto this place Iyeth the Downs, much frequented and resorted unto by the Gentry for Horse-races, as very fit for that purpose, which brings a considerable advantage unto the Town. Woodstock.

Woodstock, delightfully seated on a rising ground, on a small River, and a large Park (esteemed the first inclosed Park) encompassed with a Wall, within which was a once stately house of the Kings (demolished in the late wars) called Woodstock-bower, built by King Henry the first, and enlarged with a Labyrinth of many windings backwards and forwards, by King Henry the second, for the keeping of the beatiful Damosel Rosamond Clifford, his dearly beloved Mistress, from his jealous and enraged Queen Elianors malicious plots; yet notwithstanding she was treacherously surprised by some perfidious Knave, who informed the Queen of a Clew of silk that conducted the King and others unto her; and taking an opportune time when the King was absent, being prepared with a glass of poyson, no sooner was she come unto her, but she forced her to drink the same, which quickly put an end to her dayes, to the great grief and enragement of the King. And here was born Edward the Black Prince. This Town of Woodstock is a well compacted Borough-town, governed by a Maior, four Aldermen, and other Sub- Officers, electeth Parliament men, holdeth a Court for the tryal of all Actions, without limitation of any; and hath an indifferent good Market for provisions, &c. on Tusdays. Godstow-Nunnery.

Not far from this Town stood Godstow, a small Nunnery, built by Dame Ida a wealthy Widow, and repaired and liberally endowed with a yearly revenew by King John, to the end that those holy Virgins might by their Prayers to God, relieve the souls of King Henry the second his father, and of Rosamond who was there interr'd, with this Epitaph:

p.hi: Hac jacet in tumba Rosa mundi, non Rosa munda,

div1.p: Non redolet, sed olet, quœ redolere solet. which Mr. Cambden hath thus Englished.

Rose of the World, not Rose the fresh pure flower, Within this Tomb hath taken up her bower: She senteth now, and nothing sweet doth smell, Which earst was wont to savour passing well. Chipping-Norton.

Chipping-Norton, scituate dry, on the side of a hill, and near a small Rivulet, a large, but stragling Town, yet well compacted about the Marketplace: It is a Town-Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, and other Sub-Officers, keeps Courts for all Actions under 4 l. and hath a good Market on Wednesdays for corn, cattle, and provisions. Banbury.

Banbury, for wealth and beauty the second Town in the County, and of some note for its good cakes and cheese, seated on the River Cherwell, and in a flat; a pretty large Town-Corporate, governed by a Maior, 12 Aldermen,
and other Sub-Officers, sendeth one Burgess to Parliament; keepeth Courts for the tryal of all Actions under 40 l. Is honoured by giving Title to the Right Honorable Nicholas Knowles Earl of Banbury, &c. and hath a very considerable Market for living cattle, sheep, and provisions (but little corn) on Thursdays. This Town (with the Church, a large Structure) sometime since suffered much by fire; but is at present very well repaired and beautified with well-built houses, most of which are of stone. Memorable is this Town for being the place where Kinric the West-Saxon King, in a memorable battel put to flight the Britains; but especially for the bloody conflict there-by fought between the two houses of York and Lancaster, in which the day was favourable to the Lancastrians, and where they took King Edward the fourth Prisoner. Deddington.
Deddington, seated on a rising ground, and in a fertile soil for corn; it is a pretty large Town, but hath a small Market for provisions on Saturdays. Burcester.

Burcester, seated on the head of a small Rivulet which falleth into the Cherwell, a stragling Town, except about the Market-place; and of late its Market, which is on Fridays, is grown pretty considerble for cattle and sheep. Aldchester.
Nigh unto this Town is Aldchester, which was a station of the Romans. Tame.

Tame, pleasantly seated on a River so called, which, with its branches doth almost encompass it, and over which it hath a Bridge which leadeth to Buckinghamshire; The Town is large, having one spacious street, in the midst of which is the Market-place; whose Market, which is on Tuesdays, is well frequented by Grasiers and Butchers from London and other parts, for the buying of cattle, for which it is eminent: And here is a famous Free-School, and a small Hospital, founded by the Lord Williams of Tame. Watlington.

Watlington, scituate on a small Brook, and under the Chiltern-hills, which with a continual ridge, divide this County from Buckinghamshire; an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market for provisions on Saturdays. Henley.

Henley, or Henley upon Thames, as being thereon seated, over which it hath a fair Bridge; It is a large Town-Corporate, governed by a Warden, and other inferiour Officers; enjoyeth a considerable trade for Maulting, its Inhabitants (which for the most part are Bargemen or Watermen) gain a good livelyhood by transporting of mault, wood, and other goods to London, and in return bring such commodities as they and the Inhabitants of the adjacent Towns have need of, at easie rates: and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very considerable for corn, especially barley, which is brought them for their great Mault-trade, there being oft-times in one day sold about 300 Cart-load of barley. Dorchester.

Dorchester, seated on the River Isis or Thame, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge; a Town formerly of more note then now it is, when Berinus, Apostle of the West-Saxons, had his Episcopal See here, (as before noted) which afterwards was removed to Lincoln; yet as being seated on the Road (although it hath no Market) is well frequented, having several Inns and Houses of Entertainment, and is graced with a very large and fair Church.

div1.n: Rutlandshire: BEING Part of the CORITANI and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Rutlandshire: BEING Part of the CORITANI, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.
div1.p: RUTLAND, the smallest County in England; being in extent from Ezenden in the East, to Wissenden in the West, not above 10 miles; and from Caldecot in the South, to Thistleton in the North, about 12; making its circumference not to exceed 40 miles. Its fertility.

And although for quantity the least in the Kingdom, yet for quality may be compared with the best; being blest with a healthful air, and a fertile soil, both for tillage and pasturage, (especially about the Vale of Catmose) affording store of corn, and feeding good heards of cattle, and flocks of sheep, whose wool participates of the colour of the earth, which is reddish. Its Rivers. Parks. It is well clothed with wood, watered with fresh streams, the chief amongst which are the Weland, and the Washe; and hath more Parks (considering its extent) then any County in England.
It gives Title of an Earldom to the Right Honorable John Mannors Earl of Rutland, Lord Ross of Hamlack, Trusbut, and Belvois, &c. Its bounds.
Ith ath for its bounds, on the East Lincolnshire; on the South the River Weland, which severeth it from Northamptonshire; and on the West and North Leicestershire. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants, when the Romans set footing here, were the Coritani; who, with the lcenians, were brought to a submission to the Roman power by P. Ostorius, when Claudius the Emperour reigned; after which, in the time of the Saxons, it became part of the Kingdom of the Mercians.
This County was not over-pestered with Religious houses; nor much strengthned with Castles. Its division.

It is severed into five hundreds, as appears in the Mapp, in which are numbred 48 Parishes, and for the intercourse of traffick hath two Market- towns; viz,
Okcham.

Okeham, seated in a rich and pleasant Valley, called the Vale of Catmose; so called, as some would have it, by reason of the Oaks thereabouts growing in great plenty. The Town is not large, yet is the chief of the County, where the Assizes and Sessions are held, which makes it to be better inhabited and frequented, then otherwise it would. Its buildings are indifferent good, especially its Church, Free-School, and Hospital: nor is its Castle to be forgotten, which sheweth more of antiquity then beauty, being the place where the Assizes are held. Its Market is on Saturdays, which is indifferently well served with provisions. This Town hath an ancient priviledge belonging to its Royalty, which is, If any Noble man enter within the Precinct of the said Lordship or Royalty, as an homage he is to forfeit a shoo from the Horse on which he rideth, unless he redeem it at a price with money; which homage hath been acknowledged by divers of the Nobility that have passed this way; as is evidenced by the several Horshoos which have been nailed up on the Shire-hall door. Uppingham.

Uppingham, seated on an eminence; a pretty compacted and well-built Town, which hath the accommodation of a very good Free-School and an Hospital, and a well frequented Market on Wednesdays (esteemed better then Okeham) being well served with living cattle, corn, and provisions.

div1.n: SHROPSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORNAVII and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: SHROPSHIRE: BEING Part of the CORNAVII, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Generall Mapp of Shrop Shire with its Hundreds

div1.p: SHROPSHIRE, well replenished with Towns and Castles on every side, by reason of its being a frontier County for the repelling, and over-awing the Welch-men in the bordering Marches, or bounds betwixt the English and Welch; and divers Noble men in this Tract were called Barons of the March, and Lords Marchers, and had every one of them in their Territory a certain peculiar Jurisdiction; and in their own Courts ministred Law unto the Inhabitants, with divers priviledges and immunities. Its fertility and commodities.

It is of a fertile soil, both for tillage and pasturage, abounding in wheat and barley, is well clothed with wood, feedeth store of cattle; and in the bowels of the earth are Mines of iron and pit-coal in great plenty. It is well watered with fresh streams, amongst which are the Severn, (which in a crooked and winding course cutteth the shire in the midst) the Terne, Clun, Rea, Team, and Roden, &c. in all which are plenty of fresh-water fish. Chief Hills.
It is very hilly and mountainous, especially towards the Southern and Western parts; the chief of which are the Wrekin, Brethen, Brown-clee, and Stitter-stones. Ancient Cities in this Shire.

In this shire were several places of good account in the time of the Romans, where their Legions lodged, although long since reduced to ruins;and such were the ancient Viroconium of Ptolomy, (the chiefest City of the Cornavii,) out of whose ruins was raised Wrocester, Usoconia, now Oken-yate, and under or near Red-castle, according to report, was a flourishing City in Arthurs days, which place the Inhabitants now call Berry. Religious Houses.
Amongst the places set apart for religious worship, these were of most note, Wenlock. Bildas, Bromfield, Dudley, Wigmore, Stowe, Coulmere, Hamond, Bishops-castle, and Lyleshill. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds Staffordshire; for its Southern, the Counties of Worcester, Hereford, and Radnor; for its Western, those of Montgomery and Denbigh; and for its Northern, Cheshire. Its extent.

Its extent from Tong-castle in the East, to Oswestre in the West, is about
25 miles; and from Stow in the South, to Hynton in the North, is about 33, and makes in circumference about 134 miles. Its division and Parishes.

As to its division, it is severed into 15 Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp; in which are numbred 170 Parish Churches, and is traded unto by 15 Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Sbrewsbury.

Shrewsbury, raised out of the ruins of the ancient Uriconium not far distant, and called by the Saxons, Scrobbesbyrig, the Seat of the Princes of Powis, until forced thence by the Saxons. It is seated almost in the heart of the County, on a pleasant ascent, and on the banks of the Severn, which do almost encompass it on all sides, except towards the North; and from the said River the Inhabitants are well served with water, by an Aquæduct conveyed through Pipes; besides several Conduits. It is a place which for largeness numbring sive Parish Churches, besides a Chappel, (two of which, St. Maries and St. Alchmonds, are fair Structures, and beautified with lofty Spires,) neatness of buildings, both publick and private, largeness (and variety) of streets, and populousness, may be ranged in the number of Cities of the sirst rank. And here was a once stately Abbey founded by Roger Earl of Montgomery, (as was its Castle) the remains of which is yet in good part in being. It is a Town of a good strength, as well by Nature as Art, being fenced about with a strong Wall, besides another Bulwark ranging from the Castle unto (and in part along) the Severn, through which there are three entrances into the Town, on the West and East by two fair Stonebridges, with Gates, Towers, and Barrs; and on the North by a strong Gate, over which is mounted the said Castle, once exceeding strong. It is a place of a great resort, and well inhabited both by the English and the Welch, who speak both Speeches, and enjoyetha very great trade for cloths, cottons, frizes, and variety of other commodities, this being the common Mart between England and Middle-Wales. This Town enjoyeth large immunities, keepeth Courts, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, hath the accommodation of a very large Free-School for the education of Youth, is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Charles Talbot Earl of Shrewsbury, &c. For Civil Magistrates, is governed by a Maior, 24 Aldermen, and 48 Common-councel men, a Recorder, Steward, and Town-Clark; and hath weekly three Markets, on Wednesdays for provisions, on Thursdays for Welch- cottons, &c. here sold in great abundance, and thence sent to London; and on Saturdays for cattle, and all sorts of provisions in great plenty. Strettons.
Strettons, seated betwixt two hills; a small Town, but hath a good Market for corn on Thursdays. Oswestree.

Oswestree, so called from Oswald King of the Northumbers, who was here slain in a bloody battel, and cruelly torn in pieces by Penda the Pagan Mercian Prince, being before called Maserfield; it is seated near the spring- head of a small River, is a Town-Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, and Burgesses; was once a place of great strength, being fortisied with a Wall, a Ditch, and a Castle, and was a place of a greater account then now it is, before the Mart for Welch cottons, &c. was removed to Shrewsbury, yet is it an indifferent Town, hath a trade for Flannels; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is well resorted unto, and furnished with cattle and provisions. Ellsmeer.
Ellsmeer, seated on the side of a large Meer, and in a little, but rich and fertile Territory so called; it is a small Town, and hath a mean Market on Tuesdays. Whitchurch.

Whitchurch, seated on the confines of the County near Cheshire, a good Town, but of no great trade; yet its Market, which is on Fridays, is indifferent good for cattle and provisions.
Draiton.

Draiton, scituate on the river Terne, where it severeth the County from Staffordshire, a place of some note for a bloody Battle there fought betwixt the houses of York and Lancaster: It is an indifferent Town, whose Market which is on Wednesdays is very good for Horses and Cattle, and but indifferent for provisions. Wem.
Wem, seated on the river Roden, a small Town, but hath a great Market on Thursdays, for Cattle and provisions. Newport.

Newport, seated on a plain or flat adjoyning to Staffordshire; an indifferent Town, graced with a fair Free-School, and a Market-house, and hath a considerable Market for cattle and provisions on Saturdays. Wellington.
Wellington, seated near the Wreking-hill; a small Town, but hath a good Market for corn and provisions on Thursdays. Wenlock magna.

Wenlock magna, scituate in the Road from Worcester to Shrewsbury; a place of note in the time of the Saxons for its Nunnery, where Milburga the holy Virgin lived a devout life, and was entomb'd; It is a Town-Corporate, governed by a Bailiff and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men; is of some account for its Lyme and Tobacco-pipes here made in great plenty; and hath a very good Market for corn and provisions on Mondays. Eridgnorth.

Bridgnorth, said to be first built by Achelfleda, Lady of the Mercians; It is a large Town-Corporate, seated on the Severn, which divides it, but is joyned together by a fair Stone-bridge; is governed by two Bailiffs and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men, conteineth two Parish Churches, is well inhabited, and consisteth of two parts; the one called the upper, and the other the lower Town. It was in former time fortified with Walls, a Ditch, and a stately Castle seated on a Rock, now decayed; and hath at present a good Market for corn, cattle, and provisions. Shipton.
Shipton, a small mean Town, which hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays. Clebury.
Clebury, or Cleobury Martimer, seated on the River Rea, and near the Forest of Wire; a mean Town, and hath a small Market on Ludlow,

Ludlow, seated on the banks of the Temd, a Town more fair then ancient, being beautified with many fair Edifices, amongst which the Palace of the President of the Marshes is the chief; It is a large Town-Corporate, governed by Bailiffs and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men; and hath a very great Market for corn, cattle, and provisions on Mondays. The Town is strong, being defended by a Wall and a Castle, both built by Roger Montgomery, is very populous and well inhabited, and is of chief note for being the place where the Courts for the Marshes of Wales are kept, first ordained by King Henry the Eight for the tryal of Causes, for the easement of the Welch-men and neighbouring Inhabitants; which Court consisteth of a Lord President, divers Chancellors, a Secretary, an Attorney, a Solicitor, and four Justices of the Countys in Wales, and is kept in the Castle, a large place fit for the like purpose; and here Prince Arthur kept his Court. Bishops-Castle.

Bishops-Castle, scituate not far from the River Clun, a small Borough-Town, which giveth its Vote in Parliament by two Burgesses; its chief Officer is a Bailiff; and hath a good Market for corn, &c. on Fridays.

Near this Town is a noted hill, called Caer-Caradoc, where the Noble and Valiant British King Caractacus, raised (as Camden noteth) in the front thereof a huge Rampier of stone, and he and his people resolutely made it good for a great while against the furious assaults of Ostorius, Lieutenant for the Romans, and his Souldiers; but in the end, being too powerful, broke down the same, and forced them to take sanctuary in the mountains, but his Queen, Daughter, and Brethren were taken prisoners; and not long had he his liberty, for committing himself to the protection of Qu. Cartismandua, she basely delivered him up unto Ostorius, who soon sent him to Rome to Claudius the Emperour, who for his noble Speech made before him, obteined pardon for him, and his.

div1.n: Somersetshire: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: Somersetshire: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Somerset With its Hundreds

div1.p: SOMERSET, a large and wealthy County, and of a rich and fertile soil, both for tillage and pasturage, being on every side garnished with rich Pastures and delightful Meadows, yet not without stony hills. Its Air.
It is blest with a sweet and temperate Air, is exceeding populous and well frequented, and the rather by reason of its commodious Havens and Sea-port Towns. Good havens. Ill wayes in the Winter.

'Tis a Country of much pleasure in the Sommer, and as bad in the Winter; occasioned by its being wet and moorish, especially in the midst of the County, which is a great trouble to Travellers; but this inconvenience they well pass over, knowing the ensuing profits and pleasures that the Sommer season affordeth unto them, insomuch that they have this Proverb, That what is worse for the rider, is best for the abider. Commodities

The chief profits of this County ariseth from corn and cattle, wherewith it is so plentifully stored, that it may challenge any neighbouring Country both for quantity of fat cattle, and rich grain. In the bowels of the earth (in many places) are rich lead Mines, especially about Mindip-hills, and Bradsield Downs. St. Vincents Rock. Great store of Bristolstones. And St. Vincents Rock is not without great store of Diamonds, which are known by the name of Bristol-stones, which for a bright lustre come little short of those of India, and had they their hardness, might easily pass for the same. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds Wiltshire; for its Southern, those of Devon and Dorset; for its Western also Devonshire; and for its Northern, the Severn Sea, and part of Glocestershire. Its extent.

Its extent from Frowm-Selwood in the East, to Oure in the West, is about 55 miles; and from Chard in the South, to Porshut-point in the North, where it is broadest, about 40; and makes in circumference about 204 miles. Rivers.
It is well watered with Rivers, which slow from the Sea, the chief of which are the Severn, Avon, Parret, Frome, Brue, and the Ivel, which are well stored with excellent fish.
This County is honoured with the Title of a Dukedom, which at present is in the person of the Right Noble John Duke of Somerset, &c.
It is dignified with three Cities, viz. Bristol, Bath, and Wells. Divers bloody battels here fought.

It hath been the Theatre of divers bloody battels, and chiesly at these places following. At Pen a small Village near unto Cadbury, Edmond surnamed lronside, gave the Danes a notable foyl in his pursuit of Canutus the then Usurper of the Crown of England. Not far from Bridgwater, Ealstan Bishop of Sherbourn gave a great overthrow to the Danish Camp. At Cadbury King Arthur in a battel obteined a great and memorable Victory against the English Saxons; and near this place Keniwalch a West-Saxon obteined the like victory against the Britains, to their ever after dread of the English Saxons. And lastly, not far from Banesdown, King Elfred gave the Danes such an overthrow, as constrained them to a submission, and caused Godrus their King to be a Christian himself, being his Godfather at the Font. Religious houses.

Nor hath this County been less famous for its beautiful houses consecrated to Religious Uses; as at Barelinch, which was possessed by black Chanons: At the Isle of Muchelney, made so by the Rivers Juel and Pedred, was a Monastery built by King Athelstan: Also at Hinton and Witham were Nunneries; but above all Glassenbury, which for beauty, glory, and antiquity, worthily deserveth commendation, of which a word or two anon.
This County is severed into 29 Hundreds, in which are numbred 385 Parish Churches; and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants hath 30 Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Bristoll.

Bristoll, an eminent and large City, in which, with its Suburbs, are conteined divers Churches; but having given a description thereof in the Treatise of Glocestershire, I shall say no more here, but refer you unto the same. Bath.

Bath, seated on the Avon, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, and in a low and small plain, which is begirt with aspiring hills, out of which issue forth several Springs of water, which pay their tribute to this City. It is a place of great antiquity, as doth appear by the many Roman inscriptions, and Images commonly found in the Walls which encompass it; and where the Abbey now standeth (according to report) in ancient time there was a Temple consecrated to Minerva the Goddess of Fountains and Baths.

This City, according to Mr. Cambden, hath had sevetal names attributed unto it: It was called by Ptolomy YDATA QEPMA, that is, Hot waters; Antoninus, Aquæ Solis, the Waters of the Sun; the Britains, Yrennaint Twymin, and Caer-Badon, and Caer-Palladur, the City of Palace water; and the Saxons, Almanchester, the City of sickly folks. It is a fair and neat City, replenished with well-built houses, for Divine worship hath at present one Parish Church, besides its Abbey or Cathedral, a superb building; is honoured with the Title of an Earldom, which is now in the person of the Right Honorable John Earl of Bath, &c. is governed by a Maior, Aldermen, Common-council, with other Sub-Officers, enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; Its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well served with corn and provisions; it enjoyeth a good trade for its clothing here made, and is a place well inhabited and resorted unto, and the more for its medicinal Baths, from whence it took its name, and is of chiefest note. The Baths good for the curing several Distempers.

These Baths by long experience are found to be of great vertue in the curing of Aches and other Distempers, and corrupt humors in the body of man; which brings a great resort of people of all sorts, qualities, and degrees from all parts of the Kingdom, and foreign parts twice every year, to get cure
of their distempers, to the great enrichment of the Inhabitants. And in respect of their admirable virtues, some have feigned that they were conveyed thither first by Magick art, in the knowledge of which the Britains were held very expert. There are within this City four several Baths, and their waters as to heat are of a different temperature; an account of which I shall borrow from Mr. Cambden, where he saith, That the Cross-Bath (so called from a Cross in old time standing up in the midst thereof) is of a mild and temperate heat, is enclosed with a wall, and about the sides thereof are placed 12 seats of stone: The second which is near adjoyning, is of a much hotter temperature, and is thereupon called the hot bath; adjoyning to these Baths, (he saith) is a Lazar, or Spittle house for relief of poor diseased people: The third and fourth (as joyned together) are the greatest, and best Baths, being seated near the Abbey in the heart of the City, and called the King and Queens Baths, and are enclosed with walls, having the conveniency of 32 seats made of arched work, so ordered that men and women sit apart. And it is observed that these Baths are not wholsom at all hours, for from 8 a clock in the morning to about 3 in the afternoon, they are in a manner scalding hot, and do work, and cast up from the bottom a filth, during which time they are shut up, and none permitted entrance. Wells.

Wells, seated at the foot of a hill, so called from the Springs and Wells there springing up. It is a small City, but well Inhabited, and of good account, being dignified with an Episcopal See, under whose jurisdiction is also that of Bath. It is garnished with fair and stately buildings both publique and private, amongst which these are of most note. Its Cathedral dedicated to St. Andrew, (said to be first built by Ina King of the West-Saxons who made it a Colledge) a stately and beautiful pile of building, having in the west end a frontise-piece of excellent Imigary and carved stone-work; Then the Bishops Palace adjoyning to the Cathedral, built in manner of a Castle, and fortified with walls and a mote; and on the other side fair houses of the Prebendaries for 27 Prebends, with 19 other Prebends, together with a Dean, Chaunter, Chancellor, and 3 Arch-Deacons, viz. of Bath, Wells, and Taunton belonging to the Church; and lastly its Market-house which is a fair building susteined by Pillars. This City is governed by a Maior, 7 Masters, 16 Burgesses, a Recorder, Town-Clark, and other sub-Officers, hath the election of Parliament men, and its Markets which are upon Wednesdays and Saturdays want not for any provisions, which are had at easie rates. Pensford.

Pensford, seated on the river Chue, which at a small distance falleth into the Avon; a Town of good account, and much inhabited by Hatters and Bakers whose bread is much bought, and its Market which is on Tuesdays is well served with corn and provisions. In this Town is a Court kept every Tuesday three weeks, holding pleas for all actions by way of attachment. Canesham.
Canesham, commonly called smoaky Canesham, scituate on the Avon over which it hath a Bridge, much inhabited by Maultsters, and hath an indifferent good Market on Thursdays. Wrinton.
Wrinton, seated amongst the Mendip-hills; a pretty good Town, whose Market which is on Tuesdays, is well served with corn and provisions. Frowm-selwood.

Frowm-selwood, steeply seated, and on the river Frome, where it hath a Bridge, the Town is well inhabited by Clothiers, and its Market which is on Wednesdays is well provided of provisions, &c. Philips-Norton.
Philips-Norton, so called from its Church dedicated to St. Philip; great Market-town, which is kept on. Farley Castle.

Nigh to this Town is Farley Castle, seated on a rock.
Axbridge.

Glassenbury, seated near the Tor; a good Town, whose Market, which is kept on Tuesdays, is well served with corn, fowl, fish, and other provisions. This place is of chief note for its once famous and stately Abbey of Glassenbury, where (as 'tis reported) the body of Joseph of Arimathea, whom Philip the Apostle of the Gauls sent into Britain to preach the Gospel of Christ, lyeth here interr'd: and the ruins of this Monastery doth shew it to have been a large Structure, where King Inas built a fair and stately Church; and in the Church-yard was the Sepulchre of King Arthur, whose body, by command of King Henry the Second, after great search was found out, which lay many feet under ground, but not without several Inscriptions on his Tomb-stone. Glassenbury Tor.

Near adjoyning, on a high and steep hill, is placed a Tower, now called Glassenbury-Tor, which commandeth a great prospect round about, and serveth as a Land-mark to Seamen; and here on the top thereof, the last Abbot was hanged by command of King Henry the Eighth. Aveland-Isle.

Not far from Glassenbury is Aveland-Isle, where three Rivers meeting do make a Meer, which issue forth at one small mouth, and fall into Uzella Frith in the Severn Ocean; and the Country hereabouts is very fenny and moorish, and called Gidney-moor, Brent-marsh, Weed-moor, where there was a Mannor-house of King ælfreds, Heth-moor, Mark-moor, South- moor, Alder-moor, Kennerd-moor, Hulck-moor, and other Moors. Moors and watery places. Shepton-Mallet.
Shepton-Mallet, scituate under Mendiphills; a pretty big, but poor Town, yet inhabited by several wealthy Clothiers, and hath a very good Market on Fridays. Bruton.

Bruton, seated on the River Brew, a well-built and inhabited Town, of a good trade for Clothing, Serges, and Maulting; and hath a very great Market for provisions, &c. on Saturdays. The Town is graced with a very beautiful Church, hath a Free-School founded by King Edward the Sixth, and a most goodly Alms-house, that hath rather the resemblance of a Colledge, then an Hospital: And since the desolution of the Monastery built by the Mohuns, it hath been honoured with the seat of the Berkleys, the present being the Right Honorable Maurice Lord Berkley, Viscount Fitz-harding, and is a branch of the Berkleys of Berkley-Castle in Glocestershire; a Family that hath produced many worthy men, famous in their Generation; by whose example the Inhabitants have ever been so eminently loyal, that they have been great Sufferers in the late rebellious times. Wincaunton.
Wincaunton, seated on the side of a hill in the Road to London; a good Market-town on Wednesdays, which is very considerable for Cheese. Pen.

Nigh unto this Town is Pen, a small Village, but note-worthy for being the place where Keniwalch a West-Saxon overthrew the Britains; the like did King Edmond surnamed Iron-side, against the Danes. Milborn-port.
Milborn-port, seated on the confines of Dorsetshire; a Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men. Evil.

Evil, or Yeovel, a Borough-town, governed by a Port-Reve, keepeth Courts for the tryal of Actions; is seated on the River so called, where it hath a bridge; and hath a very considerable Market on Fridays for corn, cheese, hemp, flax, and provisions in great plenty, taking its rise from the decay of Ilchester near adjoyning. Camalet-hill.

Near unto this Town is Camalet, a steep hill, and of a difficult access; on the top whereof (which is of a large space of ground) is to be seen the
ruins of a decayed Castle of the Romans, with tripple Rampiers of earth cast up, with five or six deep Ditches about the hill, and this place the Inhabitants call King Arthurs Palace. Ilchester.

Ilchester, seated on the River Yeovel, a Town of great Antiquity, as doth appear by the Roman coyns there oft digged up; nor was it wanting of strength; for when the Nobles of England had entred into a League for the deposing of King William Rufus, and to raise up his Brother Robert Duke of Normandy, here the warlike Robert Mowbray, after his burning of Bath, made a forcible assault, but to small purpose; and we find that at the coming of the Normans, it was so populous, that it had in it 107 Burgesses, and numbred 16 Parish Churches; but whatsoever its estate was then, it is otherwise now, for at present it hath but two Churches; yet is it a Town- Corporate, governed by a Bailiff, and 12 Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men; is the place where the County Goal is kept; and hath an indifferent good Market on Wednesdays. Langport.

Langport, seated on the top of a hill, in a miry and moorish Country, and on the banks of the large River Parr, which is navigable for barges from Bristoll, from whence it hath some trade. It is a well frequented Town, and hath a good Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Muchenay.

At Muchenay near adjoyning, the Walls of an old decayed Abbey, built by King Athelstane, are to be seen. And near unto Langport Northwards is Auler, which though at present a small Village, yet in times past was a place of good account. North-Curry.
North-Curry, seated on the River Tone, a pretty good Town; which hath two Markets weekly on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are well served with provisions. Somerton.

Somerton, in former time of great note, and much frequented, insomuch that the shire took its name from it. It is at present a large, but poor Town; and hath a very considerable Market on Mondays for corn, provisions, some sheep and Cattle; and every Monday fortnight hath a very great Market, or rather a Fair for lean and fat cattle. South-Pedderton.
South-Pedderton, seated on the Parret, once honoured with a Royal Seat of King Ina; hath a good Market for corn and provisions on Thursdays. Crokethorne.
Crokethorne, or Crewkerne, scituate on a branch of the Parret, and on the confines of Dorset-shire; whose Market, which is on Saturdays, is very good for corn, sheep, and provisions. Ilmister.
Ilmister, seated betwixt hills, in a dirty bottom; a Town that suffered much by a late fire, so that its Market, which is on Saturdays, is but small. Chard.

Chard, scituate on the side of a hill, and on the edge of the shire, adjoyning to the Counties of Dorset and Devon; hath the accommodation of a very good Market for corn and provisions on Mondays: And passing North-westwards from Chard are Black-down-hills. Taunton.

Taunton, pleasantly seated amongst delectable Meadows, and on the River Thone or Tone, which is navigable for barges within three miles of the Town, where it hath a fine bridge. It was once strengthned with a stately Castle belonging to the Bishops of Winchester, which now is demolished; and was formerly governed by a Maior, but at present by a Bailiff; yet is it a very fine, neat, and well-built Town, graced with spacious streets, conteineth two Parish Churches, is well inhabited both by Gentry and Trades-men, especially by Clothiers, who here drive a considerable trade for Serges and Clothing, here and in parts adjacent made, being esteemed the best Town in the County; and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are very great, and well provided with corn, flesh, fish, and fowl.
Wellington.
Wellington, seated on the Tone, a pretty good Town; and hath an indifferent Market on Thursdays. Wives-comb.
Wives-comb, scituate amongst rich and pleasant fields; hath a good Market on Tuesdays. Bridgwater.

Bridgwater, seated on a Navigable River, over which it hath a fine Stone- bridge; It is a large, and well frequented, and inhabited Borough-town, which gives Title to the Right Honourable John Earl of Bridgwater, &c. it hath the election of two Parliament men, is governed by a Maior, and other Sub- Officers; hath a great Market on Thursdays for corn and provisions, which during the Sommer season is well served with cattle of all sorts; and was anciently a place of good note, having a Castle and an Abbey. North-Petherton.
North-Petherton, an indifferent Town; and hath a new erected Market on Tuesdays, which for the present is but small. Watchet.

Watchet, seated on the Severn Sea, a very small Market-town on but hath a pretty good Harbour, and is frequented by some Vessels, who bring coals; for which it hath an indifferent good trade, selling the same to the adjacent parts for the burning of Lime, for the manuring their ground. Dunster.

Dunster, seated upon a Flat, and on a low ground, being on all sides encompassed with hills, except towards the Sea, on which it is seated. It is a very good and well-built Town, at present defended by a Castle, mounted on the top of a hill; and hath a very good Market for cattle, corn, and provisions on Fridays. Myne-head.

Mynehead, scituate also on the Sea-shoar; a Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, hath the accommodation of a very good Harbour for ships of a great burthen to ride in, and is a place of some trade, especially into Ireland; yet hath it but a very small Market on Porlock.
Porlock, seated in the Western point of the County, and on the Seashoar, where it hath a good Harbour, or Bay so called, being a place resorted unto; and hath a Marketon Dulverton.
Dulverton, seated on a branch of the Ex, and in a solitary and hilly Moor; a little Town, which hath a small Market on Saturdays.

div1.n: Staffordshire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Staffordshire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of Staffordshire with its Hundreds

div1.p: STAFFORDSHIRE, scituated much about the midst of England, having on the East the Counties of Derby and Warwick; on the South, those of Warwick and Worcester; on the West, Shropshire and Cheshire; and on the North, also those of Darby and Cheshire. Its extent.

Its extent from South to North (which maketh the length of the County) is about 40 miles; and from East to west (where broadest) about 22; which makes its circumference to be about 141 miles. Its Air.
The Air is good and healthful, though somewhat sharp in the Winter season, which doth occasion some to esteem it a Country more apt to preserve, then recover health.

It is of a different soil. The Southern parts being generally barren, as sandy, gravelly, or heathy, so that it yields little good Pasturage or Meadows, save on the banks of the Rivers; but by the industry of the Husbanaman in manuring it with Lyme and Marle, they reap great store of corn, with which they supply the defects of the Northern parts which are hilly, and full of great Heaths and Moors, affording good Pasturage, and breed very good cattle; and here is made great store of butter and cheese, of which in Uttoxater-market alone, there is weekly vended about 500 ls. worth, besides abundance of cattle there sold, as also at Newcastle and Leek, most of which are fatted up upon Dove-bank, which is esteemed the sweetest Pasturage, and best feeding Land in these parts. Ancient In-habitants.
The people which possessed this part before the Romans, were the Cornavii, which afterwards became part of the Mercian Kingdome. Well watered with Rivers,

This County is better watered with Rivers, Springs, and Brooks, then
any in England, most of which fall into the Trent before its departure out of the shire: the chief amongst which are the Dove, Penk, Sow, Hause, Lyme, upon which New-castle stands, Manifold (which at water fall, loseth it self under ground for some miles, and after discharges it self into the Dove,) Churnet and Tean, both which likewise fall into the Dove, and the Dove into the Trent near Burton upon Trent, as Blith a Rivulet, doth near Hamstall, Ridware, and Tame at Whichnor-bridge; and over which Rivers there are at least twenty four Stone-bridges arehed for the faseguard of Travellors, the most of them maintained at the Counties charge.Bridges. The County much inclined to sterility. Heaths, Moors and Woods.

To speak of the Country in general, it is very sterile, the greatest part being taken up with Heaths, Moors, and Woods; and to omit many of smaller note, there is Canock-wood, Alderwas-hay, Hopways-hay, Kinvar- Forest, Pensey-Chase, Need-wood, Hopton-heath, where, in March, 1643. a bloody battel was fought betwixt the King and Parliaments Forces, in which the noble, loyal, and valiant Spencer, Earl of Northampton, Commander of his Majesties Forces, was flain; also Swiverton-heath, Blore-heath, where another battel was fought, Muclestone-heath, Asbley- heath, Titensore-heath, Olton-heath, Meer-heath, and Heaths adjacent: Calton-moor, Caldon-moor, Wetley-moor, the Mooridge of a large extent, Okeamore, Hollington-heath, the Gun, and divers other large Heaths, which I shall forbear the naming; insomuch, that you may go the whole length of the County, and see little but Heath and Moors, and yet these are not altogether without profit and pleasure, for they are imployed to breed sheep, conies, or deer; and many of them, by the skill of the painful Husbandman, produce good corn, and the sweetest mutton in England, which the Dove Pastures feed in Winter, and make very fat; besides the recreation the Gentry have by hawking and hunting upon these vast Heaths, where are the greatest plenty of Heath-game of any County in this Kingdom: And by reason of the barrenness of the soil, this shire (considering its bigness) numbreth more Parks and Warrens then any other in the Nation, there hardly being any ancient Gentlemans seat in the whole County that had not one or more Parks and Warrens: And besides the vast Forests of Canock and Kinvare, the Chases of Needwood, Peasey, and Aldrewas-hay; at the beginning of the late War, here were about 50 Parks stored with Deer, many of which are now converted to Pasture ground, or Tillage.

And although an Inland County, yet by the multitude of Rivers and Brooks, it is plentifully furnished with all manner of River fish, which for goodness gives place to none other. The Dove Trout, the Trent and Dove Graling, the Trent and Blith Eele, and the Trent Pike and Pearch, there cannot be better; besides an infinite number of lesser fish of smaller account. Here are also great plenty of Swans, and all sorts of water-fowl during the Winter season. Its Commodities.

Nor is this County wanting of Salt-springs, which yield plenty of pure white-salt, not much inferiour to the best of Cheshire; and Mines of Copper, Lead, and Iron in the North part of it; also this shire affordeth excellent Alablaster, and 'tis very well accommodated with Pit-coals, and Wood both for timber and firing; but of late years the wood is much waisted; and in the North part, where wood and coal is scarcest, it is plentifully supplyed with Turff and Peat, which serve the poorer sort of people for fewel.

For publick buildings, this County affords few of note, though it was not disfurnished of Castles for defense, which have now left little but
Its ancient Castles. their names to Posterity; as Alveton, Carverswall, New-castle, Eccleshall, Tutbury, Tamworth, Dudley, Heleigb, Stafford, Tirles, Stourton, Chesterton, and Chartley, all which are ruinous or vanished, except Tamworth, Stourton, and Dudley, and those in great part diminished; but the only publick building now worth the taking notice of, is the Cathedral at Litchfield, said to be one of the neatest Cathedrals in all England, which was repaired and beautified by the Reverend Dr. Jo. Hacket, late Bishop thereof. Materials for buildings.

Nor have the Gentrey of this Country been vain in private buildings, though there wants not encouragement, here being found great plenty of timber, excellent stone, which for whiteness, fineness of greet, softness to work, and the induring of weather, is not to be exceeded; also plenty of Lyme, Plaister, or Alablaster, which makes both floors, walls, and wainscot, which in a few hours after wrought, becomes as hard as stone, and as white as snow, on which a spider is seldom seen; also bricks, tyles, and other materials for buildings. Religious Houses. And though the Inhabitants were not costly in their buildings, yet no County of the biness exceedeth them in Religious houses, for to let pass divers of smaller note, you will find the Abbeys of Burton on Trent, Rosester, Croxden, Hilton, De la Cress, Trentham, Ronton, Canwall, Saudwell; The Priories of Tutbury, Calwich, Stone, St.Thomas, Lapley; The Collegiate Churches of St. Maries in Stafford, Wolverhampton, Gnosall, and Penkrich; but little now remains of these Abbeys and Priories, save their names. Its trade and commodities.

The commodities of this Country, which brings money to the Inhabitants, are wool, (which is much the finer on the South-side of the Trent, and not much inferiour to that of Lemster) cattle, sheep, horses, butter, cheese, bacon, iron, iron-ware (especially nails) alahlaster,&c. and in brief they have all things necessary for the use of man within themselves, so that they are not constrained to buy much, except for the pleasing their extravagant fancies from London. Noted Hills.

The Hills of most note in this shire are the Wever, from whence, and from the Town of Wotton at the foot, the Proverb which Mr. Cambden mentions takes its rise, Wotton under Wever, where God came never: Mowcophill, in the confines of Cheshire, where Mill-stones are got; Dudley-hill, where the Castle now stands, hath a goodly prospect; then Ashley-heath, which is held to be the highest ground (though not the highest Hill) in this Kingdom; and affords a goodly prospect unto the adjacent parts; and the Gentle Shaw, from whence is a very fair prospect into Darbyshire and Leicestershire.

There is not much to be said for the beauty of the Towns in this shire, which are about 130, but is every where replenished with Market-towns, numbring no less then 18; many of which are of considerable account, and well traded unto, whose names are as followeth.

Lichfield, a City and County of it self, scituate in a pleasant Champain Country, divided from the Close and Cathedral, but joyned together by two Bridges and Cawseys. It is a City of great Antiquity, known unto Beda by the name of Licidfeld, which according to interpretation, is The field of dead bodies, and so called from the number of Christians there slain in the Dioclesian Persecution. And here Oswin King of the Northumbers, having vanquished the Pagan-Mercians, erected a Church, and made it the Episcopal See of Duina the Bishop; which after wards was made an Archiepiscopal Pale by Pope Hadrian in the reign of King Offa, and granted it unto Bifhop Eadulph, to the great disgrace of Lambert Arch-Bishop of Canterbury; which dignity expired with the deaths of Offa and Eadulph; for in year 1075. at a Synod holden, the Bishops were forbidden the keeping
their Sees in obscure, and small Towns, which in those dayes Litchfield was, which did occasion Peter Bishop thereof, to translate his See to Chester, which by Robert Linsey his Successor, was removed to Coventrey; nor did it long continue there, for Roger Clinton brought it back again to Litchfield, and in the year 1148, began to new build and beautifie it, and dedicated it unto the Virgin Mary and St. Chad. It is also seated near those ancient wayes, the one called Watling-street, that enters this County about Falseley, and passeth to Shropshire; and Ilkeneld, that enters this County at Monks-bridge over Dove, and cuts this County through towards Warwickshire. The City is well built, indifferent large, conteining three Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral, a beautiful and curious Structure, adjoyning to which is the Bishops Palace, now ruinated, and the Prebends Houses; The streets are paved, kept sweet, and well ordered, and is a place much frequented by the Gentry. Here is a Free Grammer-School for the education of Youth, and an Hospital called St. Johns, for the relief of the poor. The government of this City is committed to the care of two Bailiffs, and a Sheriff, which are elected out of 24 Burgesses, a Recorder, a Town-Clark, and other Sub-Officers; and amongst its immunities, sends Burgesses to Parliament. It is well served with commodities, as are its Markets on Tuesdays and Fridays with corn and provisions in great plenty. Stafford.

Stafford, where is held the Assizes and Sessions for the County, pleasantly, but lowly scituated amongst Meadows, and on the River Sowe, which washeth its South and West parts, over which it hath a bridge. It was anciently called Betheny, from Bertelin a holy man that there lead an Hermetical life; it is a fair Town, beautified with two Parish Churches, a Free-School, a fine square Market-place, in which the Shire-ball is placed, which serves in stead of a Market-house, and other good buildings, and the streets are large, paved, and well ordered; it is a place of good antiquity, said to be built by King Edward the Elder, and became first in corporated in the reign of King John, by the name of two Bailiffs and Burgesses, but lately by the name of Maior and Burgesses, and hath a Recorder, Town- Clark, and two Sergeants at Mace. It was fenced with a wall, but now levelled, except where it was secured by a large Pool of water on the East and North: Here was a Priory of black Chanons, to the honour of St. Thomas of Canterbury (as Mr. Cambden noteth) erected by the Lord Stafford once Lord thereof, from whom the Right Honourable Lord William Howard, Viscount Stafford, takes his Title. The Town enjoyeth large priviledges, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is well inhabited and frequented; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well served with corn, flesh, and other provisions. Stow.

Stow, seated on the River Trent, and in the Road from London to Chester, so called (according to Cambden) from the stones there heaped up together, as a memorial to declare to posterity the place where King Wolpher barbarously murthered his two sons Wulfald and Rufin, for embracing the Christian Faith. The Town is very poor, and hath a mean Market on Tuesdays. Eccleshall.

Eccleshall, scituated on a branch of the River Sowe, a Town of the Bishops, where he had a Castle, and made his residence. It is both small and poor, and its Market, which is on Fridays, is chiefly for pedlary-wares, and a little corn and provisions. Betles.

Betles, seated in the very consines of the County adjoyning to Cheshire, and in a barren sandv Country; a Town of no great account, nor its Market, which is on Tuesdays, of any long continuance, or very considerable. New-cast'e under Line.

New-castle under Line, (where the Duke of Lancaster had a Castle) seated on the little Rivulet Lyme; the Town is large, the streets broad and paved,
but the buildings are but low, which for the most part are thatched. It was incorporated in the 32. year of Queen Elizabeth, by the name of a Maior, Bailiffs, and Burgesses; hath a Court of Record to hold plea in all personal Actions under 40 l. before the Maior, Bailiffs, and Steward, or any two of them, whereof the Maior, or Steward is one; and amongst other its immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament. It hath a great Market on Mondays for cattle, some horses and sheep, with plenty of provisions; and after Low-Monday a Market (or rather a Fair) every fortnight for some time. St.Werburg Monastery.
Not far from this Town at Trentham, was a little Monastery of that holy Virgin St. Werburg, of the blood Royal. Leek.

Leek, seated amongst the barren Moor-lands; a Town of note for its excellent Ale. The buildings are but poor, and for the most part thatched; but its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is very considerable for cattle, sheep, oats, and provisions, being esteemed the third Market in the County. Cheadle, or Checkley.

Chcadle, or Checkly, seated between the Moor-lands, and in the fertilest part of the County. The buildings are not good, nor its Market, which is on Thursdays, much frequented, nor ancient. Uttoxater.

Uttoxater, pleasantly seated on a rising ground, near the banks of the River Dove, amongst excellent pasturage for feeding Dairies, and breeding of cattle. The Town is not very well built, but pretty large; hath a handsome Market-place; and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is said to be the greatest in this part of England for cattle, swine, sheep, butter, cheese, corn, and all provisions. Pagets-Bromley.
Pagets-Bromley, a very poor Town, seated amongst barren Land, which makes the wayes about it good; but its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very mean. Tutbury.

Tutbury, scituate on the banks of the Dove, amongst rich Meadows, and near neighbour to the Forest or Chase of Needwood; and its Market (if properly so called, by reason of its inconsiderableness) is on Tuesdays. Burton upon Trent.

Burton upon Trent, a Town which formerly had a large Abbey, and was the retiring place of that devout Irish woman Modwen. Its scituation is on the Trent, over which it hath a famous bridge which leadeth into Darbyshire; the Town consisteth of one long street, which runneth by the River from the Abbey to the bridge; and hath a good Market on Thursdays for corn and provisions. Tamworth.

Tamworth, pleasantly seated on the fruitful banks of the River Tame, and on the confines of the County, one part being in this, and the other in Warwickshire. This Town, in the time of the Mercians Kingdom, was of great repute, and much resorted unto, but its glory was eclipsed by the spoils it susteined by the Danes; afterwards it was repaired by æthelfled, Lady of the Mercians; and Edith, Daughter to King Edgar, who vowing a single and an holy life, founded here a little Monastery for Nuns, or veiled Virgins. The Town at present is of good account, being incorporated by the name of Bailiffs and Commonalty, hath a Court of Record, without limitation, holden before the Bailiffs, High-Steward, Under- Steward, Recorder, or Town-Clark, or two or more of them, it sends Burgesses to Parliament; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is indifferent good for corn and provisions, and in the Spring time for cattle and sheep, Falkesley- bridge.
At Falkesley-bridge near adjoyning, ran the ancient High-way of the Romans. Walsall.

Walsall, pleasantly seated on the top of a high Hill, composed of good Buildings, a Town-Corporate, and is governed by a
Maior, and other Sub-officers, hath a Court of Record, enjoyeth a good trade for divers manufactures made of iron, as nayes, bridle-bits, stirrups, spurs, and also bellows here made in great plenty; but its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is not very considerable. Rigley.
Rigley, seated on the South side of the River Trent, adjoyning to the large Chase or Forest of Canck, and on the Road from VVestchester and London, having a small Market on Tuesdays. Penkrich.

Penkrich, or Penkridge, a place of good Antiquity, and formerly of more note, beauty, and largeness, then now it is, being at present only famous for its Horse Fair, especially for saddle Naggs; having a Market on Tuesdays, which is not much frequented. Brewood.

Brewood, a small Town, where the Bishops of this Diocess before the Conquest had their Palace; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is of no great concernment, being almost discontinued. Wolverhampton.

Wolverhampton, or Wulfrunes-hampton, so called (as Cambden noteth) from Wulfruna, a devout woman, who enriched the Town (which before was called Hampton) with a Religious House. It is pleasantly seated on a hill, the streets handsomly paved, and the houses reasonable well built; is much frequented by Gentry, hath a neat Collegiate Church, which is annexed to the Deanery of Windsor in Barkshire; and its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is very considerable for corn, cattle, and all provisions, being esteemed the second Market in the County. Tetnall.
Tetnall, North-west of Wolverhampton, where there was fought a bloody battel in anno 911, between King Edward the Elder, and the Danes. Wednesbury.
Wednesbury, East of Wolverhampton, a place in ancient time fortified by æthelfled, Lady of the Mercians. Dudley.

Dudley in Worcestershire, as seated in a small track of Land belonging to the County, though within the limits of this shire, hath a very inconsiderable Market, but the Inhabitants drive a good trade for nayls and other iron-wares.

div1.n: SUFFOLK: BEING Part of the ICENI and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Angles
div1.head: SUFFOLK: BEING Part of the ICENI, and ancient KINGDOM of the East- Angles.

div2.n: SUFFOLK: BEING Part of the ICENI and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Angles
div2.head: SUFFOLK: BEING Part of the ICENI and ancient KINGDOM of the East-Angles

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Suffolk

div2.p: SUFFOLK (that is Southfolk, in respect of Norfolk) hath a various soyl, and consequently sundry growths and manufactures. The Eastern parts all along the coasts for five or six miles Inland, are generally heathy, sandy, full of little hills and springs, and very bleak, though heretofore it should seem to have been far more woody, as appears by the old Saxon names given to the Towns and places thereabouts; viz. Holton, Sowowld, Walder swick, Westwood-lodge, Hasilwood, Woodhall in Sutton, Ramshot, Waldring field, Walton, Holt, Wald, and Wowld, being the same which wood in Saxon or old English. The husbanding of the ground is for Rye, Peas, Brank, Hemp, Sheeps-walks, &c The more inland part is commonly called High-Suffolk, or the Wood-lands, and is pretty level, close and dirty, being clay ground, and is husbanded chiesly for the Dairy. The Southern parts along the borders of Essex, and abutting on part of Cambridgshire, are much of the same nature for Wood and Pasture ground. The parts about Bury, and from thence North-westernly, are champaign or fielding, abounding with excellent corn of all sorts; except some parts near New-market, which is a green Heath, very pleasant for Horsmanship. Its trade and Manufactures.

In the Wood-lands the great trade is for butter and cheese, which (excepting some of the first made, bought up by certain Kentish men for Feversham Fair) is there managed by Factors employed by the London Cheese- mongers, which are disperst up and down the Country, who buying it at the Dairies, ship it at the coast for London, and from thence it is dispersed to forraign parts, being of a condition for the induring long Voyages, beyond any other Cheese whatever. The butter, which hath now the great name, is spent chiefly in England (or France) and preferred before that of other Counties. But the cheese is justly disesteemed at home, being usually lean, if not ill handled, not because the ground will furnish no better, or the Dairywives art can reach no further, but because the Merchant will give as much for slett, or lean ware (that serving his turn as well forSea) as be will give for right two-meal. In the Wood-lands also, and North-east part of the County,
a considerable trade is driven in linnen made into Huswives-cloth, or salecloth. In the Track betwixt Woodbridge and Saxmundam, with their neighbouring Towns, is a good trade in Pouldavys for sail-cloth, and in sackcloth. In the Southern Track, the great, but decaying trade, is in broadcloth for beyond Sea, the Western cloths having out-stript both. There is also a trade carried on for Wool. In the Western parts, in the parts about Bury, and to the South-west, is a great employ in spinning Whitework for Norwich-Worsteds, which is helped forwards by Packers distributing prepared wool up and down the Country at certain dayes, and receiving it in yarn at other set dayes. The coast has been eminent for the Fisbing-trade, but it is now miserably decayed, to the damage of the County and Kingdom.

High-Sussolk, or the Wood-land, is chiefly the seat of the reomanry, few being there either very rich, or very poor, only in the Clothing-Woodlands many are brought to poverty. Its relative condition. In the great Towns, the mixt soil, the fielding by Bury, and the Sand-lands, the Gentry are commonly seated; the latter, that is, the Sand-lands, as to that are much of the nature of Norfolk and Cambridgsbire, there being usually one Gentleman in a Town, the rest seldom above the rank of Pesants. Norsolk exceeds Sussolk in number of its Churches, but Sussolk doth more excell Norsolk in the handsomness of them; many of those of Norsolk (excepting Norwich, and the great Towns which are sumptuous enough) being of thatcht roofs, and otherwise of too homely building. And though the coasts of Sussolk are at this day accounted in comparison the least Gentile, yet their churches are many of them the fairest, and their Steeples the loftiest. Essex differs from Suffolk in this last particular, by the multitude of its little Spire-steeples, or Tapering- shasts. Its bounds.

This County is of a large extent, and hath for its Eastern bounds the German Ocean; for its Southern the River Stower, which disjoyneth it from Essex; for its Western, Cambridgshire; and for its Northern, the Waveney, and the little Owse which severeth it from Norsolk. Its extent.

The length of this shire from Dunwich in the East, to New-market in the West, is about 40 miles; and its breadth in most places about 20, except the part towards the Sea, which is above 30; whence its circumference is 140 miles. Its conveniencies.
