'Tis blest with an Air so sweet and wholsome, that London Physicians ofttimes prescribe it for the cure of their comsumptive Patients. It is well stored with Parks, well watered with fresh Streams, well replenished with Goods of profit, and sufficiently furnisht with accommodations for pleasure, which makes it so much inhabited and frequented by Gentry. Its chief Rivers.

It is beyond other Counties served with Rivers and Brooks, the chiefest amongst which are the Owse, the Weveney, Stower, Breton, Orwell or Gippe, Deben, Ore and Blith. The two branches of the Owse are well stored with fresh-water-fish; the outlets of the other communicating with the Sea, abounds with salt-water-fish common to us in England, especially the Channels of Ipswich, Woodbridge, and Orford. Its honour.

This shire, which heretofore has been a Dukedom, is now dignified with an Earldom, appertaining to the Right Honourable James Howard Earl of Suffolk, Baron Howard of Walden, Lord Lieutenant of the County. Its division.

Suffolk is more generally divided into two parts, viz. the Franchise or Liberity of St. Edmond, and the Geldable; each of which furnishes a distinct Grand Jury at the Assizes. The Franchise conteins the Western part of Sussolk, the Geldable the Eastern; which latter comprehends the Liberty
of Blithing, or Bettles division, conteining the North-east; the Liberty of St. Audry, or division of Woodbridge, the middle the East; and the Liberty or Division of Ipswich, the South-east, with some inland Hundreds, all which have their Bailiffs or Sheriffs, bearing subordination, or respect to the High Sheriff of the County: To which four Divisions are allotted also four Quarter-Sessions to be remembred in their places. It is also subdivided into 22 Hundreds, in which are numbred 575 Parish Churches; amongst which, for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, are 27 Market-towns, of which in order. Ipswich,

Ipswich (in the Saxon Gypeswic, whence the Latin Gippeswicus, that is, the borough on the River Gype) seated on a falling ground to the Southward, by the bank of the River Orwell, or Gyppe, hard by the place where its fresh water and salt meet, which (with the Tyde) gives it the conveniency of a Key: 'tis a place of great Antiquity, and was once fenced about with a Wall or Rampier, which in anno 991 was thrown down by the Danes, that sorely harassed those parts. Nine years after they came with a fresh fury, leaving nought save the ruines of the houses. But the Danish storms blowing over it began again to flourish, so that Domesday book reckoned 800 Burgesses, paying custom in the reign of St. Edward: And though it be no City, yet for its largeness, containing now 12 Parish Churches, (besides St. Georges Chappel and another Parish Church now decayed) its various streets, populousness, and trade, it may be ranged in the number of Cities. 'Tis at present a Town Corporate, well priviledged, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; 'tis governed by two Bailiffs, chosen annually out of twelve Port-men clad in scarlet, and 24 Common Council clothed in purple; also a Recorder, a Town Clark, five Sergeants, of which one is for the Admiralty, and other Sub-Officers. Its bounds from St Mathews in the West, to St. Hellens in the East, is about a mile; and from Stoke in the South, to St. Margarets in the North, above a mile: in which are comprehended several fair buildings and rows of City-like houses; and as for its paving, it is a Town of the cleanliest streets of any in England except Bristol: but as to its Trade, receiving its riches from the Sea, it has born the fate of other late damaged Coast-Towns; so that of about 140 Sail within ordinary memory, they have at present not above 60 Sail; of which five or six are imployed in the passage trade, three or four to Dantzick, and the East Country, two or three occasionally to Rotterdam, and as many to the North Sea to fish for Codd, and the rest in the New- Castle trade. Next to the Sea-trade hath been that of Clothing, for Watshets and Plunkets, &c. for Russia, the Sound, and the Southward; but that is now fallen into the hands of a few, and more advantagious now is the affair of Ship-building, for which they imploy five or six building births, and have hands enough for a quick dispatch. To which may be added the trade of Salt fishing. Their Markets are thrice in the week, viz. on Wednesdays and Fridays, good for fish and butter, and on Saturdays well furnished and frequented for all sorts of provisions. This Town shews the ruins of six or seven Religious houses, one whereof, viz. Christ Church is converted into the Mansion house of the Right Honourable the Lord Visc. Hereford, another is imployed for a place of Judicature, with a Goal, where Quarter Sessions are held at their periods for Ipswich division, and another is made a Free-School and an Hospital) having also the conveniency of an excellent Library, stored with Books of various kinds, for the benefit of the Inhabitants and Strangers. The Town is commonly noted for giving birth to Cardinal Wolsey, who here began to build a magnificent Colledge, still bearing his name.
Bury.

Bury, or St. Edmunds Bury, so called from King Edmund the Martyr here interr'd, who was shot to death at Hoxon by the Danes, first tying him to a tree, then sticking his body full of Arrows gradually, for not renouncing the Christian Faith. This Town was famous for its Abbey, which for fairness, and prerogatives exceeded all others in England: it had in the same Church-yard three less Churches as her waiting Maids, of all which there now remain but two, which are fair and spacious Structures, but scarce sufficient for the Inhabitants, which are too many for two Assemblies. It was built again of new curious work by King Canute, to expiate the sacriledge of his Father Swenus against the former Church or Abbey, and impiety to the person of King Edmund, offering his Crown upon the Tomb of this holy Martyr, bringing in Monks with their Abbot, giving it fair Mannours, and ample Jurisdictions and Priviledges, together with the Town it self, full and whole; indeed, the reliques that this Abbey still shews, are far more majestick, then the ruins of other houses of its kind. The scituation of the Town is exceeding pleasant, being on a falling ground, towards a sinall River on the East, and in an Air as much famed as any in England, which draws the Gentry thither from several distant places; whence also, for the more ingenuous training up of Youth, the Town is furnisht with a good Grammar-School for Lads, and other schooling for young Gentlewomen according to the Modes, and Institutes of the Gentry of this Age, therein symbolizing with those about London, and at Shrewsbury and other places. 'Tis a Town-Corporate, hath an Alderman for its chief Magistrate, a Recorder, and other Sub-Officers, enjoying due priviledges, and sends Burgesses to Parliament. In the Abbey-yard stands an old Shire-house, where the Assizes are ordinarily held for the County, (very seldom at Ipswich) here are also kept the Quarter-Sessions for the Liberty of St. Edmond. 'Tis a large Town, though consisting but of two Parishes; its streets are uneven, and ill- paved, and made worse, by the frequency of its heavy carriages. The Houses are well built, its Market-hill, Fair-sted, and Corn-cross spacious and handsome; its Market, which is on Wednesdays, hath extraordinary quantities of corn brought to it, for which 'tis usually the standard of the County; it is also well furnisht with all forts of provisions, especially plenty of fresh Fish, Pigeons, and Wildfowl; it hath also a good retail return trade at the Shops every day. A bloody battel fought.

Near this Town was fought a bloody battel by Robert Bossu, Earl of Leicester, against King Henry the Second; but he was subdued by Richard Lucy, High Justice to the King, in which were slain many of his Followers, and himself and wife taken prisoners. Ikesworth.

Ikesworth, that is the Village or Mansion of Ike, or Iceni ; a small Market-town, where there is a little Market on Fridays. It affords the reliques of an ancient Priory, founded by Gilbert Blunt Lord of the Town, and it should seem to have had some Fraternity in it, by the remains of a Guild-hall; within which few years ago was digged up a pot of Roman coyn, bearing Inscriptions of divers Roman Emperours, which how far it may countenance the conjecture of Mr. Cambden concerning its name in memory of the Iceni, I cannot tell. New-market,

New-market, composed of a well-built street, seated upon the great Road, full of Inns, the Townsmen living chiefly upon Passengers, and the advantage of the Court, when his Majesty is pleased for his
divertisement in Hunting and Horse-races to lodge there, for which purpose there is a house built on Cambridge side for his reception. The Town stands in such a plain, that it hath a prospect three quarters of the Compass, almost to the bounds of the Horizon; to the South-East it is more rising ground, ending in Woodland. It consists of two Parishes, one in Suffolk, the other in Cambridgshire, but their Market-place and whole street is in Suffolk, which occasions those that live on the South-side to hang all their Sign-posts on hinges, so that when the fancy takes them, they may draw them to the sides of the Wall, and consequently into their own County. Their Market is on Tuesdays, having choice of wares, and being well frequented and served with fish and wild-fowl from the fenny Country, and Pigeons from the fielding. And here the women imploy themselves in spinning White-work. Milden-hall.

Milden-hall, seated on a branch of the Owse, a large Market-town, and very populous, having distant streets, called rows (as Beck-row, How-row, &c.) to the Fen-ward, belonging to it, as big as some little Towns; its Market, which is on Fridays, is plentiful enough, and abounds with fish and wild-fowl from Marshland, 'tis also well frequented. It is seated in a huge bleak between Fenn and Sand, hath a fair (hurch, with a tall Steeple; a good commodity is their Timber, and the poorer women imploy their time in spinning. Clare

Clare, seated on the Creek of the Stower so called; a Town of more antiquity then beauty, having nothing to boast of but the ruins of a Castle, and a Collegiate Church; it hath been a Dukedome, and is at present an Earldom, giving Title to the Right Honorable Gilbert Hollis, Earl of Clare, &c. it hath a thin Market on Fridays. The chief trade of this Town is that of Say-weaving. Heverill.

Haverill, seated on the edge of Suffolk, Essex, and Cambridgshire, a small and plain Market-town at the head of the Stower, adjoyning to the Saffron-grounds; its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is very small. The considerable trade of this Town is making Fustians. It had a pretty large Church, but that, with a good part of the Town, is now labour ing under the damage of a late wasting fire. Nigh to this Town is a large Meer, called Stower-meer. Sadbury.

Sudbury, an ancient Town, seated on the Stomer, over which it hath a fair bridge leading into Essex. It was probably somewhile the chief Shiretown, and seems still so for Ecclesiastical Jurisdiction, the County being divided into two Arch-Deaconries, viz. of Suffolk, and of Sudbury. And 'tis at present a good large Town, conteining three Parish Churches; and by reason of its trade of clothing is well enough frequented, the Inhabitants advancing a considerable imployment in Says, for which 'tis as notable in its proportion, as Colchester is for Bays; it is a Borough-town, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is governed by a Mator, 7 Alderment, 24 Burgesses, out of which is chosen a Bailiff, and other Sub-officers. Its Market, which is on Saturdays, is well reforted unto, and stored with provisions. It had a Priory called St. Bartholomews, for black Monks of Westminster, founded by Simon de Sudbury, in the time of Richard the Second, Arch-Bishop of Canterbury, and John de Chersey. Bildeston.

Bildeston, scituate on a Creek of the River Breton, a little Market-town, or Chaplery adjoyning to Bildeston Parish, having an ordinary Market on Wednesdays. The chief trade of this Town is clothing, chiefly the Suffolk blews and blankets; and the women either spin carded wool for the Clothier, or white-work for the Packer. Lavenham.

Levenham, on the branch of the River Breton, a large Clothing-town,
enjoying a pretty good trade, having a good Market on Tuesdays, which is the more frequented, by reason of a famous Lecture there. It hath a comely and spacious Church and Steeple, seated on an eminence. Neyland.

Neyland, scituate on the brink of the Stower,in a rich bottom; a large Country-town, accommodated for clothing, chiefly for Bayes and Sayes, for which they have Commerce with London; its Market is on Fridays, which is but mean. Hadleigh.

Hadleigh, seated on the Preston, in a bottom; a Town of great note in former times for its clothing, and being the place where Guthrup the Dane, whom Elfred baptized, was interr'd. 'Tis at present a large Town, but hath lost the greatest part of its trade for Turkey-ware, as also for Bayes and Sayes. It holds its priviledges for a Corporation, being governed by a Maior, Aldermen, and Councel, &c. and it hath a very considerable Market on Mondays for all provisions, especially meat; and another smaller Market on Saturdays. A great ornament to the Town is its Church, which is very sumptuous, and is a peculiar of Canterbury. This Town remembers the Martyrdom of Dr. Taylor, their sometime famous Minister, who there suffered for Religion. Needham.

Needham, that is the dwelling place of want, no improper name for the Town at this day; it stands low, on the Southern bank of the Orwell, and is a wide, long, and poor streat, seated on the Western Road, being a Hamlet or Chaplery belonging to the Town of Barking: its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is but small, by reason of its neighbourhood to Stow, which surpasses it. It drives still a trade, though less then formerly, in the Suffolk blews and Broad-cloths for Russia, Turkey, and elsewhere; the work of the poorer sort of women is spinning of wool for Clothiers, and making of Bone-lace. Stow-Market,

Stow-Market, seated between the branches of the Gyppe or Orwell, upon a rising ground, in the Center of the County, having a fair prospect down the River Eastward. It is a large and beautiful Town, and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is well frequented and fraughted with provisions, and common retail wares. It entertains the beholder with a spacious Church, bearing St. Peters name, on whose Festival is also their Fair, which is very much flocked unto by the adjacent Country, and so much the more by persons of rank, above ordinary Fair-haunters, by reason of a famed Cherry-yard near adjoyning, so well stored then with fruit (the best in their kind that are vendible in England) as to furnish a treatment becoming those of palate and quality. Its Steeple is accommodated with a pleasant diverting ring of Bells, and adorned with a huge and lofty Pinacle, not easie to be paralleld. Its Chancel is the ordinary place where the general and Ecclesiastick Courts are kept by the Arch-Deacon of Polys Sudbury; abutting on its Church-yard is a well-known and approved Grammer-School. This town shews an old Mansion-house anciently belonging to the Abbey of St. Osith in Essex, called Abbots-hall, to which Manour the Town did anciently belong. The grand trade of this Town is now in Tammeys and other Norwich Stuffs, being the only Town in Suffolk considerable for that employment. Buddesdale.

Buddesdale, a little Borough-town, seated according to its name, in a steep Dale or Valley, taking into its street and name a good part of Rickingale, which makes up a little Market-town, where there is kept a pretty good Market on Thursdays. 'Tis but a Hamlet, having a small Chappel, and a Grammer-School endowed, having certain Scholarships assigned to Bennet, or Corpus Christi Colledge in Cambridge, by the guift of Sir Nicholas Bacon Lord Keeper.
Mendlesham.

Mendlesham, seated in the midst of the dirt of the Woodlands; a small Borough, but as to its out-shifts of large bounds, having a fair Church, and a little Market on Tuesdays; all the Roads leading unto it are full of sloughs, that there is little resort to it, especially in the Winter. Aye.

Aye, or Eye, scituate in a watery place; a pretty large Market-town, and an ancient Corporation, having been a Borough before the reign of King John. It is now governed by two Bailiffs, ten principal Burgesses, and twenty four Common-councel, with other Sub-Officers, they send Burgesses to Parliament, and enjoy divers immunities; its Market, which is but small (the trade being now drawn to Diss) is on Saturdays. The womens employ in this Town is making of Bone-lace. This Corporation is a peculiar of the Crown, and hath been given in Joynture with the Queens of England, and an honour of ancient time; and is now the Title of the Right Honourable Charles Lord Cornwallis of Aye, &c. It shews a fair Church, the ruins of a Castle, and an ancient Benedictine Abbey, called St. Peters. Debenham.

Debenham, near the head of the River Deben, on the side of a Hill, and in the deep Roads, which makes it the less frequented; a midling-town, of easie doings for matter of trade, and hath a Market on Fridays, which is but mean. Woodbridge.

Woodbridge, a large Town, seated on the East-side of a sandy hill, watered with several fresh Springs, having a pleasant prospect down the Channel, especially at high water; 'tis about six miles from the Main, having the Clay-grounds on the West, and the Sand-lands on the East; a Town of good traffick by Sea and Land, standing conveniently for carriage to and fro by Land, and for importing and exporting by Sea. The Town is well enough built, excepting the lowness of the oldest houses, and part of it well paved; it hath a fair Church, in which are several Monuments. It retains the memory of St. Maries Priory, more by a new building of that name reared upon the place, then by any notable ruins of the old Abbey. In the midst of its Market-place is also a fair Pile of brick, in a Chamber whereof are the Quarter Sessions held in course for the Liberty of St. Ethelred and Audry; they have also the conveniency of a thriving Grammer- School under eminent conduct; Its Market, which is on Wednesdays, is of considerable resort, and well traded unto for its commodities, and chiefly for its hemp. The next great business of the Town is a Sea-trade, for which they are furnisht with nine or ten ships of burden, plying between London and Newcastle, three Pinks, and two or three Hoyes for the same trade, besides more on the stocks, and five or six more Hoys for the passage trade to London with butter, cheese, pouldavis, sackcloth, plank, &c. Next is the trade of Ship-building, for which they have four or five commodious building-Docks, most of them well employed, and of a good fame amongst Mariners for Workmanship. Next is the trade of Pouldavies and Sackcloth; and lastly, that of the refining Salt; to which may be added their occasional adventures to Holland, Norway, and elsewhere. Framlingham.

Framlingham, seated near the head of a small Rivulet running to Orford; a good large Town, upon a clay hill, defended by a spacious tall Castle of Saxon-work, well walled and double ditched on one part, having a large Meer on the other part; it had thirteen high Towers, its inworks are now much defaced, there being now only a large Dwelling-house, a Grammer-School-house, &c. but its out works are more like a Castle, then the ruins of one. Here Robert Earl of Leicester, with his rabble of Flemings, who joyned with the rebellious Son of King Henry the Second, took up their quarters, sorely infesting these parts; the Market is on Saturdays, and of tolerable commerce: Its chief ornament is its Church, wherein are several Monuments.
Orford.

Orford, a Coast-town, almost between two Channels, the more Westernly of which is so small, that it might perhaps have been sometimes fordable enough to give the nomination of the Town, it lyeth near to the Main, then the mouth of its River, which runs Southward two or three miles. It was in former time a Town of good account for fishing, but that trade being lost, the Town cannot find it self; yet it holds up a pretty Corporation, is governed by a Maior, eight Portmen, and twelve chief Burgers, or as far as they can reach towards that number of their Charter, and sends Burgesses Parliament; and its Market, which is on Mondays, hath more of the name than the thing, being only frequented by a few Country people with butter and cheese, with a small quantity of meat. Here is a fair Church well mounted, but unsightly within; also the decays of a tall close-built Castle hard by, which, together with the Church-steeple, are good directions to Seamen, as the Light-house at the Ness is by Night. It gives also the ruins of an Augustine Priory, St. Georges Chappel, and an old Hall in Gedgrave, called Holy-house, where the Seamens wives use to go to pray for the safety of their Husbands. They have a building-Dock, but no employment for it. A strange fish here ta-ken. According to Ralph Coggeshall, a Fisherman here caught a fish in all parts resembling a man, hairy on the head, with a large beard, which was kept in the Castle six months, and then made its escape into the Sea again.

On the narrow stony Beach shooting Southerly betwixt the Town and the Sea, in anno 1555, when there was a great dearth, 'tis recorded their sprang up amongst the Meer-shingle, such quantities of Peas, that the people gathered there above one hundred quarters, which both abated the prizes of corn, and preserved some hundreds from famishing; at the South point of it, there still comes up yearly certain course grey Peas, and very good Coleworts out of the Stone-heaps. Aldborough.

Aldborough, another Coast-town, seated pleasantly in a Dale, between a high Hill to the Westward, (on which its large and old built Church stands) the Sea on the East, and its River or Channel running South-west; a large, long, and plain built Town, made up of two or three streets of low houses, all on a row. A quarter of a mile Southwards lyes Slaughden, where they have a commodious Key, with Ware-houses, or Fish-houses; more Southerly still along the Beach towards Orford, they have conveniencies above other Towns for the drying of their North Sea-fish; and indeed the only imployment of the Town worth noting is Fishery, especially for Herrings, and at mid-winter for Sprats, it being the only place in England for drying, or redding of Sprats; In the season they have also a fishing Fair for Makrell, and fresh Fish, and a decaying trade to the North-sea, and Ireland for Codd. The shipping of the Town consists of about four sayl Ship-built, three Pinks or Flyboats, a Yacht, or two or three Hoys, which are imployed partly in the Coal-trade, partly in the passage, and of sixteen or eighteen which they used to send to the North-sea, or Ireland, they now send one or two. It is a Town-Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, ten capital Burgesses, and twenty four inferiour Burgesses, enjoyeth ancient priviledges, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; for their defence Sea-ward they have near twenty pieces of Ordnances planted; its Market on Saturdays is but ordinary. Thorp.
A little North of the Town is a Village called Thorp, whence several parts of the County are served with Lobsters and Crabs. Saxmundsham.

Saxmundsham, sometimes called Saxlingham; a little Market-town, seated on a small Rivulet, having a pretty full Market on Thursdays.
Dunwich.

Dunwich, seated on the top of a loose Clyff, having a wide beak every way, where Felix the Burgundian, that reduced the East-Angles to the Eaith of Christ, placed an Episcopal See Anno 640. In the reign of William the Couquerour, it was said to contain 236 Burgesses, and had a Mint, some of the coyns remaining yet amongst them. In the reign of Henry the Second it was a Town of good account, and its Inhabitants rich, but now, through the removal of the Episcopal See, the encroachment of the Sea, the decay of shipping, and the secret fate that attends some old Towns, 'tis rather the remains of a Town, then a Town properly so called, the Sea having swallowed up all but two Parishes, and St. James's Chaplery; nevertheless it is a Corporation, sending Burgesses to Parliament, enjoying large immunities, especially relating to the Sea-trade, and is governed by two Bailiffs, and other Sub-Officers; its Market, which is kept on Saturdays, is but small. The shipping of the Town is inconsiderable, their business on the water being an home-fishing for sprats in Winter, and for Herrings, Mackrel, Soles, &c. at their seasons. Sowowld.

Sowowld, or Southwould, a roundish and pretty fair built Coast-town, seated on a pleasant Clyff, having the Sea on the East, its Harbour on the South, a River with a Draw-bridge on the West, and a small neck of Land on the North; it is a Town-Corporate, governed by two Bailiffs, and other Officers. For their Sea-guard they have several pieces of Ordnance planted on the Clyff, which, with the natural scituation of the place, renders it a Town of good strength, being encompassed almost with water, especially every floud. They have a very fair Church and Steeple gracefully mounted; hath a Market on Thursdays of an ordinary trade: The chief business of the Town is for Sea affairs, for which purpose they are furnished with about twenty or thirty Sayl of small Vessels, the chief trade is to Ireland, and the North-sea for Codd; they have also a Coal-trade, and a great passage trade to London with cheese and butter; they have also something to do in Ship-building, and refining of salt; the famous Bay which they have for Ships to ride in, makes them the more taken notice of by Seamen; which said Bay is chiefly made by the shooting forth of Eastonness, a little North of them, which is the most Eastern part of all England. Halesworth.

Halesworth, seated in a Wearth or Worth, (that is, a tongue of Land between two branches of the River Blith) a well frequented Town, having a considerable Market on Tuesdays; 'tis a thriving Town for retail trade, rising by the fall of Blith-borough and the Coast-towns. Linnen-yarn for Huswives-cloth and Sale-cloth is here a good commodity. Bungay.

Bungay, seated in a place sufficiently watered by the Waveney, which severeth it from Norsolk, where Hugh Bigot fortified a Castle to a great strength (hard by the Market-place) at the time of the Barons War, overtopping a huge level of Meadow-ground to Norfolk-ward; 'tis a Town of two Parish Churches, one of which is fair; and between both, in the midst of the Town, are to be seen the ruins of a famous Nunnery. Their Market on Thursdays is great, plentifully affording corn, which is chiefly brought thither out of Norfolk. Here is a Grammer-School, with ten Scholarships for Emanuel Colledge in Cambridge. The Womens imploy is that of knitting Worsted-stockings, (as Diss in Norfolk is for Silkstockings. Mettingham.
Not far from the Town is Mettingham, where Sir John surnamed de Norwich, Lord of the place, built a Quadrangular Castle on a Green-level, moated round, and a Colledge in it. Beccles.

Beccles, seated also on the Waveney, three miles from Bungay, a very large Market-town, which every Saturdays is much frequented, and well
served with provisions, and hath a passage trade by water to Yarmouth, (which is lately undertaken to be carried up the River to Bungay.) It hath a fair Church, and a bulky tall Steeple on a convenient Hill, some distance from the Church; the Town is but plainly built, having many thatcht houses, but being lately sensible of their inconvenience, as well as unsightliness, as receiving considerable damage by two Fires, 'tis like to be rebuilt with tyled Roofs. Here are held ordinarily the Quarter-Sessions for the Liberty of Blithing, or Division of Bettles; but extraordinarily they are at Halesworth. Lestoft.

Lestoft, seated on the Sea-shoar, on a falling piece of ground Southwards; an indifferent Town, whose Church is about a mile distant from it, and hath a Market on Wednesdays; it is a thriving Town, having about 24 Sayl of small Vessels belonging unto it, their chief trade is fishing in the North-sea for Codd, and at home for Herrings, lying over against the chief Herring-beds; they have a Mackrel-fair and Sprat-fair at the season. The Towns-men had lately the confidence to contend with Yarmouth in a chargeable suit about Herring-fishing to the Northward of Yarmouth-bounds, and yet not bringing their fish into Yarmouth- Port, in which they had the good fortune to get the better of it: they have also a trade to New-castle for coal, which they either unlade by Boat over against their Town in fair weather, or in foul weather put into Yarmouth- peere, as having no Haven of their own.
There are other Towns in Suffolk, which although no Market-Towns, are yet on some accounts memorable, or deserving notice, and such are Exning

Exning, or Ixning by New-market, (seeming by its name to remember the Iceni,) honoured with the birth of St. Audry, the Virgin Daughter of K. Anna, who for her holy life, and works of piety was canonized for a Saint; who was joynt Founder of the Cathedral and Nunnery: and from this Town to Ely, Henry Bishop of Ely made a Cawsey or High-road. Brandon.

Brandon, seated upon the little Owse, over which it hath both a Bridge and Ferry at a miles distance, whence it is divided into Brandon and Brandon-Ferry, at which last place is most of its business, things coming up thither from the Isle of Ely; it was once a Market-town, but hath lost its trade, and that conveniency. It gives Title to the Right Honorable Charles Gerard, Baron Gerard of Brandon. Wulpit.
Wulpit, (haply so called from some memorable pit there digged for the burial of Wolves in the time of King Edgar,) a good Town, seated on the biggest Western Road out of Suffolk.

Cambden tells a story of this Town from Bubrigensis, of two Green-boys Satyr- like, that rose up here out of the ground from the Antipodes, but for what purpose is not known, nor perhaps worth the enquiry after. Offton.

Offton, that is, Offa's-town, King of the Mercians, where (as Cambden notes) after he had barbarously murthered Ethelbert King of the East- Angles, and usurped his Kingdom, he erected a small Castle on a Clayey-hill, the ruins of which are yet apparent, under the name of Offton- Castle. Rendlesham.

Rendlesham, scituate upon the Tredle or Deben; of note in former time for being the place where Redwald King of the East-Angles kept his Court, who was the first of all his Nation that was baptized, and received the Christian Faith; but as Beda noteth, being afterward seduced by his Queen, he permitted an Altar to be placed in the said Church for her offering Sacrifices upon to Devils, together with his Altar for the worship of the true God. In this Church Swidelm King of the East-Angles was baptized by Bishop Chalda.
Wickham-Market,

Wickham-Market, its name gives it to have been heretofore a Market-town, though its Market is now lost, by reason of its neighbourhood to Woodbridge; yet 'tis as big as many Market-towns, and is a Stage-town upon the Eastern London Road. It hath a Spire-steeple, which is a Sea-mark to Saylors off the Whiting-sand by Orford. 'Tis also one of the Towns where General and Spiritual Courts are held for the Arch-Deacon of Suffolk, to whom the Eastern part of the County is assigned, as the Western is to the Arch-Deacon of Sudbury. Walderswick.

Walderswick, a Seafaring-town at the mouth of Dunwich-haven, carrying on an imploy in building small Vessels, which would be greater, but that their Haven at certain Winds is so bank'd up with Sand, that there is no passing in or out. They also drive a little Sea trade of their own with three or four Ships, after the way of its neighbouring Town Sowowld. It shows a sumptuous Church, and a Spire-steeple, which may argue somewhat for its former greatness in comparison to what 'tis now. Blith-borough.

Blithborough, that is, the chief Town on the River Blith, over which it hath a bridge. 'Tis now a poor decayed Town, or Post-stage on the great Road, having a curious handsom Church for its only Ornament; but was once beautified by King Henry the First, and Richard Beaveis Bishop of London, with a Priory of black Chanons, who granted the same as a cell to the Chanons of St. Osith, the ruins of which are now to be seen; it had a Market; here is the Goal for the division of Bettles, as a remembrance of the Sessions, which was formerly here kept. It was sometime of note for being the burial place of Anna a Christian King, whom Peuda the Mercian slew in a pitched field fight. Burrough-Castle.

Burrough-Caftel, of old Cnobbersburg, that is Cnobbers-City, on the edge of the County near Yarmouth, where the Rivers Yare and Waveney meet. Here was (according to Beda) a most pleasant Castle, and that by reason of the Woods, and Sea adjoyning, wherein Fursey a devout Scot built a Monastery, and by whose perswasions Sigebert King of the East- Angles became a Monk, and resigned up his Kingdom, and being afterwards forced out of the Monastery, to encourage his people in battel against the Mercians, lost his life: Of this Castle nought remains, save the ruins of its Walls, where Roman coyn is often digged up. Towns at which have been Religious Houses, besides those intimated aforesaid. Religious Houses in former times

At Briset, a Priory of black Chanons: at Battisford, St. Johns Hospital: at Denton, a Colledge: at Brush-yard an Abbey: at Butley, a Priory of black Chanons: at Campsey-ash, a Nunnery: at Stoke by Clare, a Priory of black Monks: at Darsham, a Priory: at Edwardston an Abbey: at Flixton, a Nunnery of Augustins: at Horningfleet, an Abbey of Regular Chanons: at Hoxton, an Abbey: at Hintlesham, a Priory: at Carsey, a Priory: at Felixton, an Abbey: at Gorleston, a Priory: at Mendham, a Priory: at Letheringham, an Abbey: at Sproughton, a Chantery: at Layston, a Priory of White Chanons: at Redling field, a Nunnery of black Nuns: at Rumborough, an Augustine Abbey of black Monks: at Suape, a Priory of black Monks: at Sibton, an Abbey of Cistertian Monks: at Walton, a Priory of black Monks: at Wanyford, a Priory: at Wingfield, a Colledge: at Walton, and at Wickso, a Priory of black Monks,

div2.n: PARKS in the County are at these places following.

head.hi: PARKS in the County are at these places following.

div2.p: Alpheton, Bargate, Barnadiston, Bradley, Brightwell, Cavendish, Chevington, Chilton, Codenham, Earl-soham, little Fakenham, Framlingham, little Glembam, Hadleigh, Hawley, Henham, Heveningham, Huntingfield, Kentwell-hall in long Melford, Kenton, Ipswich, St. James's, Lavenham, Letheringham, Lowdham, Melford-hall, Nettlested, Parham, Redgrave, Redling field, Sekford, Shimpling, Sibton, Smallbridge, Stavender in Butley, Stoke-neyland, Stradishall, Sudburne, Thorp, Thwait, Trimley, Westhorp, Westwood-lodge, Wing field, &c. Things worthy of note in this County.

The Moving sands at Downham. The two Springs. at Lopham-ford, the one running directly one way, and the other another way. The huge Ditch, called the Devils Ditch, by New-market. The self-sprung Peas and Coleworts upon the stony Beach by Orford. The excellent Cornground gained from the Fenland on the borders of Cambridgshire, by draining the Decoy and fishery at Iken. That also at Somerleyton, with the curious breed of Hernseys there. Certain unfreezing waters at Bealings parva, and Hasketon. An unusual White Earth at Boyton, which if it fell into the hands of some industrious Delsist, might perhaps be improved to equal the Gally-ware of the City, &c.

div1.n: SURREY: BEING Part of the REGNI and ancient KINGDOM of the South-Saxons
div1.head: SURREY: BEING Part of the REGNI, and ancient KINGDOM of the South- Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of Surrey with its Hundreds

div1.p: SURREY, a County of a different soil, and not over fertile (especially in the midst) yet where it beareth upon the Thames, and lyeth as a plain and Champain Country; it is grateful to the Husbandman, and principally towards the South, where a continual Valley by little and little falling low (in old time called Holmesdale) by reason of the Meadows, Fields, Groves, Parks, Rivers, and aspiring Hills, is a place of great delight and recreation, Its Air. Kings Palaces.

The Air is most sweet, delectable and healthful, for which canse it hath been ennobled with several of the Kings Palaces, is well replenished with Towns, and garnished with the seats of Gentlemen, it being better stored with game then grain. Its Gommodities.
It affordeth for its Commodities and Manufactures, Corn, Fullers-earth, Tapestries, Box, and Wallnuts in great abundance. Its bounds,
It is bounded on the East with Kent; on the South with Sussex; on the West with Hamshire and Berkshire; and on the North with the River of Thames, which severeth it from Middlesex. Its extent.

It is of no large extent, being from Rotherith in the East, to Fernham in Weft about 34 miles, and from Awfold in the South, to Stanes-bridge in the North, where it is broadest, about 22 ; which makes its circumference to be about 112 miles. Ancient Inhabitants.

The People which here inhabited (according to Ptolomy) before the Roman Scepter swayed this Kingdom, were the Regni, and upon their quitting the Land, it fell into the hands of the South-Saxons. Castles. Religious houses.

This Shire hath been well strengthned with Castles, such were Addington, Bletchingley, Darkin, Farnham, Guilford, Goseford, Reygate, and Starburg; and as well served with Religions Houses, the chief amongst which were at Bermundsey and St. Maries in Southwark, at Shene, Chertsey, Horsley, Merton, Newark, Reygate, and Waverley. Its division.

This County is severed into fourteen Hundreds, whose names are set down in the Mapp, in which are numbred. 140 Parisb Churches,
and hath the accomodation of nine Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Scuthwark.

Southwark, or the Borongh of Southwark, scituate on the banks of the Thames, opposite to the City of London, to which it is joyned by a stately bridge, which I have already treated of in the Description of the said City, and is a member thereof, being so annexed by King Edward the Sixth, but doth still enjoy several of its ancient priviledges peculiar to it self, as holding of Courts within themselves, and electing of Burgesses, &c. It is a place, which for quantity of buildings and Inhabitants, may be ranged in the number of those that are called Cities; enjoying a good trade, and is well resorted unto, but by reason of its vicinity to London, together with its shambles for Butchers, Poulterers, &c. its Markets are not considerable. Its buildings are faire and good, especially in the High-street (which is spacious, and full of Inns and Taverns) which leadeth from the Bridge to St. Georges Church. Places of Antiquity and worthy of note, are the Priory of the blessed Virgin Mary, called St. Mary over Rhe, a large Structure, now made use of as the principal Church. The famous Abbey of Monks of St. Benets order, called Bermundsey, consecrated in times past to our Saviour. The Palace of the Bishop of Winchester, seated near the Thames, a building more large then handsome. St. Thomas 's Hospital, founded by the Citizens of London, for the relief of impotent persons. The Kings Bench Prison, and Marshall-see, places too well known to many: And lastly the Butchers Theatre, called the Bare-Garden. Croydon.

Croydon, lowly seated, near the Spring-head of the River Wandle, which falleth into the Thames at Wandsworth, and is in a manner begirt with aspiring Hills, which are for the most part well clothed with Wood, of which great store of Charcoal is made, which finds good vent at London, and elsewhere, for which it is of note. The Town is large, its Houses well-built, and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is considerable, and well served with corn and provisions; it is dignisied with the Seat of the Arch-Bishop of Canterbury; is beautified with a fair and large Church, hath an Hospital for the relief of poor people, and a Free-School for the education of Youth. From this Town to Farnham runneth the Downs, called Banstead-Downs, which affordeth great delight for Hawking, Hunting, and Horse-races. Kingston.

Kingston, a large and ancient Town-Corporate, which enjoyeth large immunities; a place in former times well known for its Castle belonging to the Clares, Earls of Glocester; and is of note for being the place where, upon a stage in the open Market-place stood the Chair of Majesty, where æthelstan, Ethelred, and Edwin were crowned Kings, and received their Imperial Scepters; from whence 'tis said the Town took its name, being before called Moreford. See Cambden page 297. Its scituation is on the banks of the Thames, over which it hath a fair bridge, which leadeth to Kingston-week in Middlesex; its Houses are well built, amongst which are several good Inns and Taverns for the reception of Strangers, it being the usual place where the Assizes for the County are held; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very considerable for corn and provisions. Ewell.
Ewell, a small Town, and hath a Market on which is so inconsiderable, that it doth not deserve the name thereof. Reygate

Reygate, seated in the Vale of Homesdale, of note for the bloody battels here fought against the Danes, in which they were vanquished; also for its ancient, but ruinated Castle, where in the midst of a large Court, there is a Vault of a great depth and length, at the end of which is a large and spacious room, where 'tis reported the Barons met in Council in their Warr against King John; and for being the place where is digged up excellent
Fullers-earth in great plenty. It is a good large Borough-town, which gives its voice in Parliament by two Burgesses; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very considerable, and well served with corn and provisions.

Not far from Reygate are Blechingley and Gatton, two ancient Boroughtowns, which have the election of Parliament men; which although at present but small, were formerly large, especially Gatton, where Roman coyns have been oft-times digged up. Darkin,

Darkin, scituate on a branch of the River Mole, where at the foot of White-hill (on which grow good plenty of Box-trees) the said River looseth it self under ground, at a place called Swallow, and riseth again near Norbury. It is a good large Town, and hath a considerable Market on Thursdays for corn and provisions, especially all sorts of Poultrey and Fowl. Godalming,
Godalming, seated on the River Wey, where it divideth it self into several streams, and watereth the adjacent parts.
Nigh unto this Town is the Manour of Cateshull, which Hamon of Gatton (as Mr. Cambden noteth) held to be the Marshall of Harlots, when the King came into these parts. Guilford,

Guilford, no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the declining of a Hill, and on the River Wey, which affords a good advantage to the Inhabitants in the conveyance of their goods by water in barges to London, which is much facilitated by the several Land-locks or Sluces on the said River. It is an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Maior, and other Sub-Officers, and sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; it was a place of a larger extent when the English-Saxon Kings had their Palace here, then now it is, yet is it a fair, near, well-built, and large Town, conteining three Parish Churches, one of which is a fair Strcture; it is well inhabited and frequented, where the Assizes for the County are of kept, and as seated on the Road is full of Inns and Taverns for the reception of Passengers, amongst which there are two very famous, viz. the Red-lyon and White-hart. Here was a Castle of a large extent, which now sheweth nothing but its ruinous Walls; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very well served with corn and provisions.
This Town of late received honour by giving Title to the Right Hononrable Elizabeth, Viscountess of Kynelmalky in Ireland, who was created for her life Countess of Guilford. Farnham.

Farnham, which seems to takes its name from the great store of Fern here growing; it is a good Town, seated on the River Wey: of note for being the place where King Elfred, with a small power subdued the Danes, with a great slaughter; and for its spacious Castle highly seated, built by Henry of Bloys, brother to King Stephen. It hath a great Market on Saturdays for all provisions, but chiefly for oats and barley. Hasilmer.
On the edge of the County reguarding Hantshire is Hasilmer, a Broughtown which electeth Parliament men. Other places of note in this County. Chertsey,

Chertsey, seated in a wet quarter, and not far from the Thames, over which it hath a bridge; a Town of good antiquity, where there was a little Monastery founded by Frithwald: and here King Henry the Sixth, who was deposed and made away in the Tower of London, was interr'd without Funeral pomp, but for his holy life, was imputed a Saint, and afterwards intombed at Windsor in Berkshire. Ockley,

Ockley, or Aclea, seated near an old Roman Port-way, which is called Stany-street, where King æthelwold, son to King Egbert, fouugt a bloody battel against the Danes, which proved very successful unto him. Nonsnch,

Nonsnch, a once noble and stately Palace of the Kings, built by K. Henry the Enghth, delightfully seated amongst Parks, which for its magnisicence, and rare workmanship, with its delicate Gardens, Orchards, and Groves, may deservedly be called Nonsuch.
Ebesham
Ebesham, very pleantly seated; a small Town, but of late much resorted unto by the Gentry and Citizens of London in the Sommer season for drinkings its medicinal waters. Cashalton,

Cashalton, supposed (by Cambden) to be the ancient City of Nojoinagus of Ptolomy, and Noviomagus of Antoine; for on the top of a Hill near adjoyning, there are to be seen the signs of a large Town; it is a place now of note for its good Trouts and Walnuts. Merton.

Merton, where Kenulph king of the West- Saxons came to an untimely end in a small Cottage of an Harlot, on whom he had placed his affections; but the Traitor was immediately stabbed by the Kings followers for his disloyal treachery: And here was a Monastery founded by Henry the first for black Chanons, which was famous for the Statute of Merton enacted here in the 21 of King Henry the third. Otelands,
Otelands, another House of the Kings, pleasantly seated in a Park, and near the banks of the Thames. Richmond.

Richmond, also on the banks of the Thames, and on an easie ascent; a fair, large, and well-built Town, whose pleasant and healthful scituation hath invited so many Gentry to be its Inhabitants, as it did King Henry the Seventh to build here a once stately and magnisicent Palace, which is now reduced to ruins by the late Usurpers, as is Nonsuch and Otelands.

This Richmond was a place unfortunate to England, where several of their dearly beloved Princes ended their days; viz. Edward the third, who conquered France. The beautiful Anne, wife to King Richard the Second, and Daughter to the Emperour Charles the Fourth; and this Lady was the first that taught the English women the way of riding on Horse-back, as now they do, and to leave off their undecent way astride like unto men: and lastly of Queen Elizabeth. Wimbleton,
Wimbleton, of note for a bloody battle there fought between Cheaulin the West-Saxon, and young Ethelbert of Kent, wherein he was vanquished, and two of his chief Commanders slain. Moreclack,
Moreclack, a pleasant and well seated Town on the banks of the Thames, where excellent Tapestry-hangings are made. Putney.
Putney, a well-built Town, seated on the banks of the Thames, well inhabited by Gentry, and much resorted unto in the Sommer for its Bowling- green on the Heath: Wandlesworth. Battersea.

Wandlesworth and Battersea, two Towns much inhabited by the Gentry and Citizens of London, the latter seated on the banks of the Thames; and the former at some distance, and on a well streamed River, which driveth several Mills, which are well employed by the London Mealmen: And here are good store of Frying-pans made, insomuch that the houses where they are wrought are so called. Lambeth,

Lambeth, scituate opposite to Westminster, of chief note for being the residence of his Grace, Gilbert Lord Arch-Bishop of Canterbury, where he hath a fair Palace. It is seated in a wet and moorish ground, and by many esteemed unwholsome to live in; nevertheless it is well inhabited by Gentry and Citizens, both in the Town and Marsh, which may be reckoned as a Hamlet there to belonging. And at this Town Kanute, the last of the Danish Kings, ended his dayes amongst his Cups.

div1.n: SUSSEX: BEING Part of the REGNI and ancient KINGDOM of the South-Saxons
div1.head: SUSSEX: BEING Part of the REGNI, and ancient KINGDOM of the South- Saxons.

div2.n: SUSSEX: BEING Part of the REGNI and ancient KINGDOM of the South-Saxons
div2.head: SUSSEX: BEING Part of the REGNI and ancient KINGDOM of the South-Saxons

figure.head: A Mapp of the County of Sussex with its Rapes

div2.p: SUSSEX, a large County, in form long and narrow; whose length from Rye in the Rape of Hastings, to Harling in the Rape of Chichester Westwards, is about 56 miles; and its breadth, where broadest, not exceeding 20; the whole circumference making about 158 miles. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with Kent; on the South with the British Sea, which is called the Downs, well known to Seamen; on the West with Hantshire; and on the North with Surrey, and part of Kent. Its Air.
The Air, though clouded with mists and thick vapours which arise from the Sea, yet is good and healthful. Well watered. Hath plenty of fish and fowl.

It is well replenished with Rivers, from which and the Sea, the Inhabitants have sufficient plenty of fish and fowl. And although it hath so large an extent of Sea-coast, yet is it but thin of Harbours, and those that are being as uncertain for continuance, as dangerous for entrance, by reason of its Shelves and Rocks; as also the abundance of Beach cast up by the South-west winds. Its fertility and soil.

The soil is fertile, and grateful to the Cultivator, but troublesome to the Traveller (in that part called the Weld) especially in the Winter season, the Land lying low, and the wayes deep; but that part called the Downs, is a very pleasant and Champa in Country.

The Sea-coast is hilly (which is called the Downs) and is exceeding fertile in corn and grafs, feeding store of cattle. The middle part hath Meadows, and Corn-fields; and its North-part is over-shadowed with shady Groves and Woods, where in times past was that famous Wood Andradswald, which extended it self in length 120 miles, and in breadth about 20, a place memorable for the death of Sigebert King of the West-Saxons, who being deposed from his Throne, was here stabbed by a Swinherd, and so ended his dayes. Plenty of Iron. And in this part of the shire in several places are store of Iron-mines, for the fining and making of which (into Guns, Barrs, &c.) they have great Furnases. And although the melting the fame is very expensive
in the wasting of Wood, yet the Undertakers find good encouragement therein.

Peculiar to this County (in great plenty) is a small Bird, about the bigness of a Lark, called a Wheat-ear, as being in the prime when Wheat is ripe, which for fatness and curiousnes of flesh exceedeth all others. Commodities and Manufactures.
The Manufactures and Commodities which this shire affordeth, are Iron unwrought, and wrought into Guns, &c. corn, cattle, sheep, wool, and wood. Religious Houses.
It was formerly well furnished with Religious Houses, numbring no less then 18, all which felt the heavy hand of King Henry the Eight. Ancient Inhabitants.

The people which here inhabited before the Romans, were the Regni, who were subdued by Vespastan the Leader of the second Legion under Aulus Plautius, Lieutenant in this Kingdom under Claudius the Emperour; and upon the departure of the Romans, it became part of the Kingdom of the West-Saxons.
It is dignified with the Title of an Earldom, which appertaineth to the Right Honorable James Earl of Sussex, Baron Savil of Ponfract, &c. Its division.

It is severed into six Rapes, viz. Chichester, Arundel, Bramber, Lewes, Pevensey, and Hastings; all which quite traverse the shire, and have each of them their peculiar River, Forest, and Castle; and these Rapes are subdivided into 65 Hundreds, in which are numbred 312 Parish Churches; and for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, hath sixteen Market-towns, and for their defence had ten Castles, most of which are now ruinated. Chichester Rape. Its chief places.
The Rape of Chichester, in which are seven Hundreds, hath for its chief places Chichester.

Chichester, seated in a Champain plain, and on the banks of the Levant, which encompasseth the South and West parts, and at a small distance dischargeth it self into the Sea. It was first built by Cissa the second King of the South-Saxons, where he had his Royal Palace, and by him called Cissanc-caster; yet before the Conquest it was a place of little or no name, being known only by a Monastery of St. Peter, and a little Nunnery. It is an indifferent large City, conteining five or six Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral, of a circular form, and graced with a stately Spire, built of stone, is generally beautified with good buildings, and spacious streets, especially the four which lead from the four Gates of its Wall, and cross one another at the Market-place, which is a capacious and fair Stone-building. and supported round about with Pillars. It is dignified with an Episcopal See, and seat of a Bishop; and its Cathedral (anciently dedicated to St. Peter) was first built by Bishop Radulph, but before it was quite finished, a sudden fire totally consumed it; nevertheless, soon after the said Bishop began to rebuild it, and with the liberal hand of King Henry the first finished it, and made it a superb building, which so continued till the Reign of Richard the first, at which time it was again consumed by the raging flames of a merciless fire, which also spared not the Bishops Palace and Prebends Houses: but that and the Cathedral were rebuilt and beautified by Seffrid the second Bishop of that name, whose glory was much eclipsed in the late unhappy times. It is a City endowed with many priviledges and immunities, electeth Burgesses for Parliament, is governed by a Maior, Aldermen, a Recorder, and other Sub-officers; is a place of a pretty good
trade, and would be more, were not the Haven near unto it choaked up, yet its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well served with corn, cattle, and all sorts of provisions, both flesh, fowl, and fish. Selsey-Isle.

Nigh unto this City is Selsey-Isle, or rather a Peninsula, as being almost encompassed with the Sea, and its arms or branches; it is at present of chief note for its good Cockles and Lobsters here taken in great plenty; but in former time for its City so called, now devoured by the Sea, where was an ancient Episcopal See, first planted by Wilfrid Arch- Bishop of York, who being banished by Edfrid King of the Northumbers, preached the Gospel to the South-Saxons, and had this Isle given him by Edilwach their King for his seat; and upon the subduing of this Kingdom by Cedwall King of the West-Saxons, it was made an Episcopal See, which so continued until Bishop Stigand removed it to Chichester. Bognor-rocks.
Not far from this place near the Sea-shoar is Bognor-Rocks. Thorney-Isle.
Also Westwards of Selsey is Thorney-Isle, a small place, but hath a Town so called. Midhurst.

Midhurst, seated on the River and a branch thereof which doth almost encompass it. It is an indifferent large Borough-town, electing Parliament men, and hath a pretty good Market on Thursdays. Arundel Rape.
The Rape of Arundel, in which are five Hundreds, hath for its chief places Petworth.

Petworth, of a pleasant scituation, adjoyning unto two Parks, and not far from the River Arum: It is a small Town, hath a mean Market on Wednesdays, and is of chief note for its noble House belonging to the Earls of Northumberland. Storington.
Storington, seated in a barren soil, in a plain, a small Town, which hath a mean Market on Wednesdays. Arundel.

Arundell, pleasantly seated on the side of a Hill, near a Forest so called, and on the Western banks of the River Arum, over which it hath a Wooden-bridge: It is an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Maior, and other Sub-Officers, and amongst its immunities, hath the election of Parliament men, and is a place of note for its ancient and strong Castle, which flourished in the time of the Saxon Empire, and after its passing several hands, at length it became the Earl of Arundels, and gave Title of Earl of Arundel to the Dukes of Norfolk. The Town is indifferent large, and the Houses well built, and hatha Market on Bramber Rape.
The Rape of Bramber, in which are ten Hundreds, hath for its chief places Horsham.

Horsham, scituate near the large Forest of St. Leonards, so called, as tradition would have it, from Horsa brother to Hengist, who were the first Leaders of the English Saxons into this Islana. It is a large Boroughtown, governed by two Bailiffs, hath the election of Parliament men, is the place where the County Goal is kept, and of late years where the Assizes are often holden; and hath a very great Market on Saturdays for corn, and all sorts of provisions, especially fowl, which is bought up by the London Haglers.
Stening.

Stening, seated under the Downs, a Boroughtown, which electeth Parliament men, and hath an indifferent Market on Wednesdays. And here was said to be a cell of black Monks, wherein St. Cudman was enshrined, which occasioned this place to be visited by Pilgrims. Bramber.
Not far from Stening is Bramber, a small Borough-town, which gives its voice in Parliament by two Burgesses. Shorham.

Shorham, or New Shorham, (to distinguish it from the old near adjoyning, which is now but of slender account) seated on an Arm of the Sea, which makes it to be a place of some trade, and would be more, had it a good Harbour, or Road for ships. It is a Town-Corporate, governed by a Constable and Burgesses, and electeth Burgesses, but hath not the benefit of a Market. Tarring.
Tarring, scituate upon the Downs, and not far from the Sea, an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Lewes Rape.
The Rape of Lewes, in which are thirteen Hundreds, hath for its chief places

Lewes, seated every way on an eminence, and on the banks of the River Arun, which after no long course dischargeth it self into the Sea. It is a Town of good antiquity, where King Athelstan appointed the Mintage of his Mony, and where William de Warron built a strong Castle, to which the disloyal Barons of King Henry the Third, in an hostile manner assembled together, and fought a bloody battel against their Soveraign and his Son, in which conflict the Kings Horse was slain under him, Richard King of the Romans surprized, and taken in a Windmill, where he got for shelter; and Prince Edward delivered to them upon unequal Articles of Peace. It is a Town-Corporate, governed by two Constables, enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament; and hath a very good Market for corn and provisions on Saturdays. This Town for fairness of buildings and streets, populousness of Inhabitants, both of Gentry and Trades-men, and largeness, conteining six Parish Churches, may be esteemed one of the best Towns in the County, having its Suburbs, one Westwards, another Southwards, called South-over, and a third Eastward and called the Clyff, which is severed from the Town by the River. Not far from the Castle, Mr. Cambden maketh mention of a little Chappel disconsolately seated amongst briers and brambles, wherein was interred the body of a person of the blood Royal of the Danes, who there led a solitary life; which doth appear by the engraven arched work in Verses in old and worn out Characters on its wall. New-Haven.

At the entrance of the River Arun into the Sea, is New-Haven, of late made a pretty secure Harbour for ships, which hither put in soul weather, which these Seas are much subject unto, chiefly occasioned through the shelves and rocks. Cuxfield.
Cuxfield, seated in the dirty part of the Country, an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Fridays. Bright-Helmiston.

Bright-Helmiston, seated near the Sea, where it hath an indifferent good Harbour: The Town is large, but ill-built, is very populous, whose Inhabitants are chiefly Fishermen; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is very small.

div2.n: Pevesey Rape
div2.p: The Rape of Pevesey, in which are seventeen Hundreds, hath for its chief places, East-Grinsted.

East-Grinsted, seated on a Hill, near the borders of the County reguarding Surrey, and not far from Ashdown Forest; it is a small Boroughtown, graced with a fair Church, is governed by a Bailiff and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men, is the place where the Assizes are often holden, and hath a good Market on Thursdays. Eastbourn.

East-bourn, seated near the Sea, of chief note for being the place where the birds, called the Wheat-ears, are caught in such great plenty; and here the Sea-shoar ariseth into the highest Promontory on the South- Coast of England, which is called the Beach, Beachy-points, and Beauclyff (places not unknown to Sea-men.) Hastings Rape.
The Rape of Hastings, in which are thirteen Hundreds, hath for its chief places, Winchelsey.

Winchelsey, a place of good antiquity, although not so ancient as a former of that name, which in Anno Dom. 1250. was swallowed up by the raging Ocean, and was of great strength and beauty, being enclosed with strong Walls, and other Fortifications, for its security against any Invasion, but the Sea shrinking from it by little and little, it soon began to decay, having now lost much of its pristine beauty; yet doth it still retain its priviledges; as electing of Parliament men, keeping of Courts; in being a Member of one of the Cinque Ports, by being governed by a Maior (who is Lord of Yarmouth for the Fishing Trade) and Jurats, and in giving Title to the Right Honourable Henage Earl of Winchelsey, &c. The Town is seated on a Rock, or sandy Clyff, and on an Inlet or Arm of the Sea, where it maketh four Cateracts; and were its Haven commodious, and not choaked up, it would be a place of a good trade. The Town was formerly large, numbring eighteen Parish Churches, seventeen of which are now reduced to ruin, and its buildings exceedingly wasted, and much complaineth for want of Inhabitants; so that its Markets are now disused. In the midst of the Town is a Market-house, from which ruuneth four Streets, at the end of every one of which are four wayes, which were formerly taken up with buildings; the Town being now reduced to a far narrower compass then formerly. Camber-castle.
Within a mile of Winchelsey, and near the Seashoar, is a Castle which beareth the name of the Town, formerly called Camber-castle. Rhye.

Rhye, one of the Cinque-port Towns, which began to flourish upon the decay of Winchelsey, and was by William Ipres Earl of Kent fortified, and in the Reign of Edward the Third it was walled, where the Clyffs defended it not. It is at present a fair and well-built Town, with the streets paved, governed by a Maior and Jurats, is well inhabited and frequented, especially by Fishermen, being of note for its excellent Herrings here taken, and for being the ready passage from London to Normandy. It hath a commodious Haven, is accommodated with two Markets weekly on Wednesdays and Saturdays, which are very well served with provisions and corn.
Battel.

Battel, seated in the dirty part of the County, so called, as 'tis said, from the great battel there fought, in which in one dayes fight the fortune of England was tryed, where Harold the King gave place to the Conquerour by loosing his life, together with 67974 English men; It is an indifferent Town, and hath a Market on Thursdays, and once every Moneth is a Market newly erected for the fale of cattle on Tuesdays. Hastings.

Hastings, of good antiquity and note, being a Town- Corporate, governed by a Maior and Jurats, enjoyeth large immunities, is one of the Cinque-ports, and is of note for being the place where William the Conquerour set up his Fortress at his landing, at Bulver-hith not far distance, where he caused his Fleet to be burnt. As to the scituation of this Town, it is couched between a high Clyft Seawards, and as high a hill landwards. It is a large Town, and hath two streets extended in length from North to South, in each of which there is a Parish Church: Its Haven is fed by a small River, and had once for its defence a strong Castle seated on a Hill, which now is reduced to rums; yet doth it ferve in the night as a direction to Saylers by the Lights therein placed; and its Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are well reforted unto and served with corn and provisions, but especially fish which is here had in great plenty.

div1.n: Warwickshire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Warwickshire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of Warwickshire with its Hundreds

div1.p: THE County of WARWICK seated in a manner in the heart of England, and participates with her in the best, both for pureness of Air, richness of Soil, and pleasure to its Inhabitants. Its parts.

It may be divided into two parts, the one called Feldon, and the other Woodland, and these are in a manner separated by the River Avon, which in a crooked passage runneth through the Country. Feldon Part. The part called Feldon, which lyeth Southward, is more Champain, affording rich Meadows, which feed store of Sheep and cattle; and is exceeding grateful to the Husbandman in its crops of corn. Woodland Part. The part called Woodland, of old Arden, lyeth Northwards of the Avon, and took its name from the great plenty of Woods, which are now much wasted by the making of Iron; and the Soil of this part is more churlish and ungrateful to the Husbandman. Its bounds.

The bounds of this County on the East are Leicestershire and Northamptonshire; on the South, those of Oxfora, Glocester, with part of Worcester; on the West, Worcestershire; and on the North, Staffordshire. Its extent.

Its extent from Hilmorton in the East, to Hewel-grange in the West, is about 25 miles; and from Long-Compton in the South, to Newton in the North, about 33; which makes its circumference to be about 135 miles. Ancient Inhabitants.
The ancient people known to the Romans were the Cornavii, which afterwards became the Kingdom of the Mercians. Its Commodities.

This Shire for its Commodities affordeth great plenty of wool, wood, iron, and torn, especially in the Vale Red-horse, and is plentifully watered with Rivers, the chief of which is the Avon. Religious Houses.

Here were many Religious Houses, as at Asley, Atherton, Balshall, Combe, Coventrey, Killingworth, Nuneaton, Pollesworth, Roxhall, Stoneley, Thellisford, and Warwick. And for defence had several Castles, divers of which do now lye buried in their Rubbish.
It is severed into five Hundreds, in which are numbred 158 Parish Churches; and for the convenience of its Inhabitants hath 17 Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Coventrey,

Coventrey, so called of a Convent of Monks; commodiously seated for an Inland City, being esteemed the principal place for trade in these parts, and more then ordinarily frequented and inhabited, and the rather for the great quantities of cloaths here made and vended. It is a fair, neat, and large City, conteining three Churches, of which that of St. Michael and the Holy Trinity are lostily built, and is beautified with good buildings, and well ordered streets; and its Cross composed of curious and beautiful workmanship, being lately repaired, is stately to behold. It was begirt with a curious Wall, which now is demolished, and gave entrance into the City by 13 Gates, at one of which hangeth a Shield-bone of wild Bore, far greater then that of an Ox, which was said to be flain by the renowned Guy of Warwick. This place in former time was famous for its now ruinous Monastery or Convent, founded by King Canutus, which was much enlarged, and most richly beautified by Leofrick Earl of the Mercians; which invited Robert de Limsey Bishop of Litchsield and Chester to translate his See hither, which in some few years was again removed to Litchfield. Nor is it to be forgot how the Lady Godiva, wife to the said Leofrick for the purchasing the Citizens freedom, and to be eased from those heavy taxes which he imposed upon them for some offence committed by them against him, about Noon-day rode naked through the chief streets of the City; a penance, though much improper for a Husband to command, and as immodest for her to imbrace, yet for the good of the Inhabitants the cheerfully accepted of. This City, although within the confines of Warwickshire, yet is exempted from its jurisdiction, as being a County incorporate of it self, having within its Liberty several Towns, and doth enjoy ample immunities, also sends Burgesses to Parliament, keepeth Courts for the hearing of Causes, the tryal of Felons, where they have a Goal for Offenders, and is governed by a Maior, two Sheriffs, and other Sub-Officers. It is a place well served with commodities, and its Market on Fridays is very great, for corn, provisions, cattle, &c. Warwick.

Warwick, said to be built by Gurgunstus about 375 years before the birth of Christ; by the Britains called Caer-Guaruic, and Caer-Leon, and by Mr. Cambden said to be the Præsidium of the Romans, where they had their Garison, which was a band of Dalmatian Horsemen; for it seemeth that such was the great care of the Romans, for the preservation of their conquered Territories, that they placed in their Garisons men of several Nations, by which means the native Inhabitants, being ignorant of their language and manners, were the less capable of joyning in any conspiracy with them. And when the Romans were thus Masters of the Town, it was in a very flourishing condition, large, and of great strength, as well by nature as art, whose scituation is on a steep Rock, and washed by the River Avon, over which it hath a strong and well-built Stone-bridge; and was fortified with a Wall (which in many places is yet apparent to be seen) and a strong and stately Castle which over-looketh the Town, which is now the seat of the Right Honorable Robert Grevill, Baron Brook of Beauchamps-Court, &c. It is at present a Town of good account, indifferent large, conteining two Parish Churches (besides several demolished) amongst which St. Maries is the chief, which is a fair Structure, wherein are divers beautiful Tombs. Its Houses are well-built, its Streets spacious and well ordered, is a place well inhabited, enjoyeth a good trade, chiefly for Mault, and the rather as being the place where the Assizes and
general Sessions for the County are kept; it hath the accommodation of a Free-School, and a well endowed Hospital for decayed Gentlemen; amongst its immunities sends Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by a Maior, 12 Brethren, 24 Burgesses for Common-councel, a Recorder, and other Sub officers. And its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great, and well provided with corn and provisions; And of late is built a stately Market-house of Freestone, susteined by several Pillars. Guy-cliff.

Near unto Warwick is Guy-cliff, most delectably seated amongst Groves and fresh Streams, where Guy of Warwick was said to have built a Chappel, and after he had left off his noble and valiant exploits, here led an Hermetical life, and when he dyed was here interr'd. Cambden, page 564. Henley.
Henley, seated on the River Alne, a small Town, and hath a mean Market on Mondays. Aulcester.

Aulcester, scituate on the Avon, and not far from the place where the Arrow falleth into the Alne; an ancient Town-Corporate, and formerly of a greater trade then now it is, whose Market, which is on Tuesdays, is indifferent good for provisions. Stratford.

Stratford, seated on the North-side of the Avon, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge susteined by fourteen Arches; it is a good Town, conteining two Churches, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a considerable trade for Mault here made; and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is very well served with corn and provisions. Shipton.
Shipton, scituate on the Stower, over which it hath a Bridge; a small Town, and hath a good Market on Saturdays for provisions. Kyneton.
Kyneton, seated on a branch of the Avon, a little Town, which hath a very small Market on Tuesdays. Southam,
seated in fertile soil for corn; an indifferent Town, whose Market, which is on Mondays, is well served with corn and provisions, and is considerable for cattle. Rugby.
Rugby, seated on a branch of the Avon, over which it hath a bridge; 'tis a small Town, much inhabited by Butchers, and hath a good Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Dunsmere-heath.
Near unto this Town is Dunsmere-heath. Nun-Eaton.
Nun-Eaton, seated on the River Auker, where there was a Nunnery of devout Nuns. It is a long Town, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Atherston.
Atherston, seated by a small Brook, an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Merivall.
Near Atherton standeth Merivall, where Robert Ferrers erected a Monastery, and was therein interr'd, being enwrapped in an Ox-hide instead of a Winding-sheet. Seckington.

Near unto this place (as Mr. Cambden noteth) stood the ancient and flourishing Town, in the time of the Saxons called Secandunum, which at this day is called Seckington. And here æthelbald King of the Mercians, in the year of our Lord 749. in the Civil War was stabbed to death by Beared, who soon after for his reward was slain by Offa. Mancester.

Southwards of Atherton is seated Mancester, where it hath a Stone-bridge over the River Auker; a place at present but small, but in former time very considerable, being raised out of the ruins of the ancient Manduessedum mentioned by Antonine the Emperour. Tamworth.

Tamworth, scituate part in this County, and part in Staffordshire, and on the River Tame, where the River Auker falleth into it; which said Rivers no less pleasantly then commodiously wash two parts of the Town over each of which is a Stone-bridge: It is a good fair Town, beautified
with a large Church, strengthened with a small, but strong Castle; and hath a Market on Saturdays, which is well served with corn, provisions, and lean cattle. Sutton-Cofield.
Sutton-Cofield, seated in an excellent air, and amongst woods, which yield pleasure to its Inhabitants, but in a barren soil. The Town is small, and hath a mean Market on Mondays. Bromicham.

Bromicham, seated on the side of a hill, very dry, and on a small River: It is a large and well-built Town, very populous, much resorted unto, and enjoyeth a very great trade for iron and steel-wares, and tools here made, also for saddles and bridles, which find good vent at London, Ireland, and other parts; its Market is on Thursdays, which is very considerable for living cattle, corn, mault, and provisions, besides the Manufactures of the Town. Colshill.
Colshill, scituate on the side of a hill, by the River Cole, over which it hath a Stone-bridge; a small Town, and hath a mean Market on Wednesdays. Solibull.
Solibull, seated on a Flat, a very mean Town, which had a Market, but at present so inconsiderable, that it is not took notice of. Other places of note in this County.
At Seckington, in Anno Dom. 749. King Cuthred in a battel slew æthelbald.
At Off-church, Offa King of the Mercians had his Palace, and here his son St. Fremund was interr'd.
At Chesterton, was the ancient Foss-way of the Romans.
At Newenham Regis, is a Spring whose water, if drunk with salt, loosneth, and if with sugar, bindeth the body; and is said to be very soveraign against Ulcers, Imposthumes, and the Gout.
At Lemington, there issueth out within a stride of each other, two Springs of water, but of different taste and operation, the one being salt, and the other fresh.
At Shugbury, the precious stone Astroites is found.
At Kennelworth, there was an Abbey or Monastery, and a large and stately Castle, both now demolished.

div1.n: Westmoreland: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div1.head: Westmoreland: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers.

div2.n: Westmoreland: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div2.head: Westmoreland: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers

figure.head: A Mapp of the Countie of Westmorland

div2.p: VVESTMORELAND, called by late Latine Writers VVestmoria, and VVestmorlandia; which name was attributed unto it as lying amongst Moors and high Hills, or Fells, and was anciently for the most part un-manured; And, such barren places which cannot easily (by the painful labour of the Husbandman) be brought to fruitfulness, the Northern English-men call Moors; and Westmoreland is nothingelse but a VVestern Moorish and barren Country, yet not without many fruitful Valleys, abounding with good Arable, Meadow, and Pasture grounds, which bear good crops of corn, and feed good flocks, and herds of cattle. Its bounds.
This County hath for its Eastern bounds the Bishoprick of Durham, and Yorkshire; for its Southern, Lancashire; and for its Western and Northern, Lancashire and Cumberland. Extent. Air.

Its extent is but small, for from Burton in the South, to the joyning with Cumberland and Durham (in the Mountains near the first rise of the two Rivers, Tees and Tyne) in the North, is about 35 miles; and the broadest part from East to West, which is from the Spittle on Stainmoor, to the Shirestones on Wrey-nose-hill, doth not exceed 24 miles, and makes in circumference about 112 miles; so that its from is somewhat longer then broad. And being so far engaged Northwards, the air is something sharp and piercing in the Winter season, and more sit to preserve then recover health. Mountains.

This County (as I have already noted) is very Mountainous, there running a ridge of high Hills, Mountains or Fells, from Yorkshire, by Grayrig-hawse, Crookdale-hawse, Longsledale, Kentmeer, Troutheck, Ambleside, Rydale, Gresmeer, & Dunmaile-Raise unto Withburn in Cumberland; & these Mountains do divide the Barony of Kendale from the Bottom of VVestmoreland; through which Mountains or Fells there are but 3 common Roads, and those none of the best, viz. Grayrig-hawse, Crookdale-hawse, and over Kirkstone near Ambleside. Here is also another ridge of Hills from Hucat, Morvill-hill by
Holomil-cross, the Spittle on Stainmore, the back of Hellbeck, Murton-pike, and Howgil-Gastle, unto Blencarne, Kirkland, and Skirwith-Fells in Cumberland. Its Rivers.

Amongst the Rivers that water this County, these are of most note: Brathey, which severs this County from Lancashire; Routha, which runs from Gresmeer by Rydale and Ambleside; Winster, Spur, Kent, Burbeck, Lon, Eden, Lowther, and Eamant which severs this Shire from Cumberland. Lakes and Meers.

Here are several Lakes and Meers, as Winder-meer, which is the greatest standing water in England, Rydale-water, Ester-water, Gresmeer-water, Kent-meer, ulles-water, which separates this County from Cumberland, Brother-water, Hawse-water, and others.
This County gives Title to the Right Honorable Francis Fane, Earl of Westmoreland, &c. Castles.
