And being a County far engaged to the North, it was (as the other Northern Counties) strengthened with divers Castles.

The English gaining the displeasure of Malcolme King of the Scots, he entred this County with Sword and Destruction, sacking Durham, Holderness, Tesidale, and Weremouth, and sending from thence great booties into this Kingdom. In this Expedition Edgar, Etheling, with Margaret and Christian his Sisters met King Malcolme, who worthily received them; and Margaret the only Heir of the Saxons Monarchy, afterwards married the said Malcolme, from whom is lineally descended our Soveraign King Charles, uniting into one Royal Stem the Imperial Titles of the Saxons, Normans, English, and Scotch. Its division according to Ecclesiastick and Temporal Government.

The division of this County, according to its Ecclesiastical Government, is part (viz. the Barony of Kendale) within the Diocess of Chester, and part (viz. the Bottom of Westmoreland) in the Diocess of Carlisle; and these parts are subdivided into several Deaneries. And its division according to the Temporal Government thereof, is into two great Baronies, the one (being divided by a ridge of Mountains or Fells already taken notice of) conteining the South part of this County, is called Kendale Barony, which is divided into the Wards of Kendale and Lonsdale, which are subdivided into several Constablewicks: and the other Barony, called the Barony of Westmoreland, conteineth all the rest of the County, and is also divided into two Wards, to wit, the East-ward and the West-ward, in which are also divers Constablewicks. And in these Wards are numbred 26 Parishes, and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants hath eight Market-towns, whose names are as followeth, as they are seated in the several Wards; and first with those of Lonsdale-ward. Lonsdale-ward. Kirby-Launs-dale.

Kirby-Launsdale, viz. the Church-town in Lonsdale, seated on the banks of the River Lon, and in the pleasant and rich Vale of Lonsdale: It is a large and well-built Town, beautified with a fair Church, and a large Stone-bridge over the said River; is well inhabited, and much resorted unto both to Church, and Market, being the greatest Town in the County, except Kendale; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is well served with provisions, and traded unto for cloth. Burton.
Burton, scituate in a Valley, and near the great hill called Farleton-knot- hill; an indifferent well-built Town, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays, of no long continuance.

Kendale, or rather Kirby-Kendale, a very fair, large, well-built, inhabited and frequented Borough and Market-town, which for largeness, neatness, good buildings, and trading, is the chief in the County; and for its excellent Manufactures, together with the ingenuity, civility, and industry of its Inhabitants, it hath deservedly purchased a great name; and the great trade here droven makes it to be very populous; for the people here seem to be shapen out for trade, improving themselves not only in their old Manufactures of cotton, and course woollen-cloth, but of late in making of Druggets, Serges, Hats, Worsted-stockings, &c. whereby the poor are daily set on work, and the Town and adjacent parts much enriched. This Town is most pleasantly seated in a good air (amongst Hills) in a Valley so called, and on the West-side of the River Can or Kent, over which it hath two fair Stone-bridges, and a third of Wood, which leadeth to the Castle scituate near the banks thereof, now reduced to ruins, which was a fair old building, anciently the seat of some of the Lords of this Town, and was of chief note for giving birth to Queen Katherine, the sixth wife to King Henry the Eighth. The Town is built in form of a Cross, having two long streets, which overthwart one another, besides some others; and is beautified with a very fair and large Church, susteined by five rows of fair Pillars, with several Apartments, in which are the Monuments or Tombs of divers of the Gntry; and to this, as the Parish Church, belongeth 12 Chappels of Ease. It is a place that boasteth not much of its Antiquity; its chiefest honour being in giving Title to three Earls, viz. John Duke of Bedford, John Duke of Somerset, and John de Foix; as also to a Duke, which was Charles third son to his Royal Highness James Duke of York, &c. and for being an ancient Barony, called the Baron of Kendale. On the side of the Churchyard stands a Free-School, being a large building, and well endowed with good exhibitions for preferring of poor Scholars, going from hence to Queens-Colledge in Oxford. The government of this Town is committed to the care of a Maior, 12 Aldermen, 20 Common-councel-men, a Recorder, Town-Clark, and two Attorneys, who attend at their Sessions and Courts of Record, with other Sub-officers; and the Maior, Recorder, and two of the Senior Aldermen are alwaies Justices of the Peace for the Corporation, and keep their quarterly Sessions. Likewise here are kept the Sessions of the Peace for this part of the County, called the Barony of Kendale, as the Sessions for the Bottom (or the other part of the County) are kept at Appleby; which two parts do comprehend the whole shire, and much resemble the ridings of Yorkshire. Here are also in this Town seven Companies, viz the Mercers, Shearmen, Cordwainers, Tanners, Glovers, Taylors, and Pewterers, each of which have their Hall or place of assembly for the electing of Officers, and officiating the concerns of the said Company. And for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, hath a very great Market on Saturdays, which is well provided with corn, living cattle, and provisions. Ambleside.
Ambleside, seated near the great Lake of Wimander, hath an indifferent good Market for wool, yarn, and provisions on Wednesdays. The ancient City of Amboglana.

And near unto this Town, at the upper end of the said Lake, lyeth the dead Carcass (as one would say) of an ancient City, with great ruins of Walls, and many heaps of Rubbish one from another, with remains of buildings that are yet to be seen. The Fortress thereof was somewhat long, being fenced about with a Rampire, and took up in length 132 Ells, and in breadth about 80; And this is thought (by Mr. Cambden) to be the Roman
work, and called Amboglana, as have been evidenced by the paved Highwayes leading unto it, as alfo by the British bricks, and Roman coyns oft-times there found. Winder-meer.

This Meer of Winder-meer, or Winandermeer, is the greatest standing water in all England (probably so called, either from the great Winds often there, or from its winding and turning in and out) which is of a great breadth and depth, and of about 10 miles in length, wherein are great store of fish, as Skellies and Charrs (only taken here, and in ulles-water, another large Meer in this County, the rareness of which fish doth occasion many Charr-pies to be sent yearly abroad as presents) Trouts, Pikes, Pearch, and Eels. It hath (as most Lakes in the North) a clear pebbly bottom) which may be, gave the occasion of saying, that it's all paved at the bottom with stone. At the East-side of this Lake is a large Parish, which carrieth the name thereof, in which Eothred King of Northumberland, in Anno Dom. 792, when he had by force fetched King Elfwolds sons out of York, slew them, that he might secure the Kingdom to himself and his. The Church belonging to this Parish is a fair building, all leaded, and hath a large Quire-window of excellent coloured glass, where are lively pourtraed the figures of divers Abbots, with sundry bearings of the neighbouring Gentry, amongst which is that of the Flemings, viz. G. a Frett of 6 pieces A. now belonging to my Honorable Friend Daniel Fleming of Rydale Esq; which said Window-piece, as is said, anciently belonged to the Abbey of Fourness in Lancashire, and upon its desolution by King Henry the Eighth, was purchased by the Inhabitants of this Parish. Witherslack-Mannor, a Chappel lately built.

In the Mannor of Witherslack was lately built a fair Parochial Chappel, as being too remote from its Parish Church Bethome; which said Chappel was liberally endowed by Dr. John Barwick late Dean of St. Pauls, who was here born, and was solemnly consecrated the 22. of June, 1671. and dedicated to St. Paul.

Near Ridale-hall is a great Lake called Ridale-water (stiled sometimes anciently Routh-a-meer) wherein are several Islands, and is well stored with fish; as are Elter-water, Loughrigg-Tarne, and other waters within the Parish of Gresmeer.

In the Parish of Gresmeer is a great part of Dunmaile-Raise, being a Mountain, over which the High-way leading from Kendale by Ambleside unto Keswick and Cockermouth, doth pass: so called from a great heap or raise of stones by the High-way side (dividing this County from Cumberland) cast up together in ancient time, either by King Dunmaile, sometime King of Cumberland, as a mark for the bounds of his Kingdom; or by some other in remembrance of his name for some memorable act there done by him, or a victory obteined against him. East-ward. Appleby.

Appleby, memorable for its scituation and antiquity; for in the time of the Romans it was called Abellaba: And the Aurelian Maures kept their station there. It is pleasantly seated, being for the most part encompassed with the River Eden; but so slenderly inhabited, the buildings (for the most part, although of late much amended) so mean, and the Inhabitants generally so idle (having no Manufacture of note amongst them) that were it not that by reason of the Antiquity it had deserved to be accounted the chief Town of the County, and to have the Assizes and Sessions kept there, it would be little better then a Village; for all the beauty of it is in one broad street, which from North to South riseth with an easie ascent, having in the upper part thereof a Castle highly seated, which is almost environed
with the River. In the nether end of it is the Church, and not far. from it a School liberally endowed, and carefully looked after. This is a very ancient Borough and Corporation, for K. Henry the Second granted to these Burgesses the like Liberties which the City of York had, and was discharged from the Toll in all places except London and York, and granted them the Borough at the Fee-farm Rent of 20 l.per ann. payable at Michaelmass and Easter to the Sheriff of Westmoreland at Appleby, which by K. John was confirmed. This Corporation anciently consisted of a Maior, and two Provosts or Bailiffs, but at present of a Maior and 12 Aldermen, many of the neighbouring Gentry being of late years chosen Free-men and Aldermen, on purpose to give a greater reputation thereunto. William of Newborough called this Town and Castle Princely holds, where he writeth that William King of Scots surprised them on a sudden, a little before himself was taken prisoner at Alnewick, which K. John after wards recovered, and gave to Robert de Vipount, in consideration of his singular good service to him and the Kingdom. This Castle was a place of strength and eminence, where K. Henry the Third placed Constables, and was by the Lady Clifford about the year 1651. repaired with additional buildings: At which time she laid the Foundation of an Almes-house, or Hospital, in the East-side of the street leading to the Castle, which being finished, she liberally endowed, and placed there in the Mother, a deceased Ministers Wife, and 12 Sisters, (11 of them being Widows, and the twelfth a maimed Maid) and in Ann. 1661. she obteined from his Majesty a License under the great Seal for the same. She also purchased Lands, which she setled upon Feoffees in trust for the yearly repairing (as occasion requires) of the Church, School-house, Moot-hall, or Town-hall, and Bridge, which is a fair one of stone. And further, she expended about 6 or 700 l. in the repairing of the Church, then very ruinous, where she caused a Vault to be made, wherein she intends to be buried, having already erected her Tombstone over it. This Town amongst its immunities sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath a good Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Kir by-Stephens.

Kirby-Stephens, beautified with a fair Church, seated near the skirt of the Hills which severeth this County from Yorkshire; it is a good and well known Town, which of late is much improved by the trade of making stockings, and hath a good Market on Fridays.

Near unto this Town is seated Wharton-hall, which gives Title to the Right Honorable, Philip Lord Wharton, &c. and not far distant is Pendargon- Castle, lately rebuilt by the Countess of Pembrook. Burgh.

Burgh or Brough, seated under Stainmore, formerly of great note, being the ancient Verteræ, where (as 'tis said) in the declension of the Roman Empire, one of their Captains made his abode with a band of the Directors, and was fenced about with a Fortress; but now the Town is decayed, and become a small Village, and hath a very inconsiderable Market on Thursdays. Orton.

Orton, seated amongst the Heaths, very destitute of Wood, in somuch that the people say they have not a stick, or bough to hang a dog on. The Town is but small, and hath a mean Market lately erected on Wednesdays. Stainmore-hill

On Stainmore a great Hill (so called for its being very stony) is a Cross, said to be erected upon a Peace concluded between William the Conquerour, and Malcolme King of Scotland, which was, That Malcolme should retein Cumberland with the same rights that his Predecessors did enjoy it, and that the Subjects of each Kingdom might know their limits, and how far they were to pass, a Stone-cross was here erected, which was called Ree-cross, that is, the Cross of Kings, for on the South-side thereof the Arms of the King of England were engraven; and on the North-side those of the King of Scotland.
In this part of the County there is never a Market-town, but hath several places of note, amongst which are Shappe.

Shappe, a great Parish, wherein stood the only Abbey in this County, seated near the banks of Lowther River, founded by Thomas Son of Jospatrick, in the twentieth year of King Henry the First. Not far fromwhich there is a Well or Fountain, which after the manner of Euripus, ebbeth and floweth many times in a day: Also there are great stones in form of Piramides, some of which are above 9 foot high, and 14 thick, being ranged as it were directly in a row for about a mile in length, and placed at equal distances from each other, which may seem to have been pitched, and erected for to continue the memorial of some worthy act there atchieved.

In the Parish of Barton, formerly a Barony, at the nether end of Ulles- water is Powley-bridge over the River Eamont. Not far from hence is Barton- School, founded by Dr. Gerard Langbaine late Provost of Queens-Colledge in Oxford. Maburgh.

Maburgh, a small Town, seated on the River Eamont, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, but was formerly of note, being a Roman Fort, now quite ruinated, many of the stones being taken away in the Reign of Henry the Sixth, for the repairing of Perith-Castle in Cumberland. Arthurs Round table.

Round table, a Roman work, placed by the High-way side leading between Lowther-bridge, and Eamont-bridge; which is a large round Circle of ground, inclosing a fair Plain in the midst, and this the Country people will have to be a place made use of by the Knights of the Round table for their Tilts and Turnaments, there being two opposite passes to make their approaches in; and do therefore call it Arthurs round table. Brawham-Castle.

Here are also other places of Antiquity, as the ruins of Castles, called Castle-steads, with Forts and Trenches: and at the joyning of the River Eamont with that of Lowther, is Brawham-Castle, now belonging to the Countess of Pembrook, which seemeth to have been a place of some account in the time of the Romans, as appears by the several pieces of Coyns, &c. which have been there digged up.

On the banks of the River Lowther, is the Seat of Sir John Lowther Baronet, which beareth the name of Lowther-hall, whose Family hath there flourished beyond any Record, and do reckon thirty discents lineally from Father to Son, and all, or the greatest part Knights, as is made manifest by Records, and by the Coats of Arms of the Families that they have matched withal: and 'tis further remarkable, that not only the House carrieth the name of the Family, but likewise the Parish, the River, the Bridge, and a Park.

div1.n: WILTSHIRE: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons
div1.head: WILTSHIRE: BEING Part of the BELGæ, and ancient KINGDOM of the West-Saxons.

figure.head: A Mapp of Wiltshire with its Hundreds

div1.p: VVILTSHIRE, altogether an Inland Country, no less fertile then delightful, and enjoying a most sweet and delightful air. Its Northern part, called North-Wiltshire, hath delectable hills well clothed with woods, and watered with fresh streams, amongst which is the Isis, which soon becometh the chief in the Kingdom. Its Southern parts are more even, and exceding fertile in corn, and grass, feeding great flocks of sheep, and are also well watered with the Rivers of Avon, Willy, and Adler: And the middle part of this County is most plain and level, and beareth the name of Salisbury-plain, which is a large and spacious track of ground, found very profitable to the Inhabitants of those parts, by the feeding of such great flocks of sheep. Its Rivers. Its bounds.

This Shire hath for its Eastern limits the Counties of Berks and Hantshire; for its Southern, part of Hantshire and Dorsetshire; for its Western, that of Somerset; and for its Northern, Glocestershire. Its extent from Inglesham in the North, to Burgat Damorum in the South, maketh about 39 miles; and from Butter-meer in the East, to the Shire-stones in the West, is said to be about 29; and makes in circumference about 140 miles. Extent. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants known to Cæsar, were the Belgæ, which were subdued by Vespasian, Lieutenant of the second Legion under Claudius, and afterwards became part of the West-Saxon Kingdom. Wansdike.

In the midst of this Shire there is a Dike which runneth from East to West for many miles, called Wansdike, a place of some wonder, and by the common sort of people, said to be cast up by the Devil upon a Wednesday; but as Mr. Cambden observeth, was rather made by the Saxons for the dividing of this Kingdom of the West-Saxons, from that of the Mercians, this being the place where they fought for the enlargement of their Dominions. And near unto this Dike is Wodensburge a small Village (so called from Woden the Saxons Ancestor and great God) where Ceauline that warlike King of the VVest-Saxons, in Anno 590. received such a great overthrow by the Britains and English in a fierce battel, that not being able to recover him
self, he was constrained to quit his Kingdom, and to end his dayes in a miserable exil'd condition. And here it was that Ina the West-Saxon joyned battel with Ceolred the Mercian, whence both of them quitted the field with equal loss. Its Division.

This County is severed into 29 Hundreds, whose names appear in the Mapp, in which are numbred 304 Parish Churches, is accommodated with one City, and hath intercourse of Traffick by twenty Market- towns. Religious houses.

In former time here were many Religious Houses, amongst which those of most note were, Malmesbury, Ambresbury, Salisbury, Lacock, Stanley, Wilton, Ivy-church, Farnleg, Bradstock, Briopune, Bromham, with several others of less note. Salisbury.

Salisbury, of old Sorbiodunum, a City of great Antiquity, formerly the seat of the Romans, where Kenrick vanquished the Britains, and where Canutus the Dane committed great spoils by fire. This City of Salisbury, commonly called New-Sarum, was raised out of the old, which was dryly seated on a great Eminence; being a place only designed for strength and war; yet honoured it was with an Episcopal See, and a fair Cathedral. As to the present City, it is pleasantly seated on a River, whose streams commodiously vater most of the streets, which are large and spacious. It is a place beautified with fair buildings, the chief amongst which is its Minster or Cathedral, dedicated to the blessed Virgin Mary, a stately and beautiful Structure, first began by Bishop Poor, and in forty years was raised to its perfect beauty, having as many Gates or Doors for entrance, as Months in the year, as many Windows as Weeks, and as many Pillars (great and small) as Days in the year. Its Steeple hath a lofty spire, which proudly sheweth it self from a great distance; and its Cloyster is large, and curiously wrought, to which near adjoyning is the Bishops Palace. Next to its Cathedral may be reckoned its Town-hall, a fair building, seated in a spacious Market-place. This City is dignified with an Earldom, which at present is invested in the person of the Right Honorable James Cecil Earl of Salisbury, &c. Amongst its immunities sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, (as doth Old-Sarum) is a place well inhabited and frequented, enjoyeth a good trade; and its Markets, which are on Tuesdays and Saturdays, are very considerable for corn and provisions, and for living cattle on Tuesdays.

This Diocess conteineth the Counties of Wilts and Berks, in which are 544 Parish Churches, of which 109 are Impropriations, and hath three Arch-Deacons, viz. of Salisbury, Berkshire, and Wiltshire. Stone-benge.See Cambden, 251.

This City is encompassed with open Fields and Plains, which take their name from the City; in which said Plains at about six miles distance, is to be seen the great and wonderful piece of work called Stone-henge, composed of great and unwrought stones, some of which are 28 foot high, and 7 broad, and so laid over-thwart one another, that it is wonderful to behold, insomuch that the people reckon them to be one of the wonders and miracles of this Nation. And these stone are said to be thus raised by the Britains, as a Monumental Sepulcher (to remain to perpetuity) of the vertue and manhood of Ambrosius Aurelianus, who took upon him the Imperial purple Robe of Britain in the Declension of the Roman Empire, succoured his languishing Country, and by the aid of that war-like Arthur repressed the furious rage of the Enemy, vanquishing powerful Armies, and in the end, in the last battle fought on this Plain, lost his life. And for the better confirming of this report, true it is that mens bones have been ofttimes digged up, and the Town of Ambresbury seated on the Avon, seems to
be so called from Ambrose, in which Town divers of the British Kings, according to their History, lay interr'd; where there was a Monastery for 300 Monks, which was rifled, and spoiled by Gurmundus; and in the place thereof, Alfritha Wife to King Edgar, to expiate her crime for the killing King Edward her Son in Law, built a stately Nunnery, and richly endowed it, in which Queen Eleanor, Widdow to King Henry the Third, renouncing all worldly Pomp as a Nun, devoted her self to a holy life.

Mr. Cambden, as also Mr. Indico Jones (who wrote a learned Tract; entituled Stony-henge) are of opinion, That these stones are not naturally hewed out of the Rock, but artificially made of pure sand, and by some conglutinous matter incorporated together, like unto some such kind of Trophees of Victory in Yorkshire; and the better to make this Opinion seem rational, Cambden taketh occasion to speak, That the Cesterns in Rome were made of sand digged out of the ground, which with the strongest kind of Lime wrought together, became so hard, that they seemed stones; and that Statues, and Images of Marble chippings, and smal Gritt grown together, become so firm, that they pass for solid Marble. Wilton.

Wilton, a place well watered, as seated between the River Willey and another; a Town in ancient time called Ellandunum, and was sometime of such considerable account, that it was the head Town of the County, was dignified with an Episcopal See, had a Monastery, and enjoyed great immunities; but this place suffered great spoils by the Danes, which with other its ill-fortunes, especially by turning the Western High-road, by little and little it be came to what it is at present, a small mean Town, yet ceaseth it not as a Borough-town, to elect Parliament, men, and is the place where the Knights of the Shire are chosen, and where the Sheriff keepeth his monthly County Courts, and hath a small Market on Wednesdays.

In this Town it was that Egbert, King of the West-Saxons, obteined a victory against Beor-wolfe of Mercian, but not without the loss of aboundance of men slain on each side: And here it was that ælfred joyned battol with the Danes, who in the end were the Victors. Duncton.

Dounton, or Duncton, seated on the Avon, a Borough-town of great antiquity, which electeth Parliament men, is of some note for being the habitation of the famous Beavois of Southampton; and hath a small Market on Fridays. Clarendon-Fark.
Eastwards of Salisbury is that large and spacious Park of Clarendon, which gives Title to the Right Honorable Edward Earl of Clarendon, &c. Amersbury.

Amersbury, or Ambresbury, seated on the Avon; a Town of great antiquity, as I have already noted in the description of Stony-henge, at present indifferent large, but the Houses scatteringly built; and its Market, which is on Fridays; is so inconsiderable, that it is not taken notice of, if not disused. Hindon.

Hindon, seated on the South-part of the County reguarding Dorsetshire; an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Bailiff, electeth Parliament men, and hath a very considerable Market (especially for corn) on Thursdays. Willye.

Eastwards from Hindon on the River Willyborne, is seated a small Village called Willye, opposite to which is a large military Fort, called by the Inhabitants Yanesbury-Castle, which, to all probability, was a Garison of the Romans, and by some believed to be Vespatians Camp; and not far from this Fort are two others of less note. Mere.
Mere, seated near large Hills, where there is a Beacon; it hath a Market on but at present of little account, by reason of the late damage it suffered by fire.
Not far from Mere is Stourton, which gives Title to the Right Honorable William Stourton, Baron Stourton of Stourton. Westbury.

Westbury, or Westbury under the Plain, a Borough-town, governed by a Maior, electeth Parliament men; is an indifferent good Town, and hath a Market on Fridays, which is very considerable for corn. Werminster.

Werminster, at the Spring-head of the River Willeyborne, of old Verlutio, which (as Mr. Cambden noteth) in former time was a Town of great account, enjoyed ample immunities, paid no Tribute, nor was rated by the Hide; and hath at present a very considerable Market for corn, &c. on Saturdays. Troubridge.
Troubridge, scituate on a Hill, a Town of good account for clothing, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Edingdon.

Near unto Troubridge is Edingdon of old Eathamdune, where King Al- fred in a pitched battel was successful against the Danes, and forced them to quit the Kingdom. And here William Edendon Bishop of Winchester (who was born at this Town) erected a Colledge, and called it Bon-hommes. Lavington.
Lavington, seated not far from the Downs, an indifferent Town, but hath a very great Market on Wednesdays, especially for corn and mault. Devizes.

Devizes, seated on a Hill, in a Bottom, and near Blackmere-Forest; a Town heretofore of greater note and strength, then now it is, being defended by a powerful Castle, yet is it at present a large Town, electing Parliament men, is well inhabited and traded unto for divers commodities, and principally mault; and hath a very considerable Market on Thursdays for horses, cattle of all sorts, corn, provisions, and divers other Country commodities. Bradford.

Bradford, scituate on the Avon, and on the descent of a Hill (so called of a broad Foord) where Kenilwacuh, a British King, fought a sore battel against his near Kinsman Cuthred. It is an indifferent Town, and hath a Market on Mondays. Castle-comb.
Castle-comb, so called from its old Castle, formerly a Market-town, but now disused. Chipnam.
Chipnam, or Chippenham, seated on the Avon, a Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, and hath a noted Market on Saturdays for corn and provisions. Cosham.
Nigh unto Chipnam is Cosham, now of mean account, but in former time the Mansion-house of King ætheldred. Calne.

Calne, scituate on a River so called, and in a stony ground, a poor small Borough-town, but beautified with a fair Church, gives its Vote in Parliament by two Burgesses, and hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays. At this place in Anno 977, when there were hot disputes between the Monks and Priests concerning single life, here was a Provincial Councel, or Synod (as Mr. Cambden observeth) holden, and whilst they were debating the matter in hand, the Convocation-house, wherein the States sate, by breaking of the main Timber, suddenly fell down, and many of the Noble-men, Prelates, and Gentry were wounded, and divers slain. Marlbrough.

Marlbrough, or Marlberge, seated on the Kenet, near Savernake-Forest, and Aldburne-chase, and in a Chaulky-soil; a Town of great note in former ages, and supposed to have been the ancient Cunetio of the Romans, out of whose ruins it was raised, and had a Castle once belonging to John, surnamed Sans Terre, who was after King of England, and where there was a Parliament held, and a Law made for the suppressing of all Tumults, commonly called the Statute of Marlbrough. It is at present a good and well-built Borough-town, governed by a Maior and Burgesses, hath the election of Parliament men; is dignified with an Earldom, at present in the Person of the Right Honorable William Earl of Marlbrough, &c. and hath a very considerable Market for corn, mault, provisions, butter, and especially cheese on Saturdays.
Rockly.

Near unto this place is Rockly a sinallVillage, so called from divers stones like Rocks pitched up an end, amongst which there sometimes breaks forth a violent stream of water, which is reputed the sore-runner of a Dearth, and by the Country people is called Hungersborne.
In this part are several eminent and high Hills, as Badbury-hill, Selbury- hill, St. Anns-hill, Marteusall-hill, and others. Auburne.
Auburne, seated on a branch of the Kenet, an indifferent Town, and hath a small Market on Tuesdays. Swindon.
Swindon, seated on the top of a Hill, and near a rich Vale, a Town of no largeness, but the Houses well-built of stone, and hath a considerable Market on Mondays for fat cattle. Wotton-Basset.

Wotton-Basset, adjoyning to a large Park; and not far from the spacious Forest of Bredon; it is a Maior, and Borough-town, electing Parliament men, and hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays. Highworth.
Highworth, scituate on the top of a high Hill, and in the middle of a rich Vale, near the Vale of White-horse; hath a good Market for cattle on Wednesdays. Creeklade.

Creeklade, seated Westwards of Highworth, well watered with Rivers, which almost encompass it; it is a Borough-Town which electeth Parliament men, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Malmesbury.

Malmesbury, pleasantly seated on a Hill, and on the River Avon, which almost encircleth it, over which it hath six bridges. It is a Town of great antiquity, where Maidulph an Irish-Scot, a man of great holiness and learning, under a Hill in a solitary Grove built a cell, or little Monastery, and lived an Hermetical life, and where his Successor Adelma built a fair Monastery. It is at present a good Borough-town, governed by a Maior and Aldermen, enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath a good Market for corn and provisions on Saturdays.
In this County there are other Borough-towns, which have the election of Parliament men; viz. Heitsbury, Bedwin Magna, and Lugersall.

div1.n: Worcestershire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS
div1.head: Worcestershire: BEING Part of the CORNAVII, and ancient KINGDOM of the MERCIANS.

figure.head: A Mapp of Worchester shire with its Hundreds

div1.p: VVORGESTER, a County blest with a sweet and temperate air, and of a fertile soil, both for tillage and pasturage, bearing good crops of corn, and feeding store of cattle. It is every where interlaced with aspiring Hills, which are well clothed with Wood, the chief amongst which are the Malverne, Bredon, Woodbery, aliàs Woobery, Abberleg, and Lickey: and through its Valleys run those many Rivers which so plentifully water the Country, as the Severn, (which in a winding Chanel almost cutteth the Country in the midst) the Avon, Salwarp, Team, &c. all which are plentifully stored with excellent fish, and particularly the Severn, which is of note for its Lampres. Its Rivers. Great plenty of Fruits.

This Shire hath such great aboundance of fruits, that even the Hedgerows, and High-wayes are beset therewith, which are common to all Passengers, and of which they make great plenty of Sider and Perry. Salt-pits.
Here are many Salt-pits or Wiches, which afford a most excellent, and high-prized sort of Salt for the table, which for fineness, whiteness and hardness, imitateth Loaf-sugar. Its form and Extent.

Its form is triangular, but not of an equal proportion, for from South to North are numbred about 32 miles; from South to North-west, about 22; and from thence to its North-east point, about 28; making its circumference to be about 120 miles. But indeed its extent cannot well be measured, it having so many several inlets and places, which lye in the limits of other Counties; with the like parts of other Counties within its body, all which are set forth in the Mapp; what should be the cause thereof, I leave to the judicious to judge; but according to the opinion of some (as Mr. Fuller in his Worthies of England noteth) it was occasioned by such which had the command of the County, who having parcels of their own lands dispersed in the adjacent Counties, desired them to be united thereunto, making their own Authority the more entire.
Religious Houses.
Places in this County set apart for Religious Uses wear at Bredon, Brodledge, aliàs Bordsley, Cochell, Evesholme, Fladbury, Malverin, Pershore, Westwoods, and Worcester. Its Castles.
And for places of Defence, it had the Castles of Elmeley, Handley, Hartlebury, Holt, Norton, Tichnel, and Worcester. Its bounds.
This Shire lyeth confronted on the East with Warwickshire; on the South with Glocestershire; on the West with Herefordshire and Shropshire; and on the North with Staffordshire. Its division
It is severed into five Hundreds, in which are numbred 152 Parishes; and for intercourse of Traffick is traded unto by 11 Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Worcester.

Worcester, no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the Eastern banks of the Severn, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge, with a Tower upon it; and thence arising with a gentle ascent; affordeth to the upper parts a delectable prospect in the Vale beneath. It is a City of great antiquity, called by Antonine and Ptolomy Branonium; by the Britains, Caerwrangon; and by the Latins, Vigornia; and said to be built by the Romans the better to secure themselves from the Britains, who were Masters of all beyond the Severn: likewise its Antiquity doth appear by the many ancient Charters granted unto them by the Kings of England before the Conquest, both of the Danes and Saxons, even as high as Hengist and Horsa. And although it hath received so many shocks of ill-fortune, having been fired, and its Inhabitants, almost all slain by Kanute in Anno Dom. 1041. for that they killed his Collector of the Danish Tribute; and being again rebuilt and peopled, in Anno 1113. it suffered much by the merciless flames of a sudden fire, which spared not the Castle and Cathedral Church. It was likewise twice in flames in the Civil broyls of King Stephen, which so impaired it, that it lay almost waste, and despairing of a recovery; yet notwithstanding from these dead ashes a new Phenix arose, and her buildings were raised in a more stately proportion, especially its Cathedral, dedicated to Christ and the blessed Virgin Mary, which having been beautifully repaired by the Bishop, is a stately Structure, in whose Quire are several Monuments or Tombs; as that of King John in White-marble, that of Arthur Prince of Wales, and son to King Henry the Seventh, in black jet; with several of the Beauchamps and ancient Family of the Littletons. It is a City every way considerable, enjoying ample immunities, sends two Citizens to Parliament; Is honoured with the Title of Marquisate, which is at present in the Person of the Right Noble Henry, Marquess and Earl of Worcester, &c. is dignified with an Episcopal See, and for Civil affairs, is at present governed by a Maior, Sheriff, 6 Aldermen, 24 principal Citizens, 48 less principal Citizens, called Common-councel-men, two Chamberleyns, a Recorder, Town-Clark, and other Sub-Officers. It is a place of a good largeness, conteining 9 Parish Churches, besides its Cathedral and St. Michaels, which are without the Liberties of the City; is graced with good built Houses, and well ordered Streets, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a good trade, especially for its clothing here made in great quantities; and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays, Fridays, and Saturdays, are very considerable, (especially that on Saturdays) for living cattle, corn, flesh, fish, and all provisions which are here had in great plenty, and at very easie rates. Pershore.

Pershore, of good antiquity, being said to be built by Egelward Duke of Dorset in the Reign of King Edgar: It is seated in a plain, on the great Road from Worcester to London, and on the banks of the River Avon, where it hath a Bridge for the conveniency of passage: and although it is somewhat
decayed in its trade, since the dissolution of its ancient Abbey; yet is it a pretty good Town, and hath a Market on Tuesdays, which is in good possibility to be considerable. Upton upon Severn.

Upton, or Upton upon Severn, as being seated on the River Severn, where it hath a good bridge; It is a well-built Town, which was of great account in the time of the Romans, and hath a Market on Thursdays. Malverne-hills and Chase.

Nigh this Upton are the Malverne- hills, or rather Mountains, which also give name to a Chase, which for the space of about seven miles, do as it were by degrees rise higher and higher, and on the brow of which Hills, Gilbert Clare Earl of Glocester did cause a wonderful Ditch to be cast up for a division of his Lands from those of the Church of Worcesters. Bredon-hills.

Opposite to these Hills Eastwards, are Bredon- hills, which also raise themselves to a great eminence, and are very remarkable; at the foot whereof is the Village Bredon, where was an ancient Monastery founded by Offa King of the Mercians. Bredon. Evesholme,

Evesholme, scituate on a Hill arising from the River Avon, which almost encompasseth it, where it hath a Stone-bridge; at the head whereof (and as it were in the Suburbs) sometime stood Bengworth-Castle, long since levelled to the ground, and the place hallowed for a Churchyard. Bengworth-Castle. This Town was of note for its Abbey founded by Egwin, with the helping hand of King Kenred, Son to Wolpher King of the Mercians. it is at present a large and well-built Maior-Town, esteemed the best in the County next to Worcester, conteining two or three Parish Churches, giveth its voice in Parliament by two Burgesses, is well inhabited and frequented, enjoying a good trade, principally for stockings; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is very considerable for corn, cattle, provisions and stockings.
This Town giveth name to a Vale near adjoyning, which for fertility of soil, may deservedly be called the Granery of these parts. Shipton upon Stower.

Shipton upon Stower, so called as seated on the Stower, but in a slip of the County which lyeth within Warwickshire, as appeareth by the Mapp. It is an ancient Town, and hath a very great Market on Fridays for corn. Droitwich.

Droitwich, seated on the River Salwarp, a Bailiffwick-Town, not over-large, hath a small Market on Fridays; but is of great note for its Salt-pits, having three Fountains which afford great plenty of water for the making the salt, which are fevered asunder by a small Brook of Fresh-water; and out of these Springs or Pits, excellent White-salt (as before I have noted) is boyled in their Furnaces placed round about, from Midsomer to Midwinter, for which they drive a very considerable trade. Fakenham-Forest.

Nigh unto this Town is Fakenham-Forest, and Norton-wood, which are very serviceable unto the Undertakers of these Salt-works, in supplying them with Wood for the boyling the brine in their Coppers. Norton-wood. Bromes-grove.
Bromes-grove, seated on the River Salwarp, an indifferent good Town, well inhabited by Clothiers, and hath a great Market on Tuesdays for corn, cattle, and all sorts of provisions. Sturbridge.

Sturbridge, scituate on a Flat, and on the Stower, over which it hath a bridge so called; it is a good and well-built Town, which hath the accommodation of a good Free-School, where there is a Library; and its Market, which is on Firdays, is well furnished with corn, provisions, and swine.
Clent-hill.
Between this Town and Bromes-grove, is a small track of Land which is part of Staffordshire, adjoyning to which Eastwards is Clent-hill, which commandeth a fair prospect. Kidderminster

Kidderminster, seated under a Hill, and on the Severn, where the little River Stower looseth it self, dividing the Town in twain. It is an ancient Bailiffwick-town, being indifferent large, its Houses well- built, beautified with a fair Church, is well inhabited, and much traded unto for its Stuffs, called Kidderminster-stuffs; and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is considerable for corn, cattle, provisions, and several Country Commodities. Bewdley.

Bewdley, a Bailiffwick-town, which sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, pleasantly seated on the Severn, and near the Forest of Wire, which in former time was a place of great delight, and of good account in the time of King Henry the Seventh, where he built a retiring House for Prince Arthur, and called it Tiken-hall. The Town at present is neat, and well-built, enjoyeth a good trade for Mault, Leather, and Caps, called Bewdly Caps, here made; and hath a Market on Saturdays, chiefly considerable for barley. Tiken-hall. Tenbury.

Tenbury, seated on the banks of a River which severeth the County from Shropshire, adjoyning to which is a small track of ground, which is part of Herefordshire. It is an indifferent Town, and hath a good Market on Tuesdays.

div1.n: YORKSHIRE: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div1.head: YORKSHIRE: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES, and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers.

div2.n: YORKSHIRE: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers
div2.head: YORKSHIRE: BEING Part of the BRIGANTES and ancient KINGDOM of the Northumbers

figure.head: A Mapp of York Shire with its Divisions and Hundreds

div2.p: YORKSHIRE, by the Saxons called Ebona-y-oyne, the largest County in all England, extending it self in length from Flamborow-head in the East, to Horn-Castle in the West, about 80 miles; and in breadth from Hart-hill in the South, to the mouth of the River Tees in the North, about 70; making in circumference about 308 miles. And although thus spacious, is every where blest with a wholsome and temperate air; and for the generallity is reasonable fertile, yielding sufficiency of corn and cattle for the Inhabitants; for if one part is stony, sandy and barren, another is richly adorned with Cornfields and pasturage: If in one place you find it naked of woods, in other places it is sufficiently clothed therewith; and if in one place it be wet, moorish, miry, and unpleasant, in others it is most delectable to behold. One part of this Shire is particularly famous for its Quarry of stone, which when newly taken out are very soft, but when seasoned with the wind and weather, do of themselves become exceeding hard and solid, and therefore generally hewed when they are taken up. Also another part of this County is of great note for its Limestone, which being burnt, is very good for the manuring the grounds that are hilly and cold. Temperature of Soil. Its Divisior.

This Shire being thus capacious, for the more easie and better ordering of her civil Government, is severed into three parts or divisions, viz. the North Riding, the East Riding, and the West Riding, which are subdivided into 26 Hundreds, or Wapontacks; And although there are numbred but 563 Parish Churches in this large track, yet is it very populous, full of Gentry, and hath great plenty of Chappels of Ease, which for bigness are equal to Parishes in other parts of England. Very popu-lous. Its bounds.

It hath for its Eastern limits the German Ocean; for its Southern, the large River (which severeth it from Lincolnshire, and receiveth the several Rivers which so plentifully water this County) with the Counties of Nottingham, Darby, and Cheshire; for its Western, those of Lancashire and Westmoreland; and for its Northern, the Bishoprick of Durham.
The Romans very powerful in York shire.

The Romans much slourished in this County, and had several stations, which is made manifest by the several Monuments of Inscriptions,Columns, Altars, and the like, that have oft-times been digged up ; for it seemeth shire. they had local and peculiar Topick Gods, whom they honoured as Keepers of some particular places of the Countrey. Religious houses.

Here are dispersed in this County aboundance of Abbeys, Monasteries, and Religious Houses, famous in their time before their desolution by King Henry the Eighth; and such were Whitby-Abbey, founded by the Lady Hilda Granchild to King Edwine ; Bolton-Abbey, kirkstall-Abbey, St.Maries in York, now the Princes House, and called the Manour ; the wealthy Abbey of Fountains; the famous Monastery founded by Wilfrid Arch-bishop of York in the time of the East-Saxons ; also Drax, a Religious House of Chanons ; Selby-Abbey, built by William the Conquerour, where his Son Henry the First was born, Rivas- Abbey, Gisbrough- Abbey, with some others. Its Commo-dities and Manufactures

This County is well stored with cattle,corn,sowl, and sish, it produceth divers good Manufactures; as Stockings, Allom, Jett, Lime, Knives, Pinns, but above all Cloth in great plenty. But to proceed to each Division or Riding, and then the sirst shall be

div2.n: THE North-Riding OF YORK SHIRE
div2.head: THE North-Riding OF YORK SHIRE.
div2.p: This part is of a large extent, and hath on the East the River Derwent, which severeth it from the East-Riding ; and the Sea-coast with the River Tees (which divides it from the Bishoprick of Durham) is its Northern limits ; on the West it hath Westmoreland ; and on the South the West-Riding. And this part is severed into eleven Wapentakes, and may not improperly be divided into Richmondshire, (which I shall particularly take notice of) Cleveland, a fertie part, which is honoured in giving Title to Barbara Villiers, Baroness of Nonsuch, Countess of Southampton, and Castlemain, and Dutchess of Cleveland during life. North-Allertonshire, and Blackmoor which lyeth on the Sea-shoar, where it is a black moorish Land, and very Mountainous and Craggy, but advantaged by many pleasant and fertile Dales. The chief places in this Riding are York.

York, which next to London claimeth Priority of all other Cities in England; a place of great antiquity and fame, having Its rise from the Romans, who had it in such great esteem, that Severus their Emperour here had his Palace, where he ended his days, and had those Funeral Rites solemnized on his Corps, according to their Custom, due to so great a person ; and his body being consumed by the Funeral Fire, his Ashes was put into a Vessel of the Porphyrat-stone, and carryed to Rome, and there shrined
in the Monuments of the Antonines. And here Fl. Valerius Constantius surnamed Chlorus, bid adue to the world, and in his room his son constantine was here forthwith proclaimed Emperour. Nor did this City thus flourish only under the Romans, but also was of great reputation in all succeeding Ages ; and in the several turns and changes that this Kingdom hath met with under the Saxons, Danes, and Normans, this City (though a fellow-sufferer with the rest) hath, through the helping hand and countenance of the Nobility and Gentry, still preserved its ancient lustre, and is at this present a fair, large, and beautiful City, adorned with many splendid buildings, both publick and private, is very populous, much resorted unto, and well inhabited by Gentry, and wealthy Trades-men, and numbreth about 30 Parish (hurches and Chappels, besides its Cathedral or Minster, a most magnisicent Structure, sirst built by Edwyn King of the Northumbers in Anno 627. and finished by King Oswald his Successor, and dedicated to St.Peter ; but that being destroyed by fire, as also by the Danes, that which now standeth upon the coming of the Normans, was began to be built by Arch-bishop Thomas, and by his Successors by degrees brought to what it is at present. The Diocess conteining the Counties of York and Nottingham, and for Ecclesiastical Government hath four Arch-Deacons,viz. of York, Cleveland,East-Riding, and Nottingham. Amongst its publick buildings of note, these may be taken notice of, The Bishops Palace, its Chapter-house, a curious piece of Architect; the Princes House, commonly called the Mannor; and the Courts of Judicature held for the neighbouring Marshes, according to that of Ludlow. This City is no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the River Owse, which severeth it into two parts, but joyned together by a stately Stone-bridge susteined by five Arches, one of which is very stately and large, and of these parts, that towards the East is most populous, the Houses standing thicker, and the Streets narrower. It is a place of great strength, being well fortified, and enclosed with a strong Wall, on which are many Turrets, or Watch-houses, and hath for entrance four Gates and five Posterns. It is a City and County within it self, enjoyeth large immunities, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and is not a little honoured in giving Title to the Illustrious James Duke of York, &c. sole Brother to his Majesty K.Charles the Second; is governed by a Lord Maior, twelve Aldermen clad in Scarlet, two Sherifss, 72 Common-councel-men, 6 Chamberleyns, a Recorder,Town-Clark, Sword-bearer, and common Sergeant, who with a great Mace goeth on the left hand of the Sword, as at London; and to conclude, its Markets which are on Thursdays and Saturdays, are very considerable, and well served with flesh,fish, and fowl, &c. as are its Shambles on the week dayes with provisions. Maiton.

Malton, or New-Malton, seated on the River Derwent, over which it hath a good Stone-bridge: It is composed of two Towns, the one New- Malton, and the other Old, and both conteining three Parish Churches; 'tis a place well inhabited, and accommodated with good Inns; hath two Markets weekly, on Tuesdays, which is of no long standing, and on Saturdays, which is one of the best in all the County for horses,living cattle, provisions, and most Country commodities, especially utensels for Husbandry ; and as a Borough-town (which is but meanly built) it giveth its Vote in Parliament by two Burgesses, and the Lords of this Mannor have a Market by prescription every Saturday. Pickering.

Pickering, or the Honour of Pickering, seated on a small Brook,a pretty good Town belonging to the Dutchy of Lancaster, hath a famous old Castle, now ruinous, in which they keep their Courts for the hearing of all causes
between party and party under 40 s. in the said Honour, which includeth several Villages, which as it were encompasseth it ; so that the adjacent Country is called Pickering Lith, the Forest of Pickering, and the Liberty of Pickering. And the Market is here Kept on Mondays, which is very well served with corn and Provisions. Kirby-More side.
Kirby-Moreside, scituate on the edge of the Moors, and near the River Dow; an indifferent Town, and hath a well frequented Market on Wednesdays for corn and cattle. Helmley.
Helmley, seated by the River Rye, and a Brook running through it ; an indifferent built Town of slate and stone-houses, strengthned with a Castle, and hath a good Market on Saturdays. Scarborough.

Scarborough, a place of great strength as well by Nature as Art, being seated on a steep Rock with such craggy Cliffs, that it is almost on every side inaccessible, and beareth so into the Sea, that it is washed with its Waves on all parts, except on the West, where it yieldeth access by a streight Passage, Cliff, or Gullet, where it hath a strong Wall. On the top of this Rock is a very fair, green, and large Plain, conteining above 60 Acres of ground, and hath a little Well of Fresh-water springing out of the Rock. For its further defence it hath a strong Castle, now made use of as a Garison for his Majesty; and here there was formerly a stately Tower which served as a Land-mark for Ships, which was demolished in the late unhappy Wars. This Town is not very large, but well-built and inhabited, 'tis a Town-Corporate, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by two Bailiffs, and a Common-councel, enjoyeth a good trade, having a commodious Key, and several Vessels belonging unto it, which are imployed by them, especially during the Herring-sishing season, which are taken on this Coast in exceeding great plenty: This place is also of note for its famous Spaw; much resorted unto as well by Foreigners, as by the English; and hath weekly two Markets, on Thursdays which is of good account, and on Saturdays which is but small. Robin Hoods Bay.
Near unto Scarborough is Robin Hoods Bay, so called from Robin Hood that noted Robber in the Reign of Richard the First; and here is found Jett or black Amber. Whitby.

Whitby, commodiously setted on the River Esk, at its influx into the Sea, over which it hath a Wooden-bridge. It is a well-built Town, enjoyeth a considerable trade, (chiesly for Allom, and Butter, called Whitby- butter) there belonging to it about 100 Sail of Vessels, and hath a Custom- house, and would be more considerable were its Peer finished. Here Market, which is on Saturdays, is very great, and well served with flesh, fish,fowl, &c. St. Hilda.Stones resem bling Serpent without Heads.

This place is famous for its St. Hilda Abbess of this Abbey, a woman of so holy life, that Miracles are attributed to have been wrought by her;for according to common tradition,this place was much infected with Snakes, and upon her fervent Prayers they were all destroyed, and conjured into the Sea; but the truth of this I shall not undertake to maintain, only thus much may be credibly averred, that at this day there are stones found in the Sea-sands resembling Snakes without heads, foulded and wrapped together like a wreath. Mulgrave.

Not far from Whitby is Mulgrave, pleasantly seated within a Park near the Sea; an ancient and beautiful Castle, which gives name to the Right Honorable John Sheffield Earl of Mulgrave, &c. Skeningrave.

On this Coast is seated Skeningrave, a small Town, bnt well frequented by Fisher-men. And near unto Hunt-cliff, not far from the Shoar, at a
low water, water, appeareth Rocks, about which the Seal-fish come in great sholes, and lye sleeping and sunning themselves in fair and warm weather; and according to observation, whilst these fish do thus sleep, there is one of them which continually watcheth as a sentinel, and when any danger approacheth, by flinging themselves into the water, and making a flouncing noise, the others are wakened, and by that means escape: And on this Coast are several other Towns seated, the names of which do appear in the Mapp. Seal-fish in great plenty. Gisborough.

Gisborough, delightfully seated on a Flat, and within four miles of the mouth of the Tees; of some note for being the first place in England where Allom was made: 'tis a mean Town, to what it was when it had its rich Abbey; yet is it indifferent good, and hath a Market on Mondays for provisions. Ounsbery.

Not far from Gisborough is Ounsbery, or Rosebery-Topping, highly elevated like a Piramid, and serveth as a Land-mark to Sailers: and near the top of which is a pleasant Spring, and a Cave in a Rock. And near unto Ounsbery is Ayton, remarkable for its Well which cures divers diseases in the body of man by bathing in it. Ayton. Stokesly.
Stokesly, well watered with fresh streams; a reasonable good Town, and hath a well frequented Market on Saturdays for corn, flesh and fish. Yarum.
Yarum, seated on the Tees, over which it hath a very fine Stone-bridge, which divides this County from the Bishoprick of Durham; the Town is but mean, and hath a Market on Thursdays. Vale of Ridale
In this Track is the Vale of Ridale, a fertile and pleasant place, wherein are seated 23 Parish Churches. North-Allerton

North-Allerton, seated near the River Swale, a large Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, and hath a great Market on Wednesdays for horses, cattle, corn, and provisions, and is a good Town of trade. Thrusk.
Thrusk, a small Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, where there was once a most strong Castle; hath a little Market on Mondays, and is at present of some note for its good Ale.

div2.head: Richmondshire.

figure.head: A Mapp of Richmond Shire, being part of the North Rideing of Yorke Shire

p.note: Richmondshire very moun-tainous, hath Mines of Lead, &c.

div2.p: THE other part of this Riding goeth by the name of RICHMONDSHIRE, so called from a Castle therein seated. It conteineth within its Jurisdiction five Wapentakes, to wit, those of Hang-east, Hang-west, Gilling-east, Gilling-west, and Hailikeld; It lyeth very high, is mountainous and rocky ; it hath good Mines of Lead, Copper, and Pitcoal; is interlaced with fertile Valleys, and hath for its chief places Richmond.

Richmond, first built by Alane Earl of Bretagn, soon after the coming of the Normans, who fenced it about with a Wall (which gives entrance by three Gates, which leadeth into so many Suburbs) and fortified it with a most strong Castle, highly seated on a Rock, the better to secure himself against the violent assaults of the Danes and English, reposing little trust in his Mannor-house of Gilling, not far distnat, which was a place more noted for Religion then strength. This Town is seated on the Northern banks of the Swale, where it hath a Stone-bridge: A River so rapid, that it rusheth rather then runneth among the stones, and was esteemed by the
ancient English very sacred, for that in it Paulinut, the first Arch-bishop of York, in one day baptized above 10000 men, besides women and children: And as to its present state, it is a large Town-Corporate, conteining two Churches, is graced with well-built Houses, many of which are of Free-stone, hath the accommodation of paved and well ordered streets, hath a spacious Market-place; is honoured in giving Title to the Right Noble Charles Duke of Richmond and Lennox, &c. enjoyeth large immunities, hath a Court of Record for all Actions, both real and personal, without limitation of sum for the said Liberty, and is governed by a Maior and Aldermen, with other Sub-Officers. It is also well inhabited by Gentry and Trades-men, enjoyeth a great trade (for an Inland Town) for stockings, and woolen knit Caps for Seamen; and hath a very considerable Market for cattle and provisions on Saturdays. Catarrick.

About three miles below Richmond, and on the said River Swale is seated the small Village of Catarrick, and Catarrick-bridge, which Ptolomy and Antonine call Caturactonium, and Bede Catarractan, and was an ancient City of the Romans, which is evidenced by the heaps of Rubbish, and other things of remark. Bedall.
Bedall, seated on a little Brook; a small Town, but hath a good Market on Tuesdays for corn and provisions. Masham.
Masham, scituate on the Owse; a small Market-Town on Tuesdays. Albrough.
Not far from this Town, and on the Roman Northern High-road or Street is Albrough, an ancient Borough-town, which hath the election of Parliament men. Middleham.
Middleham, seated on the Owse, and not far from Bishops-dale Chase, which hath an indifferent Market on Mondays. Bolton-Castle.
Nigh unto this Town is Bolton-Castle, seated in a Park, once a stately building. Askrigg.
Askrigg, a very small and inconsiderable Markettown Bainthridge, or Burgh.

Further Westwards is Bainthridge, scituate on the Ure, which was a Garison of the Romans; for on the top of a Hill, was a Fort or Hold, which conteined about five Acres of ground in compass, and is now called Burgh, where Mr.Cambden faith he saw many pieces of Roman Antiquities.
In this Track of Richmondshire are many waste places void of Inhabitants, and such are Swale-dale-Forest, Applearnth-Earest Deep-dele and others.

div2.n: THE East-Riding OF YORKSHIRE.
div2.head: THE East-Riding OF YORKSHIRE.

figure.head: A Mapp of the East Rideing of Yorkshire with its Wapontack

div2.p: THis Part is separated from the rest of the County by the River Darwent, which after a long and crooked course falleth into the Humber, which divides it from Lincolnshire; and for its Eastern bounds it hath the German Ocean. The parts lying on, or near the Sea-shoar, and the banks of the Darwent, are of a good soil, and fertile; but the midst (which is known by the name of Yorks-wold) is very billy and barren. It is the least part by much, yet is it severed into 6 Wapentakes, and hath for its chief places Hull.

Hull, or Kingston upon Hull; a Town of no great Antiquity, being first built by King Edward the First, who called it Kingston, where he made an Haven, and a Free Burgh, making the Inhabitants free Burgesses, and granting unto them ample immunities and liberties; so that by little and little it grew to what it is, being at present a very large Town, (though conteining but two Parish Churches) graced with fair buildings, and well ordered, and paved streets, which are sufficiently replenished with Shopkeepers, one of which resembleth Thames-street in London near the Bridge, where Pitch, Tar, Cordage, Sails, and other necessaries for ships are vended, and to which the Ships and Vessels come to lade, and unlade their Merchandizes, having a Custom-house and Key; and the commodious scituation of this Town, hath made it to be a place very well inhabited, and much resorted unto by Merchants, being furnished with shipping and all sorts of commodities in great plenty, which they have from Foreign parts, as well as from other parts of this Kingdom, being inferiour to none in England, except London and Bristoll. It is seated on the mouth of the River Hull, where it falleth into the Humber, and is a place of exceeding great strength, being able to bid defiance both to a Navy, and a Land-Army, and that by reason of its strong Block-houses, Castles, Walls, Forts, Trenches, and the Inhabitants and Souldiers within it, being at present a considerable Garison of his Majesties, under the command of the Right Honorable John Lord Bellasis, Lord Lieutenant of this Riding. It is a Town, and County Incorporate of it self, as also a Borough-town, electing Parliament men, hath for its chief Magistrates a Maior, 12 Aldermen, a Common-councel, and other Sub-officers; and gives Title of Earldom to the Right Honorable Henry Marquess of Dorchester, Earl of Kingston upon Hull,&c. It is very well served with provisions, its Shambles and other places being every day well furnished therewith, but its chief and great Market is on Saturdays. Great store of Herrings here taken.

In these Seas are taken in the season aboundance of Herrings, which are found very profitable to the Inhabitants.
Houlderness.

From Hull there runneth a Promontory, which shooteth it self forth far into the Sea, and is called Houlderness, which Ptolomy calleth Ocellum, in which are divers Towns; and this place is honoured in giving Title of Earldom, to his Grace Rupert Count Palatine of the Rhine, Duke of Cumberland, Earl of Houlderness, &c. Headon.

Headon, seated on a River, which soon falleth into the Humber, an ancient Borough-town, formerly of great account, and enjoyed a good trade; but the rise of its neighbour Hull hath wrought its ruin, being at present but mean; yet doth it send Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by a Maior, twelve Aldermen, and Sub-Officers, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. Patrington.

Not far from this place is Patrington, a Town of a pleasant scituation, and in former time of good account, where the Roman High-way from the Picts-wall ended, and was by Antonine called Prætorium. The Sprunhead.
Farther Southwards, this Promontory draweth to a narrow point, and is called the Sprun-head, a place not unknown to Seamen that frequent this Coast.
Along the Eastern Coast are divers Towns seated, whose names appear in the Mapp. Flamborough-head.

Flamborough-head, which shooteth it self forth into a little Promontory or Cape, is a place well known to Seamen; and 'tis said that Ida the Saxon, who first subdued these parts, arived and landed here: And this Promontory gives name to a Town near adjoyning. Bridlington.

Bridlington, or Burlington, a Sea-port- town, seated in a Creek, and near Flamborough-head; hath a safe Road for Ships to ride in, and a very good and commodious Key for Ships to lade and unlade at, which hath occasioned it (of late) to be a place of a good trade, and its Market, which is on Saturdays, to be well furnished with provisions,&c. It is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Richard Boyle, Earl of Burlington and Cork, &c. Kilham.
Kilham, dryly seated on the Woulds, and in a good soil for corn; a long Town, and hath a mean Market on Thursdays. Driffield.
Not far from Kilham is Driffield, of note for its Tomb of the learned Alfred King of the Northumbers; nigh unto which is Yorks Woulds. Pocklington.
Pocklington, seated on a small River which falleth into the Derwent; a little Town, and hath a mean Market on Saturdays. Wighton.
Wighton, scituate at the Spring-head of the River Skelflet; a small Town, and hath a little Market on Wednesdays. Beverley.

Beverley, seated on the River Hull, which gives passage into the Humber for boats and barges, for the conveyance of their Goods to and fro It is a large and well-built Borough and Town-Corporate, conteining two Parish Churches, besides its Minster, enjoyeth very large priviledges, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, is governed by a Maior, twelve Aldermen, and other Sub-Officers; is a place well inhabited by Gentry and Tradesmen; and its Markets, which are on Thusdays and Saturdays, are well served with provisions. This place is of some note for being the burial place of John de Beverley Arch-bishop of York, who being weary of the world, resigned up his Bishoprick, and here ended his days in a holy life about the Year of Christ 721. Meux Abbey
Not far from this place is Meux Abbey, a once very flourishing place. Howden.

Howden, seated near the Rivers Owse and Derwent, a good large Town, which gives name to a small Territory called Howdensbire, where there was sometime since a pretty Collegiate Church of five Prebendaries; and hath a very great Market on Saturdays for cattle, corn, provisions,&c.
Stamford-bridge.

At Stamford-bridge, or Battle-bridge, about nine dayes before the coming of William the Conquerour, Harald King of England, after a great slaughter committed on the Danes, in a pitcht Battel slew Harald Hardread K. of Norway, who with a Fleet of about 200 Sail of ships sorely pestered the Kingdom, and was then newly landed at Riccal, committing great spoils in the parts where he came. And the King of England having the honour of the Field, (as Cambden noteth) had as much Gold (which was there found) as twelve lusty men could carry away.

div2.n: THE West-Riding OF YORKSHIRE.
div2.head: THE West-Riding OF YORKSHIRE.

figure.head: A Mapp of the West Ridinge of Yorke Shire: With its Wapontakes

div2.p: THis Part is the largest of all, and is bounded on the East by Lamroke Dike, which divides it from Lincolnshire; on the South by the Counties of Derby, Nottingham, and Cheshire; the West by Lancashire; and on the North by the North and East Ridings. It is severed into nine Wapentakes; is every where well watered with Rivers, and replenished with good Towns, whose names are as followeth. Halifax.

Halifax, of old Horton, seated in a barren soil, upon a steep descent of an Hill, and on a branch of the River Calder; a place famous as well for being the birth-place of Johannes de sacro Bosco, the Inventor of the Sphære, and for its strict Law in the sudden beheading of such as are taken in the act of Theft; as for the largeness of the Parish, conteining eleven Chappels of Ease, of which two are Parish Chappels; and for its numbering about 12000 Inhabitants, by whose industry in the making of Cloth and other Manufactures, they have gained to themselves a very good trade and esteem in the Kingdom. It is a good fair Town, graced with Stone-built Houses, and well ordered and paved Streets, and hath a considerable Market for corn, provisions, &c. on Thursdays. Cambden, pag. 692. the reason of the Towns name. Almondbury.

About six miles from Halifax, near the Calder, and on a steep Hill, is seated Almondbury, which was the ancient Cambodunum, where there was a Fort and Castle, long since reduced to ruins; and is said to have been a place of great repute when the English Saxons first began their Regal Government, being then the Kings Town, and had in it a Cathedral Church, built by Paulinus the Apostle of these parts, and dedicated to St. Alban. Gretland. Cambden, pag. 691.

At Gretland near the Spring-head of the Calder, on the top of a high Hill (which is not to be ascended but on one side) was formerly dug up a Votive Altar, erected to the tutelar God of the whole State of the Brigantes. Barnesley.

Barnesley, commonly called black Barnesley, from the colour of the soil, and from a Collery near unto it, it is seated on a Hill-side, and near a
Brook; 'tis a reasonable well-built Town with Stone-houses, and hath a good Market on Wednesdays for provisions, mault, all sorts of grains, and wyer here made, which is the only Manufacture of this place. Sheafield.

Sheafield, watered with the River Don or Dune, once fortified with a strong Castle, till demolished in the late Wars, and is of chief note for the great quantity of Smiths there inhabiting (by reason of the many Iron Mines in these parts) who drive a good trade for all sorts of Edgetoles, and other things of Iron, especially Knives, called Sheafield Blades here made; a Manufacture so ancient, that Mr. Chaweer in one of his stories takes notice of a person with a Sheafield Whittle by his side: The Town is large, its Houses built of stone, and hath a great Market on Tuesdays for several commodities, especially corn, which is much bought up for the supply of some parts of Darbyshire, Nottinghamshire, and the West of Yorkshire.

On the River Don were seated five Castles, all within ten miles distance, of which Sheafield is one, supposed by its ruinous form, and the several Medals there found, to be built by the Romans, as was Temples-brough, where there was a Temple dedicated to Diana, now the Inheritance of Sir John Reresby of Thribergh Baronet. Strafford and Tickhill Wapentake.
The large Wapentake in which this Town of Sheafield, with divers others are seated, gives Title to the Right Honorable William Wentworth, Earl of Strafford,&c. Rotheram.

Rotheram, seated on the Don, over which it hath a fine Stone-bridge, of note for giving birth to Thomas Rotheram Arch-bishop of York, who there founded a Colledge, with three Schools for the instructing of Youth in Grammer, Musick, and VVriting, but long since laid aside. The Town is well- built with Stone-houses, and hath a very great Market on Mondays for provisions and cattle. At Conisbrough a bloody battel fought.

At Conisbrough not far distant, there was a most bloody battel fought between Hengist Captain of the English-Saxons, and the Britains, which proved unfortunate to Hengist; and as 'tis said, with the loss of his life, his Head being chopt off by the Enemy: And here is the remainder of a large strong Castle, said to be built by the Romans. Tickhill.

Tickhill, which gives name to one part of this VVapentake, yet reteineth something of its ancient Castle and Fortisications, which were demo'ished in the late Wars. It hath a distinct Liberty called the Honour of Tickhill, is part of the Dutchy of Lancaster; and hath a Market on Saturdays. Bautre.

Bautre, scituate in the edge of the County towards Nottinghamshire; a small Town, but of great trade for Mill-stones and Grind-stones, which are brought hither up the River, and hath an indifferent good Market on Saturdays. Doncaster.

Doncaster, quasi Duncastle from its Castle, now reduced to ruin; it is seated on the Done, and on the great Road to London; an ancient Town, of good Antiquity, where the Captain of the Crispian Horsemen lay in Garison under the General of Britain. In Anno 759 this Town suffered much, a great part, with its Citadel being consumed with fire, and for some time lay in its ruins; but in the end was rebuilt, with a fair Church erected in the place where the Citadel stood, and dedicated to St. George; It is a large, well-built, and inhabited Town-Corporate, governed by a Maior and Aldermen; is honoured in giving Title of Earldom to his Grace James Duke of Monmouth, Earl of Doncaster, &c. it enjoyeth a good trade, especially for Stockings, knit VVaistcoats, Petticoats, and Gloves; and hath a very good Market for corn, cattle, provisions, &c. on Saturdays.
Snath.
Snath, seated on the River Are, a small Town, and hath a little Market on Saturdays. Mersh-land, Ditch-mersh.
In this part is a little Mersh Country of about fifteen miles in clrcuit, which produceth excellent feeding for cattle, called Mersh-land, and Ditch-mersh. Selby.

Selby, honoured by giving birth to King Henry the First, is seated on the Owse, which gives passage for small Vessels to York, by reason of which it is a great Town of some trade, and hath a good Market on Mondays for merchandize and provisions. Sherborne.

Sherborne, a small, but well inhabited Town, where there is a famous Free-School; it is seated on a River which soon falleth into the Owse; hath a little Market on Saturdays. And is noted for its Pins and Cherries. Barwick in Elmet.
Not far from Sherborne, at the Springhead of the River Coc, is seated Barwick in Elmet, which was the Royal Seat of the Kings of Northumberland. A bloody battel fought at Towton.

And at Towton (on Palm- Sunday in Anno 1461.) was sought that bloody conslict between the Houses of York and Lancaster, in which Combate there appeared in the Field (as partakers on both sides) about 100000 fighting men; amongst which were aboundance of the Nobility and Gentry of the Nation: The success seemed a great part of the day very dubious, but in the end Fortune favoured the House of York, with a notable Victory over the Lancastrians: And in this fight there are said to have been slain in the Field about 30000 English men. Ponfract.

Ponfract, very delightfully seated in a sine dry track of ground (where groweth Liquorice and Skiriworts in great plenty) and in a small branch of the River Are: It is a neat Town-Corporate, adorned with fair buildings, was once strengthened with a most strong and stately Castle, mounted on an ascent, and fortified with Ditches and Bulwarks, but was demolished in the late Wars; 'tis governed by a Maior and Aldermen, sendeth Burgesses to Parliament, and hath a very great Market for corn, cattle, provisions, and divers Country commodities on Saturdays. Wakefield.

Wakefield, seated in a Seigniory or Lordship so called, which taketh up a good track of ground, and hath its Steward, who is generally a Gentleman of good repute that inhabiteth therein: It is a large Town, of good Antiquity, beautified with well-built Stone-houses, and where there is a fair Stone-bridge, upon which King Edward the Fourth erected a splendid Chappel in remembrance of those who lost their lives in battel; 'tis a place well known for its clothing here made; and hath a great Market on Thursdays and Fridays for cloth, corn, provisions, and divers Country commodities. Bradforth.
Bradforth, seated on a branch of the Are; a Stone-built Town, and hath a Market on Thursdays. Leeds.

Leeds, scituate on the Are, an ancient Town, where formerly the Kings had their Royal Palace; and here Oswy King of the Northumbers put to flight Penda the Mercian. It is at present a large and well-built Town-Corporate, governed by a Maior and Aldermen, with other Sub-Officers, electeth Parliament men, is very well inhabited, especially by wealthy Clothiers, who drive a great trade for their cloth; and hath two considerable Markets on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are well traded unto for corn, provisions, woollen-cloth, and divers good commodities. Otley.

Otley, seated on the River Wherf, and under a high and craggy Cliff, called Chevin, an ordinary Stone-built Town, which hath a Market on Tuesdays for corn and provisions.
Wetherly.
Wetherly, seated on the Wherf, a small Town, but hath a good Market on Thursdays. Tadcaster.

Tadcaster, of note for the Lime-stone here digged up in great plenty, which is bought up by the neighbouring Inhabitants, for the making of Morter. It hath a small Market on Thursdays; and here is a large Stonebridge over the River Wherf. Knaresbrough.

Knaresbrough, delightfully seated on the River Nid, and on a ragged rough Rock, where there is a Castle. It is a well-built Town-Corporate, electing Parliament men, and hath a good Market for corn and provisions on Wednesdays.

Nigh unto this place in a Moorish boggy ground, ariseth a Spring of Vitrioline taste and odour: And not far off is also a Sulpher Well, which is good for several diseases. Here is also a dropping petrefying Well, which turns wood, moss, &c. into stone. Ripley.
Ripley, seated on the Nid, over which it hath a bridge, a very small Market-town on Fridays. Borough-bridge.

Borough-bridge, seated on the High-road, and on the River Yore, over which there is a large and fair Stone-bridge. It is a small Borough-town, which electeth Parliament men, and hath a Market, or rather a Meeting on Saturdays for provisions. Pyramids.

Mr. Camben saith, that near this Town in three little fields, he saw four huge Stones, rudely wrought, placed in a direct line, like unto so many Pyramids, which he believeth to be erected by the Romans, as a signal of some Victory obteined by them; although the Country people do call them the Devils bolts, and foolishly conceit they were such as he used to shoot at ancient Cities to destroy them. Devils bolts. And to confirm this their opinion, it seemeth a little Eastwards from this place, stood the ancient City Is-vrium Brigantum, many Ages ago laid flat to the ground, and the place where it stood is imployed for tillage and pasturage. Ancient City of Is-vrium Brigantum. And near unto it is raised (as out of its ruins) the Village or Town of Aldbrough, or Old-Borrow. Rippon. St. Wilfrids Needle.

Rippon, seated between the River Yore, and a branch thereof, over which are two bridges, the one above, and the other below the Town.
