It is a place of good Antiquity, and of much same for its Religious Houses, but especially for its stately Monastery built by Wilfrid Arch-bishop of York, which being destroyed (with the Town) by the merciless Danes, was again repaired by the helping hand of Odo Arch-bishop of Canterbury, who translated from hence to Canterbury the Reliques of Wilfrid, and upon the coming of the Normans it began to be in a flourishing condition, and thrived well by its clothing. It is at present a large and well-built Town Corporate, governed by a Maior and Aldermen, hath the election of Parliament men, and is beautified with a very fine Cathedral Church, which pleaseth the eye of the beholder by its three lofty Spire- steeples; and in this Church was St. Wilfrids Needle, a place famous in our Fore-fathers days, being a narrow hole in the close vaulted Room under ground, in which place (as 'tis reported, but believe it who will) womens honesty was used to be tryed, for according to the story, those that were chast could easily pass through, but the kind-hearted souls were (by an unknown means) held fast, and could not creep through. The Town is well inhabited by Gentry, and its Market which is on Thursdays, is very great for cattle, corn, provisions, and chiesly for wool, which is much bought up by the Clothiers of Leeds. Michelholme-hill.

Not far from this Town is the losty Hill of Michelholme.
Skipton.

Skipton, seated near the River Are, in a rough, stony, craggy, hilly, and unpleasant part of the Country called Craven, which of late is honoured by giving Title to the Right Honorable William Earl of Craven, &c. The Town (for the manner of their building amongst the Hills) is fair enough, and its Market which is on Saturdays is very great. Settle.
Settle, seated on the River Rible, hath a pretty good Market on Tuesdays. Gigleswick. Spring of water.

Nigh unto this Town is Gigleswick, where there are (according to Speed) certain small Springs, very near to each other, the middlemost of which doth almost every quarter of an hour ebb and flow, about a quarter of a yard when at the Highest, and at ebb falleth so low, that it is not an Inch deep with water. And this part of the County is exceeding hilly.

THE Island of Great Britain in ancient time was divided into three parts. The first, fairest, and greatest, contained all within the French Seas, the Rivers of Severn, Dee, and Humber, and was called Lhoyger, which name in Welch it still reteineth, and in English, England. The second, took up all the Land Northwards from the Humber, to the Orkney Isles, and was called Mare Caledonium, or Deucaledonium, and now Scotland; and the third, lying between the Irish Seas, the Rivers of Severn and Dee, was anciently called Cambria, and now Wales: to which the Britains being outed of their Country, were forced to retire, and there fortified themselves. The bounds of Wales.

This Country of Wales is bounded on all sides by the Sea, except towards England, from which it is separated by the River Dee, and a line drawn to the River Wye: but anciently it extended to the River Severn Eastwards, for Offa King of the Mercians forced them to leave the plain Countries beyond that River, (which now is called the Marches of Wales) and to betake themselves to the Mountains, which he caused to be separated from England by a great Ditch, called Offa's Dike, in Welch Claudh Offa, in many places yet to be seen; which Dike beginneth at the inslux of the Wye into the Severn, and reacheth unto Chester, which is about 84 miles, where the Dee disburthens it self into the Sea. And over this Dike, by a Law made by Harald, no Welchman was permitted to pass with a weapon upon pain of loosing his right hand. offa's Dike. Its Commodities.

The whole Country is generally mountainous and barren, yet affordeth several good commodities, and is not without many fertile Valleys which bear good corn, and breedeth aboundance of small cattle, with which they furnlsh England; as also with butter, cheese, woollen-cloths, called Welch Freezes, cottons, bays, herrings both white and red, calve-skins, hides, honey, wax, &c. and the Country is well stored with Quarries of Free-stone for building, and Mill-stones; also hath Mines of Lead, Lead-ore, Coals, and some of
Silver and Tinn. And these commodities are generally brought to Shrewsbury, Oswestre, Bristoll, Worcester, and other adjacent parts, and thence dispersed into all England. Its ancient division.

About the year of Christ 870, Rodericus Magnus King of Wales did divide this Country into three Regions, Territories, or Talaiths, which were so many Kingdoms, to wit, Gwineth, Venedotia, or North-wales, and this part he gave to Anarawd his eldest Son; Deheubarth, or South-Wales, which he gave to Cadelh his second Son: And Powis, or Powis-land, which he gave to Meruin his third Son. And in each of these three Kingdoms he ordained a Royal Palace, as at Aberffraw in the Isle of Anglesey for Northwales; at Dynefar, or Dynevowr-Castle, not far from Carmarthen for South- Wales; and at Matravan in Montgomeryshire, for Powis-land. North-Wales in ancient time.

North-Wales, being the portion of his eldest Son, he ordained that the other two parts should each of them pay him 200 l. per ann. by way of Tribute. It conteined all the ground which is now known unto us by the Counties of Anglesey, Carnarvon, Merioneth, Flint, and Denbeigh; which said parts being the most mountainous, and of the difficultest access, were the last that were subdued by the English. And this part was bounded on the North with the Irish Sea, from the River Dee at Bassingwerke to Aberdyni; upon the West, and South-west by the River Dyni, which severed it from South-Wales, and some places from Powis-land; and on the South and East, it was divided from Powis-land, sometimes by high Hills, and sometimes by Rivers, until it came again to the River Dee: And this part is generally very mountainous, and full of craggy Rocks, deep Valleys, great Woods, and swift streamed Rivers. Its division and parts. Mon, now the Isle of Anglesey.

This Territory or Kingdom was then divided into four parts, of which the chiefest was called Mon, which in English is the Isle of Anglesey, and had in it three Cantreds or Hundreds, which were subdivided into six Comots; as the Cantref Aberfraw had the Comots of Lhion, and Malhtraeth; the Cantref Cemais, the Comots of Talebolion and Twr Celyn; and the Cantref Rossyr, the Comots of Tindaethwy and Mænai. Arvon, now Carnarvonshire.

The second Part of North- Wales was called Arvon, which now beareth the name of Carnarvonshire, and had in it four Cantreds, and ten Comots; viz. the Cantref Aber had the Comots of Nanconway, Y Lhechwedhvchaf, and Y Lhechwedhisaf. The Cantref Arvon had the Comots of Isgwyruai, and Ywch Gwyruai. The Cantref Lhyyn had the Comots of Cymytmayn, Canologion, and Tinlhayn: And the Cantref of Dunodic, which conteined the Comots of Ardudwy and Evionyth. Gwyneth, now Merioneth-shire.

The third part of North- Wales was called Gwyneth, which now is known by the name of Merionethshire; and conteined three Cantreds, and in every Cantred three Comots; viz. the Cantref Arustly, which had the Comots of Gwarthrenion, Iscoed, and Vwchcoed. The Cantref Meyreon had the Comots of Pennal, Talybout, and Ystumaner: And the Cantref of Penlhyn, had the Comots of Vwchmeloch, Micnaint, and Ismeloch. Y Beruedh-wlad, or the middle Country.

The fourth and last part of North-Wales was called Y Beruedhwlad, which may be called in English the middle Country, and conteined five Cantreds, and thirteen Comots; viz. the Cantref Ryvonioc, had the Comots of Isalet and Vwchalet. The Cantref Ystrat, had the Comots of Cynmeirch and Hiraethoc. The Cantef, Dyffryn Clwyd, now called the Lordship of Ruthin, had the Comots of Lhannerch, Coleigion, and Dogueilyn. The Cantref Ros, had the Comots of Creuthin, Vwchdulas, and Isdulas: And the Cantref Tegengl, which is now part of Flintshire, had the Comots of Counsylht, Prestatyn, and Ruthlan. Southwales.

South-Wales, then called Deheubarh, conteined all that track of ground
which we call the Counties of Glamorgan, Pembrook, Cardigan, Carmarthen, with part of Brecknocshire; which being the richest and most fertile part of Wales, as also lying most open to Invasions both by Sea and Land, was soonest brought under the power of the Kings of England; yet was it not without several Castles and places of defence. Its extent. Bounds.

It is bounded on the East with part of Powis-land; on the South with the Shires of Carmarden and Pembrook, with the River Tivi; on the West with the Irish Sea; and on the North with Merionythshire. Its division and parts. Caredigion, now Cardiganshire.

This Kingdom or Territory was then severed into six Parts, amongst which Caredigion, now Cardiganshire is the chief, and conteined four Cantreds, or Hundreds, and ten Comots, viz. the Cantref Canawl, which had the Comots of Anhunot, Meuenyth, and Pennarth. The Cantref Penwedic, which had the Comots of Geneurglyn, Creuthyn, and Perueth. The Cantref Castelch, which had the Comots of Mabwynion, and Caerwedros: And the Cantref of Syrwen, which had the Comots of Gwenionyth and Iscoed. Dyuet, or Pembrokeshire.

The second Part was called Dyuet, which now beareth the name of Pembrokeshire, and conteined eight Cantreds, in which were 23 Comots; viz. The Cantref Emlyn, which had the Comots of Vwchkuch, Leuethyr, and Iskuch. The Cantref Cemais, which had the Comots of Isneuer, Vwehineuer, and Trefdraeth. The Cantref Pubidioc, the Comots of Mynyw, Pencaer, and Pebidioc. The Cantref Ros, the Comots of Castelh Gwalchmai, Ygarn, and Hulfforth. The Catref Penuro, those of Penuro, Maenorbyrr, and Coedyrhaf. The Cantref Y Coed, the Comots of Lhanhayaden and Castelh Gwys. The Cantref Daugledheu, the Comots of Euelfre, Pennant and Amgoed: And the Cantref Arberth, the Comots of Penrhyn ar Elays, Esterolef and Talacharn. Caermardhyn shire.

The third part of South-Wales was Caermardhynshire, and had in it four Cantreds, and fifteen Comots; viz. The Cantref Finioc, which had the Comots of Harfryn, Isgeneny and Deruedh. The Cantref Mawr, which had those of Cethineoc, Comot Mab Elvyw, Comot Mab Ucheryd & Wydigaga. The Cantref Eginoc, which had those of Gwyr, Cydweli and Carnwilheon: And the Cantref Bachan, which had the Comots of Caeo, Malhaen, and Maenor Deilo. Morganwc, or Glamorganshire.

The fourth part was called Morganwc, and now is known by the name of Glamorganshire; and had in it four Cantreds, and fifteen Comots; viz. the Cantref Gwentlhwg, which had the Comots of Yrhardh Ganol, and Eithafdylygion. The Cantref Brenhinol, which had those of Iscaeth, Vwchcaeth, Senghennyth, and Cybowr. The Cantref Pennythen, which had those of Meyskyn, Glynrhodny, Maenor Talauan, and Maenor Ruthyn: And the Cantref Croneth, which had the Comots of Rwngneth ac Avan, Tir yr Hwndrwd, and Maenor Glynogwr. Gwent part of Monmouthshire

The fifth part was called Gwent, now part of Monmouthshire, and had three Cantreds, and ten Comots; viz. The Cantref Gwent, which had the Comots of Tref y grug, Iscoed Lhefnyeh, and Y mynyth. Herefordshire. Forest of Dean in Glocestershire. The Cantref Iscoed, which had the Comots of Brynbuga, Vwchwed, Y Teirtref, and Erging acewyas, now in Herefordshire: And the Cantref Coch, now in Glocestershire, and called the Forest of Dean. Brecheinoc, now Brecknockshire.

The sixth and last part of South-Wales was Brecheinoc, now Brecknockshire; and had three Cantreds, and eight Comots; viz. the Cantref Selef, which had the Comots of Selef and Trahayern. The Cantref Mawr, which had those of Tir Raulff, Lhywel, and Cerrig Howel: And the Cantref Canol, which had the Comots Brwynlhys or Eglwys yail, and Talgarth Ystradyw. Its Extent.

The Country called Powis-land, or Mathraual, is the least part of the three, conteining only the Land between the Wye and the Severn, to wit, the County of Montgomery, and part of Radnor, Brecknock, Denbigh, and Shropshire. Bounds. It was separated on the South and West by the Rivers of Wye, Tywy,
and some Meers from South-Wales; on the East by the Marches of England; and on the North, with North-Wales. Division. This Part was divided into Powis-Vadoc, Powis between Wye and Severn, and Powis-Wenu ynwyn. Powi-Vadoc.

Powis-Vadoc conteined five Cantreds, and was severed into fifteen Comots; viz. Now in several Counties. The Cantref Y Barwn, which had the Comots of Dynmael, Edeyrneon, and Glyndourdwy, which is Merionethshire, (except Dynmael, which is in Denbighshire.) The Cantref Y Rhiw, which had the Comots of Yal in Denbighshire, and Sratalyn and Hop now in Flintshire. The Cantref Vwchnant, which had the Comots of Merforth in Flintshire, Maelor-Gymraeg, in English Bromfield, now in Denbighshire, and Maelor Saesneg, now in Flintshire. The Cantref Trefred, which had the Comots of Croesvain, Tref-y-wayn, in English Chirk, and in Denbighshire, and Croes Oswallt, or Oswestree, which is in Shropshire: And the Cantref Rayder, which had the Comots of Mochnant Israider, Cynlhaeth, and Nanhendwy, now all in Chirkland in Denbighshire. Pow is-land between the Wye and the Severn.

The second Part of Powis-land, to wit, Powis between the Wye and the Severn, had four Cantreds, and thirteen Comots; viz. The Cantref Melienyth, which had the Comots of Ceri, Swythygre, Riwalalht, and Glyn-Jeithon. The Cantref Eluel, which had those of Vwchmynydh, Isnynydh, and Ihechdhyfnog. The Cantref of Yclawdh, those of Dyffryn, Teyueydiat, Swydhynogen, and Pennwelht: And the Cantref Buelht, which had the Comots of Swydhyvam, Dreulys, and Isyrwon. The third part of Powisland.

The third and last Part of this Powisland, to wit, Powis-Wenwynwyn, had likewise five Cantreds, and twelve Comots: viz. The Cantref Conan, which had the Comots of Cyueiliac and Mouthwy. The Cantref Cydewen, which had those of Conan and Hauren. The Cantref Lhyswynaf, which had those of Mechain-Vwchcoed, and Caereneon. The Cantref Y Vyrnwy, which had those of Mochnantvwch-Rayader, Ihannerch-Hudol, and Mechain-Iscoed: And the Cantref Ystlye, had the Comots of Deuthwr, Corthwr-Isaf, and Strat- Marchelh. The present division of Wales.

Thus much concerning the ancient division of Wales; but at present according to an Act of Parliament made in the Reign of K. Henry the Eighth, it is severed into two parts, to wit, North-Wales and South-Wales, both which have as it were devoured all Powis-land; and in each of these Parts there are six Counties; viz. in the North those of Anglesey, Caernarvon, Denbigh, Flint, Merioneth, and Montgomery; and in the South those of Brecknock, Cardigan, Carmarden, Glamorgan, Pembroke, and Radnor.

Again, Wales like unto England is divided into four Circuits for the Administration of Justice, and then the first shall contein the Counties of Denbigh, Flint, and Montgomery: The second those of Brecknock, Glamorgan, and Radnor: The third those of Cardigan, Carmarden, and Pembroke: And the fourth those of the Isle of Anglesey, Caernarvon, and Merioneth.
But let us proceed to the description of these Counties Alphabetically, as they lye in each part, and first with those in South-Wales.

div1.n: South-Wales: This Part conteineth the Counties of Brecknock, Cardigan, Caermarden, Glamorgan, Pembroke and Radnor Of which in order.
div1.head: South-Wales: This Part conteineth the Counties of Brecknock, Cardigan, Caermarden, Glamorgan, Pembroke, and Radnor. Of which in order.

div2.head: Brecknockshire.

figure.head: A Generall Mapp of South Wales

div2.p: BRECKNOCKSHIRE, the ancient Habitation of the Silures, who were great opposers of the Romans, untill subdued by Julius Frontinus; by the Welch called Brechinean, from one Brechanius a Prince, who is said to have had a great and holy off-spring of twenty four Daughters, and all Saints; it is a Country generally very mountainous, some of which are exceeding high, as Canterbochan, Talgar, Ewias, but especially Monuchdenny-hill not far from Brecknock, which exalteth it self above the clouds; and although thus hilly, and enclosed with Mountains, yet is it not without many large and fertile Plains, and Valleys which yield plenty of corn, and feed store of cattle; and the more by reason of its Rivers Uske and Wye, which receive those many streams which so plentifully water the Country, and afford to the Inhabitants such great aboundance of fish, especially Salmon and Trouts, in the Wye. Hills. Fertility. Its Bounds.
This Shire hath for its bounds on the East the Counties of Radnor, Hereford, and Monmouth; on the South Glamorganshire; on the West Caermarden and Cardigan; and on the North Radnorshire. Its Extent.
Its Extent from East to West is about 20 miles; and from South to North about 28; and makes in circumference about 102 miles. Its Dvision.

It is severed into six Hundreds, in which are numbred 61 Parish Churches, 'twas strengthened with nine Castles, and hath intercourse of traffick with four Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Brecknock.

Brecknock, by the Britains called Aberhodney, as seated at the meeting of the Rivers Hodney and Uske, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge. It is a place of good antiquity, as doth appear by the Roman coyns which have oft-times been digged up, and is at present a very large Bailiffwick- Town, conteining three Churches, of which one is a Collegiate Church, seated at the West-end of the Town; its Houses are well built, and neatly compacted; 'twas formerly strengthened with a stately Castle,as also with a strong wall, which gave entrance by 3 Gates; It is honoured in giving Title
of Earldom to the Right Noble James Butler, Duke, Marquess, and Earl of Ormond, Earl of Breknock and Ossery, Viscount Thurles, and Baron Arclo, and Llanthony, &c. For Civil affaire, it is governed by two Bailiffs, fifteen Aldermen, two Chamberleyns, two Constables, a Town-Clark, and other Sub-Officers; amongst its immunities sendeth a Burgest to Parliament; is a place well inhabited, and the rather as being the Shire-Town where the Assizes are kept; it doth enjoy a good trade for clothing; and for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, it hath weekly two Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, which are very well served with cattle, corn, and provisions. Brecknock-meer.

About two miles from this Town there is a large Pool or Meer, conteining some miles in compass, called Brecknock-meer, and by the Britains Linsavethen, where, according to report, sometime stood a fair City, which was swallowed up by an Earth-quake, which Camben believeth to be the Loventrium of Ptolomy; and in this Meer are aboundance of excellent fish, and in times past had great store of Otters. Crecowell.
Crecowell, seated on the Usk, over which it hath a bridge; a pretty Town, but hath a very mean Market. Hay.

Hay, seated on and between the Wye and the Dulas; a Town of good note in the time of the Romans, being then fortified with a Castle, and a Wall, which was spoiled in the Rebellion of Owen Glendowerdwy. It is at present a good Town, and hath a great Market for corn, cattle, provisions, &c. on Mondays. Bealt.

Bealt, pleasantly seated amongst Woods, and on the Wye, over which it hath a very large Wooden-bridge which leadeth into Radnorshire; a place formerly of good account, but at present a pretty small Town, which enjoyeth a considerable trade for stockings, and hath weekly two very good Markets on Mondays for cattle, and on Saturdays for corn and provisions.

div2.head: Cardiganshire
div2.p: CARDIGANSHIRE, by the Britains called Sire- Aber-Tivi, of a different soil, and ill clothed with wood; the Southern and Western parts being plain, and very fertile, (yet not without some Hills;) and its Eastern and Northern parts are Mountainous, and not so fertile, yet intermixed with good Pasture grounds, and large Pools: And generally it affordeth plenty of corn, cattle, sea-fowl, fish, and not without some Veins of Lead. Fertility. Its Rivers.

It is well watered with Rivers, the chief amongst which are the Tivye (at present as well stored with Salmons, as in former times it was with Bevers) and the Ridal, which hath its Spring out of the Plinillimon-hill, (a Mountain of a very great extent and height) as hath the Wye and Severn, two noted Rivers. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with the Counties of Radnor and Brecknock; on the South with the Tyvye, which parts it from the Shires of Caermarden and Pembroke; on the West with the Irish Sea, which with the Rivers which fall into it, do sufficiently furnish the Inhabitants with Salmons, and other fish; and on the North it hath the Counties of Merioneth and Montgomery. Ancient Inhabitants.

The ancient Inhabitants of this County, as also those of Caermarden and Pembroke, were the Dimetæ of Ptolomy, who under the conduct of the Noble, and famous Caractacus their King, did much anoy the Romans before they were reduced to obedience by Julius Frontinus. Its Castles.

It was formerly strengthened with several Castles, as at Stratneyrie, Lhanrysted, Aber-Roydel, Walter, Dyverth, and elsewhere; and was not without its Religious Houses, at Cardigan, Stratfleur, Istradsleet, Llanbadern-vaur, once an Episcopal See, and Llan-Deui-breui, sometime in great esteem for its Synod there holden by the famous David, Bishop of Menevia, where he refuted the Pelagian Heresie. Religious Houses. Its extert.

This Shire is of no large extent, being in length from Cardigan in the South-west, to the Plinillimon-hill, which is its North-Easternly bounds, about 36 miles; and in breadth (where broadest) not above sixteen or seventeen.
It is severed into five Hundreds or Cantrefs, in which are dispersed 64 Parish Churches, and hath the accommodation of four Market-towns, viz. Cardigan.

Cardigan, no less pleasantly then commodiously seated on the banks of the Tywye, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge susteined by several Arches, which leadeth into Pembrokcshire, and is not far from its inslux into the Sea, and being the Shire-town where the Assizes are held, and the County Goal kept, is well inhabited and frequented, being a large Town, though it conteineth but one Church, which is a fair Structure, and is graced with a well-built Shire-hall, and several good buildings, and as a Town-Corporate is governed by a Maior, Aldermen, Common-councel, and other Sub-Officers, enjoyeth several immunities, and hath the election of a
Parliament man. It is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Robert Brudenel, Earl of Cardigan, &c. and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays. This Town was formerly strengthened with a Wall, and a fair and spacious Castle built by Gilbert de Clare, on the side of the River upon a Rock, long since reduced to ruin. Llanbeder.

Llanbeder, seated on the Tyvye, which is passed over by a bridge into Caermardenshire, and on a Plain, but the Church on a rising ground; the Town is indifferent good, is governed by a Port Reive and Steward; and hath a Market on Tuesdays, which is well resorted unto for grain and provisions, and from the latter end of April, to the beginning of July, is very great for Sheep, Heafers, Cows and Calves. The Well Kitho.
Within half a mile of this Town, is a Well called Kitho, whose water is esteemed very good for sore eyes. Tregaron.

Tregaron, scituate on a Plain, and on the Tyvye; a mean Town-Corporate, which hath a Maior for its chief Magistrate, is beautified with a fair Church, and hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays. Aberysthwy.

Aberysthwy, or Aberysthyth, so called from the River Ystwyth near adjoyning; it is seated on a rising ground, and on the River Rydall, near its Influx into the Sea, once strengthened with a Wall, and Castle now ruinated; The Town is long and ill-built, is governed by a Maior, and other Sub-Officers, hath a very great Market on Mondays for corn, wool, cheese, and provisions, supplying several Counties therewith; and is a place much resorted unto by reason of its fishing trade for herrings, codds, whitings, and other fish, and would be more were its Inhabitants industrious. Lhan-Badernvaur.
Near unto this Town is seated Lhan- Badernvaur, a well-built Town, graced with a fair Church, which was formerly an Episcopal See, and is now the Parish Church to Aberysthwy.

div2.head: Caermardenshire
div2.p: CAERMARDENSHIRE, esteemed by some the strongest County in all South-Wales, and generally of a fertile soil, bearing good crops, hath rich Meadows which feed store of cattle, and is well clothed with wood; and this fertility is the more augmented, as not being so mountainous as its neighbouring Counties, and those Hills it hath are not so high. It is also well watered with Rivers, as the Tovye, Tavy, Tyvye, Lough, or Taff, with several others which discharge themselves into the Sea, in which and in the said Rivers, the Inhabitants are plentifully served with fowl and fish, especially Salmons in great aboundance; and in the bowels of the Earth in many places are dugg Pitt-coal. Its Rivers. Its bounds.

This County hath for its Eastern bounds the Shires of Brecknock and Glamorgan; for its Southern the Severn, or British Sea; for its Western Pembrokeshire; and for its Northern the River Tyvy, which separates it from Cardiganshire. Its Extent.
Its Extent from South-west to North-east, is about 35 miles; and from East to West, where broadest, about 20; which makes its circumference to be about 102 miles. Its division.
It is severed into six Hundreds, in which are numbred 87 Parish Churches; is traded unto by eight Market-towns, and was formerly strengthned with ten Castles. Caermarden.

Caermarden, by Ptolomy called Maridunum, by Antonine Muridunum, and by the Welch Caer-fridhin; a Town pleasantly seated on the banks of the Towy, over which it hath a fair Stone-bridge; which said River being Navigable for small Vessels, they have a good Key for the lading and unlading of their Merchandizes, and is a place well inhabited and traded unto. It is a place of good antiquity, and boasteth for that it gave birth to Merlin the Britains famous Prophet or South-sayer. Soon after the coming of the Normans, this Town was brought under their subjection, and was for a good while sorely harazed, being oft-times assaulted, and once or twice set on fire; but in the end being fortified with a Wall, and a large Castle seated on a hanging Rock, built by Gilbert de Clare (both long since reduced to ruin) it was freed from those calamities, and was afterwards by the English Princes made the Chancery, and Exchequer of South- Wales. It is at present a Town and County Incorporate, is governed by a Maior, two Sheriffs, elected out of sixteen Burgesses or Aldermen all clad in Scarlet, with other Sub-officers, having a Sword, Cap of Maintenance, and two Maces, and doth enjoy ample immunities, as keeping of Courts, electing of a Parliament man, &c. is the place where the Assizes are held for the County; and its Markets, which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are very great for corn, cattle, and provisions, both flesh, fish, and fowl in great plenty.
Caleg-Castle.

Not far from this Town, on an eminence or high rocky Hill, formerly stood Careg-Castle; under which are said to be many Vaults and spacious Caves, where also there is said to be a Well, whose water ebbeth and floweth as the Sea every twelve hours. Llancharne.

Llancharne, or Llaugharne, seated on the Towy, near its inslux into the Sea, (where, as also at Llanstephen near adjoyning) were two Castles of great strength, which now lye buried in their Rubbish. The Town is well built, of some trade, having several Vessels belonging unto it, and its Market, which is on Fridays, is very good for corn, flesh, and fish. Killmanloyd.

Mr. Cambden maketh mention of an Earthen Vessel dugg up at Killmanloyd near adjoyning, filled with Roman coyn of embased silver, from the time of Commodus the Emperour, unto the fifth Tribuneship of Gordian the Third, which was in Anno Dom. 243.
Near adjoyning to this Town is a Salt-work, or Wich, where good quantitie of Salt are made out of the Sea-water. Kidwelyn.

Kidwelyn, a Maior-town, seated on the Severn Sea, formerly a place of good account for clothing, but at present is well frequented by Fishermen; and hath two indifferent good Markets weekly on Tuesdays and Saturdays. Llanelly.

Llanelly, or Lanelthye, seated on a River or Creek of the Sea, a pretty good Town, well traded unto for Sea-coal, and hath a Market on Thursdays, which is of good account for all sorts of cattle, corn, and provisions. Llandi loudwre

Llandilouawre, scituate on an ascent, and on the River Towy, over which it hath a fair bridge; a pretty good Town, hath two Markets weekly on Tuesdays and Saturdays for cattle, corn, and provisions; and the Parish to which it belongeth is exceeding large, extending it self about thirteen miles in length, and seven or eight in breadth. Dinevor-Castle
Not far from this Town was seated on the top of a Hill Dinevor-Castle, which belonged to the Princes of South-Wales, at which time it was in a flourishing condition. Llangadoke.
Llangadoke, seated between the Rivers Brane and Sawthy, which soon after empty themselves into the Towy. It is an indifferent Town, and hath a good Market on Thursdays. Llanymdofry.

Llanymdofry, well seated amongst Rivers; a pretty fair Bailiffwick and Town-Corporate, once strengthened with a fair (but now ruinous) Castle, and hath two very great Markets weekly on Wednesdays and Saturdays for provisions, and the greatest for sheep and cattle in the County. New-Castle:

New-Castle in Emlin, seated on the Tyvy, over which it hath a fair bridge which leadeth into Cardiganshire; an indifferent Town, had once a fair Castle, which was destroyed by fire in the late Wars; and its Market on Fridays is of good account for cattle, corn, and provisions.

div2.head: Glamorganshire
div2.p: GLAMORGANSHIRE, by the Welch called Glath- Morgan (as some would have it) from Mergan a great British Prince, and was anciently inhabited by the Silures.

It is a Country of a temperate and healthful air; and of a different soil and scituation; the Northern part being extreamly mountainous, full of thick Woods, very barren, and thin of Inhabitants; yet these Mountains are found to feed good herds of cattle, and to send forth several fresh Springs, which do much add to the fertility of the Country; the chief amongst which are the Tavye, Taff, Ogmore, Rumney, Ewenny, Elay, Nid or Neath, &c. And the Southern part which is washed by the Severn Sea, and receiveth the said Rivers, is more upon a levell, and very fertile, bearing great crops of corn, feeding good store of sheep and cattle, is well inhabited, and thick beset with Towns and Houses of the Gentry. Its Rivers. Its Castles.

This County for its defence, lying open to foreign Invasion, was strengthned with aboundance of Castles, and such were those of Ogmor, Sanraven, Kenfig, Tregantlow, Pile, Neath, Swanzey, Oystermouth, Penrice, Webley, Lochor, Kelligarne, New-Castle, Old-Castle, East-Orchard, West-Orchard, Flemingston, Llanblethan, Marmion, Llanquian, Skurlagh, Ealavan, Penmark, Portkery, Barry, Sully, Landymore, Leach, Denis-powis, Winston, Rayleigh, Peterston, St. Georges, Landaph, Llanbrissent, White-Castle, Red-Castle, Morlaish, and Caerphilly which was a powerful Fortress of the Romans; all these long since submitied to the fate of devouring time. And besides these Castles, there are others that are habitable in these modern times, and such are the stately, spacious, and strong Castle of Cardiff; the stately and well scituated Marine Castle of St. Donats; the pleasant and well seated Castle of St. Fagans; the well seated Castle of Wenvoe; the goodly, convenient, and well seated Castle of Funmun near the Sea; the ancient, well scituate, and stately Castle of Coythy; the pleasant, and well seated Castle of Oxwith near the Sea; the Castle of Penlline, which enjoyeth a delectable prospect; and the Castle of Mengch, in English Monks Castle, which was rather a quadrangular large Covent, then any Fortress of Defence. Its bounds.

The bounds of this County are on the East with Monmouthshire, from which it is parted by the River Rumpney; on the South with the Severn Sea; on the West also with part of the Sea, and Cacrmardenshire; and on the North with Brecknockshire. Its Extent.
Its extent from East to West (where it shooteth it self into the Sea) is about 40 miles; and from South to North about 20; and makes in circumference about 112 miles. Its division.

It is severed into ten Hundreds, in which are numbred 118 Parish Churches; and for the conveniency of its Inhabitants, is traded unto by eight Market- towns, whose names are as followeth.
Cardiff.

Cardiff, by the Welch called Caerdidd, the fairest Town in all South-wales, well seated on the River Tave or Taff, over which it hath a fair bridge, to which Vessels of small burthen do come to lade and unlade their Goods; It is also seated in a rich and fertile soil both for tillage and pasturage, and in a levell, which at the distance of three or four miles, is environed with pleasant Hills, rendring a delectable prospect. The Town is large, is adorned with well built Houses, and well ordered and clean streets, conteining within its walls (which gives entrance by four Gates) two Parishes, but is at present contented with one Church, that of St. Maries about 26 years since (by the undermining of the River) having its foundation washed away, and the greatest part fallen down. Without the East-Gate is a large Suburb called Crockerton; without the North-Gate stands the white Fryers; and without the West-Gate a small Suburb, adjoyning to which is the black Fryers; and in this part is seated the Castle, built (together with the Town-wall) by Fitz-Haimon, in the Reign of King Rusus, which is a spacious, stately, and strong building, now the Seat of the Right Honorable the Earl of Pembroke. It is a Town-Corporate, governed by a Constable of the Castle (who is Deputy-constable to the Earl of Pembroke) 12 Aldermen, as many Capital Burgesses, a Steward, Town-Clark, two Attorneys, and other Sub-Officers, enjoyeth several immunities, keepeth Courts, sendeth a Burgess to Parliament, is the place where the Assizes are kept for the County, and where the Justices yearly keep two general Sessions of the Peace. It is a place well frequented, whose Inhabitants have great intercourse of traffick with Bristoll; and its Markets are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, that on Saturdays being the best, and is very considerable, and well provided with corn, cattle, swine, sheep, and all sorts of provisions in great plenty, and at very easie rates. Sylye and Barry Isles.
About three miles from the mouth of the Taff are two small (but pleasant) Isles, near the shoar, and close together, the one called Sylye, and the other Barry. Llandaff.

Llandaff, scituate upon an ascent, and on the River Taff or Tave, near unto Cardiff, but its Cathedral standeth upon a low ground, being a spacious and superb Structure, first built by German and Lupus, French Bishops, soon after their suppressing the Pelagian Heresie that much infested Britain, who consecrated Dubricius a devout man the first Bishop thereof, whose Successor was St. Telean, to whom it was dedicated, and so called, being then extraordinary richly endowed, although otherwise at present. And as the See of a Bishop it is a City, but of a small extent, scarce comparing with a good Town, having at present not so much as a Market kept, which is occasioned by reason of its vicinity to Cardiff so considerable. This Bishoprick conteineth within its Diocess part of the Counties of Glamorgan and Monmouth, in which are 177 Parishes, of which 98 are Impropriations, and hath one Arch-Deacon, which is of Llandaff,

Near adjoyning to the Cathedral are the remains of an old Castle which was the ancient Palace of the Bishops, untill sold with the Lordship from the See by Dr. Kitching then Bishop thereof. Caerphilly,

Caerphilly, seated between and near the Rivers Taff and Rumney, in a Moorish ground, and amongst the Hills; once a place of good account and largeness, being supposed to be a Fort or Garison of the Romans; it is at present an ancient Borough-town, & hath a Market on Thursdays; upon a pretended Charter, or rather old Custome, assuming to themselves that priviledge, as being under the Jurisdiction of the Castle so called near adjoyning, which was formerly a strong hold of the Romans, as appears by its ruinous walls, and ancient Roman coyns oft dugg up.
Llantrissent.

Llantrissent, seated also in the hilly part of the Country, an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Port-Reue, who is sworn by the Deputy-Constable of the Castle thereof, and hath an indifferent Market on Fridays. Cowbridge.

Cowbridge; by the Britains called Pontvan, from its Stone-bridge over the River on which it is seated, which soon after looseth it self into the Sea; it is also seated in a low bottom, and in a fertile soil; is an indifferent good Town, where the Justices keep a Quarter Sessions for the County the week after Easter; hath a well frequented Market on Tuesdays for corn, cattle, sheep, and provisions; and is governed by a Bailiff, or Bailiffs annually chosen, and sworn by the Deputy-Constable (under the Earl of Pembroke) of the Castle of St. Quintin near adjoyning. Lantwyt.

Not far from Cowbridge, and near the Sea-shoar, and in a good rich soil, is seated Lantwyt major, which hath been an ancient Borough-town, and had a Market kept on Sunday mornings, but now discontinued. Bridge-end.
Bridge-end, seated on the River Ogmore, which severeth it into two parts, but joyned together by a Stone-bridge; a considerable Market- town on Saturdays for corn, cattle, and provisions.

Not far from this Town, on the said River Ogmore, near unto Newton, there springeth up a Well, which at full Sea is almost empty of water, and at low water, or ebb, is ready to rise over. Kenseage. Margan.

Farther along the Sea-coast towards Aberavon, are seated Kenseage or Kenfig, a very ancient Borough-town, governed by a Port-Reve, was formerly a Market-town, but long since disused: And Margan, where on the top of a Hill called Minyd-Margan, was erected a Monument with strang Characters. Aberavon.
Aberavon, seated on the River Avon, near its fall into the Sea; an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Port-Reve, and had formerly a Market which now is disused. Neath.

Neath seated on a River so called, over which it hath a bridge, to which small Vessels come for the lading of Coals here had in great plenty, to the great profit of the Inhabitants: It is a Town of good Antiquity, and was of a greater extent then now it is, yet is it indifferent large, hath a good Market for provisions on and is governed by a Port-Reve annually chosen, and sworn by the Deputy-Constable of the Castle of Neath.
Over against this Town, on the other side of the River, are yet the remains of a once rich and stately Monastery; but the Abby-house (a large Structure) is at present kept in good repair. Swansey.

Swansey, commodiously seated on the Sea-shoar, where the River Tawy dischargeth it self, by the Welch called Aber-Taw, an ancient Port-Reve Town, belonging to the Right Honorable Henry Marquess of Worcester, who is also Lord of the Liberty of Gowre, which taketh up that part of the County which thrusteth it self forth into the Sea; It is a large, clean, and well-built Town, which for riches and trade is esteemed the chief of the County, and that by reason of their Coal-pits, and the great industry of its Inhabitants; Its Markets which are on Wednesdays and Saturdays, are very well frequented and traded unto, affording great plenty of commodities and provisions. Penrise.
Penrise, seated near the Sea; hath a late erected Market on which for the present is not very considerable. Llogor.

Opposite to Swansey is Llogor, so called from the River on which it is seated, where it parts this County from Caermardenshire; It is an ancient Borough-town, governed by a Port-Reve, and was once strengthened with a Castle of good account.

div2.head: Pembrokeshire
div2.p: PEMBROKESHIRE, of a fertile soil, and apt to bear corn; hath rich pastures, is well stored with cattle, plentifully watered with Rivers, as with the Tivye, Gledawh, Douglebye, Neverne, Clethy, Keach, &c. Rivers. which with the Sea furnish the Inhabitants with aboundance of excellent fish, and water-fowl; In the bowels of the Earth are plenty of Pitt-coal, and is well inhabited and garnished with Towns. Its bounds.
It is bounded on all parts with the Irish Sea, except towards the North with the River Tywy which divides it from Cardiganshire; and on the East with Caermardenshire. Extent.
Its Extent from East to West is about 20 miles; and from South to North about 26; and makes in circumference about 93 miles. Division.

It is divided into seven Hundreds, in which are numbred 145 Parishes, hath been strengthened with 16 Castles, besides two Block-houses commanding Milford-haven; and is traded unto by eight Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Pembroke.

Pembroke, the chief Shire-Town, commodiously seated in the best part of the Country, and upon the Eastern or innermost Creek of Milfordhaven, over which it hath two fair bridges, one leading to Mounton adjoyning, where there is a fair Church, and a decayed Priory: And the other on the North-side, where there are two French Mills for the grinding of corn. It is the chief Shire-Town, being a place of good account, well frequented and inhabited by Gentlemen and Trades-men, is much resorted unto by shipping, where there is a Custom-house; is a place of good strength, being fortified with a Wall, on which are several Towers, having three Gates for entrance, and also with a strong Castle seated on a Rock, where there is a Vault which affordeth a strange Echo, called the Wogan; It is a large Town-Corporate, conteining two Parish Churches, its Houses well built, is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable William Herbert Earl of Pembroke, &c. is governed by a Maior, and other Sub-officers, enjoyeth several immunities, sendeth a Burgess to Parliament; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very good, and well served with provisions, &c. Milford-Haven.

This Milford-Haven is esteemed the best in all England, not only for its largeness, being capacious enough to gIve entertainment to about 1000 sail of Ships at one time, and to ride secure, at a good distance from one another; but also for its variety of deep and safe Creeks, and nooked Bays for Ships to harbour in, having within it 13 Roads, 16 Creeks, and 5 Bays, all which are known by their several names. Several Isles.

Hereabouts in the neighbouring Sea, and not far from the Shoar, are seated several small Islands, viz. Sheep-Isle, Gateholme-Isle, Midlan-Isle, Scalme- Isle, and Stockholme-Isle, which three last are the largest, with some other small ones not worth the naming.
St. Davids.

St. Davids, ill seated in a barren soil, within a mile of the Sea-shoar, and on the small River Ilen, being destitute of wood, so that it is exposed both to wind and storms. It is called by the Britains Tuy-Dewy, from Devi a Religious Bishop, who made it an Episcopal See, and was once the Metropolitan See in the British Church, and long time continued the Supream Ordinary of the Welch. And here lived Calphurnius a British Priest, whose Wife was Concha, Sister to St. Martin, and both of them the Parents of St. Patrick the Apostle of the Irish. It was once a City of good account, but at present but small, being dismantled of its Walls, not having the benefit of a Market, and but thinly inhabited; yet is it the See of a Bishop, where he hath his Palace, formerly a fair Structure, but now much out of repair, as are the Houses of the dignisied Prebends. But its Cathedral dedicated to St. Andrew and David, is a good building, which is well looked after, in the midst of whose Quire lyeth entombed the body of Edmond Earl of Richmond, Father to King Henry the Seventh.

This Diocess doth contein the Counties of Pembroke, Cardigan, Caermarden, Brecknock, and Radnor, with some small parts in the Counties of Monmouth, Hereford, Glamorgan, and Montgomery, in all which are 308 Parishes, of which 120 are Impropriations; and hath four Arch-Deacons, viz. of St. Davids, Cardigan, Caermarden, and Brecknock. And in this City is a good Free-School for the Education of Youth. St. Davids Head.

Nigh unto this City is a Promontory, called St. Davids Land or Head, from whence, in a clear Sun-shining day, Ireland may easily be discerned. White sand-bay Ramsey Isle. And in the Rocks in these parts the Faulcons have their airies, and breed: Also here is White sand-bay; and at the extream point of the said Promontory, Ramsey-Isle sheweth it self, which is almost two mile long, and a mile and an half broad; nigh unto which are several very small ones, which together are known by the name of the Bishop and his Clerks. Haverford-west.

Haverford-west, by the Britains called Hulphord, a Town and County of it self, commodiously seated on the side of a Hill, and on a Creek of Milford-Haven, over which it hath a good Stone-bridge, which leadeth to Prendergast, where there is a Church. It is a very large and fair Town-Corporate, conteining three Parish Churches, is beautified with well-built Houses, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a good trade, having several Vessels belonging unto the Town, is the place where the Assizes are held, and where the Gounty-Goal is kept; and hath two Markets weekly, viz. on Tuesdays and Saturdays, which are very great for cattle, provisions, &c. It is governed by a Maior, a Sheriff, and Common-councel, with Justices of the Peace, enjoyeth several priviledges, keepeth Courts, and sendeth a Burgess to Parliament. It was once strengthned with a Wall and a Castle, built by the Earls of Clare, both which were demolished in the late Wars, when it was made a Garison. And near unto this Town divers Gentlemen have their Seats. Tenby.

Tenby, in Welch Tenby-y-Pyscod, seated on the Sea, where it hath a commodious Haven or Road for Ships, being formerly much frequented, especially by Fishermen, having a good Key, enjoyed a great trade, and its inhabitants were wealthy; but in the Wars, being made a Garison-Town, it suffered much, and was dismantled of its Castle, since which it is greatly fallen to decay to what it was; yet hath it still two Markets weekly on Wednesdays and Saturdays, which are very good for corn, provisions, and fish.
St. Katherins Rock.
Nigh unto this Town is St. Katherine Rock, and further Southwards is the small Island of Calde, as also Lud-sopp-point. Calde-Isle. Narberth.
Narberth, or Narbart, seated on a Hill; an indifferent good Town, which is strengthened with a Castle, and hath a well frequented Market on Wednesdays. Wiston.
Wiston, a Maior-Town which is but mean, as is its Market; it is governed by a Maior and Bailiffs, and strengthened with a Castle, now the Habitation of a Gentleman. Fishgard.

Fishgard, so called in English for the taking of fish, and in Welch Aber-gwain, governed by a Maior and Bailiffs, is seated on a steep Cliff, and on the Sea-shoar, where it hath a commodious Harbour for Ships; a Town of great trade for Herrings here taken, and hath a small Market on Newport.

Newport, seated on the foot of a high Hill, by the River Nevernsside near the Sea-shoar; a large but ill-built and inhabited Town, governed by a Port-Reve and a Bailiff, hath a fair Church, and an ancient and ruinous Castle; its Market is on which is good for cattle, corn, and provisions; and here is a Wear for fishing, which at present is much out of repair. Kilgarven.

Kilgarven, seated on the River Tyuy and on a Rock; a long Town, consisting of one Street, is governed by a Port-Reve and Bailiffs, is of chief note for its great plenty of Salmons; 'twas once strengthened with a Castle built by Girald, which hath now nothing to shew but its ruinous Walls; and its Market which is on Wednesdays, is indifferently well served with provisions. St. Dogmacles.

Near unto this Town is St. Dogmacles, seated in a bottom, and on the River Tyuy, which affords excellent Salmons; it is governed by a Port-Reve and Bailiffs, and was once enriched with a famous Monastery, long since decayed.

div2.head: Radnorshire
div2.p: RADNORSHIRE, of a sharp and piercing air; and for soil very hungry and ungrateful to the Husband-man without great pains and labour in cultivating it, and that occasioned as being so mountainous and rocky, especially in the West and North parts, which are fit only to feed cattle: And were it not for the many Rivers which so plentifully water it, as the Wye, Teme, Lug, Arro, Clowdok, Ythor, Machaway, Dulas, Darnol, Comaron, and others, it would be more sterile. Rivers. Its bounds.
It hath for its Eastern bounds Herefordshire; for its Southern and Western Brecknockshire; and for its Northern Montgomeryshire. Extent.

Its Extent from East to West is 24 miles; and from South to North about 22; and makes in circumference about 90 miles. Its division. Castles. It is severed into six Hundreds, in which are numbred fifty two Parish Churches; hath been strengthened with several Castles, amongst which were those of Paine, Colwen, Trim, Cuthremion, and others; and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants hath three Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. New-Radnor.

New-Radnor, seated near the Spring-head of the River Somergil, and in a pleasnt Valley at the foot of a profitable Hill, which feedeth aboundance of sheep and cattle, called the Forest of Radnor; and on the top of the Hill is seated its Castle, long since reduced to ruin by the force of Owen Glendore, and his party, who also did much damage to the Town, which is now inteded to be repaired; and from its Bulwarks a Trench was drawn along the West of the Town, where was raised a a strong Stone-wall, whose ruins do yet shew the same. This Town was raised out of the ruins of old Radnor, called by the Britains Maisevethhean, and for its high scituation Pencrag. It is a very ancient Town- Corporate, whose Jurisdiction reacheth ten or twelve miles in compass, is governed by a Bailiff and twenty five Burgesses, enjoyeth large immunities, keepeth Courts of Plea for all Actions without limitation of sum, and hath the election of a Parliament man; it had formerly a Market on Tuesdays, but at present is disused. Prestaine.

Prestaine, seated on the River Lug, and in a pleasant and rich Vale, by the Welch called Llhan-Andre, which from a small Village in former dayes, is now become a fair, large, and well-built Town, with paved and well ordered Streets, being also well inhabited and frequented, where the Assizes are held, and the County-Goal kept; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very good for provisions and grain, especially Barley, of which they make good store of Mault.
Knighton.

Knighton, seated in a Valley, on a rising ground, and on the River Teme, over which it hath a bridge; a very fair and well-built Borough-town, and of a good resort, whose Inhabitants enjoy a considerable trade; and its Market, which is on Tuesdays, is very well served with cattle, corn, provisions, Iron-ware, hopps, salt, linnen and woollen-cloth, and other Country commodities. Offa's Dike.

Nigh unto this Town runneth Offa's Dike, so called from Offa King of the Mercians, who caused the same to be cast up from Dee-mouth unto Wymouth, which is about 80 miles, for the separating the Britains from the English, and by a Law made by Harald, what Welch-man soever that should be found on this side the said Offa's Dike with a Weapon, should by the Kings Officer have his right hand cut off. Raihader-Gowy.
Raihader-Gowy, or Rayder-gowy, seated on the Wye, and in the hilly part of the Country; a small Town, and hath an inconsiderable Market on

div1.head: North-Wales

div2.n: THE Isle and County OF ANGLESEY.
div2.head: THE Isle and County OF ANGLESEY.
div2.p: This Part conteineth the Counties of Anglesey, Caernarvon, Denbigh, Flint, Merioneth, and Montgomery.

figure.head: A Generall Mapp of North Wales

div2.p: THE Isle of ANGLESER, by the Roman known by the name of Mona, and by the Britains, Mon, and Tirmon; is severed from the Continent of Britain, by a narrow streight of the River Menai, which divides it from Caernarvonshire, and on all other parts it is washed with the Irish Sea. It was the ancient Seat of the Druides, and brought with no small difficulty under the Romish Scepter by Julius Agricola; and in their declension was much infested by the Irish and Norwegians. Its Extent

This Isle is of no large extent, scarce numbring 80 miles in circuit; being in length from Beau-morice in the East, to Holy-head in the West, about 24 miles; and from Abermanay-ferry in the South, to Llanbaderik in the North, about 17. Fertility.

It is so fertile and abounding in all things that are necessary for the use of man, as corn, cattle, and other provisions, both flesh, fish, and fowl, that the Welch call it Mam-Cymry, that is, the Mother of Wales, as supplying its defects, although for sight, it seemeth dry, stony, hilly, and unpleasant. It also produceth a sort of stones called Molares, very fit and good for Mill-stones and Grind-stones. The Hills.
The Hills of most note are those of Round-table, Mynydd-y- Iwr, Bodavon, and Trwsklwin.
The air is reasonable healthful, and not much subject to diseases, except Agues at some times, which are occasioned by the Foggs and misty Exhalations of the Irish Sea.
It is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Arthur Earl of Anglesey,&c. Its Dvision.

This Isle is severed into six Hundreds, was once very populous, conteining 360 Towns and Villages, which at present are reduced to 74 Parishes; and for the accommodation of the Inhabitants, is traded unto by two Market-towns, and hath several good Ports and Harbours; as also divers Ferries for the conveyance of Passengers to and fro.
Its chief places are Beau-morish.

Beau-morish, seated on a moorish ground, but commandeth a fair prospect into the Sea, where it hath a very good Harbour for Ships; It was built by King Edward the First, the better to secure his conquest, who fortified it with a powerful Castle now in good repair. It is a pretty handsome and well-built Town-Corporate, governed by a Maior, Recorder, two Bailiffs, who are Justices of the Peace, and 21 Common-councel, called chief Burgess; it hath the election of a Parliament man, is the chief Shire-Town, where the Great Sessions, County Court, and Quarter Sessions are held, and County-Goal is kept; it is indifferently well inhabited and frequented, as being the usual Town for the reception of Passengers from London to Ireland, before their taking shipping at Holy-head, a small Town on the other side of the Isle reguarding Ireland, (in Welch called Caer-guby, from Kibie a holy man, who there ended his daies in the service of God;) and hath weekly two Markets on Wednesdays and Saturdays, which are indifferent good. Lhan-vais.

Nigh unto this Town was seated a famous Religious House in the time of the Fryers Minors, called Lhan-vais, which was held in great repute amongst the English Kings, and where the Daughter of King John, with many Lords and Persons of worth and honour were interr'd, that were slain in the Wars against the Welch. Pestholme Isle.
In the Eastern point near the Shoar, lyeth a small Isle called Prestholme, wherein is seated St. sirian Chap. Newburgh.

Newburgh, seated near Brant River, where it formeth a Bay, and falleth into Menai River; a small Borough-town, governed by a Maior, two Bailiffs, and a Recorder, and hath a Market on Tuesdays which is not very great, but in former time was of good account. Aberfraw.
Aberfraw, at present a small Village, but in times past was of great account, when the Kings of North-Wales had here their Palace.

div2.head: Caernarvonshire.
div2.p: CAERNARVONSHIRE, by the Britains called Sire- Caer-ar- von, and in composition before Wales was divided into Shire, was known by the name of Snowden Forest, the principal Hill (or Hills) in the County bearing now that name, (in British called Eryri) being of a very great extent and height, and affordeth excellent sweet Mutton; on the top of which floateth a Meer, and maketh a River which falleth into the Sea at Trathe-Mawer. Very mountainous.

It is a Country of a sharp and piercing air, and generally very mountainous, especially in the midst, which may not unaptly be called the British Alps, (which was a great cause of its long resistance, being the last County that was brought under the Dominions of the Kings of England,) yet is it not unfertile, feeding good herds of cattle, and hath aboundance of fish and fowl, especially that part towards Ireland, which giveth place to few Shires in North-Wales. Fertility. Its form.

The form of this County is much like a wedge, long and narrow, thrusting it self forth far into the Sea, whose extream point is called Langanum Promontory, also Brachy-pult-point, and Ponvenkele-point; and here lyeth the Isles of Bradsey and Gwelyn; and a little further North-Eastward, two little small Isles, called Stidwall and Mercross. Small Isles. Extent.

Its extent from Conwey River in the East, to Llenoy River in the West, is said to be 20 miles; and from Penvenkele-point, to Ormes-head-point in the North, about 40; and making in circumference about 110 miles. Bounds.

It hath for its bounds on the South Merionethshire (from which it is severed by Rivers, Meers, and Mountains) and the Irish Seas, which is also its Western and Northern limits, except where it is fronted by the Isle of Anglesey; and on the East the River Conwey, which parts it from Denbighshire, which Rivers together with the Sea, sendeth forth, or receiveth those many Rivers and Meers which so plentifully water the Country, and afford fish and fowl to the Inhabitants.
It is severed into several Hundreds, in which are numbred 68 Parish Churches, and hath traffick with 6 Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Caernarvon.

Caernarvon, raised out of the ruins of the ancient City Segontium, mentioned by Antonine the Emperour; by some supposed to be the City of Constantine, for that the body of Constantius, the Father of Constantine the Great, in Anno 1283. was here found, which afterwards was interr'd in the Church of this Town, by command of K. Edward the First. It is commodiously seated on the Sea-shoar, where it hath an excellent prospect into the Isle of Anglesey; it was a place of good account, where the Princes of Wales had their Chancery and Exchequer for North-Wales, and is of great strength, as well by Nature as Art, being encompassed on all parts (except towards the East) with the Sea and two Rivers; and had a strong Castle on the North-west part, whose Walls in a manner did also encompass it, where in a Tower thereof called Eagle-Tower, Edward the Second, the first Prince of Wales was born: It is of no great extent, numbring but one Parish Church, its houses and streets are well built and ordered, is well inhabited, is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Charles Dormer, Earl of Caernarvon, &c. it enjoyeth
several immunities, sendeth a Burgess to Parliament, is governed by the Constable of the Castle, who by his Patent is ever Maior, and hath for his Assistants an Alderman, two Bailiffs, a Town-Clark and Sub-Officers; and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is very good for corn and provisions. Bangor.

Bangor, seated low, and also on the said narrow Sea, opposite to Anglesey, but more North-wards; a Town in ancient time so large, that it was called Banchor-vaur, that is Bangor the Great, and was defended by a powerful Castle, built by Hugh Earl of Chester, which long since was laid level with the ground. This Town or City is but small, yet dignified with the See of a Bishop, whose Diocess conteineth the Counties of Caernarvon and Anglesey, together with part of those of Denbigh, Merioneth, and Montgomery, in which are 107 Parishes, whereof 36 are Impropriations, and hath under it also three Arch-Deacons, viz. of Bangor, Anglesey, and Merioneth, one of which is added to the Bishoprick for support thereof. Its Cathedral is large and well-built, and consecrated unto Daniel sometime Bishop thereof, about the year 516, which being miserably defaced, and set on fire by that impious Rebel Owen Glendowr, (whose intentions was to put an end to all the Cities in Wales, for that they acknowledged the King of England) was afterwards in some measure repaired and beautified by Henry Deane then Bishop thereof, in the reign of Henry the Seventh: the buildings of this City are indifferent good, the chief of which are the Bishops Palace, and the Free-School-house; it is pretty well inhabited, hath an indifferent good Market on Wednesdays, and is governed by the Bishops Steward, who keepeth Court-Leets, and Court-Baron for the Bishop. Pen-maen-maur.

Nigh unto Bangor is Pen-maen-maur, that is the Great Stony-head, being an exceeding high and steep Rock, which at high Sea so hangeth over, that it affordeth a very narrow passage, having on the one side great stones, which hang over their heads as threatning a downfall; and on the other the furious Sea, which lyeth of an exceeding steep depth under it. Pen-maen-bychan. But having passed this, as also Pen-maen-bychan, that is the Lesser Stony-head, the Country openeth it self in a broad Plain as far as the River Conwey. Aberconwey.

Aberconwey, or Caer-gyffyn, seated at the mouth of the River Conwey, raised out of the ruins of the ancient Canonium of Antonine, being strongly fenced both with Walls and a Castle; It is a pretty good Town, governed by an Alderman and two Bailiffs, which for largeness and good buildings, doth rather deserve the name of a pretty City, then a Town, especially were it thicker of Inhabitants, and better resorted unto; yet its Market, which is on Fridays, is well served with provisions, and several Country commodities. Diganwy.

Near unto this Town stood the ancient City Diganwy, many ages ago consumed with lightning; which place, Mr. Cambden is of the opinion, was the City Dictum, where the Captain over the Band of the Nervians Dictenses kept their Guard under the latter Emperours. Ormes-headpoint. And this part of the Country thrusteth forth a Promontory with a bending elbow, where is Ormes-head- point; in the Sea near the shoar opposite to Aberconwy, is seated Sinadon-Castle. Sinadon-Castle Krekyth.

Krekyth, seated on the South-side of the Irish Sea near Traeth-mawer Bay or Haven, where stood formerly a Castle, now all ruinous, except an arched Chamber called Sir Howel-y-wyall. It is a small and poor Town-Corporate, which enjoyeth large immunities, and hath a mean Market on Fridays. Pulhely.

Pulhely, scituate also on the Sea-shoar, and between two Rivers; a pretty large and indifferent well-built Bailiffwick-town, which hath a good Market on Wednesdays for corn and provisions, and enjoyeth a small trade by Sea. Newin.

div2.head: Denbighshire.
div2.p: DENBIGHSHIRE, in British Sire-Denbigh, whose ancient Inhabitants were the Ordovices; hath a wholsome air, yet sharp, as being on all sides exposed to the winds: and the high Hills (wherewith this County sufficiently aboundeth) do a long time retein the Snow, and the tops thereof in the Summer season being the Country mans morning Almanack, to denote a fair day by the rising of certain Vapours. Its Fertility.

It is of a different soil, the middle, where it lyeth flat, is a pleasant and fertile Vale, reaching in length from South to North 17 miles, and in breadth about five, called the Vale of Cluyd, in Welch Dryffin Cluyd, much inhabited by Gentry; it lyeth open to the Sea,and on all other parts begirt with high Hills or Mountains, amongst which that of most note is Moillenlly, at the top whereof is (or was) a warlike Fence, with a Trench and Rampier; and from these Hills the River Cluyd springeth, which watereth this Vale. The Western part being heathy, is much inclined to sterility, and but thinly inhabited, except the part which lyeth towards the Sea; and the Eastern beyond the said Valley, is the most ungrateful to the Husbandman. Its Form and Exten.
Its form is long and narrow, being in length from East to West about 31 miles; and from South to North about 17; and makes in circumference about 114 miles. Its bounds.

It is bounded on the East with Shropshire and Cheshire; on the South with Montgomeryshire; and on the West with those of Merioneth and Caernarvon, from which it is parted by the River Conwey; and on the North with the Irish Sea and Flintshire.

This County (with Flint and Caernarvon) are not divided into several Hundreds by prick'd lines, for want of their particulars in the Parliament Rolls formerly delivered in, but since which, this Shire is severed into twelve Hundreds, in which are numbred 57 Parish Churches, and is traded unto by four Market-towns, whose names are as followeth; and was strengthened with five Castles, the chief amongst which are those of Chirk, and Castle-Dinas. Denbigh.

Denbigh, called by the Britains Cled Fryn-yn Ross, seated on the hanging of a rocky Hill, about two miles from the River Cluyd, but on a branch thereof; once a place of great strength when fortified with a strong Wall, and an impregnable Castle, by Henry Lacy Earl of Lincoln, which were lately disinantled. The Town is indifferent large,well-built, inhabited by Glovers and Tanners, enjoyeth a good trade, and by some is esteemed the best Town in all North-Wales. It is honoured in giving Title to the Right Honorable Bazill Fielding Earl of Denbigh.&c. is governed by two Aldermen, two Bailiffs and 25 Capital Burgesses, with other Sub-Officers, hath the election of a Parliament man; and hath a good Market for corn, cattle, and provisions on Wednesdays.
Llanrost.

Llanrost, seated on the River Conway, a small Town, which hath a good Free-School; its Market on Tuesdays is indifferent good, and of late graced with a Market-house built at the charge of Maurice Winn Esq. Ruthin.

Ruthin, scituate in the Vale, and on the banks of the River Cluyd, and of note for its once large and fair Castle; It is a large, well inhabited and frequented Town-Corporate, governed by two Aldermen and Burgesses, hath a large Hospital, and a Free-School governed by a Warden, which were founded and well endowed by Dr.Gabriel Goodman, Dean of Westminster, in the reign of Queen Elizabeth; and its Market, which is on Mondays, is very considerable for corn and provisions, being esteemed the best in the Vale. Wrexham.

Wrexham, seated in a small territory called Mailor Gymraig, and in English Bromfield, which affordeth plenty of Lead, in a good soil,and on a small River which falleth into the Dee; It is an indifferent large, well-built, and inhabited Town, graced with a fair Church, whose Steeple is not inferiour to any in England, and hath two Markets weekly, on Mondays which is but small,and on Thursdays, which is very great for corn, cattle, and provisions. Llansainan.Arthurs round table.

In this County is Llansainan, seated on the River Aled, a small Town, but of note for its Cave made in the side of a stony Hill or Rock, wherein there are twenty four Seats to set in, some bigger and lesser, a place much frequented by Sheepherds, and others who tend their cattle, which is now known by the name of Arthurs Round table.

div2.head: Flintshire.
div2.p: FLINTSHIRE, not over mountainous, as the other parts of Wales, and interlaced with fertile Valleys both for corn and pasturage, feeding good store of small cattle, from which they make plenty of butter and cheese. They have also great aboundance of honey, of which they make a sort of wholesome drink called Matheglin, much drank amongst them; but the Country is very defective of wood, as also of fruits. The air and temperature.
The air is healthful, though somewhat colder then in the other parts,as lying open to the Northern winds. Its Rivers.

It is indifferently well watered with Rivers,as the Cluyd, and the Dee, which send forth (or receive) several lesser streams, which, with the Sea (which is its Northern bounds) do plentifully furnish the Inhabitants with fish and fowl, and hath several safe Harbours for Ships to ride, and anchor in; and this part of the County hath plenty of corn,cattle, and Mines of Pitt-coal, and the adjacent Mountains store of Lead-ore. Its form,extent,and bounds.

It is of no large Extent, stretching it self long and narrow, having a piece of it severed from the rest by the interposition of Denbighshire, which is its Southern and Western limits,as Cheshire is its Eastern. St.Winefrids-Well, or Holy-Well.

This Shire is most famous for St.Winefrids-Well, not farr from Cajervis, called by the English Holy-Well; and is a place of great note, and much frequented as well by those to bath in, (being held a place very good for the curing the diseases of the body) as by Pilgrims out of their Devotion; and in memorial of that Christian Virgin Winefred, who being beautiful, was doated upon by a young lustful Prince or Lord of the Country, who made fervent courtship to her to gain her Virginity; but her Vertues being a sufficient bulwark to withstand his amorous assaults; and despairing to gain his will on her, having the opportunity of time and place, surprized and ravished her, after which to stop her cries and acclamations, cruelly slew her, and cut off her head; out of which place (according to report) did immediately gush forth a Spring, which remaineth to this day, with so rapid a stream, that at a small distance it is able to drive a Mill. Over the head of this Spring or Well, there now standeth a Chappel built of Freestone, of curious workmanship with wrought Pillars, in the Chancel whereof in the Glass-window, is lively pourtraied the History of St. Winefrid, of her life, and how her head was cut off, and set on again by St. Beuno. And in this Well there groweth Moss, of a most sweet and pleasant smell, which the Country people believe to be St.Winefrids hair.
This County is severed into five Hundreds, which are but thinly inhabited,numbring no more then 28 Parishes, and hath but two Market-towns. Its places of most note are Flint.

Flint, commodiously seated on the River Dee, it is but small, and hath no Market, yet the Shire-Town, and sendeth a Burgess to Parliament; it is a place of chief note for its Castle (now old and ruinous) founded by Henry
the Second,and finished by Edward the First,and not long after gave Harbour and enterteinment to that Noble,but unfortunate Prince Richard the Second,at his coming out of Ireland, being within her Walls a free and absolute King, but no sooner had he quitted the same,but he was taken prisoner by Henry Bullingbrook Duke of Lancaster, who put an end to his liberty and life. Basingwark.
Near to Flint is Basingwark, once famous for its Monastery; and here began that Ditch drawn thence unto or near Wrexham. Cajervis.

Cajervis, seated on an ascent (and about three miles from the ancient and small City Varis of the Romans, which sheweth something of its Antiquity) a small Town, and hath a Market on Tuesdays, which is very good for corn and provisions. St. Asaph.

St.Asaph, seated on the River Elwy, where it receiveth the River Cluyd, over each of which it hath a Bridge; a place of more fame for its Antiquity,then for its largeness or beauty, being an ancient Episcopal See, first founded by Kentigerne a Scot, Bishop of Glasco, in Anne 560, who also built the Cathedral, and a Monastery, which consisted of about 650, of which about 300 that were unlearned, imployed their times in husbandry within the limits of the said Monastery, and the rest to a holy life. And upon his return into Scotland he ordained Asaph, a godly man,to be his Successor, from whom it took its name. The Town or City is not large, nor its buildings extraordinary good,its chief glory being its Cathedral, an indifferent Structure, which hath an Arch-Deacon bearing the same name;and its Market, which is on Saturdays, is but small. Other places of note in this County are Kilken.
Kilken, (a little Village) where there is a Well, which at certain times ebbeth and floweth like unto the Sea. Coles-hill.
Coles-hill, or Coles-hull, where the Welch obteined a great Victory over the English. Banchor.

Banchor, or Bangor, seated in that part of the County which is severed from the rest, and on the River Dee; a place of great Antiquity,and eminent for its famous Monastery of the Britains, which according to Beda, was so large,and had so great a number of Monks, that they were divided into seven Companies, each conteining about 300 persons, and had their several Ruler allotted them.

div2.head: Merionethshire.
div2.p: MERIONETHSHIRE, by the Britains called Sire-Verioneth, whose ancient Inhabitants were the Ordovices; it is a Country well watered with Rivers, amongst which are the Dee, Dowye, Druryd, Farles, Llanbeder, &c. is exceeding mountainous and rocky, very unpleasant, rough, and generally much inclined to sterility, bearing but thin Crops of Corn, yet is it found to graze good flocks of sheep, and herds of cattle, from which the Inhabitants draw their chief maintenance, and is well provided with red- Deer, fowl and fish, especially herrings taken on the Coast in very great aboundance. Affordeth plenty of Herrings. And it is observed that these Mountains exalt themselves to so great an eminence, with peeked tops,that in many places two men may stand and discourse together, the one upon one Mountain, and the other upon another, but before they can meet, they must travel some miles. Its bounds.

It hath for its bounds on the East Montgomeryshire; on the South the River Dovye, which in part separateth it from Cardiganshire; on the West the Irish Sea; and on the North the Shires of Caernarvon and Denbigh. Its Extent.

Its extent from Aberdowye in the South, to Llansanfraid in the North-east, is about 35 miles; and in breadth from Harlech in the West, to the part opposite to it in the East, about 20 miles. Thinly inhabited.

And as this Shire is thus mountainous and barren, so is it destitute of Towns and Inhabitants, numbring but 37 ordinary Parishes, which are dispersed in six Hundreds, and hath intercourse of traffick with three Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Harlech.

Harlech, seated on a Rock on the Sea-shoar, a small Borough-town, whose Inhabitants are not many, nor its Houses over beautiful, yet is it the chief Shire-town, doth send a Burgess to Parliament, is governed by a Maior for its chief Magistrate, and hath a mean Market on

This place was in former time of good account for its once strong and beautiful Castle, built by King Edward the first, highly seated, commanding both Sea and Country adjoyning, and walled about with a double bulwark; the Constable whereof by his Patent is ever Maior of the Town; and this Castle being thus strong, was a Garison for his Majesty in the late troubles, commanded by Colonel William Owen; by whose vigilancy, and the natural strength of the place, was the longest that resisted the powerful assault of the Enemy, who afterwards dismantled the same. Tracth-Bicah,Traeth-Mawer
Near unto this Town are two great inlets of the Sea, calle Tracth-Bica, and Traeth-Mawer.

And in this part near Fastineog, there is a paved-Port way of the Romans, supposed to be made by Helena, Mother to Constantine the Great, (who did many such noble acts) for that the said place beareth the name in Welch of Sarn-Helen, and in English Helens-street. Dolgelhe.

Dolgelhe, seated on the Avon, in a Vale so called, and at the foot of the great Rock Cader-Idris, which exalteth it self about three miles in height: An ordinary Country-Town, but of good account for Welch Cottons, and hath an indifferent Market on Tuesdays for provisions. Bala.

Bala, scituate in a Flat, near Pimble-Meer, in Welch Lhyn-Tegyd, which is of a large extent, being about three miles in length, and one and an half in breadth; through which the River Dee is said to run, but not to mingle with the water of the Lake or Meer, for that the Salmons usually taken in the Dee, are never found therein, and the fish called Gwyniaid, much like unto Whitings, which are plentifully taken in the Meer, are never found in the River. It is a small Town-Corporate, which enjoyeth many immunities, is governed by Bailiffs, and hath an indifferent Market on Saturdays.

div2.head: Montgomeryshire.
div2.p: MONTGO MERYSHIRE, in Welch Siretresaldwin, very hilly and mountainous, but interlaced with many fertile Valleys, both for corn and pasturage; in old time noted for its breed of good Horses. Its chief Hills.

Amongst its Hills these are of most note, Brothen, Carlion Moyluadian, Corndon, but above all the Plymillimon-hill, seated part in this County, and part in Cardiganshire; the Severn or Sabrina (the Second River in the Kingdom) which with the Dowye, receiveth those many streams which so plentifully water the County. Bounds.

It hath for its Eastern limits Shropshire; for its Southern the Counties of Radnor and Cardigan; for its Western Merionethshire; and for its Northern Denbighshire, with part of Merioneth and Shropshire. Extent.
Its extent from East to West, where broadest, is about 28 miles; and from South to North about 25. Its Dvision.

As to its Division, it is severed into seven Hundreds, in which are numbred 47 Parish Churches, and for the accommodation of its Inhabitants, hath six Market-towns, whose names are as followeth. Montgomery.

Montgomery, first built by Roger de Montgomery Earl of Shrewsbury, from whom it took its name; It is pleasantly seated in a healthfull air, on an easie ascent of a Hill, and amongst rich Grounds for corn, and feeding of cattle; 'twas once a place of good strength, when fenced about with a wall, and fortisied with a powerful Castle (which was dismantled in the late Warrs) the better to secure the Lands which by Conquest the said Roger de Montgomery gained from the Welch. It is an indifserent large Town-Corporate, governed by Bailiffs, sendeth a Burgess to Parliament, (which is elected by the Burgesses of Llanidlos, Llanvilling, Mackynlleth, and Welch-pool; Is the Shire-Town, hath some honour in giving Title to the Right Honorable William Herbert, Earl of Pembroke and Montgomery, &c. and its Market, which is on Thursdays, is well resorted unto, and hath a good Shambles. Corndon-hill.

Near unto this Town is Corndon-hill, which proudly mounteth up to a great eminence, on the top of which (according to Cambden) are placed circular-wife certain Stones, supposed to be in memory of some Victory. Welch-pool.

Welch-pool, in Welch Trellin, seated on the Severn, and in a rich Vale, the greatest and best built Town-Corporate in the County, being governed by Bailiffs, is well inhabited, enjoyeth a very good trade for English Commodities from Bristoll; its Market, which is on Mondays, is very considerable for cattle, provisions, and slannels: And its Castle (now called Powis-Castle) built of a kind of reddish Stone, (which within the compass of its wall conteineth two Castles) is of late a stately and large Pile of building. Buttington.

Opposite to this Town, and on the other side of the River is Buttington, where the Danes kept their Winter station, and were from thence expelled by Adbered Earl of the Mercians.
Llanvilling.

Llanvilling, supposed to be raised out of the ruins of Mediolanum, a Town of the Ordovices, seated in a Flat amongst the Hills, and between the River Cain and the Brook Ebir; a good Town, and hath a considerable Market on Thursdays for cattle, corn, wooll, and provisions. Mathraval.
Within three miles of this Town is Mathraval- Castle, sometimes the Royal Seat of the Princes of Powis-land. Machynleth.
